My return trip to Cusco several days later was on the Vistadome which was a very pleasant experience but just didn't compare to the Belmond. If you can come up with the extra money to do the Belmond Hiram Bingham I wouldn't hesitate!

fun way to get to Machu Pichu. We took the Hiram Bingham train to Machu Pichu and had a blast. What a fun experience for our whole family! We also met lovely people. drank and ate well and were poised for a great trip to one of the wonders of the world. If it is in your budget, take the Hiram Bingham.

Good but not great.. The train up was nice. The menu that was on the table showed three entrees but they only had one the steak. It was very good. Cooked the way I liked it. Probably one of the better steak I have had and the way I like it. The club car was very nice. The bus transportation to Machu Picchu was very disorganized. On the way back to Cusco the menu also had three choices. The only choices were fish and fish. Other than the food the trip was good.

Fantastic train tour. We did this train a few days ago and it was a great trip.Service was 5 stars and they accommodated all our food issues and allergies.Service was excellent and friendly.I highly recommend this unique train ride from Aguascalientes to Cusco.

Special Experience. The experience was lovely from beginning to end. Private waiting room at Aguas Calientes with drinks and live music, personal concierge to escort us to our table on board, rich wooden paneling and brass fittings, warm light, linens, pretty good food and wine, attentive and friendly service.

A real treat!. We were lucky enough to travel on the Belmond Hiram Bingham luxury train from Machupicchu to Cusco. The train journey time is four hours, but every minute is filled with treats and good service...waiters serve aperitifs, starters, wine, main courses, sweets and coffee and liquors. Everything is brought to you and it is all accompanied by a trio playing live Peruvian music. A must (although you might have to save up)!!

Blue ribbon experience. From the moment you arrive and the station you know this experience is going to be special.Faultless service ,very comfortable and excellent food.Not cheap but great value for money

Loved it ! Great ending to a beautiful day . We originally did not book on the Hiram Bingham train. The times cut our day too short for a one-day visit and the price was much higher than the Vistadome However about three weeks before our trip they reached out to us and offered a discount fare which we took advantage of for the return trip back to Cusco. We all ready had our tickets to Machu Picchu also which are non-refundable. This actually ended up extending our day and the train was beautiful, the service was fantastic, and the food was amazing. I have never traveled in such elegant style and the trip was very well-timed so the meal ended as we arrived in Cusco. It was a highlight of our trip

Once in a lifetime adventure.. This is a must do if you can afford it. I don't think I would have enjoyed a 3.5 hour train ride without all the entertainment on board the Hiram Bingham.We did a day return to Machu Picchu.There was a small reception before we boarded the train, they served champagne and played some music with ladies dancing.The food was great, 3 course meals each way, the bar was great, good drinks and snacks, the musicians were phenomenal. We had our own mini party going on in the bar area. We had a blast!Our bus and entry to the ruins were included and our guide was Ruddie, he was great and knowledgeable.After the tour we has evening tea the Belmond Santuary hotel, which was included.Then we left for our return train for another 3 course meal and lots of snacks.It is not cheap but if you can afford it, do it!

Fabulous luxury train journey. Travelled on the train to and from Machu Picchu. Fabulous luxury experience. On way back from Machu we had a great dinner and were entertained by a band in the bar area. Members of the party managed to dance, in spite of rolling motion of train. A definite must for anyone visiting Machu in style.

Hiram Bingham Train - Sense of historical train travel. We returned from Machu Picchu on the H. Bingham train. The old style cars that we were seated in had the taste of old dining cars. We were served supper. The food was ok but not super great. A very loud combo played in the bar car and a great time was had by all.The train left late in the afternoon and it was soon dark, so the beautiful scenery passes unseen. The staff was pleasant and courteous. We had a good trip back to Cusco.

Great end. The hotel is beautiful and the staff very accommodating. I was not prepared for the inundation of vagabonds outside the confines of the hotel, but once inside the doors, it was an oasis of calm and serene. Cuzco is beautiful and if you have the fortitude to say no to anyone and everyone that approaches you to buy something, it can be quite enjoyable place to visit.

And we still loved it!. So this was an experience - and it wasn't the fault of Belmond. After a two day transportation strike that nearly knocked us out of this trip (note to self about this possibility) we were so very happy to get tickets for our trek to MP the day following the strike. Everything was going as planned - great departure, lot's of fun, a wonderful lunch, energetic music and great drinks in the observation car. Then the train stopped. Another train had broken down about a mile from Aqua Calientes and they were unable to move it - not forward or backward. And now it was pelting rain (makes a difference in a few more lines). After a few hours and much deliberation the staff had us get off the train, grab an umbrella and walk along the side of the tracks - in the muck and rocks. We walked past the broken down train and on down the tracks to another train that had been pulled up to the one that was disabled. You might think that this would have been a big mess. Well, it was a little mess, but the energy of the staff and our guide (Angela) turned it into more of an adventure than a disaster. We ultimately arrived to Aqua Calientes and then on to Machu Picchu. Keep in mind we were very late at this point and in doubt as to whether we would even get to see MP after all that we had been through. The site allowed us to stay until 6pm - bless them, which at that time was nearly dark. The trip back to Cusco ran very late - we were 2:15 am getting back to the hotel. We couldn't even make up this story -- and we kept a light spirit. Dinner was great, drinks help just about anything. We saw MP and it is fantastic. I commend the Hiram Bingham staff for making the most out of a bad situation. They could have simply sent us back, but their commitment to getting us to our destination made for a GREAT story! If I ever go back - I'll go Hiram Bingham. It's a little more expensive, but it's THE way to make this trip.

Do it!. What a way to travel! As far as I am concerned, the only way to start a tour from Cusco to Aguas Calientes for Machu Picchu. The welcome with music, the boarding and the nice staff promised for a trip worth the money. And so it was. We had a great group of only about 16 people, mostly spending the time in the panorama bar compartment with Pisco Sours. Brunch was also excellent and the band provided great entertainment, while the Peruvian landscape passed by. We had a return ticket for the next day and although the trip is good too, at night without the view it is not quite the same. I would do it differently next time and and just get the day time one way. But I highly recommend the Hiram Bingham and its great staff to all Peru visitors. Fun and also romantic.

The Only Way to Travel to Machu Picchu. Not quite like the daily commute into London! It was a party, there is no other way to describe the journey in both directions. Of course the lunch on the way out and dinner on the return was excellent as was the service but it was the live music in the bar come observation car that made it a very special experience indeed. This train is the way to travel to Machu Picchu, ignore the price, just do it!

Worth the splurge. We booked a one-way ticket package from Cuzco to Machu Picchu on the Hiram Bingham. Given the high cost of the package, we were initially a bit concerned that the trip wouldn’t live up to our expectations, but it turned out to be more than worth spending the additional money. From the moment we arrived at the train station in Poroy, the service was exemplary. After checking in, we were shown to our seats on the train (and seated in a spacious booth for four even though we were just two) and given glasses of sparkling wine. We spent the first hour or so of the train trip in the bar car – there was live music and great views from the back of the train. A three-course lunch was included in the trip as well and the food was delicious. All of the wines to accompany the meal were included as well. (I would note that the meal was billed as “brunch” when I booked, but it was really lunch, not breakfast food at all.) Included in the package was our entrance and guided tour of Machu Picchu. There were only four of us in our tour group and our guide was excellent. By the time we arrived at Machu Picchu in the early afternoon, many tour groups were starting to leave, so the site was slightly less crowded. We also enjoyed the tea provided at the Sanctuary Lodge in the afternoon after our tour of Machu Picchu. The only negative about the Hiram Bingham would be that the tickets were a bit difficult to book online.
Best part of trip. The Hiram Bingham train ride to Machu Picchu was the best of the best. Superb service and value. It was a bit pricey, but worth every penny.

Out of this world. We took this train from Urubamba to Machu Piccho and it was a life time experience! The food, the high service, the views, everything. You have to take this train at least once in your life time.

Fun. We travelled back to Cusco from Machu Picchu on this train, and enjoyed the experience. When you arrive at the train station, there is a large, comfortable lounge for Hiram Bingham passengers; so make sure you seek it out. We arrived very early and the place was in darkness ... but we went in anyway, since the door seemed to be unlocked, and made ourselves at home. Soon enough some staff arrived. The departure was a little haphazard … and we never got our pre-boarding ‘fizz’ despite being the first in the lounge by a good margin! On board the train, the service was efficient and the food was pretty much what you’d expect – OK but without being anything to write home about (and my fish was rather dry). We had drinks in the bar car before supper (I would recommend the chillcano, which is a pisco, fruit juice and ginger ale concoction). Pisco drinks are free but others are quite pricy. There was also a three piece band playing. Ordinarily, I’m not keen on this sort of thing. However, the players were really quite talented and a lot of fun … with all those watching being given percussion instruments to jam along with. I do, however, hope that any videos of my dancing never see the light of day. All in all, a nice way to travel back to Cusco.

NICE BELMOND HIRAM BINGHAM 1920’S VINTAGE EXPERIENCE!!. I am a wholly deaf solo traveller – on Tuesday 8th September, 2015, I was picked up by the transfer taxi at 8.10am from Belmond Hotel Monasterio Cusco (approx. 30 mins driving journey each way). I arrived at Poroy Railway Station, the other tourists (whom I met there) and I were greeted by the friendly members of Belmond Hiram Bingham staff! They escorted us to our seats in the early 1920’s vintage type train.  During the train journey to Aguas Calientes for Machu Picchu, we enjoyed looking at the beautiful Peruvian countryside scenery from the train’s bar carriage with the observation car where we drank various drinks and the live musical band played (I cannot hear, of course) before we had the brunch meal in the dining carriage.  We arrived in Aguas Calientes, we got the bus to Machu Picchu. The friendly Peruvian male guide showed the 3 other tourists and myself around Machu Picchu. I asked him if we would visit the House of Guardians with the breath-taking view of whole Machu Picchu – he said that we would go there after visiting the other parts of Machu Picchu first. Unfortunately, he talked to the other 3 tourists too long than necessary while I waited in the less important part of Machu Picchu – such waste of time! We did not have enough time to spend at the House of Guardians, so I had to take some photos of myself with the background of whole Machu Picchu in a hurry and I did not get a chance to walk up to the House of Guardians before we had to return to Belmond Sanctuary Hotel for the afternoon tea. I was not happy! We should have been there at the House of Guardians a bit longer – it’s an important part of Machu Picchu than the other parts!  We returned to that train and the live musical band played again in the bar carriage for the evening drinks before we had the dinner in the dining carriage. We arrived in Poroy after 9pm that evening before our transfer taxis picking us up for returning to the hotels in Cusco. It was the greatest lifetime experience!

A Memorable Experience!. I am glad I upgraded from the regular train to this luxury one on the way back from Machu Picchu! What a treat!Don't fill up before your 4 course meal because you will want to eat the food! The courses start off small, so don't be fooled! I barely had enough room for dessert and who wants to miss that?? :)The live music is great too, even if you only listen in for a short time. Nicely decorated, timely staff, clean, fun times and great food, this was truly a memorable experience!

Fantastic experience!. My husband and I splurged on the HB for our return trip to Cusco, and we are so happy that we did. The quality and service were outstanding from the train station waiting room until we stepped off the train at Poroy. The interior of the train is beautiful with high-quality details across the board, the wait staff are very attentive, and there is live music aboard the train. The food and drinks also exceeded our already-high expectations. We would definitely opt for the HB in the future if we decide to return to Machu Picchu.

Spectacular!. My husband and I decided to splurge on the Hiram Bingham, and we are SO glad we did! It was worth every penny!Our day started off in Poroy (train station near Cusco), where there were dancers and champagne to greet us as we arrived to the train. We were escorted to our seats, and on the ride to Machu Picchu, enjoyed fabulous entertainment in the observation car, wonderful drinks, and a delicious 3-course brunch. Our tour of the ruins once we arrived was incredible. Our guide Angela was the best tour guide I have ever had- anywhere. She was extremely knowledgeable about the site, and very friendly and personable. What made the tour even better is that we were there late in the afternoon after most of the crowds had left- we have several pictures without any people in them! We ended our tour with a beautiful tea time at the Sanctuary Lodge and headed back to the train, as we were doing this as a day trip. It was definitely a long day, but we didn't have a lot of time in Peru and had other things we wanted to do in Cusco. The day trip was definitely do-able. On the ride back, we enjoyed more drinks and entertainment in the bar car, and a wonderful 5 course gourmet dinner.The train was absolutely beautiful. Very classy with an old-world feel which I loved. And the service was impeccable. It seemed as though there were more staff members than guests, and they ensured everybody was happy and comfortable the entire day. Truly first class!This was the day of a lifetime and truly one of the best experiences I have ever had. Well worth the steep price tag!

First Peru Trip. This train was a great option. At first we did not want to spend our $$$ but it was worth it. Friendly service, great staff, good food and a great band.Time flew during our round trip

Hiram Bingham. If you can do it, you have to do this once! After an exciting and long day of hiking at Machu Pichu, the train ride back on the Hiram Bingham was yet another experience that we won't forget. Elegant dining, dancing and fun.

Amazing Experience. This was a super cool experience! We took the train back to Cuzco after spending time in Machu Picchu. We waited in the private lounge before we got on the train where they served appies and cocktails. This was great considering it was pouring rain outside. We were then led to our table on the train. The food and the service was excellent. The bar car was awesome... we went over there to listen to the live entertainment where ton of passengers where drinking and dancing. So much fun!I would likely say that I wouldn't have been able to do this on my own as it was pretty expensive from my understanding, but given that my mom arranged the mother daughter trip I am glad she chose for us to do this. It was truly amazing and I recommend it if you can afford it!

A great experience. We chose to take the Hiram Bingham train down to Cusco after two days in Machu Picchu. We were looked after from the minute we checked in at the station. There is a private lounge which serves passed hors d' oeuvres and cocktails as well as provides live entertainment. We were personally escorted to our table when boarding. The bar car has the most wonderful live music and is a really fun environment of people who are all revved up from their visit to Machu Picchu. Food service and presentation were excellent. This was a fabulous upgrade to our trip and I would strongly recommend this to all.

An Incredible Experience. This was a fantastic experience at the end of an amazing two days climbing Machu Picchu and enjoying one of the great wonders of the world.The three hour journey back to Cuzco was an absolute experience. The set up of the dining carriages was outstanding and the menu superb.However, the introduction for the first hour was a terrific Peruvian band who played a mixture of Peruvian favourites and western rock that had the whole train up and dancing across several generations. I would note that the "rack rate" for this trip was high at US$499 however I don't expect that this is close to the far lower packaged price we paid as part of our whole of Peru experience so make enquiries.

Is it always this much fun?. I am not sure if our journey on the Hiram Bingham train is the norm, or if we just lucked out. We entered the magical wood and brass, crystal and linen sanctuary of our car after a beautiful day on Machu Picchu, ordered dinner from the limited but elegant menu, and proceeded down to the bar car for Pisco sours and a Spanish trio of guitar and drum. The car was filled with Spanish and Mexican tourists, some Europeans and Americans. Everyone started to sing along with Guantanamera and Volare (even Americans know those). But then the dancing on a moving train began, Flamenco style with maracas and castanets handed around. Honestly, haven't had such a fun night out in years. Worth the splurge.

Worth it...?? Yes!. Be careful, several reviews here do NOT concern the Hiram Bingham train, but apparently the Vistadome or another one. This is the (super expensive!) but three course luxury meal and top service private train for max 84 people. With observation balcony, bar etc. Due to the rest of the package also (excellent private tour guide, private bus up and down to the ruins themselves from Aguas Calientes, bypassing all queues, entry of MP guaranteed and included, making use of nightfall to have dinner) and the highly interesting mix of people on board for the trip, really the top way to see Machu Picchu. We think there are two best ways to experience Machu Picchu, this is the one, and the other extreme is to walk the Inca trail - if you're up to it.
Excellent. It was an absolutely spectacular experience. The train is beautiful, the staff very friendly, and the service , food .....excellent . The best way to visit Machu Picchu ...

If you're are gonna splurge on one thing in Peru, this is it!. This is easily the most luxurious train I've ever been on. We were totally taken care of the entire day through. From arrival to departure, the service and experience were first class! If you're into hiking the Inca Trail and roughing it, this isn't the train for you. It's expensive and luxurious. I'm so glad that I spent the extra money and went this way. It was a very special experience for us. Some people choose to take the train one way back to Poroy. It's a great time, but you miss the incredible views along the way. The ride up leaves promptly at 9:05am. Don't be late! It's about 40min taxi from Cusco. Do yourself a favor and leave an hour ahead of time so you get their early. They greet you with mimosas and traditional dancing in the train station. You get seated at your table and they take your order for brunch. This was fine dining absolutely! After taking our order, we were free to wander to the back of the train where the fun begins with a three piece band and a bar car with an open-air patio on the back. Drinks and snacks are included in the price except for premium liquor. Pisco sours were plentiful though. Be careful though, they can sneak up on you and you've got a big day ahead. Stay hydrated!!!! The views on the way to Machu Picchu are fantastic. Once we got there, we had our own guide for two of us. He took us around the entire site showing us various points of interest and giving us background information. Machu Picchu is amazing. Just don't miss it, no matter what if you go to Peru. Seriously, it's better than any picture, post card, poster or documentary I've ever seen. if you don't take the Hiram Bingham train, get there somehow. After touring Machu Picchu, we had afternoon tea at the Belmond Sanctuary Lodge. There were lots of little snacks to choose from that were all beautifully displayed and very delicious. The tea was refreshing after hiking around Machu Picchu, but if you wanted a pisco sour(or some other cocktail), that was available too. The ride back to Poroy had more people on board due to some people taking the train one way. It was dark on the way back and so no awesome views. However, the atmosphere on board becomes more of a party...especially in the back bar car. There's live music again and dancing. Dinner was absolutely first rate. The train manager was the best. He was very helpful, attentive and friendly. He arranged for us to have a quick visit to the kitchen car with the chefs who were friendly and putting out some fantastic food!This was a first class experience. It's very expensive, but they really delivered throughout the day. It's worth it if you're looking for this type of experience. You can certainly spend less money, but this is pretty much a once-in-a-lifetime experience. Go for it!

The Best Way To Travel. We took the train both ways to Maccu Pichu. It was a lovely ride. Brunch on the way up and dinner the next night was truly well prepared. My 17 year old son enjoyed the entertainment in the bar car. The train was an hour and half late arriving back in Cusco, but it was not a big deal. The folks on the train were well organized and friendly. The private waiting room at Machu Pichu was an extra treat. It was lovely and a throwback to times long gone.

Lovely, but watch for the catch. We thoroughly enjoyed our trip on the Hiram Bingham, but it was shorter than it should/could have been. We were booked only from Ollantaytambo, not Cusco, meaning that the journey was half the length we expected. The cost is not halved however; full price is still paid. This may or may not not be the fault of Hiram Bingham; it could be down to Lima Tours, or the Belmond Group, trying to ensure that the Rio Sagrado hotel gets its share of business, it's difficult to tell. Having said all of that, the experience we did have was delightful. The scenery is spectacular, especially when viewed from the well appointed observation car. Lunch was pretty good given the fact that one is eating on a train and the staff were pleasant and attentive. Due to the shortness of our journey, lunch felt somewhat rushed which was a shame. The train seems to be less smooth a ride than the Andean Explorer, but it is nonetheless an experience well worth having.

Luxury And beauty. We couldn't t believe it, it was the best day ever, to leave in the morning through the mountains with music and drinks, fabulous lunch, beautiful view, friendly and efficient staff, charming guests from all over the world. We had a lot of fun and walked in the magnificent Machupicchu.

Luxurious and fun. I had always dreamed of riding an orient express train if only for one day! We had already been to machu picchu with our conference tour group the week before on the vista dome. While the first sight of the ruins is something that I will never forget, I think that the Hiram Bingham train ride is also something that we will never forget. You cannot compare the methods of transportation - it is impossible. The Bingham train is extravagant and totally worth every penny. Beautifully polished brass, wonderfuly comfortable tables and exceptional meals and service were all here. We rode both the am and pm trains and both had great attributes. Beautiful vistas and terrific scenery in the morning along with a great brunch of filet made for a wonderful start to the day. The evening was fun and exciting with great music and drinking in the bar car followed by another fabulous dinner. I am so glad we did this.

A real treat. A real treat to end an amazing experience visiting Machu Picchu. We started off with Pisco Sours in the bar with live music. We were soon dancing in the aisles. Settling down to a four course delicious meal in the luxuriously created carriage, we were in Cusco before we knew it. Service impeccable. We loved it.

A split personality experience. We took the evening train from Machu Picchu back into Cusco with great expectations, using this experience as a test for whether we would enjoy longer experience on some of Belmond's other luxury trains like the Orient Express or the Royal Scotsman. Our experience was of mixed results.On the positive side, the train is absolutely beautiful, exceptionally well maintained and looks exactly like the picture on the website. The service provided by the staff was professional, friendly, and attentive...but then again, not significantly better than the service on the Vistadome (our way of coming into Maccu Picchu). Dinner was exceptional, with a beautifully laid out table and comfortable table for two (which we really appreciated). And the food was very well prepared and presented, with near perfect balance between all of the flavors. On all of these categories, the trip met or exceeded our expectations.On a negative note, the train has not been marketed/positioned reflective of its more affluent status. I'm not being snobbish, but am saying that A) there are cheaper ways to travel and B) that one expects similar travel companions if one it traveling on high end luxury mode of transportation. In short, if you're a "luxury train experience" (as Belmond describe the experience), then you better deliver on it. We dressed appropriate to the people we saw on Belmond's website showing the train (oxford shirts, khaki slacks, shoes and socks)...only to be greeted by a vast majority of the passengers wearing gym shorts, tank tops, flip flops and other attire more appropriate at the pool...but clearly not for dinner. Boarding of the train was not some civilized "call your name" event (given that everyone had assigned seats and package was handled by porters), but instead a free-for-all with passengers cramming through the doors to be the first ones on the train...boarding on Southwest Airlines "open seating" is generally handled better. And then, once aboard this beautiful vintage train, the lounge car became a "sail away" event on a party cruise with exceptionally loud music, conga line dancing and power drinking (after all, wine & beer are included in the price). Now, there's nothing wrong with a party cruise, but if you go on a party cruise boat lead to believe that it will be a "luxury experience", then one is going to be in for a shock. I think the crowning blow was when the "traditionally Peruvian Band" broke into The Eagle's "Hotel California" and The Stones "Satisfaction"....sorry, I enjoy both of those songs, but that wasn't what I was lead to believe would be the entertainment on my journey.One could say that Belmond isn't responsible for the behaviors/attitudes of fellow travelers...and to a degree, I would agree. However, much like cruise lines, the Hiram Bingham should set "the tone" for the journey, making it clear what acceptable attire is (just like on cruise lines), selecting appropriate entertainment, and possible increasing pricing reflect a more luxury travel experience closer to the one promised on their website.Based upon this experience, I would never take the Hiram Bingham again nor would I spend the $1500/night per person for their luxury trains elsewhere. If I'm going to spend that kind of money, then I want something more than an airline boarding process, a "sail away" party and The Eagle's "Hotel California".

Spectacular way to visit Machu Picchu!. I was lucky enough to experience the Belmond Hiram Bingham train ride and visit to Machu Picchu last week, and it was an absolutely spectacular experience. The train is beautiful, the staff incredibly friendly, and the service top-notch. The food was all excellent, the bar and viewing car is delightful, and the transfers to and from Machu Picchu were smooth and seamless. Our guide from the train, Carlos, was great, and we were able to tour Machu Picchu very thoroughly. The whole day was truly amazing, and I feel so lucky to have had this experience as part of my visit to Peru. Very highly recommended!

This could have been SO much better. 3 1/2 Stars: We were so looking forward to this part of our Peruvian journey based on all the accolades and positive reviews. The experience was a contrast: the train itself is beautiful and the service was excellent but the "entertainment" was exceptionally loud and reminiscent of happy hour on a cruise ship. We enjoyed some aspects of the trip and were extremely disappointed with others.We were on the Macchu Pichu/Aguas Calientes to Cusco train, and arrived at the station a little before the indicated time. Due to the elegant nature of the train we decided to wear clothing that was a little dressier than what we had been wearing during our jungle/mountain adventure. Other people started to arrive dressed way more casually than I would have thought appropriate. The "band" played Peruvian music to set the mood and orange juice and sparkling wine were offered prior to boarding.Andy, the Train Manager, approached us and asked for our passports and got our seat assignments. Shortly after we were escorted onto the train and shown to our seats. We were very impressed by the elegance of the train. Our waiter told us that once we departed they would take our dinner order and we were welcome to go to the Bar car for a cocktail before dinner. I hadn't had a martini since we had been in Peru (two weeks) and was looking forward to enjoying one.Once we placed our order we moved to the bar car, which had a very nice bar with stools and several banquettes that were already occupied, and ordered drinks. Shortly after, the band started playing, and playing LOUD and not Peruvian music. Hotel California? La Bamba? Seriously? The people seated on the banquettes were really getting into it, which was great for them. For those of us that were expecting something a little more subdued it wasn't so great. Being the space was small the music an revelry was only amplified, making conversation nearly impossible. Sadly we only stayed a short while and returned to our seats.Dinner was served at 7 and it was excellent. The included wines were also very good and the service was polite and professional. We finished dinner about 30 minutes prior to arriving in Cusco and were given our bill for the drinks from the bar car (@$15 per drink). We arrived on time and disembarked the train, and we both agreed that, while we were glad we tried the Hiram Bingham, it didn't live up to the positive press and we wouldn't do it again.Possibly our expectations were set way too high. Maybe Belmond will change the "entertainment" to better match the atmosphere of the train (a guitar player would work nicely), but having crystal glasses and china plates while a band plays "Hot! Hot! Hot!" just doesn't seem to match.

Travel in Style. Fantastic train ride. The only way to travel between Cusco and Machu Picchu. The food was great,and the entertainment was the best. On the way back to Cusco, we ended up in the bar cart drinking pisco sours and playing musical instruments that the band handed out. Highly recommended!

another excellent part of our trip ..... when one boards the Hiram Bingham at Ollyantaytambo, as we did, you do not really know what to expect. The station goes nothing away as it is just another stop on the busy PeruRail network ..... however, as the train pulls in and the staff alight it all becomes clear that you are in for a treat. Professional, friendly and English speaking staff check tickets and escort you to your allocated seats in the main cars ... wide and comfortable fabric covered seats, very elegant and reminiscent of the past age of steam travel. Brunch was served almost immediately after leaving the station and was presented well, and tasted wonderful. The trains bar car and observation lounge were unused by us as we only had an hour and 30 mins on the train taken up by eating but the views from the window are stunning enough to not miss seeing it from the rear of the train. Arrival in Aquas Calientes is chaotic and slightly scruffy looking but its all part of the adventure. We took the train both up and down from MachuPicchu which is lovely but you must realise the return journey is all after sunset so the scenery is nonexistent but dining with new found friends was a real bonus. definitely worth the extra money on your trip.

Not on the same level as the rest of our Belmond Tour. My wife and I had a wonderful eight night private customized tour organized by Belmond Journeys in Peru staying at Lima, Vale Sagrado, Machu Picchu, Cusco. We took the Hiram Bingham train from Ollantaytamdo to Machu Picchu (were we slept at the Sanctuary Lodge) and returned next day on the evening train to Cusco. I have to say that this train is a long way from being an Orient Express Luxury experience.On the way up we had our wonderful private guide Belmond guide Jorge meet us at Aguas Calientes to help us get on the bus to Machu Picchu, Sanctuary Lodge. The main issue was on the evening trip back where we were left in the hands of a rather grumpy Hiram Bingham guide...he seemed to have an attitude problem, telling guests to find their own way back to the Machu Picchu train station after we left the bus at Aguas Calientes. There was one scared American tourist who was terrified of getting lost who tagged along with us! The food on the train was OK, but hardly five star...equivalent to business class US airline cuisine at best. On a positive note the waiters were very attentive and friendly and worked hard to please.I know I will sound snobbish here but this train is certainly not on the same level as the Belmond hotels we stayed in Peru (MiraFlores Park, Rio Sagrado, Sanctuary Lodge and Palacio Nazarenas). I do understand that in order to reach a break even point they have opened up the train for use by passengers who are not staying at Belmond hotels. My suggestion would be to have a separate carriage for Belmond guests with a higher level of cuisine and specific Belmond trained staff: this would be "1st class" and for other passengers they would have the current service as "business class".If you are on a budget travel and have to choose between this train service and an overnight stay at Sanctuary lodge: do not think twice - get the Vistadome train and stay at Sanctuary lodge. If you are not travelling on budget and on a Belmond private tour, it is still the best option to get to Machu Picchu, but be prepared for a drop in service, food and general ambiance.

Most Elegant Train. The Hiram Bingham is part of the Orient Express experience. We took this train from Cuzco to Aguas Calientes. It was incredible Luxury. I will caution anyone who may be prone to Altitude sickness. Cuzco is at an elevation of 11000 feet. We got very sick because of that and were not able to fully enjoy the luxury experience. But the Champagne helped. The scenery along the Inca trail and the Urabamba river was spectacular and Aguas Calientes is a delightful little town. The Hiram Binghman people were fantatsic to us. On the return trip there were "Huelgas", small riots. The Hiram Bingham people did not want their train damaged so we had to go back in a backpacker train. They sent 2 security guards with us all the way back to Cuzco and paid for our dinner at the Monastery Hotel. They even refunded half our trip and gave us a discount on our next journey. A first class company and Train. Can't wait to do it again when we are better acclimated to the altitude.

Overall good experience, but needs improvement is some aspects. We took the Hiram Bingham train in the evening from Machu Picchu to Poroy station in Cusco. The one way rate included afternoon tea at the Belmond Sanctuary Lodge (where we stayed), Charter bus transfer from the Sanctuary Lodge to Aguas Calientes train station, welcome drink at the VIP lounge at the train station, onboard dinner including wine, beer and Pisco Sour, as well as onboard entertainment. Everything included in the rate was delivered, but not with the flair expected. We were the first to arrive at the VIP lounge at the Aguas Calientes train station and while it was clean and comfortable there was no Belmond representative to greet guests. There were no local entertainers at the station as shown in the pictures on the Belmond Hiram Bingham website. Finally, approximately 15-20 minutes prior to boarding a flustered Belmond representatives arrived at a check-in podium. There were no signs or announcements and so several guests inquired about boarding and were told to sit down and wait to be called. Shortly thereafter they called a few guests that were waiting, but as other guests arrived they would proceed straight to the podium and then board. Incidentally, we were never called and ended up boarding last. In a chaotic and hurried manner, approximately 15-10 minutes prior to departing Belmond representatives set-up and distributed wet towels and welcome drinks while the onboard entertainment trio played a piece. In our opinion, it was a very disorganized and rushed process. Once onboard, it was a little more structured. Before dinner we proceeded to the bar car where there was live entertainment. It was a very festive atmosphere - everyone was drinking and dancing. Dinner was very good considering it was on a train. Overall we enjoyed the Hiram Bingham train experience. However, based on the fare per person and reputation, we expected a well-organized boarding process and elegant experience at every level including the MP/Aguas Calientes train station VIP lounge.

Fantastic!!. When I first saw the pics of this train trip I knew I had to go on it with the family. Its EXPENSIVE!! I decided to book tickets one way and return by the Vistadome since the return would be in the evening and there would be nothing to see in the darkness. My decision was correct. When we reached the station in anticipation the cart with champagne/hot drinks and the folk dance at the station whetted our appetite for more. We went into the train and it was GORGEOUS! Excellent old world charm with warm wood panelled interiors in the observation deck and bar bring forth a luxurious aura that's difficult to see in a train anywhere nowadays. The trip started with coffee and champagne and the food and wines flowed forth! The live band in the observation car with the cliquey clack of the train and the magnificent views of the Peruvian countryside made the ride a superb experience.At the end I wondered if I just turn around and NOT see the Machu Picchu ruins!!

Wonderful experience. Such a fabulous way to travel up to Machu Picchu. Examplary service, generously free-flowing drinks, good food - and a fabulous party atmosphere in the bar / observation car with an excellent band playing as we left Cusco. We'd feared this might be a little stuffy or formal: far from it. Perfect luxury of the highest standard.

LACK OF CUSTOMER SERVICE. To be fair this review is not about the train ride itself, as we got caught up in the strike in May 2015 and were never able to take the train from Aguas Callientes to Cusco. This review concerns the total and complete lack of customer service from the staff of Hiram Bingham. The waiting room was full of stranded passengers and not one Hiram Bingham representative was in the lounge to talk to. Not only that but there were no snacks or drinks (an empty fridge was to be seen) for those waiting to try to catch another mode of transport. For a company that is supposed to be high-end, there was nothing tangible to prove this. We were completely let down by Belmond.

Loved it. A great way to travel to Machu Pichu , luxury train with great staff and service and very good value. Food was excellent and in the bar carriage its party time on the way home with Pisco sours and a local band playing everything from traditional Peruvian, Spanish to the Rolling Stones!If you are in the area it has to be done !
Beauty and Service like the old days. Very special old train with excellent service and cuisine Waiter Pablo stands out Very professional Fun experience Perfect way to get to Machu Picchu

The luxury way to Machu Picchu. We boarded the train from sacred Valley on the Hiram Bingham which included cocktail in the bar with live music and snacks, followed by three course meal with wine at the table, while we absorbed the amazing view. Our tickets included a guide and a return bus ride to Machu Picchu. We were than escorted to a hotel just at the base at 4:15 where we had a big spread of afternoon tea. We had booked from home three months ahead of travel. It was worth the price.( you do not need to book price guide to Machu Picchu as this covers every thing for first day).We would have loved to come back on the same train but it does not run on Sunday.

Luxury transport. Booked the tickets from home several months out from our trip to Peru. Ended up booking the HB train both ways, with a day in between where we stayed in Aguas Calientes. The train down to AC leaves in the morning, brunch is served (quite good food, white table cloth setting) along with local wines and Pisco sours (included in ticket price). Our train had 2 dining cars, where your seat is assigned by staff, this may mean you get your own table or will be seated with others at a table of four. The last car on the morning train is the bar car, which can get pretty rowdy (as the Piscos flow), especially on the night train return. A small band plays local (and not so local) songs, they don't need the amplifier, as it makes for loudness that's hard to talk over. In this same car is the back observation area, to get good views of the passing scenery, farms, small towns sheer rock walls framing the gorges. Ride is 3.5 hours one way. Once up in AC, and a short jaunt thru the market, we are shown to the bus (valued at $24US for two and included in the train ticket price) which takes about 20 or so minutes to reach the beginning of the park. You are dropped outside the Belmond Sanctuary Hotel (the same parent company as the train service, and the only hotel actually located at Machu Picchu). Entrance to MP is also included (approx $50 US each) in the ticket price. At the entrance/exit to MP, don't forget to get your stamp for posterity sake!A guide (English speaking) for small groups is also provided to tour the park, about 3 hours of walking the site and learning the "truth" about Bingham's find and National Geographic/Yale University's role100 years ago. At the end of the tour, the group re-meets up for tea at the Sanctuary (also included in price) for 45 minutes before the bus returns to AC.The return HB train is mostly in the dark, a nice dinner is served as part of the ticket price..along with wines and piscos, the bar car band encourages group participation as entertainment. A pricey ticket for return travel, but everything is taken care of for you, which makes for ease. Don't forget your HB duffel bag that is provided complimentary too!

First class way to return from Mach Picchu to Cusco. We returned from Machu Picchu to the Sacred Valley on the Hiram Bingham which included dinner and drinks . We went from the Sanctuary Lodge and travelled with some other guests who also stayed there. The 3 hours or so went quite quickly with the company and before we knew it we were getting off at Rio Sagrado as the line was closed further down the line to Cusco

Worth the price. This was a great way to get to Aguas Caliente/Machu Pichuu. We purchased our tickets through travel agency but I will say that you should not pay attention to the seating on your ticket, as it is merely allowing you on the train. Prior to boarding a train representative with a master seating chart, will guide you to a seat or seats.The trip up is different from the return trip as the return is in the dark.The personnel on the train are excellent and very efficient. On the return trip dinner is served a few hours out of the final stop so I took the after dinner time to visit the club car and found that I was the only one other than the band, bar and wait staff. I had more fun going back because they played and we laughed and talked.The train will give you a personal bag for each ticket holder and you can bring this and another smaller bag. My wife and I stayed 2 nights in the Inkaterra and found that these two bags were more than large enough to accommodate our needs.

Would have been nice if it weren't for the snobs. We enjoyed this train ride and the food was excellent as was the staff but most of the people on this train thought they were above everyone else. They were rude to the wait staff and we had a table of four that decided to play loud music on their IPad. It was so loud we went back to the observation car to get away from it. When I was in the observation car there were people standing the back of the car that would not move so I could get some clean shots of the river and scenery even though they were not taking pictures. I would not do this again.

Disappointing. We travelled on the afternoon service to Cusco and were generally disappointed in both the service and the food. Having travelled previously on a "luxury" train the Hiram Bingham fell very short of being luxurious. The food was unremarkable in both taste and presentation and the drinks were lukewarm and mostly unpleasant. The staff appeared to be flustered and it appeared they were short of staff. I would suggest the daytime service may be better as at least you can be distracted by being able to view the scenery.

Nice Ride. We rode the Hiram Bingham back from Machu Picchu (we hiked there). The train itself was very nice, although since we are younger and had packs, they seemed to treat us a little differently at first. Sort of as though we didn't belong there because we weren't dressed in slacks and dress shoes....which was irritating. Anyway, the train was nice and we had a nice table for two. We went to the bar car for the first hour and had an enjoyable time....the pisco sours were quite good. Then we went back for dinner. The food was excellent and the wine was fairly good as well. The waitstaff was nice and accommodating and I was able to get a vegetarian meal that was not on the menu. Our car was rather rowdy as there was a large group at the one end that was rather loud and kept shouting "Viva Chile"....this was annoying. The train also got in about an hour late, for which no explanation was given. So, all in all it was nice, but probably way overpriced considering the issue mentioned above.

Luxury Family Adventure. Our family of four (kids 12 and 8) took the Hiram Bingham one way from the Sacred Valley to Machu Picchu. I was concerned that we would not get the "full" experience because we were not able to take the entire Cusco-Aguas Calientes route because of the rainy season and the shortened train service. My concerns, however were unfounded and the HB was definitely one of the highlights of our trip. From the beautiful dining car, to the bar cars with champagne and pisco sours, to the fun observation deck with live music and entertainment, there was something special for everyone in our family. Yes, compared to the other trains, the HB is expensive. If you travel one way on the HB and the Vista Dome the other, which is what we did, you get more "bang for your buck" if you do the one way to MP. On this route, your tickets to MP are included, plus the private bus from the train to the Citadel, a small guided tour of MP with a HB guide, and an afternoon tea in the Sanctuary Lodge. If you chose the return to Cusco one way, you will only get the train and dinner, and not the other extras mentioned above. Of course, round trip on the HB, you get it all! We chose to spend the night and do an extra day at MP. We were very glad we did. Although the HB return would have been lovely, the extra time we had the next day was well worth it. For one, it was raining when we arrived and during much of our tour. The next day we were met with beautiful sunshine. We were able to see MP in the mystique of the rain and clouds and also in the glory of the sunshine. We also then had time to hike to the Sun Gate. All in all, it was a splurge that was well worth it, and one I would do again. It was the perfect balance of luxury and adventure our family was seeking.

Only way to travel. Could there be a better experience then visiting Machu Picu? How about a luxurious train trip there and back? Sit in comfort and watch the beautiful landscape of Peru, or move to the observation car and listen to live music. Stand on the end platform and see the tracks and terrain whiz by. Beautiful solid wood finishing, extremely comfortable seating with tables.Excellent dinner served on return journey. Wine and drinks included.

Beyond words of gratitude to the HB staff. I took my elderly mom to see MP for the first time. At first, I was hesitant as how she'd treated due to the fact that she uses a personal small 4 wheel walker. This was no problem at all at the HB train. From the train, bus, tour in MP and afternoon tea at the Sanctuary Lodge, the staff, especially the Tour Guide, Carlos, were so amazing. Carlos went out of his way to make sure my mom and I were comfortable and happy. He was extremely patient with us and never left our side through out our journey until we were safely back in the hotel shuttle. So we wouldn't delay the rest of the group visiting MP, Carlos - HB Tour Guide, even provided a private tour for my mom and I so we could go at our own pace and be extremely happy. My mom was so happy that she came to MP and we have tons of pictures to share with the family. Belmond is extremely lucky to have a wonderful associate such as Carlos, representing their company. He is the reason I'll return and recommend tons of other passengers aboard this wonderful train. Truly worth every penny spent.

Handicapped. Make sure that you inform them if you needhandicapped assistance .There is no liftThat we saw.Access to the lounge couldBe difficult without.The train staff offeredTo help my wife get to the lounge car.TheRestroom is small.The staff was very friendlyAnd helpful.Food was good.

So much fun!. I had so much fun on this trip that I was disappointed when the train pulled into the station and it was over. The train itself was lovely, comfortable seats, fine linens at the table. Service was excellent and attentive. After putting in my meal order, I went to the bar car and listened to the band and danced with other passengers until the meal was ready. The band was a lot of fun, playing a mix of songs in English and Spanish. They went out of their way to make it a fun experience by involving the passengers like an intimate concert performance. To be honest, the time in the bar car was the highlight of the trip so if you don't want to listen to the music, you might not enjoy this trip as much as I did because then you just are having dinner on a nice train and IMO it is less an experience and more just transport (nice though it may be).The only thing I did not enjoy was the tea that is included at the Belmond Lodge at Machu Picchu. The service was spotty at best (in fact, I could never manage to get served any tea at all) and the food was mediocre.

Train ride from Machu Picchu to Cusco. Over priced, over rated, and unorganized. Bought specific seats so we could sit together but they moved us without asking, to seats we didn't want. 2 Bar cars, one wasn't opened until well after we left and the other never opened. The musicians and waiters were hanging out in both bar cars, doing nothing. Car service to the hotel didn't take us to hotel, they left us 4 blocks from hotel. It was $700 for 2 of us for a 2 1/2 hour train ride. Very disappointed

Unique and fun experience. We took the regular train to Aguas Calientes, and the Hiram Bingham back to get to Cusco. Definitely recommend doing this one way - feels like traveling back in time. Food was excellent.Really fun part of the trip was when we went into the bar car, drank pisco sours and danced to live music before dinner was served.

Not really worth the wait. The train is typical of the Belmond (Orient Express) offerings and is luxurious. Sadly, the experience is not as good as on the other trains in the group, and does not really fulfil the expectations of a Belmond train. The food was excellent (dinner), wine was OK, but the whole event is too down market to match up to expectations. The pre-boarding afternoon tea at the Sanctuary Lodge was little more than a bunfight and set the tone for the rest of the journey, I'm afraid. When one of our fellow passengers laid out and went to sleep at the table next to us, it summed the whole evening up.

The most fun you'll ever have on a train!!. I have to admit, when we booked this excursion I was skeptical. Even though it was "all inclusive", the price seemed high for a train ride with dinner. It was the perfect ending to a long day of hiking. Everything was absolutely first class, from the train station waiting area to the boarding process, the dinner, wine and entertainment in the bar car. We were traveling with another couple who enjoyed it equally as much. We had a BLAST!! I definitely recommend this trip, if not for both ways at least one way on the way home.

Much better than regular train. Overrated as one of best trains in the world? Probably. But it still was a very enjoyable train ride and an amazing improvement over trips I took in the 70s and 90s. The food was excellent, the service very good and the entertainment pleasant and lively

This was a unique experience as a way to Machu Picchu. PeruRail engines pulling restored rail cars from the early 1900's. The 3 hour trip from the combination hotel/ train depot was a bit slow paced and pretty bumpy. With the exception of a combination bar/open air observation/live entertainment hub all other cars were dining cars so you constantly felt like you were being prepared for a meal. Of course you actually were as two meals brunch on the way to MP and dinner on way back to Sacred Valley were provided along with all beverages. If you are staying in Cusco it's about 90 minute drive to Sacred Valley to catch this train. The food, service and dining car ambience were exceptional but it fell short of being the "romantic" trip it could have been. Still HBT is first class all the way even down to a bus reserved for the final leg up to MP. Having already experienced it If I'd return to MP I'd probably just throw a snack in my back pack and catch a regular PeruRail train up to the site.

A fun way to get to Macchu Picchu from Cuzco. Ok, so I went during rainy season, which goes from december to end of April. Because of flooding on the tracks , during these months you most take the bimodal trip which is 1/2 bus. 1/2 HB train... You pick up the train in Wanchaq station and about 9am..you are in Agua Calientes by about noon, and the last 2 kilometers takes about 20-30 minutes up a steep switchback road...the views are AMAZING!..to backtrack, while on the train on is served brunch, a four course meal, and includes Pisco sour, wine, beer, also Peruvian live music in the bar car. The trip includes entree to Machu Picchu and a private guide ( our group had 7 people, all english speaking)for about a 3 hour tour ( which just about killed me)...but the views were spectacular, the guide well informed...it's just I have arthritis and it was a bit hard keeping up the pace. At the end of the tour , around 4:40 we all met back up at the Sactuary Hotel (The only hotel in Macchu Picchu - I hear it can take a year or more to get a reservation)--we had high tea, then went back down the mountain to Agua Calientes to catch the HB train back to Cuzco. Not much to see outside because it was dark by then..but the bar car had a very lively group of travelers and live musicians playing and dancing until dinner was serving in the dining car at 6:30...another 4-5 course meal with, wine, beer, Pisco sours....even got a lesson from the bartender in how to make one properly...after arriving back at the Belmond Hotel ( 1/2 way) we returned to the buses for the last part of the trip back to Cuzco...I think pretty much everyone fell asleep from total exhaustion.

First class. We traveled to/from Machu Picchu on the train and this was a luxurious experience. Started with drinks and music in the observation car and a lovely meal about 1130 am. They called it "brunch", but it was more like a dinner menu. On the way back, more drinks, music, and a lighter dinner. Train moves pretty slowly, so you see much on the way there. Many locals out working in fields and waving. At one point there was an old woman following us and she was keeping up. Dark on the ride home and it moved faster.

Belmond Hiram Bingham Train to Machu Picchu " A luxury experience". Our experience started with Perurail and booking on line. We had some difficulty initially for my credit card blocked the first attempt. This is a tip: Contact your card company and indicate that you will be placing a foreign charge and amount. This will make the booking seamless. We received personal attention after placing call to agent for Perurail. She walked me through the process and even stayed on line till transaction was complete. This is just the beginning of the outstanding service to expect on this " Journey of a Lifetime" Our trip began in the Sacred Valley station steps away from the Belmond Rio Sagrado Hotel. A delightful greeting with tea, assorted pastries etc. and a staff graciously greeting each guest and after check in escorting them to train platform. The temporary steps made the climb onto the awaiting train very easy for ascent. What awaits is a sheer delight! You are personally escorted to your table complete with all amenities one would expect in this luxurious dining compartment. Tables are spaced to allow for privacy. The observation car in the rear was the place to be for the journey until Brunch was served. Music, drinks, and wonderful photo opportunities! We even did a" rhumba" or two as we gently rolled to our destination. Brunch was delicious & service 5 star*.Transfer to bus was also seamless. Our guide Gherman was knowledgeable and also accomodating to whatever physical challenges one might have based on age and fitness. Our small group of 4 experienced an amazing tour of MP. Tea at the Sanctuary Lodge was a nice experience and well done! The return transfer to train was escorted by staff and once again the experience continued with fine food, drink and convivium.  We arrived at Rio Sagrado station to await transfer to bus and as expected, our luggage was waiting for us to be boarded for our trip to Cusco and check- in at Belmond Hotel MonasterioOne of our personal mantras is " We will run out of Time before Money" Spend the money for this incredible experience!

A unique experience. While there are several ways to travel to Macchu Picchu, this is certainly relaxing and memorable. From the dancers and champagne before you board, to the excellent Peruvian band during the train ride, you are constantly entertained. There is never a shortage of food or drink on the Hiram Bingham. The observation car provides breathtaking views of the ever changing landscape. It is also important to note that our tour guide at Machu Picchu (provided by Hiram Bingham) was extremely knowledgeable and personable.

Good service but only got ½ travel.. bad management dont go there in February!. My girlfriend gave me a xmaspresent. A romantic travel to Machu Picchu with the great Orient Express. But out there they shorthend the trip hours because of the rainy season.. but it was Ok because it was daylight and they went by 25 km/h.. but back it went dark so it was even an hour shorther and we even didnt finish the dessert before we have to leave the train and take the rest of the trip in a wan. A very disappointing way of finishing such an expensive trip.At the train only some of the drinks were free, the servants tried to sell us CD with the music played on the train (why dont pay 10 dollars extra to avoid the market??) and in the morning it was a little hard to get on the right bus to the train but we succeed with no help. Dont go there in february .. so so bad!!Perurail told us they were aware it wasnt so good about that some drinks were for free and some not.. and we have to say the servants did to make it a nice travel, the food were good. But why do they serve a very poor Chilewine with so much tannin in so its like biting the table. Damn it - we were in Peru - then serve some beer from Russia or so,. It was a very poor final. Sad a management of PeruRail ruin it all.Never do it again..! But we have a nice story for our next travel article..we will warn everybody.

Just wonderful. Whilst one cannot complain about the sheer luxury from start to finish the Hiram Bingham is indeed a rare treat , I wish the same could be said for trying to book it through the Peru Rail website. It's also worth noting during the rainy season the train starts its journey from the Sacred Valley as part of the line just outside of Cusco is prone to flooding, this is not something immediately obvious when booking ( in fact I was only told about this 4 weeks before departure which seems very odd since this is standard operating procedure in the wet season). The train , service and food is a wonderful experience and will not be forgotten ! The stricking scenery only adds further to a great train experience !

Agatha Christie Elegance. Live music and champagne in the club car before dinner, crystal, silver, and china service, a rose on the table, smoked salmon, perfectly prepared filet served with wine. Now add the spectacular Andes scenery and the journey becomes a lifetime experience. Fellow travelers seem to quickly relax and adapt to the elegance and soon we're all friends. We discover a connection with one couple, (Doesn't matter where we travel, my husband will see someone he knows!) HIghly recommend this fabulous experience!

Great way to travel. We loved the train and the experience. The kids enjoyed the music. The dining was great...they do have alternative options so that was helpful with the children. Service was fabulous.

Definitely do the EVENING trip---Book WELL IN ADVANCE. This is DEFINITELY a bucket list/ life event however the entertainment and food should NOT have to compete with the unbelievable scenery between Cusco and Aguas Caliente. For that reason I HIGHLY recommend taking the Vista train to Aguas Caliente during the daytime, and indulging in the Hiram Bingham in the dark. You need the incredible views from the Vista Train to fully appreciate the unbelievable sights which are the Andes----its simply breathtaking!We knew it would be a pretty special trip when we showed up at the station over 30 min. before departure and the musicians in the bar car were already playing a tango. Endless trays of complimentary Pisco Sours accompanied them as well as a very happy group of South Americans who were already celebrating. Its a festive atmosphere from the time you hit the door of the special station room for HB passengers.Food was incredible, service outstanding and as I said, fantastic entertainment. We thoroughly enjoyed talking to our fellow passengers in the bar car----some Americans and some South Americans and Europeans. The trip between the two towns in the dark is good for either sleeping, or having one incredible time on a train like the Hiram Bingham. SO GLAD we chose to splurge and enjoy ourselves!
Worth the Price. This is a luxury train like the Orient Express for a trip to Machu Picchu. It's worth the price - scenery along the way is outstanding and the food and service first class.

Orient Express Experience on Way to Machu Picchu. I can't recommend this experience enough. Outstanding service reminiscent of the glory days of train travel. Very high quality food, drink and wine selections. The band in the bar car was very entertaining with numerous traditional Peruvian pieces mixed in with a variety of more modern covers by such bands as the Beatles. We had filet mignon for lunch and duck for dinner which were one of two choices for each meal. Tea service was also provided at 4 PM at the hotel next to the entrance of Machu Picchu. The train specialty drink was the Pisco Sour and is not to be missed. It was an approximately 4 hour trip from Cusco to Machu Picchu, with the first 1.5 hours being on a mini bus due to service on the tracks outside of Cusco. The ride comes with entrance into the site and an excellent 2 hour+ tour of the site by Carlos, our guide for the entire day. Don't be scared by sticker shock. This is a once-in-a-lifetime experience and worth every penny.

Fantastic Day on the Hiram Bingham. Travelled from Cusco to Machu Picchu via bus then train. The train tracks outside Cusco are being repaired so we took a bus 35 km to meet the train. The train mimic's a 1920's era train with a dinning car, bar car and a viewing car. They served lunch on the way to Machu Picchu and dinner on the way back. From when we checked in at Cusco's train station to when we were dropped off at our hotel, the staff was excellent. Our tour guide Carlos was fantastic and excited to share his knowledge of Machu Picchu along with the region during our bus ride. The food, entertainment and service from the staff were second to none. One if the best tours I have been on.

a very pleasant trip. we went to aguas calientes from sacred valley and it was a wonderful tour. The meal was excelent, train very comfortable, staff kind and atencious, bar with fantastic drinks, and a band singing and putting everybody dancing! We loved it!

Indulge yourself with a Great Experience. It has been a year+ since I lived the Hiram Bingham experience on my way to Machu Pichu and the memories are as fresh as if it was yesterday. The high quality service, the excellent food, the entertainment during the trip, the professionalism of every one involved and the attention to every single details brings the definition of great service to a another level.

Good trip and experience. Probably value for money when one considers the included guided Machu Picchu tour.. Travelled from Poroy Station (about a 30 minute drive from Cusco) to Aquas Calientes (end of the train line for Machu Picchu), a distance of some 112 kilometres but the journey took just under 3 1/2 hours due to the fact that in many places it is a single line and we had to stop to allow other trains travelling in the opposite direction to pass. We also made several stops at some train stations along the way, principally, at Ollyantaytambo. There was also one switch back section that allowed us to lose some altitude. We took the Vistadome train 2 days later for the journey back from Aquas Calientes to Poroy.I had purchased the train tickets on-line from the PeruRail website and had found this to be a reasonably simple exercise. I was though concerned when allocated tickets 1 and 6 in carriage A that we might not be sitting together but an email to PeruRail and a speedy response from them assured me that these seats were single seats opposite each other. The seating was in a configuration of 1 seat (with another opposite facing it with a table in between) then a bench seat for 2 people (again with another opposite for 2 people with a table in between. Effectively in each row 3 people faced the direction in which the train was going and 3 were going backwards. Cost of tickets included a guided tour of Machu Picchu, afternoon tea at the Belmond Sanctuary Lodge (located just outside the gates to Machu Pichu) as well as the return bus tickets from the train station to Machu Picchu.Station at Poroy was reasonably comfortable with a small cafe. The Vistadome train also leaves from here and it was the first train to leave about 20 minutes before us - the Hiram Bingham departing on time at 9-05 a.m from the same platform as the Vistadome train.There was a check-in booth inside the station where our names were ticked off and we were shown to some seats in Carriage A but these did not match the seat numbers on our tickets. I had read on Trip Advisor that this had also happened to some previous travellers and there had been some awkward scenes when the people originally allocated those seats had turned up to claim them so I asked our porter/steward, Hugo, as to whether we could sit in our originally booked seats. He proceeded to tell me that there were no seats 1 and 6 opposite each other which was clearly not true as I discovered on a quick walk down the carriage. I pointed this out to him upon his return and he said he would speak with his boss. When he had not returned some 10 minutes later we just moved to seats 1 and 6 and nothing more was said, though it wasn't a great start.Our train only had 2 buffet/dining carriages, a bar carriage and an observatory carriage. All were beautifully appointed Pullman cars and our table was set with a linen table cloth, China plates, crystal glasses and silver cutlery. When we left Poroy station our carriage was only about 60% full but it picked up more passengers at Ollyantaytambo. There was also some musicians on the platform (who boarded the train) and some very colourful traditionally dressed dancers (who did not).Whilst I understand that you can organise to store some larger luggage on the train most people just had small bags. We took two soft sided sports bags - one of which fitted into the open storage shelf above our seats and the other under our seats. We had left our larger bags in storage at our hotel in Cusco.Train was very comfortable although we spent much of the journey in our allocated seats in the dining car and in the Observation car. The musical troupe was playing in the Bar car but this was pretty well occupied by what appeared to be a local dignitary and his entourage including cameramen.Food was OK - a 3 course set menu starting with trout ceviche, a chicken dish then cheesecake (with a cornflour base) and tea/coffee. Drinks, including a champagne not long after boarding, and beer/wine were free. Service during the meal was good but drinks at other times were very slow to arrive. We also received 2 soft sided travel bags as a gift from Belmond.Great and varied scenery. The line started initially through fairly flat farm land with lots of horses, cows and goats (all tied up as there were no fences between the different fields and no barriers to stop them going onto the train line). Also went through the middle of a couple of smallish towns. Passed a man slaughtering a pig beside the train line while his son stoked the wood under a big black pot of what looked like boiling water.Further on the snow capped Andes loomed above us and as we moved into the mountains we started to travel beside a fast flowing river that would accompany us almost all the way to Aquas Callientes. Just past Piscacucho we sighted some people trekking the early part of the 4 day Inca Trail journey.Upon our arrival at Aquas Calientes, we were met by representatives of the Sumaq Machu Picchu Hotel where we had booked a 2 night stay - fabulous hotel - who took our bags away to the hotel whilst we followed our tour guide - Carlos - ( who had journeyed up on the train and introduced himself to us on the train) to the buses that would take us up to Machu Picchu. Belmond had reserved seats on 2 separate buses. Our group was only comprised of 7 people.Prior to heading into Machu Picchu, we stopped at the bathrooms at the gates - there are no toilets inside Machu Picchu. Whilst the cost of entry to the toilets was only 1 Sole it was free for Hiram Bingham travellers. We also received priority entrance, past a couple of fairly long queues of people, into Machu Picchu.Following our guided tour of the ruins, which lasted about 2 1/2 hours, we adjourned to the Belmond Sanctuary Lodge for afternoon tea which comprised drinks (including tea and coffee) and a range of snacks including sandwiches, canapés and cakes.At about 5.40pm we were given a signal that there was a bus waiting to take us back down the hill to Aquas Calientes.Overall the whole day trip, apart from the initial issue with our seats, was particularly well organised by Belmond.Would I recommend it - probably yes, provided that the price still included the guided tour of Machu Picchu, bus fare up and back plus afternoon tea at the Belmond. I am not sure though that I would recommend the return journey from Aquas Calientes to Poroy as this journey generally leaves late in the afternoon and finishes after nightfall. As a result you would miss much of the magnificent scenery.

The other way to see machu picchu. If you don't hike the old Inca trail to arrive at Machu Picchu, then you should take the Hiram Bingham train. Both give you a once in a lifetime experience. By this train, you get luxury service as it was in the great days of train travel. From the service pre-boarding to the meals onboard, to the semi private tour of the ruins, you are treated like royalty. My suggestion is to stay overnight at least one night in Agua Caliente, either at the Sanctuary at the top or Inka Terrace in the town.

Luxury on the Move. There are three ways to get to Machu Picchu: hike the Inca Trail, take a train, or take the Hiram Bingham. The three hour adventure is the way to go, if you want a splurge! Modelled on the sophisticated Orient Express dining cars, with wood panelling, white linen table cloths, silver cutlery and fine dishware, your trip includes brunch on the way up, and dinner on the way back. Live music in the bar car, an observation car including an open-air platform at the rear complete the scene. The food is great, the service impeccable and the scenery, as the jungle forms around you, is amazing. Definitely a splurge worth taking!

Unmissable. We went to and from Machu picchu on this train service which was an amazing combination of spectacular scenery, great hospitality, delicious food, plentiful wine, music, dancing and fun! And that was just the morning trip down to Machu picchu. Was much better than I had expected, and very professional all round. Recommended.

Must do. We travelled from Machu Picchu (Aguas Calientes) train station to Rio Sagrado and due to the risk of landslides were transported by bus to Cusco. We were disappointed that the trip was cut short, but the service, food and generous servings of wine made up for any initial disappointment.It's a unique train trip and not to be missed.

Amazing!. We used the Hiram Bingham for the return journey to Cusco on New Years Eve. It was absolutely worth every dollar. There was a surprise party on board; the food was outstanding. The best way to bring in 2015!

Experience of Hiram Bingham train. In November 2014 myself and 3 other friends went on the Hiram Bingham from Machu Picchu town to olanta near cusco on the evening train. We had a nice meal and the wine was average. We all felt that it was very very pricey and we certainly did not get value for money. I would not recommend this train to friends because of being grossly overpriced.

Train luxury. We returned to Cusco via the Hiram Bingham train, enjoying entertainment and a five-course peruvian meal with wine during the journey. This is not cheap, but it was wonderful: a match for the Orient Express.

The Ultimate Train Experience. One of the world's great train experiences! It begins with a glass of champagne and native entertainers before boarding. The exterior of the Hiram Bingham literally sparkles it is so clean. The interior looks like an first class elegant restaurant on wheels. Down to the smallest details it was perfection. The wine and food did not disappoint it was delicious, and presentations were almost works of art. The service was top drawer. The train journey to Machu Picchu plunges through the Andean heights along the Urubamba River reaching the Inca Citadel. Do not missthe opportunity to experience the truly luxurious HIRAM BINGHAM. The train ride of a lifetime!

5 stars trip. A wonderous way to get to one of the world wonders, service, music, drinks, etc, everything is set to have a great time, and the guide they provide us for tha Machu Pichu visit deserves a big applause

If you have the means - Book it!. The biggest concern we had with our trip to Machu Picchu was the long train ride. Those concerns quickly went away as soon as we boarded the Hiram Bingham! Belmond really goes all out with the Hiram Bingham experience. The service is top notch and the gourmet food was plentiful. The almost 4 hour trip went by incredibly fast. This has to be one of the most scenic train routes in the world. You start through the Peruvian countryside watching local farmers in action and wind up in the rain forest as you reach the base of Machu Picchu. It is very pricey, but without a doubt worth every penny!

Belmond Hirem Bingham Trai trip. Absolutely fantastic trip.Every expectation met. Any whingeling deserves to be treated as a disgruntled visitor from another planet!! (They are there on Tripadvisor!!)Every part of the trip was enjoyable and the Machu Picchu part was brilliant.Worth every cent of the $800 for both ways.

Exceeded Expectations. We planned our entire Peru/Ecuador trip so far in advance that I had forgotten we had booked a one way dinner train from Aquas Calientes to Cusco. Unfortunately, my husband had picked up a nasty travel bug and couldn't enjoy any of the wonderful live band, great food and drink on the train. Luckily, two nice women adopted me for the evening and I was able to have a delicious dinner and evening of fun conversation while my husband was covered with a blanket and given a pillow in the bar car.
