The service and food were outstanding! They even offered soup or a special bland meal for my husband but he could only handle hot tea. I highly recommend if you are wanting a very special treat and experience.

Orient Express in the Andes!. The experience starts off with the VIP waiting room, where we were catered to, and taken one by one onto the train. From the moment we stepped aboard, we felt like we were on the Orient Express with the wonderfully comfortable appointments and first class appeal. The food and drinks we were served were very good, especially when you consider that we are on a train. The observation car was fun while it was still light outside. But the Bar Car is where it was happening up until dinner. What a wonderful experience. They had a very animated band on board that had everyone singing and dancing. observatory car. The quality of this trip should not be a surprise when you realize that it is handled by Belmond. Highly recommend.

Worth the $$. My husband and I deliberated for a couple of weeks before deciding to book tickets on the Hiram Bingham. In the end, we chose to splurge. After returning from our trip, we're glad we did it! Everything was top notch - the food, the drinks, the band, the tour of Machu Picchu. The staff was extremely attentive and anticipated our every need. We had a great time and met fun people as well. Oh, and one more comment about the band - they were able to get my non-dancing husband out of his seat and on the middle of the bar car for an impromptu solo dance, which I would have thought was an impossible feat. Wow.

Oh I like this train. This was one of my favorite experiences on the trip. The train is stunning, the staff is excellent, and the food and drink are awesome. In belmond fashion I wisked into their world for a second time. The morning started with champagne then a great lunch and guide introductions. When we arrived in Machu Picchu we toured the site with our guides who were very knowledgeable, they knew us and gave us an amazing tour. After a wonderful high tea experience at the belmond hotel at the site. We were welcomed back on the train to another beautiful meal and a really entertaining band in the bar car who played some beautiful, some fun, all thoroughly enjoyable music all the back to cusco. I've been lucky enough to have had lots of fancy experiences in hotels and on trains but belmond seems to make it truly special. All around very impressive. One thought I wouldn't choose to try the train one way and take the morning train up. I did and didn't want to take the other train back. I would either book a round trip on the train or if you just want a one way experience make the one way the train back to cusco at night. Thanks to everyone on the train that made that day so awesome.

The way to go to Machu Picchu. We took the HB roundtrip to Machu Picchu in November. Everything was organised by Belmond and it run perfectly. The train is luxurious, the service impeccable and the experience one to remember for a very long time. The morning trip was more enjoyable because it was possible to see more of the landscape; and t is amazing. The evening return, the following day, provided better food. We would recommend this to anybody going to MP.

Greatest Train Ride/Robbery on Earth!. If the train engine actually works and nothing falls on tracks you will most likely be pleased with your experience. If there is any problem, I wish you the best of luck in dealing with this company's management staff for any kind of compensation or even considerate treatment. We departed from Poroy Station on Wednesday, November 12th. The trip started very well, but approximately 10 km away from the station the train stopped and we were told we were waiting for another train to pass. After waiting for about an hour, we were told that the train engine was experiencing mechanical problems and we were driven back to Poroy station in reverse. We were told that a backup engine would be swapped out then we would be on our way. We were supposed to be served lunch at 1100, but about 1130 an announcement was made that lunch would be served. Then as soon as the food started to be brought out (and before anyone could eat anything) there was another announcement that we would now be driven by bus to another station down the tracks to catch another train. We were all herded into buses and I endured the most grueling, bone-jarring bus ride in my life. About an hour later we arrived at the train station and boarded the Vistadome for the remainder of the journey to Aguas Caliente. We were served a so-called "box" lunch which consisted of a stale sandwich, cookie and a banana, literally served up in a cardboard box. We finally arrived at Aguas Caliente over 3 hours late and driven up to Machu Picchu by bus. Since we arrived so late, the park was closing so we had a very short visit, then a nice tea service at the Sanctuary Lodge.The Hiram Bingham staff made no attempt whatsoever to discuss how and if any of us would be compensated for the money paid for a luxury train ride as promised and not delivered. After inquiring, we were promised tickets for another day visit to Machu Picchu since we had our tour cut short due to the Hiram Bingham's engine problems. We also asked if we could have our Vistadome tickets for the return trip on 14 November, upgraded to the Hiram Bingham since we never had the chance to experience the luxury train ride and meal we paid for. The train staff kept telling us this was "no problem" and that the main office was aware of our request. We were given a set of entrance tickets for Machu Picchu for November 13th. and we were told that we would have the Hiram Bingham tickets waiting for us at the Aguas Caliente station. When we inquired about our return tickets at the Aguas Caliente station, we were told that there were no tickets and the Hiram Bingham office was not aware of our issue. On 13 November, as we tried to enter Macchu Picchu, we were told our tickets were no good. So we spent the next couple hours or so trying to resolve the ticket issue and thanks to the incredibly devoted management and staff at the Sanctuary Lodge, we were finally able to enter and enjoy the park. After returning to Sanctuary Lodge we spoke to the Hiram Bingham manager, Mr. Javier Carlavilla, who was incredibly rude and condescending, stating "you were delivered for a Machu Picchu tour and were given a box lunch, so what is the problem?" He also promised he was going to email the Hiram Bingham tickets to us then never sent them. Later that evening we went back to the Aguas Caliente station and asked if we could meet with Mr. Carlavilla. After we met, he was less than cordial, it seemed as if he was trying to make us feel guilty for asking for compensation for an "act of god", something totally beyond his control. He told us that we could just "show up" 14 November and tell the train staff that he said it was o.k. for us to ride the train. Really? After our experience earlier in the day of being denied access to Machu Picchu we asked for actual boarding passes. He became enraged at this, acting as if it was a tremendous inconvenience to produce a pair tickets, that he now had to call his boss to make this happen. After about an hour of excruciating waiting and arguing, we finally received our boarding passes. In fairness, the return ride to Poroy station was magnificent and without a hitch, it's a shame that the whole experience had to be tainted by the exceptionally unprofessional management of our situation.

5 star service!. The best way to go to Machu Picchu. Wonderful experience on board a Orient Express train. Very animated band on the observatory car. Good food and beverage, with traditional peruvian cuisine too. The guide on Machu Picchu was provided by Belmond team, and was a unforgettable trip!

Leisurely way to get to MP. Took the Hiram Bingham roundtrip in August. Check in was absolutely disorganized and zero communication. How hard is it to put up a sign with instructions for guests so they know where to stand? The train guests were getting persnickety with one another about cutting in line, etc. Though the morning trip was great where one can go to back of train and look out the open air platform. Some gorgeous scenery! Brunch was mediocre but let's face it, they are cooking on a train! It was still fun and romantic. Return trip wasn't as great as one can't see anything out the window because it's dark and the platform is closed. The return trip is more suited to those who want to party on way back or groups in MHO.

Amazing experience. We had booked return tickets on the Vistadome train, and then 10 days before we received a special upgrade offer for the return trip from Machu Picchu to Cusco. We paid less than 50% of the full price, which is the best money we ever spent.It all starts when you arrive at the train station. We were there quite early, and when the attendants noticed "Hiram Bingham" on our tickets, we led down a separate path that led to the HB waiting area, which has very comfortable seating. After a while staff started arriving and we were served a welcome cocktail and a small snack. Soon after we boarded, and the train is just beautiful, both inside and out. What makes the experience so special, though, is the staff. Whoever is in charge of staff training at Belmond deserves a statue. Everybody is so friendly and helpful, and seem genuinely happy to look after you. What a great way to make people feel welcome!There were musicians on the train too. Where often these will sort of go through the motions, these guys were totally into it! It was such a pleasure to watch them have fun. There was a real party going on in the bar car, before dinner was served.Food and wine were excellent. 3.5 Hours have never gone by so fast.

the best train option. From the very first minute with the dancing and music at Cusco station the experience pays back the hug he amount of money. From january to may you make a shorter trip due to maintenance works on the track. fully enjoyable is traveling in the bar wagon with the music singing and dancing and sharing with the other travelers. If you have one day to visit Machu Pichu and need to return to Cusco this is the most convenient, but expensive for sure way. Staff is incredibly helpful and friendly

Is there a better way to get to Machu Picchu!. The train is great all around - what an experience. We did up and back in a day and were wowed by the views and the great service. The bar car got wild on the way back down thanks to the free flowing pisco sours and fun band! If you cannot justify the price round trip - i would surely take it one way (maybe back down at night?)

A great train experience. Very good service and all the drinks you can take but not much room for luggage. Meals are pretty good and the train in general very comfortable. At the last car you have live music and it is the best place to enjoy the lanscape with a nice drink.

Fantastic Train Ride; Horrible booking experience. The train ride is well worth the cost. The train is gorgeous, the staff are great, and the music in the bar car (in the rear) is fantastic. However, booking a ticket is a nightmare. In general, booking and planning things in Peru and Ecuador can be challenging, but you would expect much better for a train that charges $1500 per round trip ticket. After many confusing emails (6 months prior to departure), I finally managed to get 2x one-way tickets for me and my husband. I had a confirmation number, and in the hassle of all the back and forth, I must not have given them a credit card no. THE DAY BEFORE OUR TRIP I received an email from Jimmy Yanqui, stating that since I had not paid for the trip or responded to previous emails, he had cancelled our itinerary. Unbelievable. There were no emails. We received this pleasant email the day we landed in Peru. Almost every vendor in Peru is disorganized, but from the moment I emailed PeruRail about the Hiram Bingham to the moment we boarded, it was chaos. Once we were on board, it was fantastic.

Excellent Train Experience. First off, I'll admit that my boyfriend booked our tickets, so I don't know what the cost was for the ride. Due to that, I'll refrain from speaking about value, as that's only relative to price. The service on the train was top notch. We were seated in a nice dining car, with tablecloths and flowers in vases. Once the first server knew our name, everyone in the train knew it. And they used our names whenever greeting us. It was one of those little touches that means a lot. Our tickets included drinks, snack, lunch and entertainment in the back bar car. I enjoyed champagne, pisco sours, and white wine (with lunch). The pisco sours were by far the most enjoyable drinks, with the champagne and wine being a bit too much on the sweet side for me. Admittedly, I do normally prefer fairly dry vintages. Lunch was good and the ingredients were very fresh. We are vegetarian and pescetarian, and they were able to accommodate both of our dietary needs on the ride. We had bread, salad, a main course and a dessert. The salads in Peru only really seem to be available with a vinaigrette style dressing, but it was pleasant nonetheless. The salad included beautiful avocado and peeled/seeded tomatoes. I'd never had tomatoes in my salad that had been peeled and seeded, but it was actually a nice touch. It meant they were easy to chew and not watery at all.During the ride, the views are beautiful. You go from high elevation in Cusco to a cloud forest (very tropical) and the mountains change a lot during that transition. Occasionally, you pass by small towns and farming along the railroad. Some of the most memorable moments were when we passed through a town and young children were running through the streets to wave at our train as it passed. We spent time in the bar car, where there was a band playing Peruvian music (and the occasional song that inspired all of the visitors from Mexico to sing along). They provided snacks in the bar cars (dried vegetable chips and gooseberries are what I recall) and continued to serve beverages. It was a very relaxing experience and felt like a luxury, especially in that part of the world. When I asked our tour guide (part of the tickets we purchased included tickets into Machu Picchu and a guided tour, followed by afternoon tea at the hotel owned by the Hiram Bingham company) if all Peruvians visited Machu Picchu, I was surprised when he said no. He said that it's too expensive for many. As a bonus, before we left the train, we were provided some small travel bags as a souvenir from our train ride. The only downside was that they had been stored somewhere humid and had mildew on them. When we discovered this later, we abandoned them. When we arrived at the train station, they took our luggage and ensured it arrived at our hotel. We then took the buses specially chartered for the train guests up the hill to Machu Picchu. This saved us from having to get in line and wait for who knows how long for available seats on a bus. The ride up the hill is lots of switchbacks and scary turns. If you get car sick easily, a dramamine may be called for. After our tour of Machu Picchu, we enjoyed lovely afternoon tea at the Belmond Sanctuary, the only hotel right next to the park. It was delicious and again provided plenty of options to satisfy both of our diets. Afterwards, we again loaded into buses for our group, avoiding a 1-2 hour wait other visitors made standing in long lines.

The Orient Express... on a narrow gauge track.. I am not a professional rewiewer, and this is just my opinion. My wife and I decided to splurge a little and ride the HB on our way from Cuzco to Machu Picchu. The train leaves from the Poroy station, about 20 minutes from Cuzco, and not from the city itself, probably because it's a narrower gauge than the Andean Explorer to Puno - which we also traveled in. Check-in was fast and efficient, but we were a little surprised to be seated in a different wagon than our tickets indicated. That in itself was not a problem. On the platform, passengers were entertained by musicians and dancers. The railcar was beautifully decorated, the seats very comfortable, the ensemble giving passengers a feeling of glamorous travel back in time. The bathrooms were spacious and quite clean. After departure, the bar soon became crowded as a trio of musicians performed for the passengers. Personally we found the sound level way too high, and we were amused by the trio's repertoire which consisted mostly of Mexican songs - besides "El Cóndor Pasa", there are not many Peruvian songs recognized by gringos. So we did not linger in the observation car, also because the landscape was not very attractive, at least during the first couple of hours. We skipped the Pisco Sour demonstration but did not refuse the offered drinks - good thing they were on the weak side. Because the train runs on a very narrow gauge, it's not the smoothest ride, but that's part of the fun. Then it was time for lunch. The food was fine, and given the galley's constraints, they did a pretty good job. Service was excellent, pretty much like everywhere else in Perú. Unfortunately, lunchtime coincided with the most spectacular landscapes, and much to my regret I was not able to take any photos. I thought I would be able to do so on the way back, but it was not to be. We disembarked in Aguas Calientes, and had to take a somewhat awkward walk to the waiting bus which took us to the Sanctuary Lodge. The following day, on the way back to Cuzco, the check-in was also quick, and again we were seated in a different car than our tickets indicated. When my wife asked the fellow about the reason why, his response was "Don't worry, that's my problem". And it did indeed become his problem, and ours as well, because a couple walked in, and told us that we were seated at their table. They insisted to us and the conductor that this was the table they wanted, period. After some awkward moments, both the conductor and the couple's tour guide came to apologize and ask us to move to another table, and of course we did, there had been enough of a scene as it was. We could have been offered a drink on the house, but we were not, and being the rascal that I am, I did ask them to do so, and of course they had to comply. Again, same loud music in the bar, and again dinner - also fine - prevented me to go to the observation deck and take photos. A good portion of the ride back took place at night. Now I do understand that scheduling the rides is a tricky affair, so I still would recommend visitors to Machu Picchu to experience the Hiram Bingham, albeit with the caveats above. But I can't find an excuse for our being - rather forcefully - assigned different seats than the ones on our tickets, thus creating a scene.

BEST TRANSPORTATION TO MACHU PICCHU, LUXURIOUS!!. We stayed at the Belmond Rio Sagrado for 3 days in the Sacred Valley in early October. The Belmond hotels took care of the arrangements for us once I decided upon our transportation to Machu Picchu. The Hiram Bingham train is amazing and a really fun way to go to Machu Picchu. It is reminiscent of the glory days of train travel and the ultimate in luxury. IT IS WORTH THE DIFFERENCE IN PRICE IF YOU CAN AFFORD IT!! They greet you by name with a mimosa and show you to your table for brunch when you board in Ollantaytambo on the way to Machu Picchu (if you are staying in the Sacred Valley). The ride is beautiful and seems to go by quickly when you are eating brunch. Upon arrival in Aquas Caliente they put the Hiram Bingham riders in a waiting area complete with drinks and then walk you over to the other side of the street to catch a bus to the entrance to Machu Picchu. What a ride that is!! I"m not great with heights but it was still beautiful going up so high into the mountain (25 minutes) with very seasoned drivers who seemed to have no trouble backing up on the narrow winding road to let a bus going the opposite direction pass. The Hiram Bingham provides a knowledgeable guide (our was Jesus - very proud of his heritage). There were 8 of us in the tour which was a perfect size. We spent just over 3 hours walking all over the amazing Machu Picchu, then went into the Belmond Sanctuary Lodge (the only hotel at the base of Machu Picchu) for afternoon tea. We all boarded the bus (there were 2 groups from the Hiram Bingham train) and rode the 25 minutes down the mountain. Those of us not staying in Aguas Caliente got back on the train and since my husband and I were getting off at Ollantaytambo rather than with the rest of the riders at Cuzco (Poroy to be more accurate) we were shown to the bar where live (and lively) music was being played (and pisco sours were being served). We sat there enjoying the music until our dinner was to be served. Dinner is elegant and tasty as one would expect from a fine restaurant. They stopped at Ollantaytambo for us to get off. Our driver was waiting with a flashlight at the exit of the train station and called us out by name which was fortunate because it was very dark outside and there were several taxi drivers waiting. The drivers they arrange through the hotel all have very nice cars, they provide water bottles and it is very comfortable and helpful when they know you name. The Hiram Bingham train to Machu Picchu made the visit the best possible excursion- definitely worth the cost for a once in a lifetime total experience!

Not to be missed on your trip to Peru.. While the price tag may shock at first, you realize that not everyday you are in Peru. Really no visit would be complete without having the experience of the Hiram Bingham. It is luxury and service that approaches an almost decadent level. The staff is amazing attentive to your every need. They make you feel special from start to finish. The only downside to our trip was that it ended and we had to get off the train. But, wow, what a ride it was.

Travel back in time by train. Amazing train with old world style of a dining and bar car. Drinks are served in the bar car with live entertainment and dancing throughout the car. The a wonderful 5 course dinner is served on your trip back to Cusco.
At last!!!. Unique experience, first time on the Orient Express, after waiting 45 years!!! Loved getting dressed up for a train ride.

Old wourld experence. The old Pullman cars are very well restored. The food was prepared well and the service was very good. I enjoyed the experience even thought it was very expensive. The experience is something to remember. The train cares are grand inside I wish I could say that for the ride. I suspect the train car suspension is old world as we did move around a lot on our ride. Perhaps that is part of the Orient Express experience. I am glad we had the experience.

Treat yourself and do this going up to Machu Picchu. Great experience.. Great atmosphere. Good entertainment and information given while on the train. Food was delicious. The viewing car was really fun. There was nothing to dislike! Great experience.

A delightful anachronistic experience, arrive in luxury and style. A delightful anachronistic experience.The train was finely appointed from its white table cloths to the perfectly polished brass and hardwoods that looked to have at least 20 coats of varnish.The dining was superb, the table was spacious and it was a wonderful way to make our way to Aguas Calientes / Machu Picchu.I found the band in the waiting area when were leaving a bit loud, but it was nice to have a private waiting area with clean bathrooms.Highly recommended.

A memorable journey. This train journey is a memorable way to travel from Cusco to Aguascalientes Calientes and back. Service was friendly and excellent and the food and drink were very good considering you are on a train. Comfortable seats, an observation car and plenty of photo opportunities. Other bonuses from travelling on thus train are the fact that you avoid queuing for the buses to and from Aguas Calientes to Machu Picchu and that you are allocated a Hiram Bingham guide. Our guide was called Breytzi and was outstanding; so knowledgeable and enthusiastic about her subject. This is an expensive trip but for a special occasion worth every penny.

Luxury Train Ride with Cindy Crawford. The food and service are great on the Hiram Bingham. It is a bit hectic and complicated when you arrive at the Aguascalientes Train Station due to the amount of tourists converging and the Hiram Bingham Guide begins yelling to keep walking and get on the A, B, or C bus to Machu Picchu then the buses arrive but are not marked, more confusion and some yelling of instruction and you are shoved on a bus and make the 25 minute drive up the mountain. When you arrive back at the station after touring Machu Picchu you are greeted at the private Hiram Bingham waiting room with a cool wash cloth and drink before boarding the return train and the excellent service starts over again.

An excellent ride and the only way to do Machhu Picchu!. Comfortable, unique, social and a amazing experience traveling Cusco to and from Machhu Picchu! Dance, drink and eat on your way to the city in the clouds...
First class travel. Worth every dollar. Once in a life time ride on an elegant train. Service was outstanding made me happy is all I can say.
Fun Ride. The train moves slowly through the mountains on the way to Macchu Picchu. Great scenery and a lot of windows to see it through. Left on time and was a great experience overall.

Great Way to Travel. There is only one way to get to Machu Picchu and it is by train. You have two options: the Hiram Bingham and the Vistadome. I booked both. One going to and the other, coming from. At first I thought the Hiram Bingham was a little expensive, but I did not know that we had the food, the pastries, the piscos and the music included. As well as the ride and a guided tour to Machu Picchu and afterwards a delightful tea at the Belmond Sanctuary Lodge. It’s a first class experience. Everything was extraordinary!

DO IT!. Amazing experience. We just loved it... we did a day trip to the ruins and did it both ways on the Hiram Bingham. We ate, we drank, we saw amazing scenery, we drank some more... fantastic trip! In my opinion it was well worth the extra expense - for us, Peru was more than likely a "once in a lifetime" experience and with that in mind... SPEND THE MONEY AND TAKE THIS TRAIN.We could not have enjoyed this experience any more than we did. We were there in the rainy season and thought we might have to take the 'bus/train' combo... but got hugely lucky and wound up having the train for the entire trip (and it was GREAT).

Over the Top, But Great Fun. Our tour operator booked us on the Hiram Bingham from Aguas Calientes to Cuzco. The whole experience was over the top opulence -- probably something we wouldn't have booked on our own -- but it was memorable. The bar car was rockin with the band and the free-flowing Pisco Sours. Dinner was truly excellent and on par with, if not better than, dining experiences we had in restaurants in Peru. The service was terrific. We had a ball!

The way to get to Machu Picchu. If you want to get to Machu Picchu with live music and a nice Pisco cocktail in your hand, this is the way! Old fashioned train with amazing service. Round trip includes guide, transportation to the ruins, meals and high tea in the afternoon... what else can you ask for?

Enjoy the ride. Greeting was great , they took really good care of us!Definitely the best train experience of our lives, i am writing this one 2 weeks before trying the VSOE in Asia so i may change my mind but for now i've never experienced such a great service and scenery in a train.I really recommend it.

Wonderful experience! We'll be back!. We took the Hiram Bingham train both ways to Machu Picchu and LOVED the ride! We booked on line in the U.S. I was a little nervous about doing that--the tix are not cheap and, if anything went wrong, we didn't have a back up plan... but no worries, we were greeted at the Poray train station with champagne and local music to begin our adventure. (Note that the Poray train station is about a 25-30 minute cab ride from Cusco hotels.) We were then seated in the dining room at our table for 2. I found the seats comfortable and the table convenient so I could set up my lap top and iPad. You also have access to the bar car and the panorama car. On the way to MP, my husband spent much of his time before lunch in the panorama car taking pictures. We were thrilled to be taking the train both ways, but I know some opt to take the train one way. The experiences we thought were very different, so here are some pros and cons of each:The ride to MP starts about 9 in the morning and arrives around 12:30 pm after lunch. So, although drinks and wine are free, we didn't have more than a small glass of wine with lunch. The lunch was very tasty. The ride is all during daylight, so it's good for getting pictures from the train. The band plays, but it's not too boisterous early in the morning. However, a huge advantage is that when you get to Aguas Caliente and take the bus to the hotel, you have a guided tour of the ruins included by a truly first class guide who speaks English well. Our guide was wonderfully enthusiastic and, although she only works part time and also works in the H Stern shop at the Hotel Monasterio (wish I could remember her name) her tour was one of the highlights of our visit! I think our time at MP would not have been nearly as well informed if we had not begun the visit with this guided tour. The train ride back leaves around 6 pm and gets back around 9:30 pm. This train is a party train for those who choose to join the singing and dancing in the bar car (which was everybody on our train). The only downside is that in August, the ride was mostly in the dark outside because it's the Peruvian winter, so not great for pics. The band is truly awesome (we bought their cd) and when the music program ended for dinner, everyone was dancing, no matter how old or how young. The dinner that followed was wonderful and again, all drinks are included, so we could enjoy a few pisco sours. As noted, Poroy train station is about a 30 minute ride from Cusco. The train crew helped arrange taxis for anyone who hadn't already booked a ride. Before I forget to mention, the bathrooms were great and I'm very picky about these. Also worth noting for independent travelers like us, we spent the night at MP and found out that we couldn't buy tix for MP on the second day at the park (only the first day was included with the train). Fortunately, our hotel (the Sanctuary Lodge) was able to find some, but if you book before you travel, you'll have less stress. Of course, this had nothing to do with our wonderful train ride. We thought the train was worth the splurge price and plan to do it again!

Great Train Ride!. We took the train from Aguas Calientes to Portnoy (Cuzco). This is an "all inclusive" service train. You have music, drinks and dinner and also a welcome facility at Aguas Calientes with drinks and music. It is quite an experience as the train is very comfortable and the service outstanding. The only thing I would recommend is to take the train from Cuzco to Aguas Calientes which leaves in the morning. That way you will be able to enjoy the great view as you approach Machu Pichu. We took the 5:50pm train on the way back and at this time of the year (August 2014) during winter you don't get to see much. In any event, we had a great time.

Wow. Now this really was a treat. Forget about the price of the ticket (it was paid for and forgotten.... now was the time to enjoy). When we showed the guard our tickets we were shown to a special waiting room (we were an hour early for our train). We were given tea and cold drinks, then entertained and then welcomed onto the train. It was a real experience. Out of a different era and another world. The food was spectacular. We trundled down to the bar car to enjoy the musical entertainment before heading back to our seats. The meal was exquisite and the drinks flowing. We had the most delightful time and the hours flew. It was only marred by my husband's phone going missing (his fault). This was quickly found and the the staff couldn't have been more helpful.
Orient express. Everything you'd expect of an Orient Express train trip! The scenery was beautiful, the trip relaxing, the food plentiful if a bit rushed.
Loved It. This was the best train ride ever! The time flew by as we went from Cuzco to Machu Picchu and back the next day. The food and service was excellent! What a great way to travel!

Worth the price, exceptional ride to Machu Pichu. Took the train in Nov 2011. There are many trains that you can take to Machu Pichu but nothing compares to Hiram Bingham Orient Express train.. The service is excellent, makes the whole ride a pleasure, nice lunch with elegant table setting makes you feel special. On the way back to Cusco live music at the bar, everybody enjoying themselves.. Very expensive but definetely worth the price, will always remember..

No better way to travel. A lovely train that takes you back in time to a luxury method of travel. The seats are very comfortable, the service is perfection and the food was delicious. This is definitely the best way to travel to/from Machu Picchu!

So much fun!!. This was the most fun train trip I have ever had and the perfect finish to my entire Machu Picchu experience.Yes it is expensive (USD400) but get on with an open mind, go right to the bar carriage and be prepared to enjoy the following:(1) A REALLY awesome modern Peruvian band (Trio Sabor & Sentimento) - these guys are serious professionals ie. not your typical Peruvian Pan Flute at your Sunday market. Think Santana and Gipsy Kings - mad voices and even more mad guitar skills! Plus the audience gets to join in - dancing and playing instruments. This goes for 1.5 hours at least and was the best part of the trip for me. (2) Pisco sour class while listening to the awesomeness that is (1).(3) Very good quality 5 course meal which wraps up the remaining 1.5 hours of the train trip.The rest of the positive points have already been covered in all the other reviews - absolutely beautiful period train which is classically Orient Express and very friendly staff.The only negative point I can think of is that the train leaves for Cusco in the evening which means it is too dark to enjoy the landscape ... but heck, you'd be too busy dancing to Santana and Gipsy Kings to notice :p

Macchu Picchu on doorstep. This hotel provides the nearest accommodation to the citadel.It is clean and pleasant with excellent general standards and restaurant facilities.As one might expect of a hotel of this standard everything was handled in the mot efficient way.The staff gave us a lighted candle to dissuade mosquitoes at night although we did not see any on our trip.One word of warning...if you are not going out on the Highram Bingham Train you will need to catch a bus out of the park.The queue we stood I took an over hour to get on to bus.

Very, very nice but for this price it needs to be perfect. My husband and I took the Vistadome train from Poroy to Machu Picchu and the Hiram Bingham train from Machu Picchu to Poroy (see separate review of the Vistadome train).The trip began with afternoon tea in the Sanctuary Lodge just outside the entrance to Machu Picchu. The afternoon tea in itself was nice and felt like the perfect ending to a visit to Machu Picchu. There were some odd things: we finished touring Machu Picchu an hour before the beginning of the afternoon tea. We were led into the dining room, where the afternoon tea would take place, but at no time during this one hour did a single member of staff approach us to ask if we wanted to order some refreshments or drinks. Also felt odd that there was no alcohol (even the typical glass of sparkling wine) included in the afternoon tea. We ordered some extra things and they had to be paid in USD. Luckily we had some left over from Ecuador but this was the only place in Peru where we were told to pay in USD and it felt odd.The bus from the Sanctuary Lodge to the train station was the same/normal bus that we took up by ourselves in the morning. For some reason, I had expected a different, more luxurious Hiram Bingham bus. This wasn’t really an issue, though. Just be prepared for some absolutely terrifying hair-bend turns coming back to Aguas Calientes. I was sure we were going to fall off the cliff and die.Check-in, however, ruined things. I had understood beforehand that check-in would be lovely with drinks and a band. We arrived to the check-in terminal at the designated time and were handed some warm towels, which was nice. But after that we were quickly ushered to sit down and no one asked or served any drinks to us. Some other people did have drinks. Two seconds later a harried looking member of staff approached us and wanted to know in which hotel we were staying in Cuzco. We provided the hotel name to him and then asked why he needed it. He couldn’t really respond. 30 seconds after that he told us that he’d checked us in and we should hurry and get on the train. This was 30 minutes before the train was scheduled to leave. Yes, there was a band playing and yes, we could probably have flagged down a waiter from somewhere to bring us that glass of sparkling wine I had been looking forward to ALL day but this check-in person was adamant that we needed to go. Now. We stopped outside the train to take some pictures but he said we could do that ‘later’. By this point we were so annoyed that we were being treated like two five-year-old children who’d run away from kindergarten, that we let him take us to our seats in the dining carriage. We dumped our things on the chair and went out again to take some photos. After that, we sat like obedient children at the dining table for 25 minutes. Nothing happened. I went to the bar carriage to ask if we could get some sparkling wine because we wanted to celebrate and toast our day. The waitress looked equally harried. Yes, yes, later, I was told. It materialized an hour later.This whole check-in experience was our first experience of the journey back to Poroy and we were everything but impressed.Luckily, the actual ride was better.It was a lovely old-fashioned train with a fun and very loud band playing in the bar carriage while people sang along and the drinks flowed (the pisco sours were probably the worst of all the ones that we had in Peru but the Peruvian sparkling wine was surprisingly nice).Food was very good, not earth-shatteringly memorable but still very good, especially considering you’re on a train.The included wine, however, was bad. We complained about this but were only told that there was one other included red wine (equally awful) and were then handed the menu with prices. Didn't feel that the situation was particularly well handled. I avoid train toilets like the plague, but the ones on the Hiram Bingham one were actually nice (definitely better than airplane ones!) We took the Hiram Bingham train back in the evening from Machu Picchu and of the two options, I thought the Vistadome train was definitely much better value for money. If you want to try both options, I would take the Vistadome to Machu Picchu in the morning and the Hiram Bingham back to Poroy in the evening since the Vistadome had much bigger windows (also up in the ceiling) so it would provide a better view since it will be pitch black once you start your trip back to Poroy. Also, the Hiram Bingham train has a lot of drinks that are included in the price and I felt that it was nicer to enjoy those on the way back than to arrive to Machu Picchu completely hammered. The Vistadome train was also quieter and did not rock back and forth at all as much as the Hiram Bingham train did (this might partly also have been due to it being dark outside). I had to take a seasickness pill on the Hiram Bingham train because I got nauseous (and this was before the alcohol!) whereas I had no issues on the Vistadome (and I get motion sickness relatively easily).In the end, we tried to put the negative things behind us and had a good time but for this price Hiram Bingham needs to provide a seamless, from start to finish perfect experience which it unfortunately did not. If I could, I would give 3 and a half stars.

Nice but overpriced for what it is.. This train is very elegant, with decor done in taste. The service is excellent right from the gate until arrival. There are a few downsides though: First it travels back to Cusco in the evening, when you cannot enjoy the landscape (too dark), which is a pity for a train ride; second, whilst the food service is well presented, the quality is average; and third, it is extremely pricey for what it provides.
Machu Picchu on the Hiram Bingham !!!. A three hour luxurious journey to History.....!!!! Fantastic train ride with the best of service, food, drinks and live music.... Nice views along the way !!

a "rocky" ride. We took the expensive Hiram Bingham train from sacred valley to Machu Picchu as well as from Machu Picchu to Cusco. It is fairly comfortable except for the fact that this train runs on very narrow tracks, and therefore tends to "rock" a lot-----it is amazing that the waiters/waitresses have not had any accidents with their trays etc. Having said that, the food served is fairly good, the entertainment by the musicians very enjoyable, and the views (during day-light) wonderful. A big advantage to travelling by this train is that when you are ready to leave the Machu Picchu site, you do not have to wait for a bus with the long lines. They have their own bus departing from the Belmond Santuary lodge.

Amazing trip. took a different train on the return journey - the Inka train was more a people's train - more basic and less appeal even though the view was the same.The Belmond Hiram Bingham though is special just like the final destination - this is a grand event and everything is done in style

Unforgettable!. Excellence in every detail. We travelled independently and booked tickets on the Internet and chose this option because it included everything we needed: transport to Aguas Calientes, bus to Machu Picchu, entrance ticket, guide, transport back. The train was an experience in itself - everything was just wonderful, from the bubbly they meet you with as you board the train to the impeccable service and excellent food. I travelled with a vegetarian, and of course they had a vegetarian option for the lunch menu. We enjoyed every minute of it and really felt we got our money's worth. We had: 2 glasses of sparkling wine, espresso and cakes, fresh juice, fruit, live music, 3-course lunch, 1 glass of white wine, 1 glass of red wine, another espresso, smooth bus transfer to Machu Picchu, entrance past the queues, excellent guiding for 3 hours, lovely tea etc. at the Sanctuary Lodge, bus transfer back to the station where our luggage had been stored. And no queuing in the rain. We stayed overnight in Aguas Calientes at a cheap, but clean and friendly hostel and went to the site museum next morning before taking the Vistadome back. The Vistadome was like flying Ryanair in comparison - noisy and commercial. Be advised that the taxi ride to Poroy station can take 30 minutes.

A Little Bit Disappointing. The day I travelled on this train from Poroy to Machu Picchu there were only a handful of passengers, which made for a bit of a strange atmosphere. I enjoyed the colourful folkloristic welcome, although no one explained what the masks and dances were about. The train was plushly decorated, but the observation car at the back was also the place where the band played, and played, and played -- to the enjoyment of my fellow passengers who were more interested in drinking pisco and champagne than viewing and photographing the landscape. When I could take the noise no longer I returned to my seat for a bit of peace and quiet, and to await the serving of brunch. This was rather elaborate, but I cannot say that it was overwhelming. I was quite glad to reach Machu Picchu. Here I had my own guide who was included in the train ticket and who was exceptionally nice, although I did not really need his services as I had been to Machu Picchu before and just wanted to wander around by myself. The train ticket also included afternoon tea at the on-site Sanctuary Lodge, and this was a most enjoyable experience. I took the Vistadome back to Cusco, and I felt more at home in this crowded train than I had in the Hiram Bingham. And here is a tip: If you are actually interested in seeing some of the landscape take the morning train to Machu Picchu when travelling in winter, as you will be travelling in the dark on the way back.

Pricey but unforgettable way to travel to Machu Picchu. We (married couple in our early 60s) booked the Hiram Bingham train as part of our tour package in Peru; we'd heard great things about this trip and it exceeded all of our expectations! The first day we boarded the train in the Sacred Valley (at the Ollantaytambo station), and enjoyed a very tasty brunch and lots of sightseeing on our way to the town of Aguas Calientes. After an overnight stay and two-day visit to Machu Picchu we boarded again for the return trip to Cusco. The live band in the bar car was very good (even the non-drinkers said so!), and afterwards we enjoyed an excellent gourmet dinner with some new friends.Be aware that while you're free to roam the train, you'll be sitting in a dining car (I didn't find the seats to be as uncomfortable as others have mentioned). That can also make it a challenge to take photographs on both sides of the train!
Was not that impressed. Very slow service and uncomfortable seats. Take the Vistadome and save yourself hundreds! Have a nice meal after the train with the savings.

Great experience on the Hiram Bingham. At some point in life, one no longer yearns for the material and tangible things but rather focuses on the experiences of the journey. The 3 hr return trip from Machu Picchu to Poroy/Cusco gave just that. Great staff and great people. Thank you!

The best way to Macchu Picchu. The best and only way to Macchu Picchu. The train from Cuzco to Macchu Picchu is approximately 3.5 hours and worth every penny. Beer, wine, and champagne, along with your lunch and snacks are included in the ticket price. There is a live band on the train playing latin music on the way there. Very high class car for seating and dining- the bar cart and panoramic carts are also accessible to ticket holders.

Excellent ride and especially excellent for the drinking and dining. A crazy expensive train ride from Cusco to Machu Picchu. The menus were awesome as were the drinks - we traveled from Cusco to Machu Picchu so didn't drink due to our excursions later in the day. The food was excellent as was the entertainment. The seating left something to be desired - we were not aware that we would be seated primarily in the dining car. The seats themselves were our only complaint - much like economy on an airline...

Great Times. We arrived to visit Machu Picchu on the vistadome and spent two days, on the way back to Cusco we took the Hiram Bingham, my 10 yo daughter and I.It was great, from the greeting at the station with champagne, the party in the bar carriage where my daughter was invited to be part of the band, to the excellent food and wine. I have never been on a train like this, it's not the Eurostar, it's very classic.Thanks for a great trip!

Best way to enjoy the beautiful landscape. After some delay for technical problems, we took this train to Agua-Caliente. The staff was amazing and kept us informed. Once on the train we soon realised that this was a very special train. Lunch was good and the service amazing. We particularly enjoyed observing the beautiful and changing landscape through the window. We spent 2 nights in the Sanctuary Lodge close to the archeological site and took the train back to a city 30 minutes outside Cusco (Note that the train does not arrive go to Cusco). The dinner and service on the train was good. Unfortunately the train leaves the station of Agua-Caliente in the evening and it was too dark to enjoy the scenery. I definitely recommend this train ride.

Fun trip back from Machu Picchu!. Crazy expensive, but had a gas! Would definitely recommend it as a one-time experience. Huge party in the bar car before dinner - dancing, music, great people. The evening quieted down a bit after that with a relaxing dinner and more music. Really nice trip back.
Amazing!. Incredible experience, great food and service. Entertainment all the way to Aguascalientes. Don't forget this when you travel to Machu Picchu

If the Orient Express was in S. America.... ... this would have been it.From offering chilled, aromatherapy washrags during the trip, to an open bar and great food / drink, this was wonderful. The staff was sweet and accommodating too!On time, everything went very smoothly.

This is the ONE!. Machu Picchu is a memorable experience and Belmond Hiram Bingham is another good experience, both matched perfect! I understand it is pricey but Machu Picchu is a place that you may go once in your life. So, make an effort and try to travel on this train and forget to buy entrance ticket, bus tickets and guide separately.We went to Machu Picchu with Hiram Bingham (one way) and return on Expedition because of our budget.This service includes:- Transfer to Machu Picchu- Lunch and all the national beverages- Bilingual guide (we were 3 people) 3 hours, if you hire a guide outside, he/she will guide you 40 minutes max.- Entrance ticket to the Citadel - Bus to go up to the Citadel.- Tea time at Belmond Sanctuary Lodge.-Open carriage to take all pictures.Relax, enjoy and be ready for the adventure.

the only way to travel to Machu Picchu. I'm so glad I convinced my husband to take the Hiram Bingham up to Machu Picchu. it was an experience we will always remember. It was absolutely beautiful and fantastic service. We had a nice greeting at the train station with local dancers and a little breakfast quinoa and champagne. Then a lovely brunch aboard using all local, organic products + good coffee and croissants. Then a nice tour of Machu Picchu with a well-informed, English speaking guide. We were with a group of about 12 so we had plenty of personal attention. The tea at the Sanctuary was nice but the hotel wasn’t as impressive as I expected. I guess its main draw is that it is at the base of Machu Picchu so they can literally walk up to the gate at daybreak.The train had a three piece band aboard that played everything from the Beatles to the local music of my husband’s Peruvian city so they were great. On the way back, they had all of us dancing before dinner but once dinner was over, just about everyone fell asleep on the return trip. It was a perfect day and perfect trip. 

Luxury travel. This must be one of THE train journeys of the world. The scenery is breathtaking, although unfortunately it was dark for our return trip. The food served was excellent, and we had an excellent guide on the train, who came with us around the site. The staff were very attentive, and we would rate this very highly.Annette Roe
Great way to end the trip. We had a great time. For my family (6 people), the music was the hightlight. Everyone was dancing. Wonderful.

Luxurious, delicious, amazing, fun, etc. One of the best trips I made in my life, the first class service is outstanding. Drinks, food, live music, it even includes entry to the sanctuary of Machu Picchu and have a private guide/ photographer. It is the best way to get to one of the wonders of the world, definitely one of the most enjoyable checks in my to do list. I highly recommend it. It is compulsory once in a lifetime. You will not regret.

Unforgettable Rail Journey. A lovely journey from Olanta to Machu Picchu with good food, picturesque scenery and a helpful guild and I wondered what the return journey to Poroy would be like in the dark. No scenery or guide but what entertainment! The food was up to the expected high standard but we had been so preoccupied during the trip that we did not have time for after dinner coffee before we arrived at our destination. An unforgettable journey and we were fortunate that the line to Poroy was opened early as I feel sure that if the train had terminated at Olanta then it would not have been nearly as enjoyable and, of course, we avoided a long road journey to Cusco.My wife does not like train journeys but the Hiram Bingham proved to be the exception, so much so that this was one of the high points of her whole holiday.

Flawless, First Class. The Hiram Bingham train service is really a luxurious, first class way to travel to and from Machu Picchu. The journey begins with a welcome cocktail in a special waiting lounge at the Poroy train station (about 25 min form Cusco). We were sent off by friendly, colorful Peruvian folk dancers. The train car harkens back to the days of old with luxurious interiors of wood and fine linens. The table settings in the dining cars were impeccable as was the overall service. Outside of the dining cars were a bar and observation car. A little cramped but entirely functional. Food and drink were a plenty as we traversed the Sacred Valley on the way to the Machu Picchu citadel. The views of the countryside were spectacular. A delicious three course brunch was served at 2/3 of the way to MP. The entertainment consisted of a lively, fun trio playing Latin, Peruvian and pop favorites. Not lacking for service detail, there was also a special waiting lounge for the trip home in the Agua Caliente station. There we were served appetizers and beverages accompanied by live music in an extra comfortable setting. The ride on the way back was at the end of the day so it was dark and not much scenery to be viewed. That did not dampen the spirit of the journey or the excellent service. The bar and the entertainment area was livened up a bit more than the incoming leg and snacks and beverages were served until the three course gourmet dinner was served. The Hiram Bingham service sure made the Machu Picchu experience extra special and unique being able to travel there and back in luxurious comfort.

Great experience!. We enjoyed a great family experience @ the HB train from Cusco to Machu Picchu and back. The service, food quality and overall experience was really great and unique. The landscape, comments from the train staff, show, drinks, etc. were also first class. This is the right way to visit Machu Picchu!

This is how travel should be...... From booking our tickets online to arranging for our luggage to be taken to our hotel all part of the exceptional service.Even before you step on board you are welcome with a glass of sparkling wine or some other refreshing juice drink, the waiting area in Poroy is not a comfortable as in Machu Pichu but in both places there is live entertainment as you wait to board.The staff were exceptional as they look after your every need and that includes bringing you oxygen because they observe you are a bit sedate or continuously topping up your drink or bringing you more chocolate.The price of the ticket includes entry into MP, a tour guide and return bus transfers from the station to MP. At the end of your trek from MP another pleasant surprise awaits in the form of afternoon tea at the Sanctuary Lodge.Had friends who hiked up and had to wake at 4am...forget it this is the only way to get to MP in style and comfort. Don't let the cost of the ticket deter you it's worth it.

Loved the HB!. Loved the Hiram Bingham, especially on the way to Machu Picchu. The train was awesome, lunch was wonderful, service great, and entertainment good. When we got to Machu Picchu, we were taken to the Sanctuary Lodge, had high tea, and then we lucked in to a private tour of Machu Picchu that was included with our Hiram Bingham ticket! On the way back, the train leaves a little late, making it a great option if you are just at Machu Picchu for one day. However, we stayed for multiple days, so we were pretty tired and the train back arrived pretty late. If you are there for more than one day and are trying to budget, I'd take the HB on the way there, and an earlier train on the way back.

Take a trip back to the golden age of rail. The HB train is a trip in time, as well as space. We took the evening (dinner) train and ate a wonderful four course meal amid wood, velvet and brass in the elegant dining car.While pricey, this is a true YOLO experience. From the time we entered the special waiting room, we were pampered. Waiters bring champagne cocktails and hors d;oeuvres. A jazz duo did Take Five, a riff on Summertime and (of course) El Condor Pasa. Our porter/waiter took our tickets and bags, loaded them on the train and then escorted us to our table. Since dinner was an hour away, we decamped to the bar car, where the waiter plied us with pisco sours and we were entertained by a rocking duo on electric guitar and box drum. They even got me up and dancing to Jailhouse Rock (in Spanish.(The dinner was wonderful and shortly thereafter we arrived at the outskirts of Cusco, totally relaxed and bathed in luxury.

the best train experience from Cusco- Machu Picchu. Is not only the place we arrive to, but "how we arrive" what makes a difference. Pamper yourself and give you this treat (at least one way) the experience is surreal, a marevelous, fancy train, decorated like the finest british trains, with wooden lavish interiors, a must go bar, an observatory wagon, live music and so much more. The meals served onboard are delicious, plus the whole ambiance of 1930's opulence is just superb. By the way when booking round trip this train you can get access to an exclusive post train experience after arriving to Aguas calientes such as going up to machu picchu in a private bus with other VIP guests and receive your Machu Picchu tour private with other peers, a fantastic 5 star experience!

Belmond,Hiram Bingham. Every detail of this trip was amazing,hotels,train and the staff.I was treated like royalty throughout.A single traveller I was a little nervous but was made to feel so special the nerves faded away on the first day .
train ride of a lifetime. Just bloody brilliant,except a bit short, food was good music was brilliant, rime passed to quickly a great way to see the countryside
the way to machupichu. We love to ride at this train for our trip to machupichu , the food incredible and the service impecable

So much more than we expected!. We had heard that it was a "must" to take the first class train service back from Macchu Picchu so we booked it not knowing what it entailed. The tea at Sanctuary Lodge was lovely followed by bus transport down to town as our luggage went on to the train platform. The rail cars were so beautiful. Antique lighting, well maintained wood work and plush seating. The bar/observation car was terrific. Very fun as band had the guests singing and dancing. Unfortunately it was too dark to enjoy much of a view... Service was outstanding. Elegant crew, super friendly. Dinner was really delicious - much better than we expected. Even our 3 sons were raving! All in all - a lovely, first class experience all around.

Nothing will compare!. This was my first train ride and I don't think anything will compare to it. The train itself is beautiful inside and out, can't believe it's about 60 years old! This was the perfect relaxing trip back down to Cuzco after our Inca trail trek. There was a bar car that had live music but we didn't visit because it was full of people, but the noise coming from it sounded like everyone was having a wonderful time. We rode down when it was dusk, therefore was disappointed that we could not see any scenery. Dinner was amazing. Every plate was garnished well and tasted wonderful. The only complaint was how bumpy the ride was, but hey, it's a 60 year old train that rode on tracks, what did I expect? The wait staff amazed me on how well they poured wine with the swaying of the train. Definitely well worth the experience.
luxury travel. Very nice with great service from start to finish. Note if you order extra wine you need to pay cash. Great fun on the way back in the observation car.

A extremly pleasant surprise. We booked the Hiram Bingham for the trip back to Cusco, well it was the last week the train did not go to Cusco due to a mud slide. We had to take a bus to Cusco from the valley. The four of us thought we would have a nice pleasant dinner on the train. The pleasant surprise was the bar car the staff told us to go to. They had a band and there was dancing- and it was just a great time before dinner. We weren't expecting that and it made our night. Dinner was excellent too, service super- food super.Highly recommend this trip!

Amazing day trip on the Hiram Bingham Train to Machu Picchu. The train trip to Machu Picchu & return was wonderful with great food, entertainment. Just being on this train made you feel special by the staff. The train ride was amazing with great views and too many photos to take.Would highly recommend this trip before exploring Machu Picchu. Great experience & memories.

Absolutely worth it ! Outstanding ..:. Still in Peru and wanted to write to write this quick review while the memory was fresh . We took the HB train to Machu Picchu on 6/5 -- the entire experience from start to finish was TOP NOTCH, from the welcome drinks and dancers - and the service was just perfect. The ride through the stunning Sacred Valley in the bar car, meeting new friends, enjoying drinks and music was one of the highlights and memories I will take with me . They take care of you all the way through Machu Picchu as well, we were fortunate and had a private guide MARIO, who was wonderful. Afternoon tea and snacks were well done and a great way to end the day . Highly recommend to anyone.

Worth Every Penny!. This was my second trip to Machu Picchu, the first one taken cattle class. There is absolutely no comparison. Riding this train made all the difference in our experience to Machu Picchu, In fact, as we had such a difficult experience for our first trip, we knew we had to come back. And we decided to do it right this time by taking the Hiram Bingham, which had been recommended to us by friends. This was far more than just a train ride. It was a total experience, from the moment we arrived at the train station until we disembarked that evening. It was an unforgettable day. I would recommend it to anyone!

Worth The $$$. I know it's expensive, but I'm telling you it's one of the best experience we had during our trip to Peru. The sights were amazing throughout the trip. Food was surprisingly outstanding!

Not Just A Luxury Train.. The Hiram Bingham cannot be written about as just a special train.Its an experience that stops you from thinking about the hole in your bank balance the minute you step into the Poroy Train Station to board the H.B. At the entrance there are folk dancers and musicians..a colourful and happy scene and you know you are being readied for more to come.The waiting lounge has sofas.Trays of champagne flutes,fresh juice and canapes are being circulated. The mood is set.Crested carpets cover a ramp that leads into the train.An attendant explains the layout ..two dining cars, a lounge, a bar a viewing platform and toilets. He shows you to your seat. It is elegant, special and fun too with live music. I loved being cared for..taken care of..to me the only blip was the tea at sanctuary lodge which just did not have the style of the H.B.

Great experience. We had a great experience on the train. The staff were very friendly, food was good, and the show in the music car was absolutely fantastic. Only downsides were disorganized boarding (looks like company has acted on earlier reviews about queues and now has a different boarding system, which they fail to explain leading everyone to be very confused), and mediocre service at the hotel meeting place in Machupicchu (staff was not friendly at all, though food was good).

Amazing!. This is such a great way to get to Machu Picchu town from Cusco. It was definitely a highlight of our trip. We took the train up one morning and came back the next afternoon. There is a bar car with a viewing platform at the end of the train, and live music for an hour or so before the meal is served. Make sure you go and watch the band - they are great! And the view from the back car is spectacular. The food is also really really good. Tips: We were a bit worried about what to wear given it's pretty upmarket, but I think you can probably get around in anything. Also, I would be wary about trying to do Machu Picchu the day you come up. If you're anything like me, you might be a bit too tipsy to manage all the stairs! Luckily we had planned to visit Machu Picchu the following day. While it was fantastic, if I did it again I would probably only do the train to Machu Picchu and not back. We were so tired after walking all day that the return trip was really a bit of a waste. Plus it's dark so you don't get the same experience as you do during the day. Overall, absolutely fantastic. Definitely give it a go if it's within your budget!

Travel in style. This was a fantastic trip. It took me back many years to where service and class was paramount. Sitting at a table which was set up beautifully with food and wine to the standard of any restaurant. The staff were wonderful and we received ongoing commentary throughout the trip. If you are going to Machu Picchu by train, upgrade and travel on the Hiram Bingham. It's worth it!!

Highlight of our trip. This is a bit more expensive to get to Machu Picchu but it was worth it. The train is beautifully restored, the food was really good and the scenery was stunning. It's a long trip but the reward at the end is draw-dropping.

Railroad romantic.. Best part of our travel in Peru. Trip is leisurely , scenery enchanting, cocktails and food fantastic! It is is a party train for the so inclined. Service is exceptional. You meet people from all over. Manchu Pichu is the icing on the cake. You appreciate the return train even more

A trip highlight. We visitied at the end of the rainy season and had seen that our trip would be bimodal, by bus and train as part of the track is closed in the rainy season. We arrived at the station in Cusco to live entertainment, music and dancing and some coffee and snacks in a nice waiting room. Groups were split into two busses, an English speaking guide and Spanish speaking. The buses were large Mercedes vans. The guide was very informative and because of the small size were able to talk and ask questions the whole time. We had a stop on the hour plus ride to stretch legs and take pics and then arrived in Urubamba. We were greeted with mimosas and live music and shown to our table. The train was very empty, especially our car which only had 4 couple in it! There was a printed menu, with one option, but you could request changes and ommisions to the menu. The service was prompt, the food was delish and and the wine was nice. We were on the train by 10AM so we enjoyed capuccinos first. The view and music were fun and kept everyone in a happy mood and very social. We went back to the observation car after the service and it was empty except the crew, loved that. Our guide from the train was also our guide for Machu Picchu and gave us advice about our hotel and many other items. We all travelled in a bus up to M.P. together and then split into small groups with the guides. Had to wait a little while for the people checking into the Sanctuary Lodge, but our guide showed us a great place to wait and take some photos. We met back at the Sanctuary for tea (a whole buffet really) and then took a bus together back to Aguas Calientes. We stayed the night there and then took the Vistadome back the next evening. I would do it again in a heartbeat, especially with all the included admission and guide, it was well worth it.

Best Day of Our Peru Trip. No one prepared us for how much fun this trip would be! I was not necessarily looking forward to a 3.5 hour train ride twice in one day - but I did not know! I did not know that this train is a party train in the best way! Our first hint should have been the Peruvian "clowns" and the costumed dancers on the platform, playing music, singing and posing happily for pictures (for free!). Get on board, place your food order and then head directly to the back. The musicians are spirited and talented (we bought their CD), the Piscos are flowing and the vibe is happy and excited. This is not a party in an over-the-top or too loud way. Just joyous. If you want quiet you certainly remain in your dining car. The scenery on the way out is amazing. Take it all in as it will be dark on the way back. After climbing around Machu Picchu in the afternoon, enjoy the lovely dinner, impeccable service and relaxing ride back. The hours fly by.I am not sure how much the ticket was as it was bought through our tour company but one of the guides said over $700 per person, round trip. Worth every penny because there was so much laughter, fun and happiness.

ride of a lifetime. If you can afford to do this - DO! Do it back from Machu Pichu not before. They have live entertainment and then dinner. It is so much fun and you can meet so many interesting travelers. Don't go on the am - waste of both time and monery.

Fabulous trip. This is a terrific way to travel and you end up at Machu Picchu....what more could you want. The train is lovely, the food was very good, the party that was going on in the bar car was a lot of fun, and it was pretty much a wonderful way to view gorgeous scenery. If only light rail in the city were this much fun.

Thank you, Hiram Bingham!. Great train ride...always wanted to do an Orient Express and didn't know that they serviced in Peru! Highly priced, but well worth it...can't buy the experience on a beautifully furnished train along with the entertainment that came along with it....sang and danced with the entertainers along with the other riders...truly fun! Staff was great, food was deelish....unforgettable! We only did one way, going to Aguas Calientes. The cost also provided the bus ride to/from Machu Picchu and a tourguide to the ruins...his name was Renato and he was excellent!! A nice way to start the trip to this magical place called MachuPicchu! HIGHLY recommend at least a one-way ride on the Hiram Bingham Orient Express!

Fantastic Experience on the HB. We recently traveled on the HB train to Machu Picchu traveling from Cusco. I'm not sure why a previous reviewer mentioned a 1.5 hour trip to the train station from Cusco. We took a car from Cusco to the station in Poroy and it was about 25-30min max from start to finish. Maybe that station wasn't available or something. Anyway, don't worry about that, its a short easy drive. Once getting on the train we settled in and began our ~3 hour journey. We hung out in our seats until we placed our orders for food and then went back to hang out in the bar/observation cars. We were in the mood for fun so we had a great time with this. They had a band playing and all the customers were singing along and enjoying drinks and each other's company. If you want to sit in peace and quiet I would recommend staying in your original seats and enjoying the trip from there. The trip itself was comfortable and the views were fantastic. We've not taken trains much for our travels and truly enjoyed this a great deal. The trip back home was great as well. The party in the bar car was a little more upbeat as there was dancing along with the music. It was a great time and we got a chance to meet so many great people from all over the world on this trip. I would highly recommend this trip to anyone who may be considering it. I know I would certainly go again if I had the chance!

A must do en route to Machu Picchu!!!. In my mind this is the best way to get to Machu Picchu (unless you do the 4 day hike on the Inca Trail). The train is superb and the service is as well. You arrive and depart in 1920's style aboard the restored Pullman Cars.

The crown jewel of Peru!. The Belmond Hiram Bingham was a truly awe-inspiring experience! There are a couple of different options when traveling by train to/from Agua Callientes in order to get closer to Machu Picchu. Although all of the options are comfortable the Hiram Bingham is in a league of its own.The lounge at Agua Callientes preps you for all that is to come on your adventure. Once on the train you have access to a luxurious dining car, a bar car, live entertainment and an observation car. No detail has been overlooked from the gourmet meal to the amazing service. Enough good can't be said.....you need to experience it for yourself.
A sensational train journey.. The views from the train are wonderful and during this visual feast you are served great food and drinks. There is a Peruvian band along with dancers.

What a great experience. When travelling from Cusco to Machu Picchu, taking the Hiram Bingham is probably the most luxurious, comfortable and splendid way of getting there. From the moment you board this exceptional train, you are being spoiled by friendly and professional staff. What a great experience. If you can afford it ou should do it at least once in your life ! Highly recommende !

A great way to reach Machu Picchu. We traveled at the end of the rainy season, so we still had to reach Rio Sagrado station via bus from Cusco. Once on the Hiram Bingham, our experience was wonderful. We were lucky to have only 17 passengers on our way to MP and the staff treated us grandly. The views from the train are amazing, they have a fun band playing live music on the way - everyone is having cocktails and a great time!

Not as expected!. For all the hype about the Hiram Bingham we found our overall experience just ok! Considering how expensive this train is, the service was lacking, the staff was not courteous, the meeting staff at the Sanctuary Hotel in Machu Picchu was just terrible and everyone was in a rush during the train ride as the route was shortened due to the rainy season. Our tour company told us to be at the Sanctuary Hotel lobby at 4:00 PM to meet with the Hiram Bingham group. We arrived 10 minutes earlier and were told that the meeting time was at 4:00 PM and to wait outside until then. When we inquire again at that time, they were not ready but now "we could enter the bar area" and wait, just to be received by a waiter and treated as a second class citizen and placed on a corner without offering us a drink. Finally the area was ready for the group (no announcement made) just to find a cold sandwiches and juices (our daughter wanted a coke from the self-service machine and was told that it was not included, only the juices on the buffet table). Then we were told that the buses to the train station were leaving and taken to the Aguas Calientes train station. We were greeted at a special reception area at the station with live music and then assign and taken to our seats at the train. Then the train departed on time and there was when everything went downhill. We knew that the train route was shorted due to the rainy season and that bus services were arranged to our hotel in Cusco. The food was very good and cooked as ordered, the portions were small and the staff was simply rude and in a rush to get all the orders out before arriving at the station. Some tables were offered hot drinks, we were not. We wanted to order drinks for the table and were told in a very condescending manner that the drinks were extra! Please, if I have the money to pay for the train that is 4 times more expensive that the next alternative (VistaDome) and the prices are well printed on the menu, I do not have to be so rudely told that I will have to pay for my drinks. To complete the already disappointing experience, the waiter bought in the check for the drinks and just said "in dollars" referring that the bill had to be paid in US dollars and not in Soles. What is I had no US dollars while on Peru! My advice, take the other trains and avoid the Hiram Bingham during the rainy season, only book the train when the route is complete and perhaps you will have a different experience. We complaint to our tour company about our experience and to our surprise, they already had similar complaints from other visitors!

Almost 3 hours of fun and awesome views!. We rode the Hiram Bingham from Rio Sagrado to the Machupicchu and we enjoyed it so much. They serve lunch on the way to Machupicchu and dinner on their way back, drinks included at the lounge or served at your table. The funniest thing is that they play live music in one of the cars that is totally panoramic, so you enjoy the beautiful views at the same time that you dance with classics played only with a couple of guitars and a box drum. Absolutely great experience! It's definitely worth it!

train experience. I have travelled on April 19th on Hiram Binham train. It was a marvelhous experience.After we did our check in, we wait in a room where we had a snall breakfast,. there was also a typical band singing ,and later on a group of dancers. As in this time of the year we first go in a bus to catch the train not in Cusco but ahead ( one hour of travelling). A guide was with us explaining everything about Macchu Picchu. Finally we entered in the train, which was very well decorated.We had music, a special brunch. Everything in high style. In Macchu Picchu we were conducted for three hours with a guide for more or less 12 people. Finally we had a tea time on the afternoon in the Sacred Lodge. I recommend this trip. It makes the difference.Angela

What a fun experience!. I loved riding the Hiram Bingham (formerly Orient Express) - It made the trip go so much faster.two passenger cabins coupled with two bar cabins and a viewing area at the back of the train. Live music, and a surprisingly good meal. It was nice having a Pisco sour, while enjoying the scenery and listening to a trio performing some Peruvian songs. We took the train from Urubamba (not Cusco) to Aguas Calientes (down from Machu Picchu). Even the waiting area makes you feel as if you were back in the mid 1900's.I know the trip is not cheap but cannot compare the prices to other train rides because I knew that was the train i wanted to experience.

Awesome Trip. My wife rode the train to Cusco and we had an awesome time, the food was great the drinks and entertainment as well. The staff was superb out attended was Hugo and he was always very attentive to us and everyone he dealt with. I plan on going back with my brother and sister in law new year and we are going back. It's worth the money. Food is included in the price

What Fun. Came back from MP on the HIram Bingham (we went up on the Vistadome) What a fun ride. Sure it is expensive but they make the most of your time with cocktails in the lounge, a great band playing everything from classic Gypsy Kings to the latest in Latin pop, followed by a good dinner with wine and dessert. Attentive service from the pick up to the drop off. 4 1/2 stars!

What a Trip. We took the Hiram Bingham between Urubamba and Aguas Calientes as part of a Celebrity Cruise excursion. The train ride just added to the great trip.
