When you arrive at Aguas Calientes they have a Bus and a Guide waiting for youto go to the Machu Picchu site. Tickets to the site are included with you fare.A special credit to the local guide, German who had made the machu picchu tour even better.Once completed the archeological site visit, the Orient Express teamis waiting at the sanctuary lodge for a well deserved rest with a special buffet and refreshments.The bus will then pick us up back from the Sanctuary lodge down to Aguacalientes. So if you sum up the ride on the train to cuzco, a premium lunch, wine and champagne, the bus fares and tickets to machu picchu site, a premium tour guide for the site, another premium buffet, bus rides back to aguacalientes... and all of this in a high quality service end to end...It worth it... probably out of the pocket for youngs and backpackers, but if you can afford it, its a must.

A Moving Luxury Experience!. What a treat to be greeted by champagne and mimosas as well as a local dance troupe. Hiram Bingham makes you forget the 3 hour ride each way with an all inclusive 3 course brunch to and 4 course gourmet dinner from Macchu Picchu as well as flowing pisco sours and wines with a 3 piece band. The friendly and accommodating staff make you feel at home!

Best train in the world. We had a great time. The ambience was very high qulaity. Food was extremely well prepared. Lot of people were dancing and driking in the dining car making it a fun trip for everyone.
Great way to travel. We were in a domed car and had marvelous views of the scenery. The Andes are beautiful and the views of the glaciers were easy to capture in photos from inside the train.

Hiram Bingham Train does not disappoint. We took the Hiram Bingham train from Agua Caliente back to Poroy Station for the Gourmet Dinner service. The thinking here is that we would not feel like hiking up Machu Picchu with a belly full of Brunch so we opted for the dinner train. You do not see much at this time of evening so the focus is on the train and the dinner which was lovely. They offered champagne in the lounge before boarding and another cocktail when we took our seats - there was no lack of beverages and the service was superb. We headed into the Bar car before dinner only to find a dance party with band -what fun. It is an evening an train ride I will never forget. Worth the splurge, Book well in advance for desired dates. We are now looking at other historic train rides with the Orient Express.

Awesome experience. Service was outstanding. They helped us get to our hotel in aguas calientes even though we weren't doing the return trip to Cusco that day. Jesus G even walked us to the hotel rather than just give directions. The food was excellent and all the staff were very professional. This was our first 'great train journey' but left us wanting more of this experience.

Worth it one way. This is a tough one to review because of the eye-popping premium charged for this train but I will try. In short, if your budget is such that you have to give up something else on your trip to do Hiram Bingham, then don't do it. However, if you are ok to spend the money, then I would recommend it at least one way. The ticket includes Machu Picchu entrance, tour guide during train ride and in ruins, round trip bus ride, lunch on the train, some wine and champagne, and all soft drinks. You also get a free tea hour at the Sanctuary Lodge at the ruins after the tour. If you are staying overnight, they also help coordinate with your hotel in Aguas Calientes for luggage hand off if you need it. In general, the service is great and definitely reduces the hassle factor for doing Machu Picchu, especially If you are trying to do it all in one day. The train itself is super cute and gives you that old world train trip charm. There is a bar car connected to an observation car but be warned that they perform live bar music in this area and it's a little over the top unless you're up for that. Personally, I found it annoying and wish they'd either played peaceful background music or nothing. However, the views from your private table in the dining car are just as good. I would recommend requesting a seat on the right side. The right side tables are all four person so if you are solo or a couple you might want to call to make your reservation to make it clear you want this. We were a couple and seated on the left. The view from those seats is fine, even preferable in some parts of the trip, but the train was not packed so we were able to switch to the right side anyways.The tour guide was great and our group was less than 10 inside the ruins. She spent two and a half hours with us and then lead us to the free tea hour at the Machu Picchu Sanctuary Lodge (only hotel at the ruins) which included soft drinks and finger food buffet.All things considered, I would say it was definitely worth the extra $100 (after factoring the value of all the extras) to ride HB over Vistadome. We rode Vistadome back. The plus of Vistadome is that instead of oxygenated AC you get skylights which enhance the view from your seat. However, this train is crowded, has no services except alla cart food and beverage, and there was an annoying cultural/fashion show that lasted 30 minutes and was not optional. You are also pretty much confined to your bus sized seat and shared table. I am not rich and I thought HB was worth it one way and if money was no object I would do it both ways if I had to do it all over again.

Take the vistadome instead. We took this one way from Aquas Calientes to Poroy which leaves at about 17:30. Do note that at this hour it is dark and you will see nothing of scenery - the focus is on their gourmet dinner which needs great improvement. I would imagine that there is more value for your money taking this Poroy to Aquas Calientes where you can enjoy brunch and the scenery.Good: pick up at Machu Picchu in a private bus / tea at the Sanctuary Lodge / cocktails in VIP lounge at the train station / wine on board / open bar on boardAverage: dinner on board uninspiring / slow speedOverall: I would not take it again given its cost of $300+ o/w. It is operated by the Orient Express so we did have high expectations given their reputation for luxury.
a unique and beautiful experience. the seating arrangement is great, we booked for 1st class, meal and service is very good, it is a wonderful moutain/river view between Cusco and MP

Nice experience. We just took this train one way because it's pretty expensive. All in all though it's worth the price. You get a nice dinner in the evening and a lot of entertainment in the bar wagons. Really enjoyed that ride.

YOU KNOW YOU WANT TO........... A truly amazing tour//trip/journey - whatever you call it - if you are this 'neck of the woods' - and have the available resources [$$] - do yourself a favour and take this totally relaxing/extravagant ride as an alternative to the cheaper/coach trip through some of the most amazing scenery you will see in central/south america - the food/service/drinks are top notch - the entertainment is great fun and totally local fare - and don't forget to try a pisco sour on board - it's all part of the fun of this amazing train adventure - i spoilt myself - and will never regret it.

The perfect way to visit Machu Picchu. We had a delightful trip to Aguas Calientes, spending most of our time in the observation car at the rear. The three piece "band" was perfect, as it just fit with the scenery and locale. We enjoyed some excellent food, and the special service was incomparable. It was so nice to get off the train and directly onto the bus to Machu Picchu. Furthermore, our guide from the train continued as our guide in the ruins. She was excellent and very helpful.

Amazing Experience. Traveled a few days ago on the Hiram Bingham, wonderful experience from start to finish.This is in sharp contrast to the earlier visit to the Lodge which even though owned by the same company couldn't be more different. Staff there didn't seem to care and carried out their duties in an automaton fashion bordering on rude.Bathroom beside reception wasn't very clean either, didn't have a very premium feel at all!Also have to say a big thank-you to Maria the Peru Rail Train Manager who couldn't do enough for us even arranging a "taxi:" with one of the band members back to Cusco. A real credit to the company and someone that Orient Express/Peru Rail should cherish!

Wonderful way to travel!. We loved traveling to Machu Picchu on the Orient Express. My husband and I went back and forth about the train or the Inca Trail and we made the right decision for us. It was well worth the steep price tag having everything taken care of for us and all of our meals and drinks included. I would highly recommend it to anyone going to Machu Picchu!Also, it included a tour guide for the ruins and our guide, Veronica, was amazing!

Worth every penny. Fabulous all inclusive & elegant service to Macho Pichoo, that is worth every penny of the relatively expansive trip. But not really, you will be entertained from 8 AM to 9 PM with music, dance, gourmet food (lunch, high tea & dinner+ open bar& soft drinks) luxury train,transfers, entry & guide to the site. Briefly, everything you may need & in luxury. Amazing service aboard and of board by a very curious staff.https://www.perurail.com/en/
Leisurely journey. Loved taking our time and the food was fabulous! There was a great little band playing in the bar car. Try a Pisco Sour.....habit forming!

It's a great treat!. The Hiram Bingham Train to Machu Picchu is everything you could want. Excellent views. Comfortable ride. We didn't enjoy the fashion show on the way back, but the music and costumes were fun.Besides, how else are you going to get to MP unless you're doing the hike?

“Hiram Bingham experience”. We caught the Hiram Bingham as the "splurge" part of our trip to South America. Yes it is expensive but we enjoyed every minute. Right from the pre train drinks at the Poroy Station, through the beautiful meals, first class service and stunning scenery we could not fault it. As part of the deal you get a guided tour of Machu Picchu, lunch at the Sanctuary Lodge as well as the train ride. As we said in a review about the Sanctuary Lodge we would rather have two trips up to Machu Picchu on the Hiram Bingham than stay up at the lodge.
unforgettable. special atmosphere. Not cheap however...but must have done, certainly for those who like trains. It can be crowdy, and sometimes tourists are noisy, but the views are magnificent
Fantastic. Loved every minute of my trip on this stunning train. The food was fantastic as was the entertainment, the views and prompt excellent service. I thoroughly recommend it, worth every penny.

Fantastic!. you get in and forget what date we are! nice service, beautiful views on the way, excellent confort, time flies and the trip is too short ! if you can affort it, it is worth it for sure! one of my best memory in Peru

The only way to travel by train. This was a just reward for hiking the inca trail for four days. We were greeted in the waiting area with Champagne and we had an absolute blast in the bar car with the band!

Train ride experience was terrific. It felt like a movie set was unrolling as the train rolled slowly through sacred valley. obviously the best way to ride to MP and back, the countryside was breathtaking, as it has been throughout Peru but the train ride made the expeience

Nice scenic train ride.. It's a small guage rail train so the ride is not smooth. It is the only way to get access to Macchu Picchu unless you hike or helicopter in. Lots of great scenery en route. Snow capped mountains, roaring rivers, steep cliffs and valleys.

Nice train ride through the Andes. This is the only way to get to Machu Picchu, so one wouldn't really expect that it MUST be a nice experience, but it was. The trains are clean and the seats fairly comfortable even though they do not recline at all. I will say that if you're overweight, you may be uncomfortable with the lack of space between you and the person traveling in the adjoining seat. It is a bench-type seat with no separator. I mention this because I have friends who struggle with weight issues, and I know that they'd have felt uncomfortable in that situation. Anyhow, the train has large windows and windows on the roof as well, so the views are nice as you take the 3 - 4 hour ride. Note, too, that there are forward-facing and backward-facing seats (essentially two people facing two people with a small table in-between) so if you're not fond of riding backward, then try to get a forward-facing seat when booking -- if possible.
Slow train to paradise!. Comfortable, fun, scenic... but slow. Great way to get to Maccu Pichu. Played cards and drank lots of red wine on the way back to Cusco. The conductors are all very nice.
Absolutely wonderful. We took the round trip to Machu Piccu and it was elegant. Wonderful food, drinks, entertainment and the staff couldn't do enough for us. The only way to do this trip by train.

fun travel. Having to make a 3-4 hour train ride with my kids was not the part of our vacation to which I was most looking forward. This train certainly helped! From the tea offered before the ride to the help with the bags to the lovely music played at the end, it was an experience unto itself. And how I loved those big bathrooms!! The food was great and the staff pleasant and competent. I am so glad that we got to travel on this lovely train.

A Must-do Splurge. Good food, a more relaxed atmosphere, and wonderful entertainment make this the best transportation option for your trip to Machu Picchu. We were greeted by traditional dancers and beverages. The seating is First Class. The gracious staff met every need and expectation. After seeing the crowded cars of the other trains, we were very glad to be riding the Hiram Bingham. If you cannot take the train both ways, I suggest taking the train to Machu Picchhu in the day. The observation car provides wonderful views, which you cannot see on the return as it is dark. In addition, when taking the Hiram Bingham to Machu Picchu, you will be able to use one of their wonderful guides. A guide is a necessity at Machu Picchu to understand and better appreciate the space. And they provide a much needed bottle of water for the tour. The band we heard was top-notch. The food was delicious. We enjoyed the lunch better than the dinner on our return trip.The air on the return trip is festive and fun. The band moves from the Observation Car to the Bar Car. Music included sing-alongs and dancing (not an easy thing on a moving train). Too bad they don't sell CDs of the band; I would have purchased one. One way or round trip, you cannot go wrong with the Hiram Bingham Train.

you have to do this - it is so worth it much better than vistadome. i did vistadome one way which is nice - if you can afford it do vistadome up to Machu Pichu and do the Hiram Bingham back
or better still do Hiram Bingham both ways
it was amazing the service second to none, the commentary really good and the amazing last carriage made of glass
wonderful!

Traveled in timeless perfection. The staff and ambience made this amazing. One employee in particular, Fernando was a miracle maker, every outlandish idea we had became a reality. It truly was THE perfect way to travel through the sacred valley. The food, service, and live music made it an experience we will never forget.
A great ride. attentive to every detail. Service was fantastic. Food and drinks were great. entertainment was fun. A great way to get to Machu pichu

Take the Train. We took the train from the Ollantaytambo Station to Aguas Calientes (the town directly below Machu Picchu) and then we took the train back from Aguas Calientes to Cusco. The train is extremely comfortable and many, but not all of the trains run by PeruRail are the "VistaDome" which has very large windows and skylights allowing you to see the countryside.We choose to do the train instead of hiking to cut down on time and well, hiking. Not only is just looking out of the windows fun but they also feed you (for free! a shock for most American travelers) and in the longer train service (back to Cusco and perhaps all the way from Cusco as well) they have a show! On our train was a fashion show (that did have a 'you can purchase' component but it wasn't pushy at all) and a cultural performance.Do not pack heavy! There is very little space on the train for luggage so make sure to pack light. We booked everything through a service (which was very helpful) and so did not experience any of the issues that others noted about online booking.

Hiram Bingham Luxury Train. I was quite skeptical about this train at first and ended pleasantly surprised by it. The service was outstanding and staff truly went out of the way to accommodate our wishes. As the train was too full, we managed to get our table changed with a smile. In Machu Picchu we befriended another traveller, who was also travelling on the Hiram Bingham for the return portion in Cusco the same evening and the most helpful staff managed to sit us all together.The servers truly made our journey wonderful looking after the little details that make a good trip great with an easy smile. I did not get the impression that this was done for the tips, but truly from the heart. Albeit the food was average and there was not much choice in the menu, I have to say that the chocolate dessert was the best I have ever had!

Amazing experience- a must for travelling to M.P. Wonderful journey, great staff. Food was average, but the carriages were lovely. The band are excellent, especially on the return evening trip. A definite must.

Luxury Ride after Inca Trail!. I too, agree that this was overpriced for the service and food offered. Didn't think I should be paying for drinks and even had to pay for a map that they were handing around! However a very peaceful and comfortable 10 hours riding through the countryside of Peru. Would have like more time at La Raya, 10 mins not long enough. http://www.worldwideadventurers.com/south-america/peru/luxury-train-travel-in-peru

EXCELLENT WAY TO GO BUT FOR PRICE JUST RATED AVERAGE. As a few others have noted (see average reviews) service can be NOT what one expects of Orient XP for the crazy price you are paying. Our trains on June 8/9 were both half empty which seems to have been matched with the level of service. No one was falling over themselves to make our journey "special'. Food was really nothing special. Just tiny portions of everything you got. Contrary to other reviewers comments, all drinks are not free - "premium" brands as they put it are charged for. At the outrageous price for this train all drinks should be included. Yes, Agua Caliente is a mess with no directions on how to find the buses up to MP. We were staying at the Sanctuary lodge so were taken care of, but others would have been left wandering. Don't get me wrong, the HB is a great way to get to and from MP. MP is a once in a lifetime trip so we splurged on the HB and a stay at the Orient XP Sanctuary Lodge (about $1000 per night full board). Do it for this reason. Don't do it for value because the price does not reflect value received. NOTE: The toilet we used on the HB had the hot and cold faucets reversed. A trivial thing but NOT what you expect of Orient Express. It goes to attention to detail (or not).NOTE: at Poroy station the Peruvian dancers included a child of no more than 3 years of age. Perhaps this is legal in Peru, but in today's world Orient Express should evaluate whether they should be participating in child labor like this.
Elegant.. A wonderful ride to a wonderful place! The service was excellent. Had a great time singing along with the Peruvian band. Sang some Beatles and some Stones.
great scenery. The train is comfortable, a smooth ride and everyone is excited to be going to Machu Picchu.

Incan Luxury. If you like to splurge, the Hiram Bingham train is for you. Much more expensive than the Vistadome, you get what you pay for. It's a once in a lifetime ride and the best part is the destination. After 3-hours of pampering, you arrive at Machu Picchu.

A fantastic train journey - not to be missed. What a fantastic experience, the journey for Poroy, just outside Cuzco to Aguas Calientes was 3 and a half hours through spectacular countryside. We were served a beautiful 3 course lunch, with drinks and entertained with local Peruvian musicians. The food, service and staff were impeccable. What a great way to travel to Machu Picchu. Worth every dollar.

Historical and breathtaking experience. We traveled with a family of 8 and did round trip and goingbwas great and coming back we went back to the lounge car and had the best time of our life with the band. These guys were so talented they had the whole back of the train going in what was the finest concert I have ever witnessed. We were hoopin and hollering we had all of the other passengers coming back to enjoy the fun. They finally had to tell us our dinner was ready but quite frankly I would of rather stayed and continue listening to these guys play. The more you showed them you were having fun the harder they played. They were great and worth the trip alone. The service and food was great and was quite charming listening to the flackery clack as you made your way to cusco. One major event though showed truly what a great crew was on hand was when my son suddenly became short in breath and felt he was having a heart attack the crew jumped in and started oxygen and got a doctor on the phone to prepare him for arrival at the station where the same doctor and ambulance were awaiting. They were very concerned and all did everything possible for this emergency. I hope they read this and understand how thankful we are that they were so prepared and concerned. My son went to the hospital and was thoroughly checked out by the same doctor and was released with having experienced shortness of breath and a severe panic attack so happy ending. But did I tell you how good that band was? Please go back and enjoy this incredible experience

If you appreciate good services and luxury, you are on your way!. For those who have few time and don't want to worry about lines, tickets, guides, etc... On a full day round trip you will have everything together! Go to the bar for piscosour and ceviche! The live music is wonderfully full of cheers! At the open car you will have the time you wish for the best pictures and scenes. And the guide at Machu Pichu, German , couldn't be more proud of what he does.

Best way to get to Machu Picchu. We took the train from Cusco to Machu Picchu and it was great. The views through the windows were fantastic. The rail line goes through the mountains, next to a river and there is lots to see. The only problem we had was the tour company put my 8 year old in a different carriage than us. The train crew wanted to put him over there, but they found a solution in a professional manner.

Once is enough. We paid the high$$ amount to be on this train as opposed to the basic train which we were on earlier. We had a nice dinner but the ride is a little rough and while I have no regrets doing it not so sure I would do it again.
The service was outstanding.... The food great, all about the train FIRST CLASS, the ratio of passengers to staff was incredible.
very slow and expensive. Good viewing through top windows. Dont know why bother with 4 seats at a table-better leg room and viewing if all faced same way.

Perfect conclusion to Machu Picchu!. Okay...so it is ridiculously expensive - no question...but the exclimation point to an other worldly adventure!The train is luxurious, elegant - a wonderful experience. Warm atmosphere with everyone sharing their Machu Picchu experience. A little band plays while they serve cocktails and appetizers. The food is very nice - service is excellent. Simply a wonderful experience!
Great ride!. Very nice train which included beverages. Beautiful ride to Aquas Calientes.
Wow, what a beautiful ride!. Service was great and the views were better. Traveling below snow capped mountains along a river rapids was a great expeience.

Hideously expensive, but the best way to travel to Machu Picchu. Everything about this train was first class, from the greeting upon arrival to dining cars to the bar car with live music. Nice way to travel!

Time warp of Luxury travel. Liked it all. There were 10 in our group all strangers ( We from CAlifornia, 1 couple from New York, 1 couple from Barcelona and a Peruvian family of 2 adults with the father being a Peruvian journalist who was taking the train and tour in preparation for a TV special with his wife abd their 2 charming totally bilingual children ages about 10 and 12 who delighted us with their insightful questions of our private guide. Our guide also gave us highlites of the sights during the train ride which was complete with a champagne breakfast. Our guide stayed with us and passed us right through the long lines to get into Machu Pichu and was thoroughly knowledgable about the sites. Lovely lunch at the hotel and great dinner on the train returning to Cusco. I was cold not having taken a jacket and was given a beautiful cashmere Orient Express blanket to wear! Something to do at least once.
GREAT!. We are not train travellers but this was certainly a very unique experience. Luxurious with full meal service and drinks. Must do when heading to Machu Piccu

An unforgettable journey. I have nothing to complain about the extraordinary service I received. Everything was extraordinary, with an excellent service, luxurious carriages, unbeatable atmosphere and punctuality
Not just a train ride. You may encounter cows on the track and the host and hostess of each car perform cultural dances and model alpaca clothing you can purchase!
5star. Great way to travel up to Macchu Picchu. Fabulous brunch on the way their and a 5 star dinner on the way back. All drinks are included. Great service, great food and great wine!

Good Service. I echo the positive comments made by prior reviewers about the train ride itself. My only issue was with the arrival in Aguas Calientes. When you step off the train, you are in a maze of vendor stalls with no indication of where you should go. We were completely lost and wandering in search of the bus to Macchu Picchu. After about 10 minutes of frantic searching in the rain we spotted a man carrying a Higram Bingham umbrella. He was apparently a staffer sent to round up lost passengers, of which there were many. Orient Express needs to improve this transfer preocess. Either guides for each small group of passengers or even a line painted on the pathway from the train to the bus with clear instructions would be useful in helping passengers find their way through the maze. After such a lovely experience on the train, being thrust into the total confusion of Aguas Calients was disappointing

Absolutely Perfect Anniversary Train Trip. We traveled on the Hiram Bingham on the morning of our anniversary, May 30th, and were welcomed with a "gleaming" table setting just as advertised. Gorky, our waiter, provided outstanding service always with a smile. Our food and beverages were also great ~ I do not think you can miss with anything you might choose to order, both in flavor and presentation.We were equally impressed with Elisia who seemed to be everywhere ensuring all guests were enjoying the journey. She is professional, full of personality and is an asset to the Hiram Bingham train! We also returned the following night on the dinner train. The mix of travelers just seemed to mesh in the bar car prior to dinner and we all had such a wonderful time with the small band providing a super variety of music we all enjoyed. Some passengers got up and danced as the tables were pulled against the wall. We met several couples and have exchanged photos from the two journeys with one happy couple from our home state.Dinner on the return was again perfect, as well as the Pisco Sour drinks. We can not say enough about the Hiram Bingham and the spirited staff we encountered as both confirm it is "About the journey"! Our two journeys to celebrate our anniversary will not be forgotten!

Absolutely Amazing. First time I went to Machupicchu in the mid 90's there was only one way to get there, in the local train where you had to sit for 4 hours in an extremely hard/rigid wooden seat & with chickens and guineas pigs ... since then lots had changed and now there are many alternatives at different prices but the one that really stands out is the Hiring Bingham Train that gets you to the ruins "in Style"The voyage is just Fantastic, the service, the food, the staff and entertainment on board is just something that you don't see quite often and a 5 star rating is not enough to describe how good it is. The attention to detail since the moment you show up to the moment you leave the train it's so personalize that you feel like royalty.The way back to Cuzco was so fun that you don't want it to be over, the band that plays live music was so good that they had the entire train dancing! while drinking tasty Pisco SoursWhen you do the math of everything you get for the ticket you pay then you realize that is 100% worth the rate!... the ride, the food, drinks, on board live entertainment, the bus to get up to Machupicchu, the guide tour for the ruins, lunch at the MP Sanctuary Lodge... etc I truly recommend this trip!

magical journey. i was lucky enough to travel to machu pichu and back the next evening on this wonderfully luxurious train........the staff were astonishingly charming and helpful....how do they remember the passengers names so quickly ?lunch on the first journey was perfect.........all delicious and not too much ...........the return jopurney in the evening was just like a private party with wonderful live music.....we were all encouraged to join in the singing and we did....especially after a couple of expertly prepared pisco sours !dinner was another superb meal ........accompanied by my favorite wine .............i wanted to stay on the train forever !

Going back in time. If you get the oppurtunity to go to Machu Picchu, tak ethe train from Cuzco to Agguas Calientes, it well work it. The landscape and scenery is breath taking. When you leave the train station you descend to the plateau of Anta lush fields and little villages at the foothills of the mjaestic Andes mountains. You see alot of what is left of the terraces from the Incas. The plains change to a deep valley gorge with a rushing river. You pass through the ruins of the Inca Fortress. Yoou than enter the amazon type microclimate with wonderful view of beautiful flowers. Than you arrive in Aguas Calientes. it's about 2km from Machu Picchu. We spent a nite there, It was wonderful to explore the town. A must on anyones bucket list.

From the Hendersons of London. We just loved it! Comfortable train - ok it sways a bit, but not our problem and the waiters seem used to it. The food was perfect (no big helping, and meat cooked to perfection). Live music and singing was great fun. We would suggest staying at Machu Picchu for one night instead of doing the round trip in one day as we did. Highly recommended.

Excellent punctuality and great service !!. We took the Peru Rail from Hydroelectric station to Aquas Calientas and from Aquas Calientas to Ollyantaytambo.It was a great experience. When we reached the Hydroelectric station we found out, there is no platform as such, which was kindof amusing and new to us. There is only one train a day from Hydroelectric to Aquas Calientas at 6:30 PM. To our surprise, it leaves exactly on time. some passengers reached the station 5 minutes earlier to departure and they were not allowed to board as there was not enough time and it is not safe to board a moving train. Very very impressive. The trian ride was smooth with average scenary views. The conductor was showing us few outstanding mountains and some Ruins throughout the trip. It was a great ride.The train from Aquas Calientas to Ollyantaytambo was also on time. They servered some snacks and Drinks during the ride. It was packed but the crew did a great job of managing the services.It is impressive how these trains are run on time. It was very clean and well kept as well. All the staff was smiling and helpful. Good Job Peru Rail !!

Make the splurge one way - to MP. We took the Hiram Bingham only one way because the train does not operate on Sunday so we had to take the Vistadome back. HB was worth the splurge, especially on the way to Agua Calientes, because everyone was in a celebratory mood anticipating seeing Machu Picchu. It is a vintage train operated on a narrow gauge track train so expect lots of rocking back and forth at a slow speed. You also hear "click click...click" the entire time, too, because there are gaps in old style rails. I think it just added to the overall vintage ambiance.We enjoyed a first class experience from the time we arrived at the Poroy station to when we finished our tour of Machu Picchu. I'm glad we did the full Orient Express experience with the Hiram Bingham train coupled with a night at the Sanctuary Lodge because it was top class all the way. It started with champagne and mimosas while standing in line to check-in with the HB. Our bags were immediately handled and we didn't see them again until we reached the Sanctuary Lodge lobby. Service on the train was top class with drinks, lunch, music and a narrated tour included. Everyone on-board who was staying at the Sanctuary Lodge was assigned to the best tour guide we had during our South America vacation, Veronica. She escorted us from the train right to bus in Agua Calientes up to MP where we checked into the Sanctuary Lodge. Then Veronica gave us entrance passes into MP and an excellent walking tour for 3 hours. At the end of the tour, it was about 4:15pm and we had the option of either staying at MP to watch the sunset or follow her back to the Sanctuary Lodge for tea which was included in the HB price. We opted for the sunset and basically had the place to ourselves. It was a terrific time to capture photos of the citadel without hordes of peoples.

A must do.... It retrospect I have to say that this was a pretty incredible ride to Machu Picchu although I found it hard to enjoy it fully since the train moves very slowly (maybe 20 mph) and there is a constant side-to-side swaying motion throughout the entire 3 hour ride. (This was not the smooth, high speed ride I had anticipated). In fact, you may want to consider bringing along motion sickness pills even if you typically don't get sick. I'm an avid fisherman and spend lots of time on the ocean and I'm not typically prone to such problems but, after riding for that long in a seat that faced the rear of the train I was feeling a bit "ugh" by the time we arrived. Several members of our group actually did get sick by the end of the ride but I suspect the addition of alcohol consumption to train's motion may be what caused their problems.The train itself presents an incredible taste of luxury. Beautifully polished wood and brass fixtures, comfortable seating, good food and a very attentive staff made for an unforgettable experience.

Worth every penny. What a great experience ! Incredible, attentive & curteous service (our Train Manager Lisa & our buttler Henry were the best !), even if the ride is a bit tedious, the glamour of this train will make it unforgettable.The only pain points would be the food (they are trying hard but lack of creativity & quality of execution, they need a real chef...) and the advertised "high tea" at the Sonesta Machu Pichu lodge is an insutl to the package: you are in a lame buffet-style cafetaria room that overlooks nothing but the buses loading area ! talk about a broken link in the experience !!!And to top it off, our car got invaded on the return a group of drunk Australian & British retirees who certainly focus on the open bar concept (sic).I just think the train operation should find a way to manage seating so that premium passengers don't have to cohabit with these loudmouth, classless groups who paid a much cheaper fare as part of a tour package...Overall,I would say the premium for the full return is worth it in theory vs the Vistadome, make sure you book in the dry season skip the fake "high tea" lodge moment and try to avoid the group crowd in your car to preserve the glamour !
Fun, but long, ride. Snack, drinks, and history all around....the bathroom was clean, the staff was kind, but the ride was 3.5 hours long!

LUXURY ON RAILS. Everything was very well organised from boarding the train, service, entertainment to disembarking. The staff could not have been more friendlier or efficient, they treated us like royalty. The food is as you would expect from the Orient Express, excellent. We enjoyed the band on our return journey. When my sister had altitude sickness the staff dealt with the upmost discretion and dignity. No one else on the carriage was aware she had a problem.

A real luxury but a great experience. A beautifully appointed train that makes the trip to Machu Picchu a real pleasure. Incredible service; wonderful people; great food on board the train. And, of course, unlimited Pisco sours!

Exceeded expectations...food, ambience and service. If you can afford it...take the HB back from Machu Picchu...it is leisurely ride and the 5 course meal is wonderful. The service is superior. It is very pricey...have to consider the experience and the food!
Incredible!!!. Don't think about it, book it! A truly magnificent experience.

Took the train from Aguas Caliente to Ollyntambo. Took the train from Aguas Caliente to Ollyntambo and it was a fun, albeit unique experience. The train was very clean. The staff served us small 'snacks' which were actually quite elaborate h'or doueveres. Further, the staff put on a fashion show down the aisle. Kept things interesting and the views are not bad too!

First class food & travel. The Hiram Bingham train is an excellent way to travel to Machu Picchu and a provides a really fun experience in Peru. We were wined and dined practically the entire trip both ways with musicians providing great entertainment during the trip. The food was excellent as was the service and the scenery along the route was impressive as we traveled along the Urubamba river. A highly recommended experience if you are going to Machu Picchu and won't be trekking along the Inca trail.
What a train ride!. this was a world class ride, the train is beautiful, and the meal was spectacular. The views going and returning home were amazing.
Very Wonderful. Met a lot of nice people on the train. It was a wonderful train ride through the country. I got wonderful pictures.
An Adveture. These restored"Bud" cars are a treat. Service was excellant.

One of the best ways to travel. We enjoyed this train to Machu Picchu and back, enjoying the comfort and luxury of this train. Great brunch on the way to Machu Picchu in the morning, punctuated with explanations from a tour guide about the history of the place. Great dinner on the way back, multiple courses, all local specialties, very tasty. Be sure to visit the panoramic car at the tail end of the train to get the best views and photo ops.

Great Train...overpriced..!!. This is great scenic train to take before / after going to Mauchu Picchu. However, the ticket prices are rather overpriced for tourist. Now...what you need to do is get a local to buy you a "locals only" car seat for about $2.

Fun on the "Orient Express". Our train ride from Machu Picchu to Cusco City was one we will never forget. The entertainment was great, so was the food. The staff went all out to make the trip so memorable. Kudos to the person in charge of food services for making my partners birthday a special night to remember. She arranged the musicians to sing "Happy Birthdday" as well a providing birthday cake with a candle. She also gave him a Hiram Bingham hat.Thank you for adding to the good memories of our trip.

Train ride to Machu Picchu. The train ride was smooth and seats were comfortable. Huge windows gave an opportunity to see the wonderful countryside. A good meal was served both on the way to and from Machu Picchu. On the home back from Machu Picchu the staff who served lunch also did a fashion show of beautiful alpaca wraps and coats. It was fun.
Scenic comfortable train with a fun, tacky fashion show thrown in!. The ride along the river was beautiful. On the way back, the RR staff put on a campy fashion show. Good free entertainment.
vista dome. The 1.5 hr ride goes by sooooo fast. The train is very comfortable and the views are fabu.
What a ride!. I loved riding through the mountains- we could even see part of the Inca Trail. Prices for mementos were very high, but food and drinks were reasonable.

an excellent start and finish to a wonderful Machu Picchu visit. The ambience was fun and service tip top but quality of food was poor and choice very limited, however,the entertainment on board was fun. Do not choose the single seats- limited views
Such a decadent experience!. Gives you a little taste of how magnificent a journey on the Orient Express would be!

Beats walking, especially if time's limited. It is a very scenic way to travel to Machu Picchu (Agua Calientes) township. Train is good quality with meals and spacious seats. Not cheap but it's quicker than walking the Inca trail!
Train to Machu Picchu. Skylights enable you to appreciate the beautiful views. Comfortable travel, snack food service nicely served. Fashion show on board was entertaining.

Peru minibus/train combo!. Once on the train from Ollantaytambo to Machu Picchu, it is a wonderful ride: the scenery is fantastic and the train, which is spotlessly clean, in fact gleaming, trundles at an appropriately leisurely pace. I took the Expedition service going and the Vistadome returning. I do not recommend paying more for the Visatadome as the coaches are really the same with the glass-cornered ceilings. The hard sell of expensive clothing in the V'dome by the charming and friendly crew turned into a full-on Fiesta with dancing and music-- enjoyable for many but noisy and bothersome for me during my post-MPicchu reveries.What really, really annoyed me was paying for a service which I didn't receive: the very uncomfortable minibus rides to and from Cusco and Ollantaytambo which actually take up a longer portion of the journey. I knew this beforehand, but experiencing it was disappointing. P Rail should not be charging the full rates for this service when having to take these buses.Also, why are tourists forced to pay these very high rates? Once in Machu Picchu town (also known as Aguas Calientes) I went to the P Rail station further down the tracks (for locals!) and saw that prices are only s/10 (neuvo soles). Would I have been prevented from buying one of these tickets?Again, the train ride is great, although I don't like to be forced into an expensive tourist bubble. Go when the full service (currently scheduled from end of April) is operational.

Pleasant enough ride with free snacks. The train as of April 2012 is only running from Ollantaytambo to Machu Picchu (1.5 hrs) so they provide a bus service from Cusco to Ollan (1.5 hrs). They have a nice office in the Plaza de Armas Cusco where you can book tix and print tix. The train was comfy enough, although the seating if you do it online is ridiculous. My husband and I were in opposite facing window seats across the aisle from each other! Maybe if you book in the office you can pick your seats, but the cheaper fares go quick. You get a complimentary soda/tea/coffee and snack (chips or nuts). The train goes pretty slow and has big windows to take in views of the Urubamba river and mountain scenery.
Excellent service, good food. But not cheap. Boarding is an experience, the drinks are good and the staff is very professional. But this all comes at a price.

I'll do more train rides after this one. A great experience, and a beautiful train. First class service and food, just like the old days of the Orient Express (or so it seems from the movies). A slow trundle along the Sacred Valley to Aguas Caliente at the base of Machu Picchu, with a very nice open viewing carriage at the back of the train. excellent food, and very well organised service including luggage handling. Seeing Machu Picchu would be worth any amount of inconvenience, but going on this train only enhances the experience. Well worth the cost. We stayed over at Machu Picchu, so didn't do the day return, but this looked like a pretty good option, although a long day. Decent espresso.
Like the Orient Express. We took the Andean Explorer from Cusco to Puno. What a ride. Expensive - $220.00 per person but it was worth it. Great food & great service from train staff.

If you have to take one train trip in your life......... ....then this MUST be the one!! You arrive at the station at 8.00am to be greeted with a glass of champagne - and from that moment it does not empty! The service was magnificent. Atmosphere - awesome, especially with the band playing. The food was just fantastic, considering its all made in the train kitchen. And then there is the scenery - 4 hours from Cusco to Machu Picchu of the most unbelievable sights. For shear luxury, this is the way to get there

PeruRail is a Disgrace: highway robbery, ineptitude, and monopoly.. I have traveled all over Europe and Southeast Asia, with weeks spent in India, Mexico, and Nicaragua. I am travel hardened. But really, PeruRail, which I fear represents Peruvian elite attitudes to foreigners, has achieved a new low.I have spent hours over days trying to book a ticket from Machu Picchu to Cusco, after finally managing to book a oneway ticket from Ollanta to MP. In case anyone can benefit from my efforts, I learned that I needed to use only Internet Explorer and that oneway tickets were much easier to book than roundtrip tickets. I already had a Verified by Visa account, so that was not a problem. Anyway, a couple of days after I booked Ollanta->MP, I tried to book an MP->Cusco ticket, but my card kept being denied. The same card that worked before. My bank told me that it did not receive any request for payment (which the PeruRail website told me). Verified by Visa (not exactly the best-run company) finally confirmed that VbV was not down. So, it's PeruRail. If you have a complaint, you can write in, assuming you can read Spanish, of course. No one will reply, though. These guys don't even publish their Skype number (assuming they have one) so you can call for free. And who might want to call in? Foreigners who now need to book in advance--the ones who would really benefit from a low- or no-cost way of getting through because of the terrible web site.PeruRail is established and elite-run, and it has rapidly and obscenely increased its prices over the past few years to gouge foreigners. Since PeruRail has a monopoly for the Cusco<->MP route and colludes with "competition" on the Ollanta<->MP route, and because the Peruvian government is in cahoots to make sure that no alternative mode of transportation for Ollanta<->MP will be created, one gets awful service at highway robbery prices. The alternative is to skip MP entirely.By the way, I am completely unsympathetic to Peru apologists who want to minimize this scandalous state of affairs. I am not expecting perfect service from those who are poor and are to be paid peanuts; rather, I am expecting satisfactory service from rich Peruvian elites who gouge foreigners. And you can bet that these elites care less than many foreigners do about poor Peruvians.

A luxury train through a fabulous setting. The Highram Bigham is expensive, but they go all out to make it pleasant and luxurious: entertainment from the time you get to the waiting room to board until you disembark. On board, that meant a guitar player and singer in the bar car, which made it very festive. Food was excellent and sophisticated. But the main thing is the terrain you pass through (very slowly--it's a 3 hour experience, when the Vistadome does it in half the time), which is the deepening valleys leading to Macchu Pichu.
Really enjoyed this. The train ca get a little hot but the ride through the countryside and along the river was amazing. Refreshments available on the train and the ticket price of $50 was fair.

Experience old-world luxury on your way to a new-world wonder. Machu Picchu is an iconic wonder of the new world. It is on every world traveler I know list of must-see sites. And while there are a number of ways to get to these remote ruins, few equal a train ride on the Hiram Bingham from the Sacred Valley to Machu Picchu. The train runs every morning up to Machu Picchu and returns back that evening. This allows you to visit Machu Picchu in one day. My husband and I stayed at the Sanctuary Lodge for extra nights in order to give ourselves more time to hike around the site but you can cover a lot of it in the one day trip. Named after the academic and explorer from the United States who rediscovered Machu Picchu in the early 20th century, the Hiram Bingham train embodies the style, sophistication and luxury one would expect from an Orient Express train. The train itself is immaculate. Details of polished wood, "period" fixtures and fine fabrics make the interior beautiful and comfortable. The train carries up to 84 passengers and has two dining cars, an observation bar car and a kitchen car. The four hour ride from the embarcation point in the Sacred Valley along the Rio Sagrado is full of amazing views and delicious food. On the way up we were served a 4 course brunch and were treated to live music. After we arrived at the train station at the base of the mountain, we were assigned guides and taken by bus to the entrance to the national park. Since we were staying at the Sanctuary Lodge (an Orient Express hotel located at the entrance to Machu Picchu), we were given time to check in before our tour began. The guide was very knowledgeable and friendly. We did not know that this guided tour of the site was included in the cost fo the train but it was great to be able get a sense of the park before we explored on our own. After the tour, afternoon tea was provided at the Sanctuary Lodge. After tea, those who were not staying up at the site overnight were taken back down to the train station. My husband and I spent the next two days exploring Machu Picchu. (Note: While we absolutely loved the site and were really blown away by its beauty, a single extra day would have been enough extra time.) After two days, we reunited with the train group and took the evening train back to the Sacred Valley. The ride back was also very nice and we were served a delicious dinner as we rode down the valley. My husband and I had a remarkable time and words can't express the beauty of the site but we would do a few things differently if we were to do it again. First we were staying at the Hotel Monasterio in Cusco the nights before and after our trip to Machu Picchu. During the rainy season the train can't leave from Cusco and so there was an hour long van ride the morning we left and late the night we returned. Hotel Monasterio is a must-see in Peru but for the nights before and after the Hiram Bingham trip we would stay at the Hotel Rio Sagrado, an other Orient Express hotel in the Sacred Valley, where the train leaves from in the rainy season. This small change could have made our travel days a little easier. Secondly, as I mentioned before, we felt that two days at the Sanctuary Lodge was too much extra time at the site. We could have spent one day and been very satisfied with our time in the park. We would have loved to spend those extra days in Cusco staying at the Hotel Monasterio and exploring the many sites in the city. What is undeniable is that all of Orient Express' properties in this region of Peru are extraordinary, unique, AND well integrated. Even though we might change some small details about the trip, we wouldn't miss the experience of the Hiram Bingham or any other Orient Express proporties and neither should you!
Loved the local treats. What a nice surprise to receive samples of local treats during he ride to Machu Picchu: fried lima beans and coca mate.
Fun train ride. Great scenery and fun just to be on a train. I liked the ride and people working on the train were very helpful. The train was a joy to look at. I felt like a kid in the candy store.

Take the Hiram Bingham. My husband & I had the opportunity to take the Hiram Bingham From Cusco to Agua Calientes, on the way to Machu Picchu. This is the only way to go! The food, service, entertainment, & the initial tour of Machu Picchu were without compare.

Great Luxurious trip. Relax and enjoy the view¡¡ I took a lot of photos from the rear cabin. You have enough time to eat, drink and sing along a great group of musicians that play songs from all over the continent. Excellent on board service.

Treat yourself to some luxury.. This is definitely the way to go....no traffic, no bumpy bus rides, you can move around from car to car to see different views, the seats are comfortable and the food is very, very good. Climbing around Manchu Picchu will take a lot of energy, so be ready and rested when you get there. The train arrives around noon, when a lot of visitors are coming off the mountain, so the crush of visitors will be less in the afternoon than in the morning. Then, after you tramped up and down the ruins, at the end of the day, relax on your way back to your starting point (several options...we got on and off at Urubamba). Well worth the investment. The train pokes along at a very moderate pace, so its easy to take lots of photos.
Awesome!. This was the trip of a lifetime! The service was stellar and the scenery incredible! The gourmet meal was over the top!

Book it! Pay the money! This train is the way to get to Machu Pichu.. We took the Hiram Bingham from Cusco to Aguas Calientes, a small city near Machu Pichu. Actually, our tour operator was concerned about train track washouts, so we joined the train about one hour out of Cusco (a bus drove us from Cusco to a remote train station). Easy and scenic morning trip out to Aguas Calientes. Then Machu Pichu. The trip back at night was special with a five course gourmet meal and lots of fine wine. We urged the chef to come out of the kitchen car and take a bow. He loved the attention. Overall, I strongly recommend this experience!
Nice train!!. Beautiful train!! the service is good and on the last wagon there is a bar with live music!!
Like the Orient Express in EU. fantastic experience, the open bar in the last wagon, was superb , the view douring the ride was unique and we had funn!!!
lush luxury. expensive but beautiful! book well in advance and get the front two seats -- huge windows!
Clean, comfortable with great views. The scenery to Machu Pichu is just amazing and the train is a perfect way to relax
So nice!!!. So far.. the best experience to get to Aguas Caliente.
Luxurious, Relaxing and Entertaining. Travel in the luxury of fine service, fine dining and live entertainment, all in the Orient Express tradition.
surprisingly luxurious. amazing views through the glass ceiling - and loved the refreshments if a little over the top for a short train ride

The perfect train ride from Machu Picchu. We took the vista train to MP and the Hiram back. It was just amazing. The whole experience - the food, the drinks, the entertainment in the club car, the royal treatment: worth every penny!!!

A journey to be treasured forever!. In November I visited Lima for work and decided to travel to Cusco for the weekend and visit Macchu Picchu. I was advised by a Peruvian friend , that it was absolutely worthwhile to travel to Aguas Calientes on the Hiram Bingham. At first I was a bit hesistant because of the price, but after reading many of the reviews and talking to someone from Peru Rail, who explained to me the services, the fact that it was an Orient Express train , I decided to treat myself to this trip, and boy was it worth it!The cars are beautifully decorated. You are welcomed at the station with Mimosas( a cocktail made with champagne and orange juice ) and an Andean traditional music show. The trip takes you through beautiful sites , you are able to see the start of the Inca Trail. You are pampered with great service, delicious food , with traditional peruvian ingredients and through the journey you have live music ... I love traveling and this trip is perhaps one of my top 3 traveling experiences ever. Highly , highly recommend it!

The Only Way to Travel to Machu Picchu. I had dreamed of taking this train for many years and I was not disappointed. The service, food and entertainment was outstanding and I also love that they give you an overnight bag to keep down the weight on the train. The views were spectacular. I would take it again even though the train service is excellent in this part of the country.

Nice view, nice food. I ended at Hiran Binghan by accident (I´ve bought Vistadome special service, but Peru Rail cancelled it without notice and upgraded me), and it was the best accident that happened to me. Big tables, a special vagon just to look outside, music, drink. It was like a 5 star hotel or like a first class of a plane. My only sadness is that I probably won´t be able to afford it again :(

SO wonderful. This is such a first class service. The relaxed check-in with coffee & rolls served to us was a nice touch. Beverages available upon boarding the train (champagne). First class service, linen tableclothes, & helpful staff made the ride to Aguas Calients very nice & entertaining. The price includes a private bus to take us to the entrance of the Santuary, entrance fees, & a private guide. This is the way to go! Expensive but extremely worth it!

Totally worth it!. This is definitely the way to travel if you can afford the ticket. The food was delicious, the drinks cold, and the service attentive. They have a set menu both ways but have a full kitchen and will make whatever you ask if you have any dietary restrictions or just don't feel like what they have on the menu. The musicians are extremely talented and will play you anything you ask - and the ride back down turns into a party like some of the other reviewers mentioned.IMPORTANT - during the rainy season, part of the track is closed down and the train actually starts from Rio Sagrado - another Orient-Express property in the Sacred Valley - about 80-90 minutes away from Cuzco. The rest of the trip is completed by bus - not nearly as nice but a comfortable ride. On the way up we were actually already staying at a hotel in the Sacred Valley and since we weren't going from Cuzco we got a 25% discount, which I assume we would have gotten if we had stopped there on the way back as well. I don't know if you can specity this on the website so I would email the Hiram Bingham reservations person directly regarding the discount. Frankly I would have enjoyed coming back to the Sacred Valley vs Cuzco - the hotels there are very nice, the scenery beautiful, and it's not quite as high Cuzco for those sensitive to altitude. The taxi transfer is less than 25% of the cost the train so it will save you money as well.

Overpriced for what you get. Luxurious and you get a meal but the vistadome train is as comfortable and the views, which are the most important thing, are obviously the same. Having travelled on both the HB is horrendously overpriced for what you get in my opinion
Great but expensive. Great way to get to Macchu Picchu. But expensive...

Expensive ticket vs Service. It is an expensive ticket and views vs. standard train are similiar. It has a luxury style with great meals and drinks. However standard vagon has good service too and have nice views.

One of the best train rides in the world. Last March I spent a week in Cuzco/Sacred Valley and booked a package through Orient Express (which included Hiram Bingham and Monasterio hotel). It was fantastic! I was afraid of the heavy rains, typical from November to March in the area. But during our ride there was no single drop of water. Due to weather conditions the train left Ollantaytambo station instead of Pisac. However, Orient Express provided breakfast boxes and comfortable shuttle to its passengers. The service is amazing, so is the food.. DELICIOUS..I remember until now the pumpkin soup I had.The landscape is fantastic and we had the chance to listen to a tour guide who showed us lost cities still not fully excavated and even some different things conventional guides do not show. If you can splurge, do it. It is a fast (but beautiful) Orient Express trains experience.
good. I think too expensive for what we paid but it was very nice all

Must Do in MP. This is a must-do activity for your MP experience! At the Poroy train station, HB provided Champaign and local Peruvian entertainment. We enjoyed the live music, drinks, brunch, and the views on the train going to MP.In case you are wondering about the seat chart, let me try to describe it: Seats 1 & 6 are across from each other on one side (2 seats), with seats 2,3,4,5 are on the opposite side (4 seats). Seat 7 &12 are across from each other on one side (behind seats 6), and seats 8, 9, 10, 11 are on the opposite side of those. And so forth….The Ticket includes entertainment, drinks, brunch or dinner, and one day ticket to MP with guide. Transportation to/from MP train station to MP entrance is included as well. (Just give you an idea…ticket to MP is S. 126 per person, approx. US$54 – cash in Sole only, no US dollars and no credit cards, and round trip bus ticket to MP from the Aquas Calientas train station is US$15.5 cash.)We went to MP with the HB tour guide. Carmelia was an excellent MP guide. She was extremely knowledgeable. We stayed at MP for one night, went back up to MP next day on our own, and joined HB train to return to Cusco.On the return trip, we had an hour of blast with live music entertainment in the caboose, followed by an excellent fine dining experience. The train arrived Poroy station as we took the final bite of the chocolate dessert. Three hour flew by really quickly.I highly recommend everyone to take Hiram Bingham train to go to MP!

a glorious return to another era. My family of six took the Hiram Bingham up to Machu Picchu. It's costly, but really fun in an extravagant sort of way. You are greeted with mimosas, feted with good food and wine on the way up, there's live music in the swanky bar car and the seats are big and soft. We especially enjoyed the open car at the back of the train where one could really see the extraordinary views unfettered by windows.I felt as though I'd slipped back into a glamorous film from the 1940's--the only down side was the guide who spoke at greater length than I wished to hear. (He was intruding on my fantasies of Cary Grant....)

4 hour ride to MP not painful at all!. This Orient Express train is high class from start to finish. When arriving at the Poroy station, you are greeted with mimosas and dancers. The dining is special as the service and food is all amazing, not to mention the view on the way "down" to Machu Picchu! What an experience of a lifetime. Put this on the bucket list!
Travel to Machu Picchu. This train is a great way to get to the ruins - comfortable and very efficient!

Train from Cusco to Machu Picchu area. The train ride was great! Nice and slow and leisurely so you could enjoy the amazing scenery along the way. Excellent train attendants! Really enjoyed the entertainment and fashion show on the return trip.

The only way to go .... Much more expensive than the expeditioner trains that run frantically between Cuzco and Machu Picchu, the Hiram Bingham is essential in the Machu Picchu experience. Cordon bleu meals using local ingredients, a three-piece band in the bar car, and an open caboose to give you a chance to take special photos of the Sacred Valley (and they are special photos). We ate well and took in the scenery on the trip down to Machu Picchu, and ate well and partied on the way back. As unforgettable as it is unmissable.
Amazing Luxury Train Ride. It does not come chepa, but once on this train you do get an amazing service, great food all surrounded by one of the most beautiful train voyages on the planet!!!

Excellent end to Machu Picchu visit. After 2 days of the amazing experience that is Machu Picchu, it was wonderful to high tea at the Sanctuary Inn and then begin the Hiram Bingham experience. The red carpet and Peruvian band greeting us signaled that we were in for a special experience. The food and service all lived up to expectations for a high end transit experience. They did an excellent job of timing the meal in such a way that we had just finished up dessert when it was time to pull into the Cusco area.
Luxury indeed. I was booked on this train by the agent and learnt later that this was part of the Orient Express. It's definitely luxury travel and the price reflects it: US$600 for a round trip.
Amazing!!!. We loved the experience. The service is great, the views, everything......love it!!!!

The only way to travel. There is only one way to visit Maccchu Picchu and that is with the Hirman Bingham Orient Express Train from Cusco. The two combined make for unbelievable day, book the directly through the Hiram Bingham who will include the entrance fee, lunch, dinner and drinks. Forget staying over night at the Hermitage at Machu Picchu as, unless you are an archaeologist, a few hours with a guide is sufficient to take in all that is on offer. That apart there is nothing else to do there and you will have to wait 6pm the next evening to catch the same train back to Cusco.You are met at the Cusco station with a glass of champagne before you board to experience this first class service with five star waiters dressed to suit, wonderful seating, a carriage bar, an observation car with an open back end that could have come out of a John Wayne movie, but that is only the start The service, cuisine and drinks are of the the finest order and there is live music at the bar on the journey whilst a guide keeps you informed as you pass through various areas. On the way there band played mostly South. American music, but on the way home they decided to party. Chairs were pushed aside for dancing and the guide joined in on the tambourine. It was a riot with everything from Bill Halley to the Beatles with fantastic guitar playing and the drummer sitting on a box drum and the Picso Sours flowed until it was time for dinner. The train literally rocked home. Only Orient Express could make this such a life long memorable occasion.

Well Done Peru Rail. The 4 hr journey was brilliant from a scenery point of view, we were not advised of the buffet and had already had breakfast at 5am but the return was also enlivened by the train staff doing a well organised "impromptu " fashion show. An audio guide could be useful to explain what you were seeing as you travelled but luckily we had a guide who was very good re info and photo opportunities.

Talking about a train with luxury. This is by far the most luxurious train I've ever taken. The staff was very friendly and before loading the train the offered mimosa's and champagne. A Cuzco dance troop perofrmed before we embarked and they were amazing, really got you energized. Once we were on the train they served an exceptional and rather large brunch (3 course meal) and they had an band in the back car which had a panoramic view + bar. The ride was very scenic and you have to take a bus once you get to Machu Picchu. On the return, the band was still going and they served a 5 course meal with extra appetizers. Boy was I full but it was a delightful ride and I highly recommend it to others.

The best way to travel to Machu Picchu. This is a very nice train. It is very clean and the staff is very polite and helpful. The train is slow, but it enables you to enjoy the road from Cuzco to Machu Picchu.

What a way to travel!. Do not hesitate! It's worth everything it costs! The first class service and the food are absolutely great and you get to relax in the nicely decorated dining car. On the way back we also had fun in the bar before being served a gourmet Thanksgiving dinner.

LNice ride, expensive and the dome train goes the same route.. This was fun and a splurge. White tableclothes, a good lunch, etc. On our return trip we took the dome train-less money, food fine and more fun.

Loved it!. The Hiram Bingham is an incredible experience. From the moment you board the train, you are treated as royalty. The food and the service is excellent. The train has a panoramic car in the back with a trio of talented musicians well versed in music from Latin American and the Caribbean. I would definitely recommend anyone visiting Machu Picchu who wants a unique experiencie to use their services. I went up to Machu Picchu in the Hiram Bingham and returned on the Vistadome because the Hiram Bingham returns late in the evening. The Vistadome is also very good, but quite a different experience from the Hiram Bingham.
A highlight of the trip!. I loved the train ride to Agua Cliente. It was comfortable, the views were awesome, and the traveling companions were fun.

Most memorable and enjoyable train journey to Machu Picchu. Superb food, great live entertainment , very friendly and helpful hostesses made the whole train journey a wonderful experience. I highly recommend to anyone wanting to visit the magnificent Machu Picchu site to take the Hiram Bingham special train.Very well organised, with welcome drinks and costumed dancers to start your 4 hour journey up to the mountain.

Don't be a cheapskate, get to Machu Picchu the RIGHT way!. Family trip to MP could not have been better. This is THE train ride to go on. From the decor to the food to the impeccable service, there is little more you can ask for.From coming off a long flight and puddle jump to CUZ that same morning, the train was a welcome spot to fit right into the old wood booths, get warm on some pisco sours, and have the staff tend to my wants and needs.Spend the dough, do it the right way. The staff here goes above and beyond to make sure you have a first-class experience!

Worth the extra money!. The Hiram Bingham Train is worth the extra money if you're not travelling on a shoestring. It adds to the whole journey and experience and is almost more memorable than Machu Picchu itself!! If you are on a budget, I would recommend travelling from Cusco to Aguas Calientes on the Hiram Bingham and returning on the Vistadome, you don't need to take it both ways.

An unforgettable, charming, beautiful experience!. I remember being torn about whether or not to splurge for the Hiram Bingham train, and now a year later, I couldn't even tell you what the price was! If you can possibly afford it, I definitely think you should. The food and drinks were great, the dancing and music was so fun, the sights were just absolutely lovely, and we will never forget the trip!
Lovely View. Great scenery and comfortable seat after doing the Trek

Amazing Journey. We took the train to Machu Picchu which was amazing. We were in the carriage with the domed glazed roof to make the most of the fantastic views en route. The staff were very attentive - serving breakfast by first setting the table with Peruvian mats then silver service for the cutlery then bringing a wooden box containing the food. They then bring a trolley of expensive guides and other goods that can be purchased such as a Perurail baseball cap (?!) and t-shirts. On the return leg, a member of staff dressed in a harlequin-like outfit and a mask and wig comes and grabs some unsuspecting ladies for a dance to the loud electro music pumping out and then the steward and stewardess turn into models walking up and down the carriage trying to sell alpaca jumpers, scarves etc. Most bizarre! Be careful not to get too distracted from the fantastic glaciers and snow-topped mountains.

A day to remember. From the moment that you arrive at the station the quality of all of your experiences is of the highest calibre. From the sumptious decor to the excellent food/drink the train provides the best of everything.And yet the atmosphere is relaxed as the staff make every effort to meet your needs.

Travel in style. The Hiram Bingham train ride to/from Machu Picchu harks back to the days of yore. The luxurious cars ensure your comfort and you will enjoy being pampered by the wait staff. The ride back in the evening is wonderful! Pre-dinner drinks in the Observation Car/Bar ensure that you're ready to dance to the music of the traveling minstrels!! Go ahead, pamper yourself!! The best thing about the ride is that you get to arrive at Machu Picchu when most of the visitors leave and you get to stay till closing time!!

Worth the ticket and more. Our trip on the Hiram Bingham to and from Machu Picchu was lovely. I had been so looking forward to this and wasn't disappointed. I was so over-excited on getting on - was almost moved to tears! (I know!) We nearly missed the train from Ollantaytambo as our pick up arrived so late - but we got there just in time. The train is pure luxury. The service on board is absolutely first rate. The food is delicious - catering for veggies too with a really lovely meal. Coming back next day from Machu Picchu was just great. Make sure you go to the bar carriage for the live music for the first hour or so before dinner - great fun. The only thing that slightly spoiled it were some very "gobby" young Americans in the next but one booth who insisted on telling the world at large about their very important jobs and boring travel experiences. Why do americans complain about everything, speak so loudly and spoil things for everyone else? Anyway - lots of people were complaining about them and they were asked by another brave couple to turn it down a bit (very politely) but they responded by making very rude comments about them. Shame on them. But they did shut up (result!). Its not cheap to go on this train - but save up - combined with the lifetime ambition to go to Machu Picchu - this was truly amazing. Ill never forget it.

Top Train. The train travels so closely to the river - it's spectacular! Unfortunately a land slide had cut one section and so we were transferred to a bus for the final stretch but it was well organised and OK. Snacks and drinks were available on the train and it was great to just sit and observe as the scenery slipped by.
Great way to travel to Machu Picchu in style. Great service & sense of occasion to/from Machu Picchu

World Class tour dedicated to delivering your Machu Picchu experience. This review was solicited by the gratitude we felt toward the crew of the train who looked after us.You're no doubt reading this to work out if the HIram Bingham is really worth the extra $$ over any other train to Machu Picchu. The answer is "Yes".My wife and I would sit outside the normal demographic for this kind of tour with the majority of passengers being empty nesters. Still though, this didn't make us any less welcome from the time we set foot in the train station to when we returned some 12 hours later. Now, 12 hours is a long time to spend on a tour especially when 8 of those is spent getting to and from the destination. Elise, Henry and Humberto on our carriage made the journey a part of the experience (the landscape helped a little too!). Whether it's enjoying the excellent choice of food and beverage in your own dining booth finished in wood and polished brass fixtures, or standing at the back of the panormic view car taking in the scenery, the service team on the train are a delight and nothing is ever too hard.Our guide at Machu Picchu was Breytzi, and if the other guides are anything like her, rest assured you'll be well looked after. Breytzi took us through the citadel and talked us through the history and findings of this amazing place. She is lively and engaging throughout her presentation. Her tourists are her VIPs and she pays special care to make sure that;1. You get spectacular photos taken (Weather permitting)2. You don't battle your way through hordes of other groups.The 4 course dinner home is fit for any 5 star restaurant, after 3 weeks of touring South America, including the so called home of Beef, Argentina, we had the best piece of beef on a train in the middle of the Andes...Amazing.Entertainment is a trio of talented singers / musicians playing a mix of traditional music and hispanic classics that my wife and I couldn't understand but loved none the less. On our particular trip home the bar car was packed with what I can only guess were Latin americans or spaniards because the entire car was singing and dancing! Great fun. Of course if you prefer to relax, your dining car is far enough for this not to be a disturbance.My wife and I believe that exceptional service isn't hard, you just need to listen and to care. The attention to detail from the crew is exceptional. They look for opportunities to make you feel special, as this was our honeymoon the crew treated us to Champagne (a bottle, not a glass) on our return to Cusco, without being asked. Not once did we feel like we were expected to tip or pay for any additional services such as the dancers, or the musicians (which is rare in this part of the world), and the crew were always there to help you with information, water or something to eat.I hope this review helps you, for us this was a once in a lifetime trip and we were thrilled that the Hiram Bingham and it's crew delivered the experience in spades.

Definitely one of the world's best!. My spouse, six-year old son, and I took the HB from Poroy in Cucso to Machu Picchu in September 2011 and took the return trip two days later. The train is staffed with waiters/waitresses, bar tenders, musicians, tour guides, supervisors, you name it. They will be as attentive as you like. You are free to explore different cars (dining car, bar car, viewing deck). They handle all luggage transport, as well as arrival/destination transfers if requested. First class travel far beyond any backpacking experiences from my twenties!

Fantastic Experience. I was travelling with my 18 yr old son who was keen to visit Machu Picchu. We didn't have much time, so after a bit of research we thought we would try the Hiram Bingham Train as part of a day trip from Cuzco.Although most trains leave very early in the morning, this one left around 9.00 a.m. It was a great three hour trip to the base of Machu Picchu. We started with a pre-boarding glass of orange juice or champagne, while watching traditional dancers and musicians. We were then entertained onboard with excellent peruvian music and provided with a delicious brunch just before our arrival. Brunch is a multi-course meal and not served until the last hour of the trip - so a light breakfast is advisable before boarding the train. Drinks, including tea, coffee, juices, soft drinks, alcoholic drinks and water, are complimentary throughout the trip.The views from the open observation car are spell binding. You pass through farming communities, small villages, and deep valleys. There is a constant stream of mountains and rivers, and you will see many locals tending to their animals, small plots of land, or walking along the roads.Once at Machu Picchu, an all inclusive tour of the famous site is done in small groups.
