One guide to six people. The tour starts with a bus ride up the steep and narrow dirt road to the top of the mountains. You then walk to the high part of the ruins and begin your afternoon tour. The benefit or arriving long after the early morning trains is that the crowds are much smaller. After the tour, there is some free time, and a very extensive afternoon tea, with complimentary drinks, savouries and sweets, for those that need replenishing. Its then back down the mountain to board the train for the trip back to Cuzco.The trip back was in darkness. This did not matter, because we were served a 5 course degustation meal, with drinks included, then treated to a party with music, dancing and fun for everyone who went to the bar and observation cars. You can stay in the quite surounds of the main cabin if you prefer a quieter or more private trip back. We arrived back in Cuzco around 9.30 p.m. after a fantastic day out.The service and staff are excellent, and the cost is very reasonable for what is offered - particularly if you compare the price with other Orient Express trains in Europe and Asia.This trip is suitable for people of all ages, but may not be ideal for younger children who want space to run around and play. Unless you intend to overnight at Machu Picchu, I would highly recommend this option as a way of visiting one of the world's best treasures in style!

An unforgetable experience. The train is extremely confortable and the staff treats you with enourmous care. They even call you by your name! We felt the romantic experience of travelling on an luxury vintage train 'comme il faut'. It a real Orient-Express feeling. On the way to Machu Picchu, in the morning, we were enjoying the view and listening to variable songs (since Peruvian to songs from the countries of the customers) on the back of the train. We were surprised about them serving pasta on the lunch, but when we arrived at Machu Picchu we understood why: we went right away to the monument, walking a lot up and down and we needed that energy. However, the guide walked very fast (it was tuff to follow) and was extremely 'politically correct'. I enjoyed more listening to the explanations of the other local guides about the historic fates and the Spanish invasion. On the way back, at night, we had a first class diner. It worths every cent!!!

A Rare Jewel and a Real Treat. Everything about the Hiram Bingham train from Cuzco to Machu Picchu (and return) is incredible. Due to space limitations, only one carry-on bag is allowed per person. To compensate for this, everyone is provided a black carry-on bag with the Hiram Bingham logo which makes a very nice souvenir.This train leaves from the Poroy station (about a 20-minute cab ride from Cuzco). The train consists of four carriages - a galley, 2 dining cars and 1 club car.Upon boarding the train the staff shows you to your seat. The tables are set with fine linen, crystal and fresh flowers. The pullman cars are beautifully restored with wood paneling and brass fixtures. The club car at the end of the train also has an outdoor observation deck worth enjoying along the journey. Champagne, mimosas, and well drinks are included along with an incredible Brunch to Machu Picchu with dinner on the return trip. A trio of 2 guitar players and 1 drummer keep everyone entertained for the 3.5 hour journey. The Left side of the train is the preferred side for the best views of the Urumbamba Valley.The staff is professional, helpful and polite. The Hiram Bingham train is a very relaxing experience. It is the ultimate decadence worth spoiling that very special person in your life.

old world experience. Okay. You can certain take much less expensive transportation to Machu Picchu But, unless you're walking the Inca Trail, this is the way to enjoy the experience to the fullest. Take the train from the Poroy Railway Station to get the "whole nine yards" - indigenous dancers and a Mimosa to send you on your way. The countryside is beautiful and the brunch (going) and dinner (returning) make for a special eventMy only disappointment? We specifically scheduled our evening trip back to Cusco the night of our 37th wedding anniversary. Unfortunately, there was no acknowledgement of the occasion by any of the staff on the train. As a matter of fact, they first seated us across from a boisterous family of 5 and when we asked to change, we were told there was nothing available....even when I said it was our anniversary. We finally ended up joining an Italian couple we had met the day before.I have friends who took the Hiram Bingham train up and back from Machu Picchu in one day. I would not recommend that. Slow down your pace, stay over at least one night and spend more time enjoying Machu Picchu. How many times in your life do you get to experience something so incredible?

The only way to travel .... All the Peru trains to Machu Pichu look good but for a special treat, splash out on the Hiram Bingham. From the 9am start you're greeted with champagne and local dancing. The inside of the train is beautiful and the viewing platform is a lovely place to spend your time travelling to Machu Pichu. The brunch and dinner served on the journey there and back is as good as any 5* restaurant in London and the drink flows (good pisco sours). The service is second to none and on the return journey the bar was the party carriage with music supplied by the train's band.Included in the price is your guide and afternoon tea at Sanctuary Lodge and the short bus journey from the train up to Machu Pichu. Everything ran smoothly and our guide, Nilo, was excellent.It really is a special treat, splash out, you won't regret it!

Fantastic Journey. I would say if you can afford to splash out and don't want to walk the trail up to Machu Pichu then definitely treat yourself to this ride. It was one of the best things I've done. I've done the Orient Express from Victoria which was very good but this is far far better. We knew right from the welcome at the station at 9am it was going to be special. The food was excellent, the champange, wine, pisco etc, etc was free flowing. The band were playing in the bar all the way there and back. If you wanted it, there was a real party atmosphere. Also the views from the viewing platform at the back of the train were fabulous. Would definitely recommend.

If you're not going to hike the trail, this is the way to go.. I'm not sure why there are so many negative reviews, but I can tell you that my wife and I had an excellent experience. I am extremely picky (see my other reviews), especially at these prices, but I was absolutely satisfied and impressed with the Hiram Bingham experience. The train is in excellent condition and beautifully appointed. The food was solid by any travel standard, and brunch was especially tasty. The booze flowed freely and the live entertainment really got everyone into good spirits on the way home. The staff was attentive and the tour guide was knowledgeable. The views from the train are amazing.

Fancy, but Bland.. Due to the tracks being washed out between Machu Picchu and Cusco, the train went back and forth to the Sacred Valley. From the Sacred Valley to Machu Picchu it was daylight so the trip was interesting. It was dark outside during the return trip.The food was okay and the service was fine.

Nice.....but so was Vista Dome. A group of 4 of us had made Machu Picchu a goal and built our entire 5 week trip (including 10 days in Peru) around this experience. We decided to go the whole hog and get the Hiram Bingham up and back, plus stay at the Lodge.We booked and paid in March for May, always believing we were leaving from Poroy, about 20 mins from Cusco. Not until we arrived in Cusco did we find out that the train left from Olyentambo, about 1.5 hours by bus on bumpy roads. The line from Poroy to Olyentambo having been closed since December! The thing is, we had purposely moved from Olyentambo to Cusco the night before to catch the train.So we still paid full price for half a journey. I know the fine print saysthey can alter the journey, but why not be up front when we booked and tell us it was closed - everyone else knew it wouldn't open until late May - except us.The 1.5 hour bumpy bus trip aside, the train, staff and meal were fine, but $322 per person for 2.5 hours..........A mistake by our travel agent meant we had to return by Vista Dome. About 1/5 the price, quicker and you get better views through the roof.Glad we went, but disappointed for the above reasons. before to catch the train only to have to drive all the way back.Our complaint is - why do they

A truly great experience. While this may cost a bit more than the regular rail service, it's worth it. When you put together the cost of Machu Piccu entrance, a guide and your meals, all of which you will have to pay for extra if you go by regular rail service, the difference isn't all that much. They handled everything from start to finish and never left your side. The food in bothe directions was excellent. It was hard to believe that a train kitchen could produce such high quality food. They fed us and kept the alcoholic drinks coming at all times. If I were coming to Machu Piccu again, this is the only way that I would travel.

Unique experience. Yes it is expensive, but worth every penny. Being in this remote area, and concerned about the quality of touristic facilities here, we decided to be on the safe side and chose the Hotel Monasterio in Cusco ( by Orient Express also) and the Hiram Bingham. Our trip to Peru turned out to be a truly memorable experience. The train transported us back 100 years to the tales of the London-Venice journeys. It was the right amount of luxury for the place. Not too fancy yet enchanting in every way. We wore jeans and hiking boots, appropriate for this destination. We were pampered by highly trained staff and enjoyed blissfully as the ride took us through a breathtaking scenery. Everyone involved was courteous and their attention to every detail was striking. There is brunch on the way out and dinner on the way back. Food was incredible, and the maitre d'hotel was able to accomodate to changes in the menu and the waiters were simply the finest. There are musicians on board and they were also amazing ! They also provided the tour guide for Machu Picchu and he was wonderful. Tea is also included after the Machu Picchu visit at the Sanctuary Lodge and that was also welcomed after experiencing a day of hiking. They took care of our bags to/from the hotel and everything went smoothly. No point in revealing all the details as it is best to discover it yourself.....

Wonderful experience. This was one of the most memorable holiday experiences of my life. Yes, it is a costly train journey, but if you have the funds, it is worth every cent. The service was impeccable, the food was delicious, the atmosphere was perfect, and the destination itself exceeded our expectations. We are both vegetarians, and our requirements were catered for (albeit, we had to remind them at the time of serving, even though this information was confirmed via email, as well as when we boarded). It was fantastic walking around the citadel with a guide all to ourselves, and due to the time of day, it was significantly less crowded than it would’ve been earlier in the morning (which is when most of the tourists arrive). The return journey was delightful. We had struck up conversations with another couple on the outward journey, and were able to continue our chats over our superb 4-course meal (with lovely accompanying wine) on the way home. Nothing about our experience aboard the Hiram Bingham train could be faulted. It was a magical experience.

Inconsistent Service, Rude Gate Agent. My trip from Cusco to Machu Picchu on HB was pleasant, largely due to my experience with my travel mates. The service provided by HB itself was inconsistent and the food on outbound trip mediocre:1. I was not offered champaign while boarding in Cusco but instead was hurried to my seat without any offer to take my luggage.  I had to take the initiaitve to go back out and pick up my own champaign and later hand my luggage to one of employees who happened to by..2. On return trip, I was told by the gate agent (I did not get his name but later told Marie at HB about the gate agent) that it was not time to board when I attempted to check in. He proceeded to check in other customers.  After realizing that departure time was even closer, I went back to gate agent to show my ticket again. He then waived me into train area. I wonder if the four travellers who I witnessed did not make their  earlier train also experience this extremely poor and down right rude  service by the agent.3. Be forewarned travlers that the seat number on your ticket does not  guarantee you that particular seat. I was assigned with families both trips not corresponding with my seat number. I understand constraints  that solo travelers might face. However, to not to have seat assignments respected nonchantly ignored was quite intolerable.In short, I am stil numb from the poor to downright abysmal service I received on the Hiram Bignham Train on Tuesday, 28 December 2010. I plan to escalate this issue with management.

Best way to travel to Machu Pichu. What an amazing ride. The staff were incredible. This was my favorite part of our vacation. We came from the Galapagos Islands and had to see Machu Pichu. We traveled with our 3 year old, and Carolina Saenz, the Tourist Train Manager, treated our son like royalty. He played with the band, danced and sand.The food, the drinks, the band, everything was out of this world. You don't even notice the 4 hour train ride because you're having so much fun. The train was operated by Orient Express and definitely had the feel of the elegant trains from the 30's and 40's. The view of the mountains were amazing. This is definitely the way to go.

Highly Recommend would do it again!. My husband and I recently went on the Hiram Bingham Train for my 50th birthday. What a beautiful, fun time. I would highly recommend taking the train both up & back. The food, service & music/entertainment were the best. On the way to Machu Picchu a delicious brunch is served along with seeing the beautiful counrtyside of Peru. On the way back at night dinner is served with Pisco sours not to be missed. Besides seeing the amazing Machu Picchu the train was one of the highglights of the trip. if you cannot go for the round trip go at least one way.

If you are considering the Hiram Bingham train; my advice: "DON'T". My wife and I took the HB to Machu Picchu from Olianta and the returned on the next day after staying at the Lodge to Cusco.... at 11 PM in mid December. My succinct advice is to select any of the other trains and train companies now available. 1. The cost is $255 per person per trip / regardless if you board on Poroy or Olianta. A marketing ploy which annoys me and, perhaps more important, would dissuade one from visiting Olianta and its environs which has some of the best attractions in Peru.2. The later outgoing time is nice but the return trip of over four hours was mostly, in December, in the dark with an arrival time at your hotel in Cusco after 11PM. Ugh! My suggestion is to take an earlier train, enjoy the customary tour, stay overnight at the Lodge, and return on an afternoon train that gets you in Cusco at some reasonable time and allows you to see some of the countryside.3. All the O/E ads and their palaver are quite overdone. Yes, the service is elegant and personal, however I found it no more exceptional than the delightful service I received from EVERYONE in Peru .... from baggage handlers, to bartenders, to waiters, to receptionists, drivers, guides and, even from, the room maids.4. On both trips, a rowdy group of vacationers were permitted to yell and whoop with the combo which was playing Spanish songs more appropriate in a Cantina than en route to the Sacred Sanctuary. When I suggested that some Peruvian music might be more suitable to set the mood and to allow conversation with companions and possible introductions to new friends, nothing ...NOTHING ... was done! Going, we skipped dessert so that we could go the the vacant club car and enjoy the ambience of the train that we had expected. Nice! On the return, another group commandeered the club car with similar loud music and yelling for one and one-half hours until everyone was called to dinner.5. Our friends had opted to stay on at the Arwana and came to MP on the following day on a vista dome coach ,.... totally enjoying their train trip and given a unique DVD about the Inca Trail as a souvenir! I wish I had joined them at considerably less expense and more pleasure but we were taken in by our images of Agatha Christie and the Original Oriental Express. Alas!So again, it is strange that O/E who operates both the HB and the Lodge can have suchdifferent reactions from vacationers. I would stay at the Lodge again with hesitation but would seek out another train to Machu Picchu. I do not believe that after spending over $1000 for a 40 km train ride, my pleasure and enjoyment should depend upon whether I was lucky enough to have reasonable fellow passenger or be subject the noise pollution that made both trips virtually unbearable unless I wanted to sneak away to some corner of the train for respite.

Excellent experience. Worth every cent. Food is good, and there is a local focus to it. Staff is amazing - friendly and great service. Very comfortable. Particular compliments to Carolina Saenz, who was the hostess for my trip. She made a real effort to ensure the passengers enjoyed the trip, and got to know each other. As my hotel pick up did not arrive, she took me into Cusco. Also, our guide was knowledgeable and interesting. If the train is within your price range, do not even consider other options. You will not regret!

Experience of a life time!. I can say that this is one of the things that you can never forget. Before coming to the station we didn't know what to expect. The first view of the train and the local show gets your imagination on fire. The 4 hours trip to Machu Picchu passes in a blink of an eye. The train travels at low speeds so you ca really enjoy the landscape. Service on board is amazing. Everything is high class. All this is the best possible intro you can get before setting your eyes on Machu Picchu. Last but not least, everyone knew english. I especially want to thank Elisa for making us feel special! Thank you once again. I really hope that I'll have a chance to come back again.Lots of greetings from Croatia!

fun, but too pricy and we didn't enjoy the food. I had read that the Hiram Bingham train was expensive, but well worth the price due to the live music, excellent food and great guides. We did enjoy the live music and the bar car, with great views of the surrounding countryside. The guides were knowledgeable, expecially our Machu Picchu guide, Jaime. Unfortunately, we didn't enjoy the food on the train very much. It's that fancy French-style food that seems over-processed to our tastes - 2 tiny slices of steak, a small triangle of omelette with bits of asparagus, and some little bitty crepes. We are not picky eaters, but we prefer simple, whole, local foods. Hey, we're in the Andes, so why not serve dishes made with potatoes, corn, quinoa, chiles, etc? I think the Hiram Bingham train would be worth the expense if the food was better. However, as it was, I'd have to say we were disappointed. I recommend taking the mid-priced train to Machu Picchu, instead of the Hiram Bingham.

Worth it 100%. I had such a wonderful time on the Hiram Bingham train to Machu Picchu. I was glad I decided to go with this train option as the service was unparalleled. I can't say enough about the food. I used the bread to clean my plate in order not to miss even the tiniest morsel or drop of sauce. I hope I can visit Machu Picchu again one day, and I would definitely get there using the Hiram Bingham train.

Totally worth it. As part of our trip to Cuzco, my wife and I decided to splurged and treat ourselves to the Hiram Bingham as part of our excursion to Machu Picchu. We booked a return trip on the same day opting not to stay the night in Machu Picchu or the viscinity.The tickets includes the entry and guide to Machu Picchu, bus transfer from Aguas caliente to the Machu Picchu site, all inclusive beverages on the train (incl peruvian alcoholic beverages and they do have espresso machine for those interested), Brunch on the train to Machu Picchu, Diner on the train back from Machu Picchu, light meal and tea/coffee at the sanctuary lodge at the Machu Picchu site.Our journey started our great as we were greated at the train station with choices of Mimosa, Sparkling Wine or Juice and a traditional dance show. That was a great way to kick things off.On the train there were two wagon for us to go from, the Diner car and the Bar/Observation car. The first part of the 4 hours trip was spent in the bar/observation car where musicians provided ample entertainment and drinks flowed freely. The later part of the trip was spent having brunch in the diner car. The brunch consisted of 4 courses which were all great.Once we arrived to Aguas caliente we were ushered to buses that took us up the road to machu picchu. We were assigned a guide and given tickets. Keep in mind you only get about 2h on the machu picchu site with this visit so make sure the guide will show you what you want. Since there were older people in our group and the ride can be quite steep, our guide only did the lower areas. We opted to abandon our guide and go the way up.We met our group back for the afternoon tea which includes a very nice buffet in the sanctuary lodge restaurant. It was good to eat as we were hungry from our machu picchu visit.On the train back, the same pattern apply where we spent about 2 hours before dinner in the bar car with the musician and then the later 2 hours having dinner. Overall we were extremely pleased with our experience in the Hiram Bingham train. It's probably not something you do more than once but it was well worth it to us. My wife was at first skeptical but she was completely charmed by the experience and will be recommending it to her friend/family.

My first train ride, and it lived up to my expectations!. I had never taken a real train ride until I had the opportunity to take this train to Machu Picchu with my family in August. My father-in-law painted a picture of a first-class experience complete with fine dining, entertainment, top notch service, etc. Needless to say, we were not disappointed. Now I am looking forward to my next train ride wherever that may be, and hopefully the experience is as good as this one was.

Best choice for me. After reading all the reviews, I chose to go with the Hiram Bingham train. It cost much more than the Vista Dome but it was worth every penny. I went 8/28/2010. I do not regret my decision. I loved it. Great lovely people working there. Thanks to Luis, Jessica, everybody was wonderful. Top notch service. Great food. It already takes a whole day to go to Machu Picchu, going in this train adds tons to the experience. It was so much fun. There is a show on board. The musicians are great. They sing all kind of songs. I am amazed at what they could play with the cajon and the flute. Jessica was our guide on board. It was great to have somebody telling us what we were seeing. Beautiful train. Email me if you have questions about it.

Pricey but worth the experience. Unfortunately, the full service wasn't running when I was there due to the heavy rains they had at the beginning of the year, so they had a reduced "special service." Wanchaq Station could've been a little smoother. There are two types of transport depending on what service you've paid for. The special service location wasn't clear, and the guard missed it on my ticket. Thankfully, I asked him in Spanish or else I would've missed some nice things. Food was excellent. Service was very good. The train was extremely comfortable. Felt somewhat pampered. It was really nice to have someone available to guide you through the train station, the lines, etc. The food at the Sanctuary Lodge (part of your ticket price) was quite good and was actually the best ceviche I've had so far in Peru. On the train ride we received lots of drinks and plenty of food. Probably too much food. :)My only negative, other than the price, is that the guide's English was pretty poor. I had to ask her things in Spanish and then explain the answer to the rest of the group, who only spoke English, many times.

Sensational. When my wife told me what it cost for tickets on this train, all that I could say was, "You paid what?" The day proved to be one of the best days of my life, and in retrospect, one of the best investments we've made in a global travel experience. Absolutely exceptional in every detail.

A classy way to visit Machu Picchu. The Hiram Bingham train was actually not our first choice for our trek to Machu Picchu. We originally tried to book one of the less expensive trains, only to find out they were all booked for the date we had planned to go. So we sucked it up and booked the Hiram Bingham. We were not disappointed.The train was small--it consisted of two dining cars, a bar car, and a kitchen car. Prior to departure we were treated to traditional dances/music at the train station, along with champagne. The trip to Machu Picchu was very leisurely, and the observation platform at the end of the bar car was the perfect place to watch the changing landscape. We enjoyed brunch, followed by entertainment (two musicians) for the duration of the trip. The musicians were great, and enouraged audience participation on instruments such as the hooves and animal jaw. (The entire trip was open bar, so as you might imagine there were some folks who really let loose.) Once we arrived at Aguas Calientes, we were taken by bus to Machu Picchu. The ride to Machu PIcchu--up an incredibly steep, windy, and narrow road--was an adventure in and of itself. Our English-speaking guide was simply terrific. Incredibly knowledgable, he took us through the ruins at a good pace, and gave us plenty of time to snap photos. After the tour, my boyfriend and I opted to explore the ruins on our own rather than attend the tea at the Sanctuary Lodge. We probably had an hour to explore before we got back on the bus for the trip down the mountain and back to the train.On the train ride back we were served a delicious 4 course dinner and treated to more musical entertainment--a bit more subdued than on the train ride out, though.Was it worth it to pay such an exhorbitant amount of money for this day trip? Absolutely. It's really a once in a lifetime experience--and we found it was worth every penny.

There is no other way. If you want a relaxing luxurious journey through the Sacred Valley to Machu Picchu there is no other way to go. the views are stunning and the food and staff excellent. Not to be missed if you can afford it!

Take the train... if you can't walk. If we had the time we would have hiked the inca trail to MP. As it was, the train experience was an easier. We were traveling during rainy season so the vistas were shortened due to low clouds and mist. The experience at MP was great only wish we had had more time. Need a week to explore the region and all the trail systems. MP has reached its carrying capacity and I'd recommend restricting tourist traffic even more than is currently being done. Fragile environment. Amazing energy place. The train trip back was a wild ride with the free flowing Picso sours and raucous sing along action in the back bar car. Once the magic maraca started to be passed everyone with enough Pisco juice in their blood had the chance to get up and dance their hearts out solo. Great atmosphere. Again, can't say enough about the staff. A special thanks for Elisa for her hospitality. Keep up the good work all.Wisconsin wanderer

If you can afford it, totally worth the money.. A great way to travel - excellent staff, fantastic food. The train arrives later in the day as well, around the time that the other trains are leaving so the site is much less crowded than earlier in the day. In addition, the guide was phenomenal - incredibly knowledgeable and very engaging, full of detailed information about the area. Added a whole other dimension to the experience.

Out of this world travel to out of this world place.. From arrival at Poroy station the whole trip was wonderful. Champagne reception, brunch and the bar and observation car set the tone for the day.A real feel for luxury taking you through the spectacular valley to the station at Machu Picchu and then on by coach to the sanctuary. Guides throughout are so enthusiastic and knowledgeable, giving you insight into the history and meaning of the area.After a 'British' tea at the lodge it is a return to the friendly staff on board to guide you back with food, wine and song to Cusco.A place I always wanted to visit was made into an exceptional journey by the experience of this Orient Express train.

Excellent day trip to MP with Hiram Bingham. We took the plunge and booked the Hiram Bingham round-trip, figuring that this was a once in a lifetime experience. We had a wonderful time, made all the better by the ever helpful Jesus (waiter) and Carlos (tour guide). The part that was most helpful was the arrival time into Machu Picchu and the fact that when you arrive, the majority of people have left and the place feels empty! That in itself was justification for the cost of this trip, for us at least. On average they say that about 3,000 people visit the site per day and by the time the HB arrives only a few hundred are left. That may seem like a large number but with the space of the site, it really felt like we were a privileged few.There are a couple of things that I would like to point out, not complaints, more like 'quibbles'. The first point is the lady representative at The Monasterio hotel (see separate review) she did not exactly give you a warm reception and was downright cool. I am certain that the OE train division wishes for their staff to appear professional and approachable at all times - well she was not. It felt like we were imposing upon her when we were clarifying details for the trip in advance.The second point is that I do not eat meat and we had told the staff at The Monasterio (Peru rail division) in advance. The lady (above) said 'do not worry there will be plenty of choice on-board and a choice of fish'. This was good enough for me as I'm easily pleased and knew that a good chef would be able to muster something up. Once we boarded Jesus (waiter) advised me to talk to Warren (Maitre D') about dietary requirements. I did so and he said that he would be able to come up with vegetables for me to replace the meat dishes. I said that would be fine for the morning train ride but for dinner I'd like a fish option. He said he thought that would be fine. Ordinarily I'd be happy with just veggies but the trip isn't cheap (as I'm certain you are aware) and I wanted 'proper' food, but I wasn't antsy about it. Another waiter brought the brunch out and on it was the meat dish, of course it was sent back (disappointing that an error was made from a 5* service provider and so few people on the train). Then after the first course Warren asked me if I had enjoyed the alpaca?! There were less than 20 people on board (and only one non-meat eater on that day) so I know that he was just making a point!! He had a superior air about him on the journey up to MP, but relaxed more on the return journey and played the drums in the bar-cart with the musicians. (For dinner the chef did concoct a great fish dish, so if you don't eat meat don't worry there are options and food is great quality). The Pisco-sours are made in a blender and so lacked the genuine taste that I had savored elsewhere.

The only way to see Machu Picchu. The trip to Machu Picchu on the Hiram Bingham was absolutely amazing, and the highlight of our trip to Peru. Absolutely superb service and the train staff are soo friendly. We loved Carlos, our guide. He was so knowlegable, and took great care of our group. We felt like a family of fortunate guests discovering the ancient ruins together. On the way b ack, we all downed pisco sours and sang and danced our way back through the amazon. amazing.Loved it and worth every penny. i want to go again!!:)

Go up rather than down!. If you are doing this trip one way then be sure you go up. It was just a joy. Not sure if it was because it was a Saturday so no return the following day but there were less than 20 guests which meant the Observation car was nearly empty a lot of the time so we were able to savour the route. The Peruvian countryside was breathtaking and the colourful people going about their lives just fascinating. It was odd to start drinking wine around 11.30 am but we forced ourself and the brunch food was OK. Light with a variety of small courses which went down well. The food on the return was superior but there is no view – certainly in March..

Expensive, but worth doing at least once.. Given the price of the Machu Picchu -> Cuscco evening trip on this train, I probably wouldn't do it more than once -- but I'm really glad that we did experience it.This train is a slow mover, so you don't take it to get from A to B in a hurry - you take it for the oppulent experience and the superb service. I tried to count how many courses we got in our meal, but lost track. From the appetisers and the Pisco Sours, to the final chocoloates an hour and a half or so later, everything was superbly presented, nicely sized portions (not overeating despite the umber of courses), and very high quality food.How many trains have you been on, where you can not only order your steak medium rare, but also have the waiter tell you "Your seafood allergy is absolutely no problem sir - I'll simply ask the chef to prepare that particular course for you without crab. It will be cooked entirely separately" ?Yes, it costs a few bucks - but I encourage you to do it at least once in your life.BTW, for guests staying at the Machu Picchu Sanctuary Lodge - there is a special "Hiram Bingham Bus" that will take you to the train station from the lodge, at something like 4:45pm. You can even do what we did and just leave your luggage at the lodge while you wander around and find your own way into town - the lodge's concierge can arrange for your left-luggage to take the "Hiram Bingham bus" into town without you - the luggage will be waiting in a safe location on the platform right next to the train as you board.

A must trip in Machu Pichu. Unless you are a backpacker or are really familiar with travel reservations (in spanish!!), this is the best way to reach Machu Pichu. The train does not offer only luxury and confort but the whole package that allows you to enjoy nthe visit without any concerns regarding: hire a guide (don´t even considerer to visit the sanctuary without a guide - you will not understand the dimention and history of the place and may be expose to risk o danificate any part of the memorial).They provide you a full service, including meals, transportation, tickets at entrance (about 40 usd), bus to go and return to the sanctuary (another 15 usd) plus guides in english or spanish.I very glad to use the hiram bingham service in my recent visit to Machu Pichu, I was short on time (only day) and without it I probably will not enjoy as much as I did.The train is the only one with a observation deck at the car tender that allows you to take pictures and film during the journey. The vistadome does not provide the same visibility. The trip itself to Machu Pichu is very interesting crusing the "Vale Sagrado" and several canions.Also they arrange package in their hotels (top class and top price). If you need any cheaper hotel, there are plenty of them in aguas calientes. The train could be booked to go in one day and return on a different date.

One of the best days of my life!. I just returned from a round-trip journey on the Hiram Bingham and found it perfect in every way. The ride itself & journey to Machu Picchu was everything I had hoped it would be, and more. I notice some people complain about the cost, but when I compare this trip to other luxury adventures, I feel it was a very good value. Personally, I felt it was worth the splurge for a once-in-a-lifetime trip to such a destination.The train was outfitted with the highest quality decoration and was very comfortable. The dining car included fine linens and meals served on china. Brunch & dinner were extensive, and superbly presented. There was a choice of entree for dinner, and the staff went out of its way to accommodate dietary restrictions, asking each passenger if they had any concerns. I had just one, and they were able to suggest a fine alternative for me.The bar & observation car was a real treat. The later was best on the outbound trip, where the very end was open-air and you could take excellent photos of the changing scenery. The bar car was best on the return; I was surprised more people did not take advantage of this car. Live musicians entertained during the entire journey, and much of the staff joined in as well. After a few drinks, the passengers joined in too :) I cannot say enough about the staff on the train and probably should have mentioned them right up front. In just a few short hours I felt like I had known them from days and was on a first name basis with each of them. They truly went out of their way to be welcoming and treat each guest to a first class experience. On the return trip they even surprised me at desert by singing "Happy Birthday" in English and then Spanish. I should mention that the bilingual staff speaks perfect English, you will not encounter any language barrier whatsoever.Not enough can be said about Machu Picchu itself, the highlight of the trip. Our guide had 10 years of experience and was very knowledgeable. There were only 5 people in our group for the tour, but I believe normally this is larger.When I booked the trip I was concerned about the demographics of the other passengers, thinking I may be out of place on such a journey. I was pleasantly surprised that there was a very wide range of ages, backgrounds, lifestyles and cultures represented by my fellow passengers. I met many friendly fellow travelers.In summary, I strongly recommend the Hiram Bingham if you are interested in the trip of a lifetime. I know no one on my trip had any complaints.

The wonderful way to enjoy a wonder of the world!. I am proud to be a Peruvian, who lives in Miami for 10 years now. As most of my friends, we went to Machu Picchu when we were finishing the high school and never went back. I am too embarrassed to recognize that I did not come back in 17 years. However, ending the difficult 2008, I decided to spend new year’s in Cusco with my mom and my sister. We had only three days, so dedicating a full day to Machu Picchu was our idea. We decided to go on the Hiram Bingham train on December 31st, 2008, and I consider that it was the best idea that we had in the whole year. The train was spectacular!!! What a marvelous way to finish a year!!The crew welcomed us in the station with champagne and mimosas, and a group of folkloric dancers cheered the morning up. Then, when we were on board, the personnel served some pastries and coffees in the bar-car where a coca-leaves-reader was waiting for us. We spent part of the ride in the bar and observation car, not only because the view along the route was splendid, but also because there was entertainment in that car. My mom, my sister and I were delighted by singing and becoming part of the duo who provided the entertainment, playing maracas and/or bongos. The staff of the bar was very attentive filling our glasses up during all the ride. I drank a delicious sparkling wine and my mom drank Pisco sours, all included!!! After an hour or so, a very pleasant attendant showed us that the brunch was served in our places in the dining car. The food, which was prepared with Andean local ingredients, was, even though it was a three-course, light and delicious in order to be lightly enough to go up in Machu Picchu. Smart thinking!!!!In Machu Picchu, we had our guided tour (also included!!!). There were just 8 of us being led by German, who knows lots of history and made our experience at the ruins so meaningful!!! After three and a half hours in Machu Picchu, we went to the Sanctuary Lodge for the tea time. The delicacies which were served with the tea were exquisite!Back on the train, we found a train beautiful decorated with party favors to celebrate new year’s on board. In our table, we had hats, whistles and streamers which were bringing forward what we will have in our way back. Despite the fact that it was dark and we cannot enjoy the view in the way back, the ride was even more spectacular!!! They served us a five-course dinner which was delicious to say the least! And after the luxurious dinner, they celebrated with us the new year’s in the bar-car singing, dancing and cheering all the way back. They also simulated the new year’s eve countdown and I felt that after that splendorous journey, 2009 would be as amazing as our Hiram Bingham ride. I really want to mention every single person in the crew who made our ride a perfection, but I hardly remember the names. I remember Elisa and Eliana. Thank you very much for giving us a royalty treatment!!!!The train is special and elegant and this ride in one day is the wonderful way to get to a wonder of the world. For me the Hiram Bingham experience was as stunning as the ruins. The decoration, ambience, food and specially the service were incredible!!! I highly recommend everybody to go to Machu Picchu on the Hiram Bingham train. Being a Peruvian who live outside of my country, tears of pride is the least that I have when I see the wonders of my country and when I see how those wonders are excelled by the impeccable service of the people of the Hiram Bingham train. I loved every minute of the way. We had a blast!!!!!

Yes it's overpriced. But it was awesome. For me, worth it!. I debated whether it was worth the extra dough. I was doing Machu Picchu in 1 day and returning to Cuzco the same day. I like to travel fast but I also like my sleep, especially at high altitude. Much of the reason I chose HB train was because of the departure time. It leaves at 9a.m. vs. the other trains around 6 or 7. Too early for me. The other advantage of the later departure time is because the other trains get to MP so far ahead of HB, MP isn't as crowded when you tour it. I have pics of the main part with no tourists at all mucking up my pics. Lastly, the ticket price includes a professional guided tour of MP and the entrance fee, which is a bit pricy.  After further research I determined I would take the HB to MP but I took the Backpacker Train back to Cuzco. Why? 1) I had an early flight out of Cuzco the next morning so I wanted to get back ASAP. The backpacker gets to the Poroy station 1 hour earlier than HB. I figured 3 - 4 hours in MP was enough for me and I was correct. Some may wish to spend days wandering MP but I took 125 photos and had a guided tour and the time there was just right. 2) Part of the allure of the train ride is the amazing views of the mountain passes. Most of the return ride home is in the dark. So you are paying for a comfy seat and a nice dinner. I didn't think it was worth it. The Backpacker train was packed and I had little leg room. No food on the train so I grabbed a sandwich at the station before I left. But I was glad to get back 1 hour earlier at a 1/6th of the price.What I liked: The back of the train is like the Vistadome train with windows on the ceiling. I stayed there most of the ride getting awesome pics. Also, the service was top-notch. They remember your name and your likes and dislikes. Amazing for such a remote part of the world. Also, the food was VERY good. Departing from the Poroy station is smart. The other trains have to sidewind up a mountain above Cuzco before they hit the Poroy station. This takes about an hour. It's only a 20 minute taxi ride to Poroy so you can save time by leaving Poroy.What I didn't like: First, the train did rock quite a bit but I don't think it's their fault. It's the rails. Second, they fed us brunch at 11a.m. so you need to get breakfast at your hotel before you leave. Also, while I was eating I was missing the best photo ops of the entire trip. It would seem to me instead of brunch, they should do a breakfast earlier so photog's like me could get the best vistas. ***** THERE WERE ONLY 7 PASSENGERS ON THE ENTIRE TRAIN. This obviously increased the level of service but it seemed to match what others have written. I'm sure Perurail is losing an arm and a leg with this economy. The train was EMPTY. There was probably room for about 80 passengers. Lucky us.

The Best Train Ride Ever!. EXCELLENT! The Hiram Bingham Orient Express Train is one train ride any traveller (who can afford it) should experience in his/her lifetime. It made the trip to Macchu Picchu such a relaxing and enjoyable experience (to say the least). The staff was fantastic and so accommodating. The nice thing about the service is that they made you feel so at home. It still has the amenities of an elegant ride but one was not uncomfortable at all about it. The food was wonderful, served in just the right amounts and timing was perfect. I would recommend this trip very highly. It could be one of the highlights of your trip to Peru!Cristina BernardoTrip taken on or about November 7, 2008

Just go one way. Just retruned from 2 days in macchu pichu. took the hiram bingham train up and was really nice. Stayed one night at the Sanctuary Lodge right on the mountain and then the next day back on the Hiram Bingham. For the price you pay, i would not recommend the return journey so much. It is dark, so there is nothing to seeand all you get for your money is a 4 course dinner. My partner spent $50 US on drinks as not everything is complimentary and when we arrived back at Poroy station there was not a cab to be found and we were lucky some of the staff helped us out as within 5 mins of the train arriving, the place was completely deserted, all guests and even the train were gone. save yourself alot of money and come back down on the Vistadome train, still a good train and spend your extra money on something worth while.

Best way to get to Machu Picchu(if you are not hiking the Inca Trail). Wonderful experience. The service and attention to detail was amazing.Excellent food and drinks and comfortable chairs made trip one of a kind.The scenery and views from the observation car, in addition to the live entertainment and constant flow of Pisco Sour made the time fly by.Worth every penny,particularly if you consider the preferential treatment and access you get when you arrive to Aguas Calientes.

$500 round trip per person! Was it worth it? I dont know!. Well, it was supposed to be a trip of a lifetime, and I certainly wanted the best of the best.......But a day trip train ride for over $1000!!! I booked the Hiram Bingham as part of a package tour so I didnt know the total price until i saw the tickets. WOW! was I surprised. The train itself was very nice and elegant and we were treated first class all the way- as well we should be. The meal and bar service was very nice but not mind blowing in any way at all. The return service was in complete darkness so the scenery was not a factor at all.I think taking the HB train was my biggest regret on this tour of Peru, i would have been much happier with the exponentially cheaper vistadome or even the backpackers train for that matter.

Not quite the ticket. Having travelled on the Orient Express from London to Venice I was quite excited at the prospect of travelling on the Hiram Bingham train through the Sacred Valley in Peru. A transport strike had prevented our outward journey so we could only travel on the return. On arrival at the station everything seemed splendid with a duo playing musical instruments and the conductors all looking splendid in cloaked uniforms as they welcomed the passengers onboard and a happy busy atmosphere as we were escorted to our seats. That's where the similarity with the Orient Express ended. I know luggage space is restricted but most people looked as if they had just walked off the mountain and boarded the train, boots and all! A plentiful suppy of pisco sours were poured before dinner which was a simple 3-course meal offering two choices of main course (meat or fish). The bar was nice with rich wood panelling and a good stock of drinks (excellent gin and tonics) but the observation deck was small and not very inviting or comfortable. The bright lights in all the carriages and motion of the train resulted in very bleary photos (or maybe it was the piscos and gin) so I was disappointed not to have a better collection of photos of the evening. Maybe it was just my camera as most shots look like the arty shots you see of motorways when the headlights appear like strips of lighting. Anyway I have no worthy photos of the evening but a very happy memory of a lively, fun-filled night aided by extremely courteous and efficent staff

The train ride was worth the trip. I went on a trip to Cuzco Peru with two friends got to Lima and went to Cuzco for 8 days. For the first three days there we explored the city of Cuzco and its surrounding ruins. We had a great time and learned so much from this great culture. On the third day we woke up early to go to Poroi where the train was leaving at 9am. The employees treated us like royalty, we had some champagne and mimosas and after a few typical dances got on the train. This train is how trains should be everywhere, very spacious with a great bar that would serve us pisco sour as soon as the glass was empty. We went to the back of the train where there was some live music and enjoyed an indescribable view, almost magical with mountains and beautiful vegetation. I want to thank especially Eliana Taipe, and Carolina Saenz who made this trip extra especial with their great personalities and attention to detail.I strongly recommend this train to go to Machu picchu and if you encounter this ladies tell them that el primo says thank you for everything.

Wonderfully luxurious way to travel to and from Machu Picchu. We hiked the Inca trail to Machu Picchu then splurged on one way Hiram Bingham tickets back to Poroy station (15mins outside Cusco). We departed via private bus from the Sanctuary Lodge at 4:45. The train was set to leave Aguas Calientes at 5:45. Once in AC, we could shop in the market for a bit or go directly to the train. The train is elegant inside and out. The staff was very well trained and professional. We noticed they did not pay much attention to the seat numbers on our tickets. We checked in and were escorted to our 2 person booth. The ride takes approximately 3 ½ hours. It gets dark around 6:15pm in the winter months so we were only able to see the views from the observation car for about 30 mins before it was dark. There are 2 dining cars and in August you can expect both to be full. It takes the entire 3 ½ hours to finish your meal and the staff have this down to a science. You will be finishing your dessert and coffee as you arrive in Poroy. Everything from the décor, food, drinks and service were excellent. The staff even presented us with a gift when we arrived in Poroy simply based on a question I had asked before we left AC. I was blown away. Customer satisfaction is obviously their top priority. The only thing that could make this an unpleasant trip would be those seated around you. We were stuck between two loud, obnoxious parties. Thankfully, everything else was wonderful.

A Wonderful Ride. Machu Picchu is a destination adventurous travelers dream about so it's only fitting that, if cost is no object, you arrive in style. The Hiram Bingham is an Orient Express train that runs from Poroy, just outside of Cusco, to Aguas Calientes, the town closet to the ruins of Machu Picchu, and back. The trip takes approximately 3 1/2 hours in each direction. Booking is handled through Peru Rail and can be a bit of a challenge. But once on board, the staff is marvelous (thanks Ellie), the food is great and the views are to die for, though the return trip, at least in winter, is mostly in the dark. If trekking the Inca Trail is not your bag and you require a little more pampering, then consider the Hiram Bingham.

See Machu Picchu in Style aboard an Orient Express Train. I travel quite a bit for pleasure and I like to mix with the locals for added color. On a recent trip to Cusco, Peru, however, I missed my bargain train to Machu Picchu and was forced to take the more expensive and luxurious Hiram Bingham Train by Orient Express with 5-Star service. What a happy accident. I was a little unsure of the experience when we began, but loved every minute of the way. The train cars are beautifully restored and classy. The service is second to none from the champagne/mimosas upon embarking to the gourmet meals on-board. The train manager Elisa and her great staff made sure that every passenger's need was attended to. The awe-inspiring scenery was enhanced by the songs of the duo who played classical guitars. The bar car featured a meticulously restored wood and brass bar with an outdoor fresh-air platform at the rear.Once we arrived at Aguas Calientes, we were broken into smaller groups and taken up to Machu Picchu. Each group had an excellent guide who spoke English. The guides made the stones of Machu Picchu come alive with the lore of the past. The return trip to Cusco was magical as the sun set over the majestic cliffs and farmland of Peru.I would recommend this trip to anyone who has a limited time to see Machu Picchu. This fit perfectly into my itinerary as I was able to see everything in one day and in high style and comfort. My only reservation was that i arrived too late to Machu Picchu to climb Juana Picchu, the tall jagged peak that overlooks Macchu Picchu.Overall, The Hiram Bingham Orient Express Train to Machu Picchu was wonderful and I would highly recommend the experience to all travelers.

Trip of a Life Time. We were a group of 12 travelling on the Hiram Bingham to Machu Picchu and were treated like royalty. From the night before, when they delivered overnight bags to our hotel in Cusco, to the very end, it was an amazing experience. When we arrived at the train station, our bags were stowed, we were given a glass of champagne or juice, and treated to local dancers. Once on the train we were seated together in one of the two dining cars and a very pleasant attendant showed us the bar and observation car. The views along the route were spectacular. There was entertainment in the observation car which we became part of, playing maracas, tamborine, jaw of an [-] and a cow bell. Lunch with wine was excellent and the service was impeccable. The bus ride to Machu Picchu was stunning and MP itself cannot be described, it must be seen. We stayed overnight at the Inkaterra Lodge which is a destination in itself. The rooms and grounds are incredible. Dinner there was a bit disappointing but the service was good. Most of us spent the next day on the hotel grounds doing the various tours available - spectacled bear, orchids, etc. The return trip was wonderful, mostly spent in the dining car reliving the experience and eating another wonderful meal. All drinks were included in this trip back. One of the many wonderful services we received on the train was luggage handling. After the bags were stowed on the train, we never touched them except to pack and unpack. They were delivered to and from the hotel for us. If you want to be treated like a king, or queen, don't miss this trip.

Nice but Aguas Calientes arrival needs work.. I echo the positive comments made by prior reviewers about the train ride itself. My only issue was with the arrival in Aguas Calientes. When you step off the train, you are in a maze of vendor stalls with no indication of where you should go. We were completely lost and wandering in search of the bus to Macchu Picchu. After about 10 minutes of frantic searching in the rain we spotted a man carrying a Higram Bingham umbrella. He was apparently a staffer sent to round up lost passengers, of which there were many. Orient Express needs to improve this transfer preocess. Either guides for each small group of passengers or even a line painted on the pathway from the train to the bus with clear instructions would be useful in helping passengers find their way through the maze. After such a lovely experience on the train, being thrust into the total confusion of Aguas Calients was disappointing.

Overpriced. Having paid so much for the trip, I expect good food, good services and nice decor. I was not disappointed. However, as compared with the Andean Explorer ( first class) which we took later to Puno, we did not find the latter in any way inferior to the Hiram Bingham. In fact, it is even better in some ways, as the toilets are larger and cleaner. dkym

3.5 Hours of Bliss!. We booked our trip on the Hiram Bingham through the Guest Services agent at our hotel (Monasterio) two weeks before our arrival. This was much more convenient than dealing with the bizarre system used by Perurail. This three and a half hour ride was almost as much a highlight of our trip as was Machu Picchu itself!We arrived at the Poroy station after a 20 minute car ride from the hotel. Upon arrival, we were greeted by a colourful display of traditional dancers and musicians. Elegant Orient Express employees in capes were serving champagne, orange juice and mimosas. Our "Hiram Bingham" embroidered overnight bags (we were staying at the Sanctuary Lodge that night) were taken from us and we were checked in and informed of our seating assignment for brunch.The train is every bit as special and elegant as we had hoped it would be. Not having travelled on an Orient Express train before, it fulfilled all of our expectations with respect to decor, ambience, food and service. Even the washrooms were luxurious: wood, marble and fresh flowers!We enjoyed more mimosas with some croissants in the bar car as we chugged out of the station. Those were followed by cappuccino with tiny sugar cookies to hold us over until brunch. As we coasted through some of the most beautiful scenery we've ever experienced, the passengers mingled and enjoyed the live music being played in the observation car.Brunch was three courses, and each was terrific. The presentation was lovely as well. We enjoyed our easy conversation with a charming couple from the UK.In no time we arrived at Aguas Calientes, where we disembarked and were transported by bus up to Machu Picchu. An added perk was our guided tour - there were just 8 of us being led by the very charismatic Nino. He made our experience at the ruins so much more meaningful than if we had just wandered around on our own with our guidebook.Unfortunately we had booked a Perurail "Ferrostal" train to take us from Aguas Calientes to Ollayantaytambo the next day, as we wanted to have as much time in Cusco as possible for our last night. That train was a NIGHTMARE! We were seated in the first two seats of our car, so our knees were touching the wall in front of us and we couldn't even put our feet flat on the floor. It was a torturous 1.5 hour trip, complete with... FASHION SHOW! I'm not kidding. Train staff actually modelled various alpaca sweaters to the beat of some generic techo music! If we weren't so uncomfortable, we would have found it amusing I'm sure. We wished we had skipped our night at the Sanctuary Lodge and just returned to Cusco on the Hiram Bingham the night before - it's that good!

Wonderful and magic experience. From the moment we arrived in Cusco, checked in at the Monasterio to the Hiram Bingham train to Machu Picchu, we felt everything was magic around us. Monasterio is unique, the service is unparallel, it is more than excellent service you are pampered, the site/building feels like going back in time. The rooms are superb and very comfortable. Having travelled a lot, this is my favourite hotel. You cannot go to Cusco and miss the Monasterio.The Hiram Bigham train from Cusco to Machu Picchu was a delight from the first minute we arrived. Everything was carefully planned to ensure we had information at all time, help with luggage's without feeling invaded. We stayed one night in Aguas Calientes and the train's staff delivered / and collected our luggages from the hotel we chose to ensure no disturbances to my trip. The food and service were excellent - really well done to the team. We felt staff were there to provide an excellent service but moreover to ensure travellers have a memorable experience (we certainly did). They have simply exceeded my expectations, the whole experience is highly recommended. Anne

Go on - you're worth it!. We took the Hiram Bingham from Cusco as part of our honeymoon and it was worth every penny, especially the outward bound trip when there were only 6 other people on the train. The service was impeccable, the decor beautiful and the food delicious. When you see the other classes of train on offer from the windows, you just know you've made the right choice! We didn't want to get off the train when we arrived.Our return journey wasn't quite as enjoyable - the train was taken over by two large tour groups whom were very noisy and it did affect our enjoyment. However don't be tempted to only go one way on the HB, you'll regret it plus you'll have to pay for the retrun anyway as they're not very good on giving you any money back. That said, this train was a highlight of our trip.

Not Worth It. i arranged an individual package with Orient Express to stay at the Hotel Monasterio in Cusco, take the Vistadome train to Machu Picchu (the Hiram Bingham does not run on Sunday), stay at the Sanctuary Lodge and return Monday on the Hirham Bingham. The two hotels were outstanding. The Monasterio exceeded our expectations.The Hiram Bingham was another matter. We enjoyed the Ghan train in Australia and the Blue Train in South Africa but were very disappointed in the Hiram Bingham. The bus from Machu Picchu dropped us off some distance from the train station with no directions on how to find the train. When we found the train we were seated at a table for four. When we showed them our tickets, we were told that the seat numbers did not mean anything. No one offered to seat us at a table for two. The bar car was small and the few tables were quickly filled. The car swayed so much that you had to hang on to the bar while having a drink. Dinner was a set menu with no choices. If you did not like trout you were out of luck. The food was edible but not enjoyable. Service was indifferent at best. The staff was curt, looked bored and did nothing to enhance our experience. The next morning a couple we had met at Machu Picchu came to our table at the Monasterio and expressed similiar frustration with the train. It is hard to believe that the hotels and the train are operated by the same company.I would reccommend that you stay at the hotels and take the Vistadome.

Would go again tomorrow. We caught the Hiram Bingham as the "splurge" part of our trip to South America. Yes it is expensive but we enjoyed every minute. Right from the pre train drinks at the Poroy Station, through the beautiful meals, first class service and stunning scenery we could not fault it. As part of the deal you get a guided tour of Machu Picchu, lunch at the Sanctuary Lodge as well as the train ride. As we said in a review about the Sanctuary Lodge we would rather have two trips up to Machu Picchu on the Hiram Bingham than stay up at the lodge.

Hiram Bingham experience. I am totally perplexed after reading Champagnetraveller's unfavorable review of the Hiram Bingham train ride from Cusco to Machu Picchu. Our experience was the opposite of his/hers. From the moment we landed in Cusco (after a very nice LanPeru flight), we were taken care of completely. Edwin, the driver assigned to us by HB for the duration of our stay in Cusco, met us at the baggage claim, handled our bags and took us in a minivan to our hotel. (Novotel...be sure to get one of the bigger and nicer "Colonial" rooms). After checking us in, he explained our itinerary and helped us book additional excursions. We chose a private city and surrounding area tour, and a group Sacred Valley tour. Although I drank tons of water and choked down a lot of coca tea, the altitude problems hit me pretty hard around 3am the first night. My husband was fine. Neither one of us drank while we were there; it just seems to hit some people harder than others. Exedrine migrane was only a small help. In retrospect, I should've asked for oxygen at the hotel which is always available. Edwin picked us up at 0810 the next morning to take us to Poroy's station where the Hiram Bingham leaves at 0900. There were local dancers there and once onboard, more local entertainment for the duration of the trip. We did not experience anything negative on the trip AT ALL. The service was gracious, the food was surprisingly good, our included guide for MP was great, the post-tour tea at the Sanctuary Lodge was wonderful, and the oxygen they offered me on the train to MP cleared up my awful headache in 5 minutes. During the ride you're able to go to either the bar car or the observation car with an open back to the tracks for some beautiful views of the Peruvian countryside. MP itself IS awesome. Of course the fact that we had perfect weather with no fog had a lot to do with our experience. The only rain we had was on the train back to Cusco, and by then it was dark anyway.  One suggestion about the HB: even though they do offer a nice brunch on the way to MP, it's not served 'till 1100, so you might want to have something small at the hotel before you go. We saw the other 2 trains in Aguas Calientes (sp?), and they seemed fine. They leave sometime around 0630 from Cusco, so they both arrive and depart before HB. Be sure to book as far in advance as you can for HB if you decide to take that route. Yes, it's expensive, but at this stage of our lives (50) we decided it would probably be a one-time deal, so we bit the bullet and economized elsewhere.  At the end of our Cusco stay Edwin took us back to the airport for our flight to Lima where we joined the ship in Callao. All in all, the trip was hassle-free and we had a blast.

Lot of eelay - Very high prices.. Due to the monopoly on this line, the prices are very expensive (compare to rest of Peru). 1 hour and 50 minutes delay on a 1 hour and 40 minutes trip. It is unacceptable with such high prices that maintenance is no done properly.

Poor communication. I took the Incarail train in executive class from Ollanteytambo to Machu Picchu in October 2016. Great experience. Visited Peru on a business trip. Was there for six days and decided to visit Macchu Pitchu on a clear day off. After some research we discovered the cheapest and easiest option was with Inca Rail. The return ticket from Poroy station on the outskirts of Cusco to Machu Picchu cost £130 each with a premium economy ticket. The only train is at 05:55am and it returns leaving Matchu Picchu at 16:20 arriving back into Poroy at around 1930hrs the train journey is roughly 3 hours each way. There is another option from Ollantaytambo station but you would need to get a bus /taxi from Cusco and it would take a few hours as it was over an hour before the train stops there en route. We booked our tickets online with Inca rail and had to print off the confirmation which had to be presented at the train station with the credit card you paid for the tickets with in order for the Inca rail staff to issue your train ticket. We arrived at Poroy station at 5am and the Inca rail staff were not there. The lady turns up about 5.15am so don't panic at first if there is no one there. She sets up inside with her laptop in the seating/ waiting area not outside in the ticket office. They advise you to be there 30 mins before departure to collect tickets. There is a coffee shop selling drinks sandwiches and cakes and there are also good clean toilet facilities. The train itself was only four carriages and it was full. There are toilets on board and staff served complimentary drinks and a sandwich which was needed at that time in the morning. Announcements made in Spanish and English. They also play pan pipe music on route but this was quite loud and annoying as a few of us wanted to sleep. We asked if they could turn it down a little and they did thankfully. You cannot walk between the carriages so if your group is split between them you cannot walk through to see them. The seating arrangements are tables of four so you might have to sit and face someone not in your party. The scenery is breathtaking. During the three hour journey we were served complimentary drinks twice, soft cold drinks or tea and coffee. On the return sector we had biscuits and cake. The staff are very helpful and the facilities are good. When we arrive at Aguascalientes train station it's right in the centre of the town has toilet facilities but it's quite confusing at first as you have to walk down through a market stall area and everyone is rushing to get to the bus queue for Macchu Pitchu so it was a little stressful. My advice would be to get off the train ASAP and take a brisk walk to the bridge which takes you across the road where you can buy your bus tickets. If you are travelling in a group split and get people in the bus queue while the rest buy the tickets. We queued 20 mins to buy the bus tickets then another hour to get on the bus up. You can buy tickets for MP in Augas Calienties tourism office ( you need your passport) but I strongly advise you buy before to save yourself a lot of time and stress. Doing Macchu Pitchu in a day is doable on this train was our best option but it involves spending two nights in Cusco as the flights do not tie in with the train times. It was very tiring but 100% worth every minute if you are limited for time. Only hiccup was the hotel receptionist in Cusco told us it would take 40 mins to Poroy station. It took ten mins so we were at the station way too early !! We think she meant 14 mins not 40!!!! An absolutely fantastic experience overall top tips book your train tickets online in advance if you can to ensure seats as they were very busy from Poroy and get off train on arrival as quick as possible to avoid huge queues.

lost world. It is the unique experience of real immersion in a lost world. You look a fantastic combination of almost extraterrestrial nature and well-preserved traces of ancient civilization.
