Don't worry, after your visit to MP, there will be plenty of time for eating and shopping before taking the train back in the evening (unless you plan to stay here overnight). Loved the train ride and free soft drinks and pastries.

Good Review. Our trip to Machu Picchu was booked by our hotel in Cusco and ended up saving us over $100 a person vs booking it before we left the USA. The hotel (Wifala Thematic) booked us Executive service going and economy service coming back. I was pleasantly surprised.The train station Ollantaytambo has a waiting area and you can buy food and drinks while waiting for your departure (the ham and cheese was awesome!) The bathrooms were very clean. The service from the personnel were nice. Everyone was smiling. Going to Aguas Calientes the train swayed quite a bit. Like another review, the train follows the river so sit on the left side going to Machu to get better pictures. They have a drink snack service. I think they have some of the best coffee :)Once you get off the train you walk maybe 3 minutes to the bus that takes you up to Machu Picchu.Coming back the economy wasn’t as roomy but honestly I took a nap and woke up with a little less than an hour in the journey. I can highly recommend the service. I included some picture.

What wonderfuyl views from a wonderful train!. Luxurious, clean train with train attendants serving coffee and snacks. We sat in a four-person square with a table between each couple and so enjoyed the sights. Highly recommend taking this trip just to see the countryside, waterfalls, Andes, etc. Loved it!!

Bumpy ride. The first thing that was strange is that I booked the tickets online, paid online and still had to go to their office in cusco main square to get the actual tickets. They just printed almost the same page I could have print at home. Don't understand why it had to be so complicated... It's 2014...The ride itself was very bumpy. Not sure it's the train fault thought it seemed old. The driver kept hinking every few minutes which was very disturbing. Chairs were uncomfortable and the service very limited. Offered some juices and hot drinks. Would have expect at least a bottled water for that price we paid.The only good thing was that it was on time.

Definitely better than Peru Rail. This was my second time using Inca Rail. It was slightly cheaper than Peru Rail and the seats were a lot better. The times were very similar to Peru Rail. I got the Executive Service, which comes with a small beverage and snack (think U.S. domestic airline short haul service). Train was on time and the seat was comfortable. I recommend taking Inca Rail if you're heading over to Machu Picchu. I purchased my ticket online and only had to show my confirmation at the ticket office on the day of departure. --Tips- if you are using a U.S. credit card (I used Chase), you may get an error due to verified by Visa. Call the 800# on the screen and advise them of your purchase then have the rep wait while you run the transaction again. The reason is that U.S. banks do not participate in verified by visa (you can google the info). I had to do the same thing when purchasing Manchu Picchu tickets.

Quiet ride. From Poroy station to Machu pIchu it was a great expereince at all. firs the poroy station was clean, well organized with waitng area, a smal coffe shop and clean and well suplied bathrooms. Once in the train the service was perfect and acomodating. Food on the car was good as service as well. They even do a fashion show inside the train and sell books and other memorabilia.

Interesting ride to Machu Picchu. Train is enjoyable ride. Two people face each other with a table between them. Cold drink (had Incan soda) and snack is provided without cost. Nice ride along the river to Aquas Calientes. Minimal baggage needs to be taken as there is minimal room to place the bags.

Fun :). We got the first class tickets so I will speak to that. The seats were comfortable and tables that fold out in front of you to give you more room, or more space to play cards. Part of the roof is glass and so as we rode through the scared valley, we could look up and see the mountains. It was beautiful. They serve drinks and appetizers during each ride from Ollantaytambo/Cusco to Aguas Calientes and back. It is about a 3 hour ride from Cusco to Aguas Calientes and train is definitely faster that using a car. On the way back to Cusco, the attendants put on a fashion show. Although it was intended to show what you could buy, they used a couple volunteers from the train to model with them. It was so much fun.
Beautiful ride!. Loved the train ride to Machu Picchu ! Once you get there, take your time and listen to your guide and then hike around!

Better than Peru Rail. Peru Rail is the larger train company by far, all of the stations include Peru advertisments and videos. BUT Inca Rail used the same tracks and stations and the staff was wonderful. At a lower rate they still give all guest a free drink and snack. Trains were on time and seats were comfy with big windows for wonderful views of Peru. I would highly recommend looking into Inca Rail when traveling to Machu Picchu!
Best trip ever. The train was perfect for the way back to Ollataytambo..we were very tired from our 3 day hike and the seats were very comfortable. they gave us snacks and coffee

In connection with the landscape and the history. The travel by train to Machu Picchu is exciting, this is comfortable and you can see the lanscape of the area. It is a good option to visit Machu Picchu the city of the ruins.

Affordable transport to Machu Picchu. If you want to get to Machu Picchu affordably, Inca Rail is the way to go. The "executive" service features a small snack and drink with the price of the ticket.One of my trains was late so I didn't get to see the spectacular views as I'd hoped, but I did safely arrive in Aguas Calientes. I don't know exactly why the train arrived an hour late, or rather, why we kept having to stop to let other trains go by, causing us to arrive an hour late, but it was rather frustrating as there was no explanation. My second train was only about 10 minutes late.If you get motion sick, cross your fingers that you're in a middle car as they seem to sway less.

The Peru Rail Vistadome. We took the Vistadome train to Machu Picchu via Ollantaytambo. The 2 hours ride was comfortable and snacks and drinks were provided. Going back to Cusco via Ollantaytambo again, there were some sort of entertainment on the train as well as some "sale" for the local Alpaca products.

One for the bucket list. I went on this train to Macchu Picchu we left early in the morning and the train journey was very enjoyable real slow and easy guess needs to be on the narrow gauge rails but very nice would recommend this trip

Just fine. I caught the Inca Train. It rattled along. The seats were comfortable and you get a drink and basic snack as part of your journey included. It is an hour and half ride from Ollyantambo to Machu Picchu town. I found it quite adequate for the trip and cheaper and the other trains.

Nice train ride. We took economy on our way to Machu Pichu and somehow on the way back, we got 1st class tickets. It was really nice. They serve you a mini 3 course meal in first class but the ride can be a little bumpy. Overall, for a train ride, this was a good experience. Economy gets served a snack and tea and the ride gives you a nice view of the city on the way to Machu Pichu.

Still expensive but much better than Peru . We were going to take an alternative route to Aguas via Santa Maria by way of the Hydroelectrico but decided to take the Inca Rail train instead. Their prices were much cheaper then Peru rails. They also seem to have better times or at least more options for times. Free drinks service and snacks were provided which was a nice addition. But still a bit expensive when you consider the price of local busses and collectivos. The ride was only a little over 2 hours and the seats were comfy.

Good ride. I am glad we made our reservation with inca rail and not peru rail. I was afraid that I am choosing the wrong service. It was clean, comfortable with a free limited beverage and snack service. I did not miss on anything traveling with inca rail. And I did see multiple Peru rail trains.

Poor trains old as Machu Picchu.... It is a shame to see this train company that makes competition with PeruRail offering such old trains that in my experience I would say are from the 1970's brought from Europe as almost trash to make Coca Cola cans. The seats in Ejecutivo service are very narrow and not very comfortable. After we boarded ,the train started to throw smoke from the air conditioning vent that lead everyone to get out of the train and being delayed for almost an hour due to this technical issues. I would strongly suggest to this company to get in shape and invest more on newer trains, no one is asking for high speed european trains but at least get new and in good shape trains such as VistaDome to make a real competition to the much needed route to/from Machu Picchu. On the other hand the service given by the train attendants was very friendly and educated.

Wonderful scenery, comfortable train!. A delightful way to finish off the Inca Trail and a visit to Machu Picchu. Pay a little more for your ticket and you'll receive a drink and snack on the journey. If it's hot, pay a little more and have an air conditioned carriage! A lovely way to see the Andes.

First Class Seat worth the cost!. This was easily the best train ride I have ever taken! Not only were there windows on the ceiling allowing you to see the mountains at all angles, but there was a delicious snack, Dancing VooDoo Devil and great fashion show! I loved it!

Wonderful Experience. The train had many windows over the cabin that allowed you to see much more of the surrounding area. The mountains and river valley were beautiful. The dining provided was good. It was an excellent way to get from Cusco to Aguas Calientes.

Great service & punctuality on Machu Pichu train (and thanks for the upgrade). Our family Machu Pichu visit was part of a 3 week Peru selfdrive roadtrip (yes we're pretty independent travelers). Our Machu Pichu day visit was planned on our son's birthday and was intended to be one of the highlights of the trip.Inca Rail made the day extra special by upgrading us to first class on our way back from Aqua Calientes to Ollantaytambo. Classy train and Oriënt Express style experience, great food, super service. And experience the kids will never forget :-)Btw seating in tourist class is also far above average in confortable large seats and you get a snack/drink included in the ticket.

Wonderful scenery!. I highly recommend this tour to reach Machu Picchu. The scenery is wonderful: the river at one side and the mountain at the other. The service is excellent with a coffee or tea served.

An interesting experience to begin/end our journey to Machu Picchu. I recently traveled on the Inca Rail with a tour group (Backroads). Our Trip Leaders had our tickets for us, so I can not comment on the website or ticket purchase experience. We were in coach class for our journey to Machu Picchu, which was OK, but seats were not the most comfortable. We were in the First Class section on the way back, and it was much more enjoyable. Enjoyed the tea and snack served both ways. For us, Inca Rail was a positive experience on our adventure vacation.
Great views. Train was a bit slow but worth taking the regular tourist train versus the luxury train. We did not get food but it is only a 1.75 hour ride. Great service

Fantastic scenery, efficient transport. As a train, it was comfortable and got us to Machu Picchu and back efficiently, even with the cheapest package. Free snacks and drinks were a nice bonus,As an experience, it was fantastic, with stunning scenery and the fantastic blues of the sky as the sun rose and set. Chatting with fellow passengers was another bonus.

Surprisingly pleasant. This was the nicest train I was ever on. Seats were comfortable and a pleasant surprise to get a drink and a snack. I recommend the Andean tea! I see some negative comments people made about the price but as I bought my ticket to Machu Picchu, accommodation and train ticket together I don't know how much the train cost separately. But it was very reasonable for the package.

A lovely way to travel - pity about the price. Like the other posters, I rode from Ollaytan to Machu Picchu. Trains arrived and departed on time. The scenery along the way was wonderful. It is an expensive journey. There is a free drink and snack along the way. Just a tip: do not bring much luggage with you. There is no space to store it on the train. The baggage racks hold a backpack at most.

Helped us relax with great service. The day after our wedding, my wife and I arrived at ollantaytambo to find a huge traffic jam and we had to run to the train station to make it on time just barely. Needless to say, we were very stressed at that point, and the staff immediately greeted us with some chilled sparkling wine. The train ride was bumpy, but the glasses were held in place by a very nice looking set of heavy, stable coasters. A very nice gesture to relax after a stressful moment.This was in the executive cabin, and the return trip in first class had even better food and drink.All in all a great travel experience.

Mystic Experience. We rode the Inca Rail from Ollantaytambo to Machu Picchu (Aguascalientes). The train attendants were very nice and were excited to answer any questions or address any concerns. All of the snacks and drinks served onboard were very good. The seats were comfortable and the train even had a bathroom just in case you needed to go! The Boarding process and deboarding was very easy. Crew spoke english. Highly recommend.

Monopolists don't really have a need to care about the quality of their products.... First of all: the prices are extortionate!!! 120$ for getting to Machu Picchu and back is ridiculous. But it's the cheapest way if you're coming from the sacred valley. I took the tourist class and could book my seats the night before for good times - though you should plan in advance how much time you wanna spend in MP and Aguas Calientes, respectively. The train itself was quite okay. The windows could have been cleaner, but the seats were comfortable and at least they offered a drink and a snack inclusively. The suspension of the train isn't the very best and neither are the tracks, so parts of the ride were quite bumpy. However, the seats were comfortable. The view, of course, is amazingly incredible! If you want to take pics, ask for a window seat and have your camera ready to shoot all the time - taking a good picture can be a challenge in a moving train and there's plenty of trees that pop up on the track's side just when you thought this is a good scene!

explorer train. traveled on this train to machu pichu.there is no need to spend any more than this for your train.excellent views through windows and skylights ,train also very clean, and well organized

From sea level to 3352m ....and a hundred years back in time. When i flew into Cusco to ride the railway,i travelled from sea level up to 3352 m and a hundred years back in time. Cusco is an unspoilt city of Spanish colonial baroque architecture resting on a rock-bed of Inca masonry. We plumped for the Monesterio Hotel,hidden amidst its cobblestone warrens. This is the favourite base for railway aficionados. And i got to tell you,roasted alpaca in this high altitude is heaven. In the morning,at 6.30, the Vistadone begins its climb from San Pedro Station on one of the most scenic and historic railway journeys i have ever undertaken.We growled up through the chaotic,red mud-brick barrios that cling to the hillside. Cusco spread out before us,all the tile roofs framed by the peaks of the Andes. Near the top of the grade,we spiralled around a horseshoe curve to El Arco summit,3677 m, where the train ducked through the ruined arch of an 18th aqueduct. then through a series of 'loop-de-loops' to Poroy and the flat fertile Pampa de Anta. The haunting music played over the sound system as snacks were served,while the narrow gauge carriage swayed. Ascending to the last zig-zag in the gorge of the Rio Vilocona,we rolled passed the Pachar depot.  Ahead lay the deep,dark,green Urubamba Gorge and the Cloud Forest,habitat of wild orchids,hummingbirds and the endangered speckled bear,all the way to Aguas Calientes,to surge like lemmings for the waiting buses for Machu Picchu. Pictures cannot convey,no matter how many photos you have seen of the ruined city clinging to the sheer mountain top in the jungle mists... the scale of the ruins. The crowds vanish among the houses,temples and palaces,visitors appear like specks on the grassy boulevard to to the young mountain,the peak dominating the view. the weather alternates from hot and sunny to cool,damp and dreary as clouds and mist drifted by,enhancing Machu Picchu's deep mystical aura.... like a Pompeii in the sky.

Not very comfortable. I took this train a couple of months ago, but it was very uncomfortable. If you have big shoulders the seats are tiny, and you sit facing somebody else, which does not give you any room to stretch your legs. It is a bit overpriced compared to their competition PeruRail which I took on the way back, for the same price we got several snacks and even a show on the train. Seats were way more comfortable as well.

Great view and atmosphere traveling to Machu Picchu. We had our tickets and places arranged from our agency, traveling with the guide. We changed our seats to the back part of the carriage (recommended) having perfect view through the roof of glass. Food opened during the ride was very poor. "Salami" sandwich was rather made with the cheapest sausage. When I asked for the regular coffee, I received tee :). They were selling nice t-shirts and stuff there. It was rare chance to buy something more or less unique - PeruRail branded things, not same shirts/sweaters you could buy from all sellers we met. They were very helpful with luggage and nice. Just little problems with English

Sound of pan pipes will haunt me. Train journey was fine and train comfortable except for the continuous pan pipe music played for whole journey. Did sleep most of the way but that was after trekking for four days.

Can a train ride be fun? Yep. We weren't particularly looking forward to sitting on the train from Aguas Calientes to Ollantaytambo for 1 hour and 45 mins after seeing Machu Picchu but Peru Rail were to surprise us. The conductors are friendly and they serve little complimentary snacks which is a nice touch. Best bit though was when the conductors dressed up for the fashion show, prancing up and down the train and there was even one in a funny mask pulling people out of their seats for a dance to the groovy music. Really funny, I haven't laughed so much in ages :)

Great Experience!. Magnificent Scenery the entire way! Urubamba River tumbling over the rocks on the left side of the train to Machu Pichu and the Andes Mountains all around. Orchids in the trees, small houses along the right here and there complete with chickens and cows. Children walking home from school, and tunnels to go through with a tight fit. Great!!

Comfortable!!!. Went to machupicchu lots of times, and this year I wanted to try the inca rail and definitive it was the right choice!! The train is big and the seats too, the staff working there are really attend and smily.There's several ways to go to machupicchu, and if you don't have to much time inca rail is the way, they are also working with Cruz del sur which ya can go easy from cusco to Aguas calientes in 4 hours aprox

Vistadome Train to Mach Picchu. Just got back from a wonderful trip to Peru and Ecuador. Took the Vistadome train from the Sacred Valley to Agua Calientes. Trains were very clean and modern and on time!. Staff was very attentive and entertaining. Beautiful scenery to observe on the way up during the day. Also opportunity to purchase items on the train...books, hats, souvenirs. On the trip back at night, the staff put on a fashion show and needless to say my wife purchased a beautiful baby alpaca top/shawl/poncho. Trains are frequent so we caught an early morning train up, explored Machu Picchu that day (including a trek to the Sun Gate), stayed in a hotel overnight, toured Agua Calientes the next day and travelled back to Cusco that night. If you can when booking tickets try to get the left side of train (facing front of train heading to Mach Picchu) for best views.

Train trip with a difference.. Suprised on going aboard at Ollantaytambu as it was very modern,very comfortable and crew all in smart uniforms. One and a half hours trip with tasty snacks, choice of tea coffee cola, juice or water. Then a fashion parade by the crew of top class alpacca wool wear for men and women with the option to buy. On return journey that night an amusing dance by colourful 'puma' character up and down the carriages. Excellent trip.

!!! Amazing Machupicchu but dishonest train company ¡¡¡. My partner and I were traveling to Machu Picchu and attempted several times to buy train tickets on Inca Rail. Their website was unavailable to take credit cards, therefore, we had to wire-transfer money from the US into their "secure" account in Cusco. After endless phone calls, as well as emails in which they were very unresponsive, they emailed to state they did not receive all the funds and was missing $75.00. We had Bank of America investigate this and they stated that Inca Rail did indeed receive ALL funds which was confirmed by their bank in Latin America. When we attempted to show them once we were in Peru all of the documentation, they completely denied it and told us that we must either pay the $75.00 again or lose all of the monies transferred and thus not be able to take the train. The other available train, Peru Rail, was completely full prior to the whole wire transfer issue so we had no choice but to pay the money again.I would have rather booked with a travel company.

Nice train ride, reasonably priced. There are only 2 train services to Machu Picchu: Peru Rail and Inca Rail. Inca Rail is cheaper but you'd have to travel (2 hours by taxi or colectivo) from Cusco to Ollantaytambo station to ride it. The train carriages are smaller than Peru Rail's and you're only allowed to carry one piece of carry-on (same size as airline carry-on) onboard. But the seats are comfortable, the cars clean with complimentary snacks. Travel time takes an hour and 40 mins.

Inca Rail. I visited Machu Picchu on April 10, 2014. On Inca Rail’s first class I traveled between Ollantaytambo and Aguas Calientes. On the way back to Ollantaytambo, I traveled on Inca Rail’s tourist class. My experience of Inca Rail’s service was excellent.I had chosen Inca Rail first because I had heard in Lima that it is the newer rail company that is competing against Peru Rail’s monopoly since about five years ago.

amazing experience. Still can't find enough words to describe how lovely our trip was! From the welcoming reception to the wonderful service and the delicious food the ride was the perfect start to our visit to Macchu Picchu.Departed perfectly on time which allowed us to enjoy long time on the site.Look forward to another visit filled with this magic.

Magical Train Ride. My wife, her sister, her 8 year old nephew and I took the Inca Rail first class ride to Machu Picchu from Ollantaytambo and we all had a wonderful experience. The car looks and feels new inside, but has a nice classical finishing all around. The attendants seem like first class airline staff, disciplined and extremely courteous. The food was superb, and I will bet nobody expects that food refinement in a 90 minute train ride in the Andes.The ride to Machu Picchu has a great view of the green, jungle-like towering mountains, and the ceiling windows in the train car allow you to enjoy them. The train is slow (30-40 km/hr), but with such a view, food and service, I didn´t mind it.The same can be said about the return trip, except that at 7 pm you will not have much of a view unless you have a full moon out there!

Pleasant. Nice way to get from Cusco to Aguas Calientes - good scenery, food was okay, service good. Wish there were other options though since the trains leave Aguas Calientes in the late afternoon - we were ready to leave in the morning and would have enjoyed some extra time in Cusco.And yes - it is expensive but you can't blame people for making a living - which major attraction isn't overpriced?

Scenic train ride to Machu Picchu. I was on a Gate1 Travel tour and boarded this train at Ollantaytambo on the way to Aguas Calientes station which takes you to Machu Picchu. Being the cheapest railway to Machu, I thought the accommodations would be "cheap," but it was actually nice! We were very happy with the whole experience. The leather seats were comfy, the wooden tables were nice and the staff was very nice. The train ride cost $50 each way.

An amazing train ride to Aguas Calientes. We took Inca Rail to Aguas Calientes the day before our visit to Machu Picchu. Peu Rail is everywhere, but Inca Rail ended up being the cheapest. We were very happy with the results.We took the Cruz Del Sur bus from Cuzco to Ollantaytambo. The bus "terminal" is about 100 yards from the train station. The bus is timed perfectly to drop you off about 30 minutes before your train departure, which is also when the gates open to wait for the train.We stayed in the executive-class ("E" class I believe), which is actually the same as the "first" class. The train cars itself are very nice...just enough space to squeeze yourself and a backpack through. There's also a small luggage rack to put your bag if you don't feel like putting it at your feet (there's plenty of room for feet & a backpack at the table, though). The cabins have about 20 four-person tables. Each seat is actually quite plush. Each table has a big, open window that you can slide down and watch the beautiful cloud forest go by. There are skylight above you as well so the cabin is very well lite.The cabins are very clean--more so than some airlines--and after your train embarks on it's voyage, you'll soon get food & drink service. The food service is a small-ish yet delicious sandwich & treat, and there's a large beverage selection. All this is provided free-of-charge. The staff on the train speaks passable english, too.The train ride itself is beautiful. I think this isn't a reflection of either of the rail providers, but rather the environment. The two hours it took to go from Ollantaytambo to Aguas Calientes went by fast because we were too buy watching the raging river underneath the train, the mountain peeks above it, or the forest going past it. We had the window all the way down and were snapping pictures like crazy. Inca Rail's moto is something along the lines of "creating lifetime memories" and it's true...you'll be treated great, and will spend most of the time focusing on the breath-taking train ride.We also rode Inca Rail back to Ollantaytombo from Aguas Calientes after we visited Machu Picchu. This is where my only complaint about Peru Rail comes in: the terminal must be completely subsidized by Inca Rail, because with the exception of the Inca Rail ticket office outside the gate, there's no other mention of Inca Rail within the station. Peru Rail announces all it's train departures & arrivals, but Inca Rail doesn't say anything, nor is there any posters or posted info. We had to ask a terminal employee if we were at the wrong train station. When she said "no", we attempted to go out on the train platform. We were stopped by a security person, who looked at our ticket, then hustled us into a corner with other equally-confused Inca Rail passengers.I highly recommend Inca Rail. The trains are beautiful, the rides are beautiful, and it's a very comfortable & relaxing trip. With the exception of the confusion at the Aguas Calientes station, there's no other complaints. Just be cognizant of your train's arrival & departure when at the station, and you'll be fine.

Gorgeous. One of the best parts or our Peru trip was the train ride to Machu Pichu! The scenery is breathtaking. IncaRail is definitely the newcomer so Peru Rail is the only visible company at the train station and it can be tricky finding someone on their staff to ask a question. However once it was game time they were organized and efficient with on-time boarding. Bathrooms were clean! Coffee/ tea/ water is provided in the price. Its also slightly cheaper than Perurail and I felt good about helping the company break a monopoly.

Wonderful views and ride.... The train ride was beautiful beyond words. The scenery with the Urubamba River rushing next to the train was brilliant. The service on board was very nice. We were in business class, which offered refreshment and snacks during the trip. The cars were very clean and very roomy. Enjoyed the trip very much.

Condor Travel Peru. We did a 9 day precruise tour of Peru - Lima / Cusco / Sacred Valley / MachuPicchu / Santiago where we embarked on the cruise to Bueons Aires. Condor travel never missed a beat, always on time with tranfers to hotels, flights, tours etc. All the guides were excellent, small groups, we chose 3-1/2 star accommodation all were very good. The cruise line offered a precruise tour and after talking to a few people we were so glad we went with Condor, cheaper and planned better. So much to see in Peru we plan on going back and will certainly book again through Condor Travel.

Great Train Ride. I had a blast, Great service from Michelle and Paulino and great experience overall. They feed you, which is more than most airlines will do, and the scenery is fabulous. They do try to sell souvenirs, but so does every other place which caters to tourists. The prices are the same for the quality stuff they have, if not cheaper since i paid more elsewhere for what they had. There is a delay sometimes since there's only one track for two trains, and the trains are dated but it's not the US and not the same standards.
Comfortable, good value. Good service ( less fancy then other companies, but offering smae service). Trains leave and arrive mostly on time. Cheaper then Peru Rail, but same traveling time.

Excellent Experience. We were traveling to Machu Picchu on the executive train, and had a wonderful time, the train is car is beautifully decorated, with large windows and skylights to enjoy to spectacular scenery along the way, the staff was very friendly and helpful with tidbits of details to see while on our journey. They seem very environmentally friendly and eco oriented in every detail, I really enjoyed that part, and look forward to my next trip.

Ollantaytambo to Aguas Calientes (Machu Picchu). Taking a train in a developing nation gave me visions of people jumping on while the train was moving and hanging off the side with much in the way of mal-odor. Nothing could be further from the truth. Better service, smiles & comfort than Amtrak! Not as good as Eurail!Comfortable seats but cramped leg space sitting 2 facing forward and 2 facing rear with a small table in between. Nice coffee, tea, juice service offered inclusive. Beautiful natural scenery of the mighty Rio Urubamaba (river)! We were in the tourist class.

Executive Class my behind! Peru Rail Vistadome is Better!. There is virtually no overhead storage on these train. It was 80 degrees and all they did was turn on some AC at both ends of the car but left the Windows down. Legroom is terriable. the worst was the seats are facing each other so you don´t know whether you will be facing forward or facing backward when the train is moving. The snack was a pathetic small bags of crackers or chocolate and a flimsy cup of tea, juice or wáter (not even any soft drinks) I would rather go for the cheaper Peru Rail Vistadome option since all the seats are facing in the forward direction. For the Price paid, not worth a crap.

train to Machu Picchu. Train was delayed over an hour and there was no leg room. Two seats faced each other overa table with no leg room. My legs went almost to the other seat as did the others coming mydirection

Inca Rail. We travelled in tourist coach to Machu Picchu and returned in the executive coach. Both services are very good. There is more space in the executive coach. It will be needed if you are tall. Excellent service. Comfortable seats. Breathtaking views. In the tourist coach they offered us coffee and returning from Machu Picchu in the executive coach they also gave us some snacks. Highly recommended.

Terrible Company. We took the train from Ollantaytambo to Aguas Calientes. There is only one way to get to Machu Picchu and that is by train either Inka Rail or Perul Rail. Inka Rail is slightly cheaper but both are expensive compared to bus travel in the area. Lack of competition allows the Rail companies to charge higher prices. The ride was very comfortable and they serviced coffee and other drinks with some snacks included in the price. All of this was acceptable to me but there was something that was very unfornate that happened to our group which cost us an extra $42 per person. When we arrived at Aguas Calientes all the train personnel were telling us that all the trains were running an hour late from Aguas Calientes which not exactly true. Only some trains were running an hour late and that caused us to miss our train. The train company made us buy another ticket and denied that their people were making those comments about the trains running late. I advise everyone to not trust anyone in regards to the time the trains leave and check with the office. Always be on time for your train at the time marked on the ticket and do not believe anything anyone says. If the time of your tickets changes the company has to train company has to write in on your train ticket.
On time, comfortable and nice ride. We enjoyed the train ride on Inca Rail to and from Aguas Calientes. Seats had lots of room and the big windows offered a clear view of the terrain.

Vista dome. Well, I can't say it was awful, I can't say it was awesome. I don't think it was worth it, but it was all there was available. On the way there we had the sun in our eyes (we were sitting on the left facing the way the train was traveling) on the way back the "vista" part was a joke. They give you drinks and a snack but it isn't worth it. Save your money for the bus or the entrance, you'll need it. You can go online ahead of time to www.perurail.com and buy your train tickets. They told us at the travel agency of our hotel, if you make it to Aguascalientes (the last train stop before Machu Picchu), they have to sell you an entrance to Machu Picchu. Our travel agency at the hotel helped us buy some of the entrances and train tickets, but we still needed the bus tickets and 2 entrances to the site. It was no big deal to do it once we got there. Make sue you bring your passport especially if you are under age, they have a special rate for students.

Fun Way to get to Machu Picchu. The narrow gauge train ride is the only way to get to the base of Machu Picchu besides hiking the Inca Trail. Riding the train was fun. It brought back memories of riding the train long ago. The seating was cramped for people with long legs. We were served a coffee, soda or tea while on the ride. Because of limited space, the luggage has to be small. Great views from the river side of the rail car.

Okay ride. We rode this train to Machu Picchu from Ollantaytambo. It was okay and they gave a small snack that was good, but it was not the best train ride I had in Peru. I was seated near the front in what was supposed to be first class but also happened to be right next to the driver and he kept blowing the whistle every two minutes, so it was impossible to sleep on the train and annoying even if you were not trying to sleep.

Up was fine but back had delays. Our trip from Ollantaytambo to Machu Picchu was in the rain but still we enjoyed the scenery and the experience on this one carriage train. We had hikers on board with their big back packs which took up a lot of available room, but overall the trip was good with drinks and snacks provided on the way. Coming back was not as enjoyable. We had numerous stops to allow both Peru Rail trains and the flash Oriental Express train to pass which meant we were late meeting our guides back in Ollantaytambo and wasted more than an hour of our precious touring time.

Train was a little late and we didnt even realize!. This trip was absolutely great. A nice trip to and from Machu Picchu! Our waiters and waitress could not have been any nicer or accommodating. Thank you to Yina, Yolare, and Olbers!

Can I get out a push?. Four hours on the narrow gauge train. Endless. We took the in-between train. Thought they would turn off the Inka music and turn out or turn down the lights. But no. Couple times went backwards for a while. Found out we could have gotten off a road a car and saved 1 1/2 hours. But now it would cost. You have no choice. But it wasn't fun taking the late train and getting in at 9 PM. Clickity-clack.

Great Ride. Nice ride and well organised. See if you can try and get seats A1 and A2 for a little extra view out the front of the train as you go.The crappy fashion show the train attendants put on during the return journey disturbs and peace and serenity you might get from the surroundings on the return trip. Otherwise the staff are quite nice and friendly.

from Cusco to Machu. we took the train from Cusco to Machu Picchu. the seats were okay, overall it was okay the compared to the other trains this was cheaper what matter most is arriving to Machu.we were served with snacks and water. not a lot of space to take a lot of luggage, good thing we only took a backpack.
Fine enough. No real complaints just that its so expensive!! The train is nice and the views are fantastic I just couldn't believe how much it was from Ollantaytambo to Machu Picchu.
great trip. after having done the 3 day Inca trail this lovely trip with open roof wiev and a nice bottle of beer was worth to come from the other end of the world.

Stunning scenery. One of the most beautiful train rides I have taken. It follows the Urubamba River gorge. Incan terraces are seen along the way in the hillsides, some being used and others in disrepair. Also pass fields of corn, potatoes and watch the farmers harvest the fields by hand.

Enjoyed this more than expected. We took the train from Ollantaytambo to Machu Picchu. Because it was a tourist class cabin, I was not expecting the cabin quality and level of service received. The seats were ample and comfortable, and the view was excellent. We were served drinks by attentive and polite cabin staff. There was a clean bathroom and a place to store backpacks. Honestly, I looked into the other cars to find out what more I could get from a higher-priced ticket, and the cabins themselves looked exactly the same. The only reason I am not giving this five stars is because of the limited amount of coaches available at certain times of the day. We wanted to change our ticket to later in the day, and were told that the mid-afternoon train only has one car. Still, it's a great experience for the price. Don't splurge on the Executive or First Class, stay with the Tourist car.

They ride on time. We took a tourist class return on Inca rail from Ollantaytambo to Machu Picchu, about an 80 minutes scenic train ride in the valley of the Rio Urubamba. Boarding was well arranged and the trains were right on time. They served a non-alcoholic drink onboard, which was also nice.On the down side, seating was designed for people 10-20 cm less tall than us gringos. And they require that you come and validate your prepurchased ticket at the Inca Rail office which seems an unnecessary extra step to me, certainly since the fee was already charged to the Visa card account. There were no overhead luggage racks, only a rack at the entrance of the train and space between juxtaposed seats. We did not notice a washroom onboard.

The train ride is beautiful, the Inca Rail office in Cusco is a nightmare. Unfortunately, on our particular trip there'd been a mudslide on the train tracks so all our travel plans to Machu Picchu had to change.Rather than helping us, the manager at Inca Rail office in Cusco insisted on charging us a 10% "cancellation" fee to change our train tickets. We said the mudslide wasn't our fault. She said it wasn't hers either. We finally paid the fee on the return trip because she was adamant and we had no choice. The other train company, "Peru Rail" didn't have availability, so were stuck with "Inca Rail" no matter what.God forbid you ever have to go into the Inca Rail office at Plaza Mayor in Cusco. You will wait. And wait. And wait. And wait. And wait to be served. You may or not get a person with a bad attitude after that.Due to the mudslide, we unfortunately had to go to Inca Rail 3 times to get everything straightened out. We basically lost a day of travel waiting to be served at Inca Rail. But as Inca Rail has a virtual monopoly on ways to get to Machu Picchu, you're forced to swallow whatever they dish out.As it turns out, going by rail is the ONLY way to get to Aguas Calientes (Machu Picchu). We didn't know this at first and assumed we could find a car or some other way to get up there. There's not. There's just rail. That's it.Interestingly, when we were finally about to take the train the next day in Ollantaytambo, we saw locals waiting for a different train. They told us they take a different train made especially for locals--and pay about $3 to ride it. That train is hidden from tourists' view.We paid $100 per person, round trip.So clearly there's some sort of game with the trains and with the fact that there's no road directly to Aguas Calientes. They make a lot of money charging tourists for train rides when there's not offering an alternative way to get up there.The actual experience of riding the train once you're in it, is really nice and relaxing and beautiful, but dealing with the Inca Rail office really left a bad taste in our mouths.

train travel top class. what a great trip. i remember the old north coast mail train in nsw australia and it was anightmare to travel in. this train was beautiful had magnificent leather seats and really comfortable, and the service was second to none. how nice to mtravel in a beautiful train. the scenery was great with lots of animals to look at and water every where. the river which flows along side for a lot of the way was beautiful. cant say a bad word about it.

Cattle Car to Machu Picchu. We actually had a decent ride up to Machu Picchu because my husband and I had a row with just two seats. The ride back was a nightmare. There is no leg room. I had actually had to put my legs between the legs of the stranger sitting across from me. I'm 5'9" so I can only imagine how someone really tall would feel. They were very nice and we got there perfectly on time but if I were to do this trip again I would really read the reviews and check for a train that rides more comfortably.

A Train Ride with Great Scenery. My wife and I took the backpacker train from Cusco to Machu Picchu since the reviews indicated that the views were very similar to the Vistadome train. I booked the tickets six months before the trip to make sure that we had seats on the train. Once on the train, we had 2 seats our of the 4 seats that were facing each other. The problem is that the amount of leg room for these seats are the same or smaller than the 2 person seats that are on the rest of the train. We ended up on the seats that were facing the direction opposite of that the train was traveling. However, it was on the left side so we had great scenery as the train hugged the side of the mountain on the side of the river. The 2 hour train ride was nice and scenic, with the train making a few stops. They provided snacks of plantains and tea/coffee. For our train ride back, we were not seated together - my wife was sitting with someone else in a 2-person seat. I got stuck again in the seats that were facing each other. But there were 2 military men that took the Inca trail that were sitting next to me and we had a great 2-hour conversation on the train ride back to Cusco, so I can't really complain. The 4th person was from Peru, and he too was seated separate from his companion. Peru Rail should allow people to select their seats, like the airlines, instead of randomly assigning seats and separating couples. Any seats number over 45 on the backpacker train is on the seats facing each other (there is only one set in our car). Maybe if you purchase your tickets at their office in Cusco, then you can select seats, but internet users are not as fortunate. Otherwise, a nice train ride.

An excellent way to get home from Machu Picchu. After 4 days on the Inca Trail, the Expedition train was an extremely comfortable way to travel back to the Sacred Valley. It is great as the ceiling has skylights so you can see the scenery and mountains as you pass by. A complimentary snack and drink is included as well. The young staff (Natalie and two young boys) were extremely helpful and friendly and talking to them made the trip pass by quickly. It is however not cheap, my one way ticket cost $71 USD!I would definitely recommend that you walk the Inca Trail if you can, rather than get the train to Machu Picchu there and back.

Better that Vistadome. We picked Inca Rail because the train was newer than the Vistadome. This one also has the skylights but all the drinks and snacks are included in the price. There is no fashion show or someone trying to sell you something. A great alternative to Peru Rail. The prices here are a little cheaper. And their new offices are right on the main square in Cuzco.

Cheaper, but same quality. We took Peru Rail to Aguascalientes Calientes and Inka Rail from. They offer the exact same service, but to a cheaper price, and run on the same railway tracks. Do take this train if you want to save a good chunk of money.

great views. the Vista Train is definitely the way to get to Machu Picchu. With sky lights above you really can see the mountain tops and get some great pictures. It cost just a little more, but its well worth it. The train tracks run along so close the the edges,you don't see much unless you can look up.

A GREAT TRAIN TRIP. This train no longer runs from Wanchuq train station in the city. You have to travel to Poroy to catch it and then the same on the way back from Agua Calientes to Cusco. Poroy is about a 20-30 ride from Cusco (depending on traffic). Another alternative is to take a day trip from Cusco to Ollantaytambo, visiting all the places in between (Maras, Moray, Chinchero, and the fortress at Ollantaytambo - hiring a guide, driver and vehicle that can accommodate up to 8 passengers, will run about $250.00 for the day (this is about a 10 hour day, with all the visiting) - entrance fees and gas included and they will drop you off at your hotel in Ollantay - lunch extra, if you stop for one - so splitting the cost with others makes it very cheap), then stay over night in Ollantaytambo and catch the train the next day to Agua Calientes/Machu Picchu. From Ollantay the train will take about 70 minutes (and Peru Rail is very good about running/departing/arriving to the minute on time). Trains from Ollantay run almost hourly, from about 6:00 a.m. Then book your return train trip direct to Poroy (then taxi or bus from Poroy into Cusco) or get off again in Ollantay and take one of the many taxi vans that wait to pick up customers here (they'll cram 8 to 12 into one van, then drive about 90-120 minutes to your drop off in Cusco - not sure of the cost). It's about $35.00 cheaper this way, per person. There are three levels of train you can take: the Hiram Bingham (far too over priced for what you get $300.00 per person, per direction from Poroy), the Vistadome (much better price - snack included, runs a lot like a plane, with stewards, etc. - great service, great scenery from large windows and glass roof, which they constantly keep clean - about $90.00 per person, per direction) and the back packers (same as above two, but less nice - about $60.00 per person, per direction). The second and third options are just different cars on the same train (yes, your ticket is for a specific seat in a specific car, not grab any available spot). NOTE: many companies will offer car service to Machu Picchu from Cusco - it doesn't exist. The road you take past Ollantaytambo is a dirt track beside the train line only as far as the hydro station, then you walk the last 5+ km (3+ miles) beside or along the train tracks to Ollantay and the path beside the tracks is RIGHT BESIDE the tracks. You better move well back when a train is coming.

Great way to get to Machu Picchu. Inca Rail provides extremely comfortable service from Ollantaytambo to Aguas Calientes. It tends to be less expensive than other services. The seats are comfortable, the service efficient, and the views spectacular. I am not sure why you would want to pay more.

cheapest train to machu picchu. We took the cheapest option to get from Ollantaytambo to Machu Picchu: IncaRail. The trains all go via the same railrioad to agua calientes and all take about 1.5 hours. Don't bother booking the more expensive peru rail, vistadome. You don't need big windows in the roof. The normal windows are enough. Leg space is the same on both trains. Service is fine, you get a free drink. Overall it is a nice train ride, but we were not impressed with the view. it was ok. The great views you get at Machu Picchu.So get the cheapest train ticket with inca rail.

Train ride to Machu Picchu. We had a private carriage on the train, which was the way to go. No queuing, plenty of space, dedicated staff. A lovely experience, with fantastic scenery. If you're eating on the train, be prepared for small food portions.

Torture ride for tall people.. So if you are above the height of say... 5'6" you should expect a very uncomfortable train ride. I'm 6'6 and spent roughly 95% of the time standing. There is zero leg room. The two staff members were apologetic but there was nothing they could do. Also when booking your return train try for as early as possible because it gets dark fast an there is no visibility of the surrounding landscape which is amazing.

Fantastic Trip. I booked to go by Inca Rail to Machu Picchu in March 2013, we booked the tickets over the internet which ws not as staright forward as it should of been as the site doesnt translate well, but eventually we sorted this out, I would recommend not leaving the booking of your train tickets till the last minute though as a result. The train was on time and our experience got much better onboard, the train was really comfy and clean, we were served complimentary drinks which was a nice touch and sat back in awe of the breathtaking scenery that unfolded infront of our eyes. I felt i had gone back in time onboard the quirky train. I would urge anyone visiting Machu to take the train as it was a real highlight of the trip.

Great sky views. I've never travelled in such a high class comfortable train. The windows extended over the roof so you could see views of mountains above, the 'hostess' served refreshments and also sold textile products which she elegantly tried on and displayed

Beware of thieves on the Inca Rail - do not leave any valuables in the baggage area. The train service itself was fine and they serve complimentary tea and drinks on the train. However, the seats are very small and cramped so you literally end up sitting with your knees touching those of the person opposite to you. As there is so little space in the seating area, they get you to put your bags in the baggage area (which is next to the attendant so we thought it would be relatively guarded). We accidentally left a mobile phone and some money in our bag and when we left the train, it was gone! We should have known better, but I want to warn other Tripadvisor readers not to repeat our mistake. Beware of thieves on the Inca Rail.

Efficient and timely. I'm unsure as to what many of the reviewers were expecting (to the reviewer upset about a sweater they bought on a train.... you bought a sweater on a train....) however both of my experiences on the Peru Rail between Ollan and Aguas were exactly as expected. They even hand out a small snack and offer hot drinks going both ways which I was taken aback by! We took the earliest ride there and the latest back which was a bit silly because we were only able to see the Andean scenery during the second half of our first ride, and by 9:30 PM and over fourteen hours at the site we were satisfied yet ready to return home to our hostel beds. The train's staff is efficient and no-nonsense, however they are also very kind and hoping to make one's experience to Machu Picchu a pleasant one. The tickets are pricey but I'd rather pay $100USD to take the train but there aren't many other alternatives and surely none that are as simple and well-handled as the train experience.

Long journey. We began our adventure leaving Cusco very early. A nearly 2 hour bus ride to Ollantaytambo... a 1 hour stay where our guide toured us around the city... a 2 hour train ride to Augas Calientes... and finally Machu Picchu... the ride was impressive, the site itself stunning, beyond words...

Bad Customer Service. I recently went to Peru on vacation and everything was perfect except our experience with Inca Rail. We arrived at the station 45 minutes early. Their audio system wasn't working and there was no indication that the train was leaving. We thought the train was running late and had not even arrived yet. When I asked one of the attendants, they told me that the train had left. When I talked to the only Inca Rail attendant they had on staff, she was very rude and said that it was our problem and that we had to purchase new train tickets. We were able to prove that we were there on time and that we were never notified of the departure, but she didn't care and was very clear about it. We purchased the new tickets with Peru Rail (much better service and way more comfortable) When we arrived to Cuzco, we went to the Inca Rail office, we explained the situation to the person they had in charge. The guy was extremely rude and had the same "it's not my problem" attitude that the woman at the train station had. One rude employee could be just a person with a bad attitude. 2 rude employees (in two different locations) clearly demonstrate that the company has poor customer service and only cares for the sale and not the satisfaction of its customers.Inca Rail is cheaper, but I highly recommend spending a few extra dollars and use Peru Rail instead.

Nice scenery. At this time the train only runs from Ollantaytambo to Agua Calientes. There are two classes. We were in first class which was comfortable. This in not a bullet train, but the slow speed allows you to see the foliage and watch the raging torrent river alongside the tracks. service was good and trip enjoyable.

Great way to get to Machu Picchu. First, let me say that I completely disagree with the reviewer who said this train is not comfortable. I found it to be very spacious and actually discussed how comfortable I was with the friends I was riding with. The ride was very pleasant and the scenery is amazing. There is food, but it's only light snacks. We (my group of 9) didn't care at all as we had food in our bags, and the ride is only a few hours anyway. Who wants to actually eat a full meal on a train when there are so many new and wonderful restaurant options to try in the area? Not us, that's for sure.If you want the highest in luxury, pay for the Hiram Bingham. If you don't want to pay an absurd amount of money for just a few hours ride, this is the next best thing. I will offer some advice though. Inca Rail lets you choose which "level" of ticket you want. If you like alcohol, pay for the ticket which includes drink service. The lower level tickets serve non alcoholic drinks and that would be fine if the trip only lasted the amount of time that it was supposed to. However, our ride had a 2 hour delay. There was a tree down on the tracks, and we found out that this is fairly common. So, had I known that delays are common, I would have purchased the option with wine so I could have at least sipped on some wine while sitting and waiting on the tree to be cleared from the tracks.Again, this train is very comfortable and I didn't find myself wanting for anything (except wine). I would absolutely choose it again, and would enjoy it once more.

Expensive, Slow and Exhusting. If there is another alternative to getting to Machu Pichu from Cuzco, take it! The train from Cuszo to Aguas Clientes is too expensive and takes for ever. No one tells you but you can take a collectivo from Cuzco to Ollantaytambo for 12 soles! That is 1.5 hour drive in beautiful country for 5 USD. Cheaper and more comfortable than the train. The train from Ollantaytambo to Machu Picchu is shorter but still, if you can take another collectivo from there to Machu Picchu, you'd be better off then the uncomfortable train ride.

Getting to Machu Picchu - Inca Rail vs Peru Rail. When I was researching information on Peru and trains to Machu Picchu I was surprised by the lack of information. Peru Rail and Inca Rail websites provided schedules but info was basic. We found the best option was to take a combi from Cusco to Ollantaytambo. This was fast, cheap and safe. Passengers were a mix of locals and foreigners. The locals kept the driver in line with driving laws and speeds. I felt safe using the combi.  IncaRail seating is crowded with passengers facing each other with a table between them. It is narrow and knees will touch as you try to sit comfortably for the ride. Friends traveled Peru Rail and said seating was much better, no one facing them and passengers were offered a beer or wine on the trip at no additional charge. There is a minor price difference between the 2 rails. For better comfort use Peru Rail.

Machu Picchu Train. We rode this train from Ollantaytambo to Machu Pichu and were very impressed by the views. The ride is slow, but the scenery is quite enjoyable. We were served drinks and a small snack which was enough to keep us comfortable for the ride. The seats were not the greatest, but they were not terrible either. A no frills ride from point A to point B - good value for the price.

Inca Rail is a great train service. When organizing your trip to Machupicchu, all you hear about is Perurail; however, Incarail is a great alternative--it goes from Ollantaytambo so this may limit some, but if you have time, Ollantaytambo is a great place to start from, a lovely Incan town and much less expensive than Cusco. Incarail is much smaller and newer, but you are treated very well and chances are you'll have a lot more space if you go with them. For $5 more, you can go "executive class" and be treated like royalty (almost!). Check them out!

PeruRail. We did the backpackers train there and the Expedition train back. The scenery is amazing and the train comfortable. I preferred the backpackers train with the table s it seemed more spacious.The fashion show and selling pressure are painful. Both trains were on line leaving snd arriving.

Not Your Average Subway. I rode this train to MP for the first time in 1973 when the trains were cold and dirty. No assigned seats and with a few stops. A mad rush at 6 or 7AM to get through the station and find a seat. Thank goodness things have changed. Clean and somewhat comfortable now, trip trough the country side and along the Urubamba River is unique and visually exciting, much more fun than detraining and running for a bus to MP. My best advice is to stay overnight and return the next afternoon.

the only way to go to MP. The train is usually picked up in Ollantaytambo (though a ride from Cusco is possible also) on to Aqua Caliente. Remember that Cusco has an altitude that is 2000 feet higher than the Valle` Sagrado and Machu Picchu. A great entrance to the adventure that awaits you and a wonderful and beautiful ride along the Urubamba River overflowing with huge granite boulders. I thought I was in Alaska for a minute.

So So Train. Gets you to your point in the Valley from Cusco to Aqua Caliente and a good fare. Also, does not have the baggage restrictions that can be found on PeruRail. Used mostly by college students and budget minded, more like backpacking in Europe

good but expensive. We had lots of fun during the train ride. Talking to people, watching the mountains and drinking Inca Cola. On our way back there was even a fashion show of alpaca products. The best idea was to have windows on the ceiling. The only problem is that Peru Rail is far overpriced! Therefore when going to Puno we took a bus, 10 times cheaper, and the landscape looked the same beautiful.

Idea Transportaton to Nearby Machu Picchu. Beautifully refurbished rail cars, superior to European cars. Traveled from Ollantaytambo to Aguas Calientes round trip and both segments were right on time. Onboard is a real treat because, in addition to large picture windows, the cars also have large vista dome type windows near the ceiling. I understand that reservations are A MUST, so be sure to book in advance. It was mesmerizing to watch the rapidly changing scenery out of the windows. Complimentary beverages and beer for sale are available from bi-lingual staff in each car.

We liked Inca Rail. We took Inca Rail from Ollantaytambo to Aguas Calientes ( I think it is now being called Machu Picchu Pueblo). We were not sure how this train would compare to Peru Rail. This train is fine and if you are looking to save a little money this one may be the way to go. The layout of the interior of the executive class of the train is similar to Peru Rail's with the same type of tables and seats. The crew was friendly and served a small snack and drink. On our return we traveled on Peru Rail. It may have just been us, but we thought the ride on Peru Rail was a little smoother. Also, on Peru they have a little fashion show. A couple of the crew members model alpaca clothing they try to sell you. A person dressed in a costume dances around to some loud music. This made the time go by faster but I would not book PeruRail just to see this. I feel that Inca Rail is a great way to get to Aguas Calientes.

Avoid seats 5&6 on the Vistadome train to Machu Picchu. We travelled from Ollantaytambo in the Sacred Valley to Machu Picchu on the Vistadome train. The scenery is fantastic and you want a good view. However, seats 5&6 are directly behind the driver's cab and we only had 6" leg room so had to reverse the seat back to travel backwards (all the other passengers were travelling forwards, airline style). Luckily two guides were travelling in seats 3&4 and swapped seats with us, one of them stood for almost the whole journey as there was so little room in our original seats.One our return we had the same seat reservations. The train was larger giving plenty of legroom but again an obstructed view behind the driver's cab. There is entertainment on the return with very loud and repetitive music (same tune of about 3-4 minutes played on a loop about 30 plus times).We were really looking forward to this part of our trip so were very disappointed. We think that inferior seats should have lower prices, as in an obstructed view seat in the theatre.
Poroi to Machupicchu. the best , we had fun ,we enjoy it, the service was great , the food was ok and the view was fantastic, we really enjoy it , we will use any of the services again

you really have to buy the tickets in Cuzco. We bought them 1.5 days before the train ride and I walked up to the booth at 30 min prior to departure and tickets were available. Yes the web site is no good but....it's not as sold out as Peru rail due to the inability to buy online. We left our bags in Couzco so did not have a problem with the weight restriction.

Peru Rail has Larger Ceiling Windows. My husband and I took Inca Rail from Ollanta to Aqual Calientes. The seating arrangement, seats, and table are the same as Peru Rail which we took back to Cusco. However Peru Rail trains have larger scenic windows on the roof/ceiling for viewing. Don’t forget you can only take 11 lbs of luggage (one carry on) on both trains to Machu Picchu, even though we saw several people with small, heavier suit cases.
Good ride, good service. The service aboard the executive class of Inca Rail was very good provided by very attentive personnel. We sincerely recommend Inca Rail from the Ollantaytambo station.

Inca Rail Dishonest & Non-Responsive. My partner and I were traveling to Machu Picchu and attempted several times to buy train tickets on Inca Rail. Their website was unavailable to take credit cards, therefore, we had to wire-transfer money from the US into their "secure" account in Cusco. After endless phone calls, as well as emails in which they were very unresponsive, they emailed to state they did not receive all the funds and was missing $75.00. We had Bank of America investigate this and they stated that Inca Rail did indeed receive ALL funds which was confirmed by their bank in Latin America. When we attempted to show them once we were in Peru all of the documentation, they completely denied it and told us that we must either pay the $75.00 again or lose all of the monies transferred and thus not be able to take the train. The other available train, Peru Rail, was completely full prior to the whole wire transfer issue so we had no choice but to pay the money again.We have forwarded our complaints to Peru Tourism as well as the Ombudsman at Conde Naste Traveler as there were other individuals we spoke to prior to the train departing that also had problems in which Inca Rail had charged them for additional fees on their credit cards. Be leary of Inca Rail, the workers and supervisor, Maria, in charge are all very dishonest and take advantage of tourists.

The Inca Rail train to Machu Picchu was a ride through time, when rail travel represented the ultimate in journeys.. The Inca Rail is two train cars owned by a private company with refurbished old fashion rail cars, including deep leather seating, a private bar and lounge car with a brass rail balcony while the train is running. The service is incredible, and the food wonderful. This was a special treat, simliar to the Hiram Bingham train but with an Incan flair. This treat was a surprise to us, one and a half hours of wonder along the sacred valley to Machu Picchu.
Uncomfortable trip. Uncomfortable seats.First class is not worth the money.Book it in Cusco, it will be cheaper.

Something to be said for a locally owned rail line in Peru. Took both trains - this and Peru Rail. We were not subjected to ridiculous fashion shows meant to sell logo-heavy travelwear on our tri with IncaRail. A much more enjoyable trip.
bumpy ride!!. our way to machu picchu was very bumpy and the attendant left the door open!!! one of the other passengers got up to shut it while the train was at full speed (25mph)...

Avoid Inca rail. Leg room is cramped up.. I decided to go on Inca Rail instead of Peru Rail since I thought it was a Peruvian owned business. The seats are set up such that each two passengers face another two. The leg space in between is not sufficient for four people. I also noticed that the Peru Rail customers had more leg room space. Besides, the manager at the hotel I was staying in in Aguas Calientes told me that all these different rail companies are actually owned by the same parent company "Orient Express". This Inca rail spin off is disguised as an independent company.

Great trip, two explored options.. We took Inca Rail between Ollantaytambo and Aguas Caliente. We did not use Peru Rail for this journey, but we did use them for a trip to Puno, so we have some idea about their service as well.Going to Aguas Calientes, we used the less expensive option. On the return trip, we used the most expensive option. In either case, they were considerably cheaper than Peru Rail and they run on the same tracks and use the same stations.Regardless of price, the view is great! Let me describe the differences in the service levels in the two options.The cheapest option has four seats per row. It's not abnormally tight seating unless you're a quite large person. They serve what is essentially a box lunch, of decent food.The most expensive option has three seats per row. The service is better and you essentially get a nice restaurant meal along with wine.The price difference when we went was $50 vs. $75 per person. We thought the extra $25 was worth them money. Either choice will get you to the same place. Our service was very reliable.By the way, it was very easy to make reservations from the United States using their Verified by Visa process (contrast this with my review of PeruRail).
nice train for tourists. i enjoyed the train ride from Cusco to Machu Pichu, good service from Peru rail staff. was ontime and met a bunch of great people

Almost the same as the Vistadome. despite the fact that the Expedition train is the cheapest of the PeruRail lines, we found the experience to be top quality. We debated spending a few extra $ for the Vistadome, but once we saw it in person we were glad that we didn't as the Expedition is almost the same. Comfortable and the views are amazing!

Service .. I took the train from AguasCalientes to Ollantaytambo , on Thursday October 27/16 at 6:20pm and we got an excellent service by Vanessa, very sweet and made us feel very comfortable.
Grace Gomez (Charlotte, USA)

Easy and clean. I was in Peru 23 years ago and did the Inca Trail to Machu Picchu on the way up and then stood in the bathroom of the local train on the way back to Ollytantambo. What a difference this was. So easy to book and to travel on. Very nice facilities. Friendly staff and very comfortable. A beautiful ride with nice scenery. It fills up so book early. The stations are nice and clean too. We took the Vistadome on the way up and the Expedition on the way back. Both were very good and our choice for what train to take each way was mainly based on the schedule. Either one is good.

Train to Machu Piccu City. The Vistadome train was very comfortable, clean and well appointed. Boarding was well-organized and timely. Staff covered the tables between seats with cloth and served drinks and snacks (ham sandwiches). It was a very pleasant experience; but the scenery made the trip. Peru is a beautiful country and going through valleys and mountains on a train was well worth the price of the ticket. I had ordered the tickets in advance but should I ever return (which I hope to do within a couple of years), I probably would inquire about the IncaRail, a more local train which, while not a Vistadome), looked to be as good. As it went though the same magnificent country, nothing wrong with saving a few bucks.

Comfortable, but definitely overpriced!. The train is comfortable, personnel attentive, particularly on the way back, when we had Karina and Esmeralda as our attendants from Machu Picchu to Poroy on oct 25 on the 16:43 train. They were remarkably friendly and fun! The train is the only way to get there, if you are not doing the Inca trail, and it is shocking to find out that foreigners have to pay at least US$ 150,00 ( the lowest price ) and there is a local train that costs US$ 20,00 round trip for nationals. The site is a country asset and obviously the country must profit from it, but in the end a concession to British companies has the monopoly of transportation to the site and gives no other option for travelers. For the price, service is barely more than decent.

Scenic ride. We chose Peru rail initially because of the schedule. It is a bit pricey though, but we very much enjoyed the ride. The inside of the train were very cozy, clean and spacious. The side and ceiling windows gives you an awesome view as you journey to and from AguasCalientes.

My preferred travel to Machu Picchu. I was able to compare both PeruRail and IncaRail. By far, my experience with PeruRail was better on every marker. The trains are better. The seating better. The staff friendlier and more informative. Our experience on PeruRail was much better. Next time, I will only select PeruRail.

the best supervisor. I want to sincerely thank on Board Service Supervisor for putting together such a flawless and wonderful trip!! To start I would like to give a big shout-out to Jorge Rojas whom help us with a big problem that we had on board expedition train We were part of an 8 person trek, for x motives 3 of us we missed our train even my bag was already on the train we were very desperate until Jorge arrived who understood our problems and he quickly contacted with the train and ensuring the rest of our group will get off in the correct stop, he sent 3 of us in the next train. The experience was such a pleasure and we are so thankful to have had him in Ollantaytambo to continue our journey with out any problem.Thanks very much again Sr. Jorge Rojas to make possible our trip and an unforgettable journey

Pretty expensive train. The train leaves perfectly on time. On board you get 1 drink and a small snack. The staff on board is really friendly. The train tracks good use some renovation. The train trip takes a lot of your time, even in a beautiful environment. On the way back in the evening the airco was blowing a lot of cold air, so it was pretty cold. In my opinion the traintickets are way too expensive, that's why I rate this 3 ☆

Brilliant ride - almost as good as Vistadome!. After travelling to Machu Picchu on the Vistadome, I wanted to see how Expedition fared on the way back to Ollantaytambo. The seats are large and there is ample legroom (I am 6ft 5ins so that's important to me!). The carriages have skylights just like the Vistadome. Soft drinks are served for free, and packets of toasted corn kernels are also handed out. All in all, it isn't much of a comedown from Vistadome, and it was very comfortable for a 90 minute trundle through the valleys!

Safe Travel via PeruRail. I found their prices cheaper than most and it's best way to travel if you wish to spend less on transportation. It is comfortable and very efficient. Safe travels to you all.

To see Machu Pichu. The train is too slow because the rail is too old and train could not run fast. I hope that PeruRail can reconstruct the old rail so that train can run fast and tourists can save time to see Machu Picchu.
Great Ride!. The price was very expensive, bur considering Macchu Picchu is a unique experience, it was worth it !

Peru Rail Train to Machu Picchu. Our group had a wonderful time on our trip to and from Machu Picchu, in fact, several of us enjoyed the train ride as much as the visit to Machu Picchu itself. The scenery is fantastic and the train travels at the perfect pace to take in the view. We were well looked after, with complimentary drinks and snacks provided, and on the way back we were even treated to a performance and fashion show by our fantastic attendants Isaac, Begonia and Nay Ruth. A very enjoyable experience.

Very slow and expensive way to get to Aguas Calientes. It's the second time I did this trip, and it wasn't any better. You are stuck on a slow-moving train with admittedly some impressive sights between Ollantaytamba and Agua Calientes.Unfortunately it's the only way to get there unless you hike the trail. I had planned to tak the train from Hydroelectrica, but even for this short distance the train needs about 2 hours and is definitely not cheap - and if you miss the only afternoon train you've had it. Thus I bit the bullet but took the shorter trainride from Ollantaytamba, and this train was 90 minutes late arrivinf, and during the whole time people were standing on the platform not really knowing what was going on.

Cusco - Machu Pichu Dream Vacation. Traveling to Machu Pichu from Cusco was a dream of mine for thirty years and my ride aboard PERU RAIL Vistadome train was a highlight of my journey. Service was excellent and the views were outstanding. It is fairly expensive for a three hour journey each way from Poroy outside of Cusco through the sacred valley to Aguas Calientes with a stop in Ollantaytambo next to the ruins. Food and beverage service provided both directions with a fashion show on the return trip.

loved!. we took Peru Rail Vistadome to Machu Picchu and Hiram Bingham back - just want to say both experiences were great, but Vistadome, for the price, is amazing -- gorgeous views, music, etc. - what a fun experience that we'll never forget!

Polar opposites - make sure you go on the Vistadome train!. We had 2 journeys, one to Aguas Calientes on the Vistadome and then coming back to Cusco (Poroy) on the Expedition.The Vistadome train was spacious and although you're sharing a block of 4 seats with others, it was manageable. Fortunately we had a friendly couple opposite us and even had a good conversation throughout the journey.The expedition on the other hand was terrible. It's blocks of 4 seats as per the Vistadome, however they are much closer together and therefore 2 adults cannot comfortably sit opposite each other. Unfortunately we had an extremely rude couple opposite us who would not move at all and with the sprained ankle I had it made for a long, uncomfortable journey as my feet were pushed up against my seat!To improve this, couples booking tickets should be seated opposite each other so they can share the leg space, not next to each other.Do not book expedition for any legs of this journey - shell out the extra amount and go for the Vistadome.One other thing I wanted to point out, I originally selected Vistadome going there as I thought it was the only train with the extra windows on top of the train - wrong, the Expedition does have that too!
Convenient. This train service is so convenient. The train ride was relaxing, they offer free snacks and drinks while on board. The staff can speak fine English, they were friendly. No complaints!

NEVER TRAVEL ON EXPEDITION WITH PERURAIL!. The train is the only way to get to Machu Picchu. Thanks to PeruRail my journey easily turned to a real nightmare. Train departed from Aguas Calientes full of different insects. I was bitten by them dozens of times, despite using deet. Crew did NOTHING, not even closed the windows. Passengers had to organize themselves in order to fight with the plague. Service was super poor considering the price of the ticket. Train itself was very very slow and arrived with nearly 1 hr delay to Poroy. In Ollantaytambo the engine broke and we had to stop there for some time. Of course, not even a glass of water had been offered to us. Continuing the journey, hard to believe, I know, but... 5 wagons suddenly detached!! No safety at all!! Two wagons continued, stopped and returned in order to re-attach the remaining wagons. Arrival to Poroy was even worse. Chaos, a lot of strangers, darkness. We didn't book any taxing as we were informed that it's easy to catch a taxi there for a price of ca. 25 soles. What we were offered was min. 40 soles. Taxi drivers are there only to cheat the tourists arriving by train. Do not expect PeruRail to help you - they don't offer even the basic shuttle service!
