Not surprisingly, Perurail did not give me the courtesy of a reply to the email I sent them when I got home.  The goal of Perurail seems to be to extract as much money from rich Americans as possible.  If you possibly can: trek to Machu Picchu, and take any alternative to Perurail, and their Vistadome back to Cusco. Right now, the only alternative seems to be Inca Rail. By all means, go with that company instead.

An awful experience. After having a wonderful experience in Cusco, on the Salkantay- Inca Trail trek, in Machu Picchu, and in Aguas Calientes, it was sad to end our vacation with these swindlers. We bought tickets for the Vistadome, from Aguas Clientes to Poroy, outside of Cusco. After an hour and half, the train stopped suddenly, and we were made to disembark in Pachar, and board buses, for an uncomfortable two hour bus ride (without toilets) to Cusco. When we asked the conductors (in fluent Spanish) what was going on, they said things like "Poroy is Pachar" and "Poroy, no that is Cusco". They clearly did not want to be bothered. The canned message on the bus said we were being taken on buses (adding an hour and a half to the trip we had paid $75/seat for) "for our safety". No live human being talked to us the entire trip. A Perurail official on the bus, checking our passport for the fourth time during this trip, would only say we were made to complete the trip on a bus "because it's the rainy season in Cusco" But it is the dry season in Cusco! We finally learned, from another trekker on the bus, that the company was working on the rails outside Cusco. It would have been nice of Perurail to tell us this, before, or during the trip! Even before this turn of events, the trip was a disappointment. The snack we were served was a pile of peanuts thrown on a plate. As one who is allergic to peanuts, I'm grateful that at least the airlines leave them in their bags. The native dancer on the conductors giving a fashion show in alpaca shawls and sweaters was cute, but that soon ended, to be followed by an hour of t them coming down the aisle trying to sell these overpriced textiles to passengers. They were so involved with this sales job, that the guy who sold me a beer couldn't be bothered to bring me change, and, after an hour, when I finally got him to do that, he said he only had dollars, not soles. I don't know how many other tourists saw the irony of our passing desperately poor Andean villagers only yards away at times, while tourists, peered up from their Iphones and videogames to buy $300 sweaters and shawls.  When I got home, I emailed the company about our experience. Not surprisingly, they did not give me the courtesy of a reply.  It contrast to all the friendly folks we in Peru, on the streets, in restaurants, hotels, and on the trail, it seems that the main goal of this company is to cynically extract as much money as possible from wealthy Americans. Unfortunately, Perurail has a virtual monopoly on any transport to and from Machu Picchu, unless you walk. However, there is an alternative: Inca Rail. I suggest that you do anything possible to keep from giving your money to these crooks.

Comfortable train, fantastic views of Andes. What a treat the train ride was! There are windows all along the side and on the roof so you can take in the magnificent Andes and the scenic Urubamba River. They served delicious snacks, which are included in the fee. On the way home, the waiters even performed a dance and put on a fashion show!

Couldn't be better. We travel on The Vistadome through the Sacred Valley.The service is impecable. You feel traveling in style. The vies along the way are breathtaking!. Valleys, river (Urubamba), and the beautiful Andes are best seeing in the Vistadome. Staff was friendly and our seats were comfortable.Train is big and roomy.The fashion show on the way back was nice and the staff pit on a show that is kind of funny.We definitely enjoyed the ride.

Not worth the extra $$. Same train, same seats, and same legroom as the Expedition. Only choose this train if the schedule fits your needs better, but not because you're expecting an "upgrade." There's no upgrade at all.

Vistadome not what it's cracked up to be.... Vistadome is not worth the extra money. I would stick with choosing the best train for your "schedule" and not make your decision based on Expedition or Vistadome. Why? Because the actual train is the same between the Expedition and the Vistadome. Same scenic windows, same seats, legroom, etc. We rode one of each during our roundtrip from Cusco to MP. In our experience, the only difference was they offered a different "snack" (neither of which was anything to get excited about) and the Vistadome included a modeling show with loud music, which we would have preferred to skip. The scenery is enough of an attraction, but they want to model some local clothing in the hopes people want to buy something. Unless the Vistadome's times work better for you, just book the Expedition. Certainly a more calming ride!

Amazing!!. My husband and I were booked on the Vistadome by Condor Travel. The trip to Machu Picchu is incredible! The windows allow for fantastic views of the surrounding mountains and scenery. The gave us a small meal on the ride to Machu Picchu that was very tasty. On the way back to Cusco, they did a fashion show with alpaca clothing and traditional dances. It was very entertaining and I definitely enjoyed the trip.
It's nice to admire the mountains range while getting to Machu Picchu. The train is average, while the service is quite good including a snack and the possibility to buy some souvenirs

Train travel with a flair. Although the windows on the top of the train are what gives it the name of Visatadome, they did not add to the view as you really can't see much by looking up. But on the way back from Macchu Picchu, we had the pleasure of a fashion show and some local costumes which made the trip pass quickly.

Vistadome Train Ride from Cusco to Aguas Calientes. My husband and I flew into Cusco from Lima. We arrived to the Peru Rail depot in Cusco by taxi ride. Apparently, we looked like confused tourists because we were greeted by Alfredo at the station. He was most helpful and took our bags and walked us through the process of getting our train tickets. Upon check-in, he noticed that we were given backward-facing seats on the train. He rode with our group to the Pachar station. He was quick to answer any questions that the passengers had, and also was bilingual. The whole process was very easy because of his assistance. We are not fluent in Spanish and it could have been quite cumbersome. Alfredo is a wonderful, professional station manager. We enjoyed the train ride because our seats were upgraded and the scenery was breath-taking. The trains were riding pretty much according to schedule, but we were on vacation so there really wasn't any issue if it had not been. I enjoyed the air conditioned cars and the ride was very accommodating.

Great train journey. We booked the vistadome train about a month ago and were informed that part of the journey was to be replaced by a bus service. Whilst it would have been nice to do the full train ride I'd rather stay safe and travel part of the journey by bus. The replacement bus is only meant to be until 21st July 2013 so shouldn't affect travellers after that date. We found the train seats comfortable and the food was really good. We had fresh pancakes, strawberries, melon and spinach quiche. We had a choice of hot and cold drinks also. The scenery was spectacular and well worth travelling by train. The glass ceiling really added to the experience as you could see the tops of the mountains all down the length of the train. The staff were really friendly and when they came around with a "duty free" style trolley selling Peru rail gifts they were up for a laugh letting passengers try on the Indiana jones style waist coats and hats for photos. There wasn't a hard sell at all, just letting passengers try on the hats. A thoroughly memorable experience! :-)

Not quite the upgrade you're paying for. Because of landslides, the train started at Ollantaytambo and everybody took the same buses from Cusco to the Ollantaytambo station. The buses were extremely uncomfortable while the Vistadome train was moderately comfortable. It served surprisingly nice food, however, and the views were great. Also, they tried to get more money from the passengers by doing things like a Peruvian fashion show which was either a fun way to pass the time or an annoying attempt at further profit, depending on your preference.
Great Way to get to Macchu Picchu. Very Scenic if you sit on the left side going up.Leave before 4:30 so you can see the area going back, after that it is too dark!Great snacks and service!

good - but doesn't go all the way to Cusco.. I had booked the train for my return from Machu Picchu to Cusco. The train ride was enjoyable except that the seating arrangement where you faced other passengers provided no legroom. I am 190cm tall and I was really cramped. I was rather surprised when the trained stopped with no announcement and we were offloaded onto busses for the remaining hour and a half of our trip. The train (apart from the legroom) was quite comfortable. The Bus on the other hand was not anywhere near as comfortable. I don't think that they should charge a premium price for the travel when the bus is clearly nowhere near the same standard. I would check on whether the rail line has been repaired before paying for the Ollantaytambo - Cusco part.

very good. Took Hiram Bingham - one way, stayed two nights at MP, then took Vistadome back. Think it was the optimal decision. The Vistadome train is nice, comfortable, allows to see the beautiful surroundings.

Scenic Journey. Lovely experience! We took the train from Ollantaytambo to Aquas Calientes. Great service, comfortable and wonderful views! The train provided a small snack which was included in the fare. The staff was very professional and courteous, but the best part were the views we got from the comfort of the train.

The finest in economy class!. We did this on one leg of our journey and were impressed. It's more economical than the Bingham train, but doesn't miss out on service. Do this for sure if you're on a budget!

Memorable. Great service with a true Peruvian flavour. Warm caring staff. The food as average. For the effort put out to serve a meal the dishes that comprise the meal can be better, more local food should be incorporated. The entertainment, was fun.

on the way to Macchu Picchu. we did like the train ride with Vista Dome. Friendly staff and a little snack made the journey feel a lot shorter. This was our train ride to Macchu Picchu. We left Macchu Picchu on the Expedition train and I must admit there is not much of a difference between these two.. - only the price. the Expedition is cheaper. In my opinion it is not necessary to spend the extra money for the Vistadome. Sorry people!! maybe a tip for the marketing department - find something unique / special for the vistadome

Lots of Fun!. We loved our train ride to Aguas Calentes. We took the train the end of June. At that time part of our trip we had to take by bus provided by Peru Rail. We picked up the bus at the main station in Cusco. This was only a 15 min walk from the Plaza De Armas. When we arrived in Peru, we went to a Peru Rail station in Ollantaytambo to pick up our actual tickets two days before. We had made reservations on line previously. We think it was at the station, when we were getting our actual tickets that we could have requested a window seat, facing forward, on the left side of the train. The left side of the train runs alongside the river. We still had a wonderful trip, though. Met some lovely people that we kept running into the remainder of our time in Peru! :) It is nice on your way to Machu Picchu, Peru Rail does serve a snack and drinks. Lovely trip!

Good but oversold...mostly same as Expedition service. My railway service review is unfortunantely not positive due to the poor service received prior to boarding ( lack of a good ticketing system, not caring about seating assignments). Try Inca Rail you may be luckier....follows details of my experience:- The ride itself was OK, good on-board service, very clean , comfortable seats, on time- Took the VistaDome on the way down to Machu Picchu, came back with their Expedition service.-Both cars had windows in the roof...vistadome are newer cars and all seats are facing forward, you get a sandwich....other than this Expedition is very similar (last seats at the front and back face the opposite way)The bad service:- When booking online you don't even get an email with what you just bought, just a reference number ( so unless youremember you do not have an idea of what dates and times or type of service you just bought)- They still ask you to claim the tickets in person at a ticket desk at the airport or in Cusco.- They ask you to bring the credit card used for the purchase with you...so if someone else is buying you the ticket, or forget to bring the creditmcard, etc you have NO WAY of getting your tickets unless someone faxes/emails you a copy of the credit card....the othe company probably does the same but this is an absolute waste of time and a great unneficiency. Technology allows today many ways to inimize the risk of credit card cloning without affecting the experience of all the users- Waited 1 hour ( together with 7 other people ) at their Lima airport ticketing office ... ( supposedly 24h service) no one ever showd up. Even called their Cusco office for help to locate the individual but nothing happened-At their ticket office in Cusco, because we did ot have ourmcreditmcards...they allowed us to claim our train tickets (following an unpleasant discussion with the attendant) by allowing us to just give them the credit card information to claim our tickets- The person at the ticketing office DID NOT CARE about giving my wyfe and I seats together ...so we had to have another unpleasant discussion when boarding the train in Ollantaytambo in order to get us seated together.- They only allow us to bring one small backpack per person...if you do otherwise will get in trouble

Over commercial and poor management. Quite frankly I was disappointed with our Vistadome experience. The crew of our wagon car made a costumed performance which was good but later converted into sales on board which continued all he way to Ollanta... Furthermore, they didn't have space in the wagon to pack those things which were not booked and continued doing that just by the side of passengers. Finally they put this staff into large metal boxes and started taking them down the train straight after train has arrived to Ollanta station... Poor passengers, who were quitting at this station, had to wait in the train...Very bad management I think...

Nice view. Amazing ride!! The shape of the windows allow you to see the mountains and sky. The employees were ver professional. The seats are very comfy. If money is not an issue, I would recommend to ride the Hiram Bingham at least one way.They both are nice trains but the HB includes everything...You just need to pay 5 times more than the vistadome.
Comfortable & scenic ride. The train was comfortable & the seats were spacious. They served a snack & drinks. There was also entertainment. Very relaxing & enjoyable ride.

Comfortable Train with Snacks / Beverage. Having been on lots of trains...Not only does this train provide comfortable seats, large vista windows. It will not only feed you; it will entertain you with a fashion show and offer thefashions for sale...It also has a Monster running through the cars, scaring and entertaining people.Excellent train crew...The only way to travel, don't take the regular train unless you like oldchug along trains with open windows for ventilation.

Good service - very professional. I was impressed with Peru Rail's Vistadome service to Machu Picchu from Cusco. Good snacks, very nice and helpful staff and the train was comfortable and clean. Highly recommended!

Good overall. This train ride was part of our tour package. It was much more comfortable than the tour buses, and it was clean in the cabin. The singular restroom per car went downhill fairly quickly. They served food that was decent and part of the ticket price. You really couldn't get to the restrooms while they were serving the snacks, which was a little awkward for those people chugging water and tea to stave off altitude problems. They made an effort for nice place settings, and the views were very nice. On the way back, though, we were all tired and the weird native dancer guy and the subsequent fashion show to tempt us to buy extremely overpriced clothing were just irritating. We were all relieved when that ended. Also, one did not escape the pan flute music on the train, either.
Beautiful way to get to and from Machu Picchu. We loved the Vistadome - the windows and views were amazing and the train was super comfortable and clean!

Odd juxtaposition. Definitely the fanciest of the trains to Machu Picchu. We hiked in, and took the train back. We were really tired and wanted to rest, but Peruvian Rail decided we needed to buy from them and tried to tempt us with a fashion show. Much of it occurred while we were waiting for another train to pass, watching barefoot local residents walking along the rails carrying their belongings on their backs. Somehow it seemed wrong.
Beautiful views. This train is a great way to travel to Machu Picchu. Especially if you like taking photos! On the way back we even got a fashion show!

A Quick and easy way to get back. The train was comfortable and had good views. We were lucky to sit in the first two seats next to the driver so we could get a great view of the surrounding countryside. Didn't enjoy the dancing.

It's the only easy way there. I always feel ripped off when I ride this train. Very expensive, cramped seating, and they have eliminated the previously complementary snacks. But it gets you there, and that's inthe only important thing.
Very picturesque ride. A really great experience, comfortable seating, very friendly and professional staff. A refreshing light snack was provided enroute.

great view. We really enjoyed our trip on the Vistadome train. On our return trip from Machu Picchu there was a dancer dressed in a costume of the local village, then the servers put on a fashion show. The rail line renovations were not completed (from the flood damage), so we had to take a bus for the second half of our trip back to Cusco.

Great Experience!. The Vistadome train was a great experience! The views from the train are unique as we go through the Inca Sacred Valley. The staff on-board were very kind and provided interesting entertainment in the way back. One of the staff, Daniel Yila, was particularly helpful and kind. The small snacks (free) added to the overall experience. It's just a pity that we couldn't depart from Cusco and had to go all the way to Pachar by bus (2.45h).

Luggage limitation?. We were worried about luggage overweighed. But found out a lot of people had larger luggage than we had. We took the train Ollanytambo to Aguas Calientes and Aguas Calientes to Pachar (bi modal transportation, bus to Cusco). Overall we had no issues at all. Our luggages were still with us when we arrived at Cusco. The return trip they provided entertainment and fashion show to sell clothing (alpaca poncho, scarf, jacket...) It was fun. They also provided snacks on the train. We had a great time.

Great option for getting around Sacred Valley. We took the train from Cusco to Machu Picchu (Agua Calientes) and then back to Ollanta the next day. It worked great! The train was comfortable, prompt, and pleasant. The scenery was diverse and beautiful. We took the Vistadome which was entirely adequate. It was a good way to meet interesting people. The price was reasonable also.
Worth it. Taking the Vistadome is totally worth it if you take it during the day. We took the train back at night and it was too dark and rainy to be worth the extra fee.

Nice ride to Machu Picchu. We took the train from Ollantaytambo (Sacred Valley) to Aguas Calientes (town to get to Machu Picchu). It was a wonderful trip, the glass ceiling allowed us to enjoy more the scene of the amazing mountains. The staff is super friendly and professional. Most of them spoke several languages.

Absolutely great train ride!. This ride was very confortable and the views are amazing! The staff is very lively and helpful! The train has big windows by the side and also on the top so you can enjoy the view even more! The valleys and mountains on the way to Machu Picchu makes you think about how the travelers found it difficult to reach it back on the day.

Beautiful. This is a beautiful train ride. It made me seriously consider quitting mayday job and becoming a subsistence farmer. The train itself was comfortable. The staff was friendly. At the end, they tried to sell you some CDs of Peruvian flute music and informational books. Also, the coffee is not real, but rather the particularly nasty species of instant coffee that is common in those parts. Still, the scenery easily makes you forget how much you paid (not cheap).

Peru Rail. Nice experience, although a bit unfortunate that we could not take the entire journey to Machu Picchu from Cusco by rail. The service is bi-modal, meaning half of the journey is an early morning bus ride out of Cusco and the remained is on the Vistadome train. Very full train, nonetheless and nice to have a snack meal both directions of travel. There was a very loud fashion show along the hallways of the train on the return passage, not possibly for everyone after a tiring day in Machu Picchu. Good experience overall

Great views. Very comfortable train with great views there glass/plastic paneled roof. Stunning views along the way, the Sacred river and Incal trail. The breakfast snack on the way to macchu Picchu and on the way back to cusco was a surprise The fashion parade with loud music in the carriage and selling of produce was of putting after a long day.
Could be better. Too much money for the service.Ok the view during the trip is beautiful, but the trains in europe are much more cheaper and better.

By Peru Rail. This is a very nice train ride up to Machu Picchu. You get to see more ruins along the way (from the train) and local country - mountain ranges. The service is good, snack, and entertaining on the way back. Note that it is about and hour and half train ride and then you still have the private car or bus from Ollyantambo. If you can combine your trip to Ollyantambo with Machu Picchu over a few days, the consolidation will be time well spent.

Vistadome Option is worth it. There are a few train options to Machu Picchu. The Hiram Bingham (the high end "oriental Express") option, the Vistadome and the Exploration option. The Vistadome was very comfortable, timely and great service. We did arrive in a wagon that was not as good as the one we had in our return, but still was good enough

Better than anticipated, great ride to Macchu Pichu. Trains are spotlessly clean and on- time. Train ride out, we were surprised and pleased with a White glove complimentary small breakfast - the evening ride had a snack box and a sort of entertainment. The real show is the gorgeous scenery which is seen in all its glory from the huge windows all over the train. Very pleased and glad we took it to see Macchu Pichu.

Awesome staff!. As anyone will find out, the tickets are very expensive, mostly just because there are so few methods of getting to aquas calientes. I would like to see a cheaper option, but other than that the staff was fantastandic, speedy and very friendly. Roly especially was a pleasure. He definitely made the experience!

Ok Train Ride. It was unfortunate that the first 1.5 hours of the train trip was a bus ride due to the tracks being in disrepair from the rainy season which seems to happen quite frequently. I would suggest getting to Ollantay by alternate means and then taking the train if you coming from Cusco as it would be cheaper.

Nice train ride. One of the classic train rides of the world which is excellently maintained. The 1.5 hr ride from Ollantay to Aquas Calientes is truly spectacular and watching the scenery change made this ride truly special. The tracks follow the Urubamba river and the large windows on the train were wonderful. The service on the train was excellent and the friendly staff took time to explain the sights.

Perurail from Ollantaytambo to Aguas Calientes. We took the Vistadome from Ollantytambo to Aguas Calientes and then back to Pachar for a bus transfer to Cusco. The seats were comfortable, but I didn't think the 'snack' was worth it. During the trip up, they brought a little cart to sell books and clothing items and a passenger across from us took a LOT of time talking to them and asking for different sizing in the clothes and so they were standing next to me for about 20 minutes, which interrupted my view and enjoyment of the trip. On the way back, they had a fashion show and a dancer, which was fun. I didn't want to pay for the Hiram Bingham train, but I wonder if the Expedition would have worked just as well for a smaller price. I was also disappointed that we had to transfer to a bus from Pachar to Cusco due to part of the rail being damaged. Our bus driver was super aggressive in his driving, which was stressful. I think they should have given us a price break due to the bus ride substitution.

Good train. Well, it's a good train, but don't expect that much. Has some snacks included, but you have to pay for waters or beers. By the way, the beer isn't very cold... anyway, during the trip they promote a "Fashion Show", where the attendants wear ponchos to sell for the passangers. Altought very expensive, this is a fun experience to see while in the train. Have a nice trip

First Class travel to Machu Picchu. Beautiful ride! What a brilliant idea - adding skylights to a train! The mountaintops tower above and the Vistadome's windows let you take it all in. You will see snow capped mountains, glaciers, rivers, and humble villages along the way. The train is clean and comfortable, and a nice snack/beverage service is included. During the trip back the staff entertains you with a little folklore dance and an Alpaca fashion show (available for purchase of course). Note: We booked our tickets through our tour group, so didn't have any trouble with reservations.We travelled in April and had no problems with rockslides or delays.

Take this train. If you are taking the train to Machu Picchu and can't afford or don't want to spend the money to take the Hiram Bingham train, take this one. The extra view from the vista dome makes all the difference. The views on this ride are spectacular. Snow covered peaks, glaciers, flowers, remote houses with satellite dishes and solar panels, rivers with spectacular white water, etc, etc. I could have stayed on all day and just ridden back and forth.

Unique and Beautiful Ride. My wife and I returned to Cusco from our Inca Trail hike that ended in Machu Picchu on the Vistadome train. This is a comfortable and quality train. A light meal is provided with drinks (alcoholic extra). The view is spectacular, of course! After the meal, a staff member for our car dressed in ceremonial costume and danced for us as Andean music played. Shortly thereafter, the staff put on a fashion show of garments made of alpaca, which were later offered for purchase. All of this made for a grand time, and the trip passed too quickly. Due to weather conditions and landslide prevention, we transferred to a bus for the final portion of the trip. This is only necessary during rainy periods. Both train and bus are operated by the same company, so transfer was flawless. Both train and bus were on time throughout. A great experience!

Great service, on time. We totally enjoyed our train trip from Ollantaytambo to Aguas Calientes and back on the Vistadome. It had very comfortable seats with plenty of leg room. They were on time (or very close to it). The only reason that I do not give them 5 "stars" in my review is due to how hard it is to book the tickets in advance (which you have to do) from outside of Peru, or at least from the US. If anyone is reading this from Perurail, please get together with whoever sells the Machu Picchu passes and the bus tickets and put together a jumbo ticket good for all three. And make sure that you figure out how to sell these to people planning their trips while in another country. Even if we COULD get tickets after arriving in Peru, we don't want to spend our precious travel time doing that. I finally called the call center in Peru and managed to get tickets, but had to photocopy my drivers license and credit card and email the copy. Not a wise thing to do - but I went ahead and did it in order to get the tickets. I changed the credit card number as soon as I got back. Also - passengers, note that you can only take 5 kilos (11 lbs) with you in your bag. You won't need more than that, but you will have to make plans to have your big suitcases secured someplace until you get back from Aguas Calientes. They give you a nice snack (little sandwich or something) on board the train, by the way. So if you are running short on time, you won't starve.
You have to reserve it ahead. It was just good, clean, on time but the food is not good. If you can use the Hiram Wingam, it is so expensive but excelent.

A nice, picturesque ride from Ollantaytambo to Aguas Calientes. I got the train from Ollantaytambo to Aguas Calientes to see Macchu Picchu. I think the ride was only about 90 minutes. There were sky lights in the train which made the journey very appealing. Now this is really important: When you embark the train at Ollantaytambo you can only take a small carry on and I mean small! They will not allow you to get on board the train with suitcases or anything that is larger than your average carry on to get on to a plane. So what to do with your suit cases then? In Ollantaytambo we stayed at Hotel Tika Wasi Valley. Our small tour group left our suitcases at this hotel whilst we travelled on to Aguas Calientes. After we saw Macchu Picchu we travelled back to Hotel Tika Wasi Valley, picked them up and went on our way back to Cuzco. When you get off the train in Aguas Calientes you have to take your small baggage down the steps at the train station. There are vendors right on the train tracks!

Look elsewhere-poor service. I got the wrong confirmation date. Even though I contacted them within minutes. They still charged me 120 dollars to correct the error. I sent 15 emails and no one seemed to care.

Train Journey With A Difference. What English Network Rail would lay on food, drink, entertainment and a fashion show for a 2 hour journey. It was a truly memorable experience & even though the journey was cut short at Pachar, due to a known landslide, the transfer to buses was slick & meant we arrived in Cusco earlier than we would have on the train. Special mention to Elio who was very polite & attentive.

Beautiful Adventure. We took the Vistadome train to and from Aguas Calientes. We were upset that we were not told in advance that part of the rail was out, and we had to take a 1.75 hour train ride from Cusco to Pacha to board the train (both ways). Our tickets said Poroy which was only 15 minutes from Cusco but we weren't told we had to go MUCH further on the bus. Quite an inconvenience.Once we got on the train, it was beautiful. Mind you, this is the slowest train ever. I think it took 2 hours to go 20 miles. Sometimes it is like you are barely moving. But the service is great, they serve you a meal, the bathrooms are clean and tidied. It is definitely the most well-kept train I've been on. The scenery is beautiful and it's a great way to travel.I would recommend but be warned that half of our "train" journey may actually be a bus ride!

Great Trip. There is definitely a big difference between Vistadome and our experience on the Expedition train. Vistadome definitely felt more "first class" with the higher end decor, comfortable seats, nice snack, variety of beverage options and customer service. Our train was delayed by about a half hour and we were never given an explanation, which is the reasoning behind the four stars. Definitely pay the extra money for the Vistadome.

Excellent way to trip. I chose the Vista Dome because wanted to have the sky as ceiling... and I did. I was rewarded with good enough food and beverages. They promote during the trip local souvenirs. The trip was nice, enjoyable and if you want to sleep you can. You need to know during the rainy season (I don't know how it is during the other season) the trip is half way on a bus, half way on the train. The bus is comfortable. The train is much more comfortable sure.

Ok ride, but shorten due to rail issues and value. I had the chance to ride both the Expedition and Vistadome on the same day. While I enjoyed the train ride while there was still some light to view outside, once darkness arrived, the view is lost.The seating is comfy,but little legroom when all the seating is full.The seating was the same as the Expedition and the snack offered was on the same par as the Expedition.The famous fashion show wasn't as bad like many stated. You could tell the employees were going through the motions. The pricing was very high and unless you are press, there are better pricing elsewhere.The service was good. From the station to the bus ride, the employees made announcements in both English and Spanish and if you had a question, someone was there to answer.Overall while I enjoy the ride, the issues with a shorten train ride (due to rail conditions between Cusco and Pachar), traveling mainly in the dark limiting viewing, sames seating on both trains and happen to ride the Expedition on the first leg to Aquas Calientes. I would ride the Expedition instead.

Nice views. Its a nice ride, no one cant really say anything against that. The prices do, i mean they can charge u what they do because its not really any options and thats always a bit annoying. But still a nice ride with nice views.
spectacular scenery. The comfort and excellent views through the overhead windows were worth the extra cost, in our opinion. The afternoon return trip from Macchu Pichu was very slow, though.

Vistadome. We travelled to Aquas Calientes on the Vistadome in early April, The train service was punctual and comfortable. The little snack on board was a pleasant surprise. The waiting area at the station, although very busy was clean and adequate with announcements for departures being clear and frequent. (english & spanish) We had been advised that large suitcases were not accepted on board, so decided that an overnight bag was adequate for a 2 day visit. It was amazing the size of the luggage some passengers managed to take on board with them As mentioned by other travellers, we were not seated together, as was nearly everyone else on the train. This was soon sorted out in the first 5 minutes and all part of the experience. On the way back I was seated amongst a large family from Belgium who treated me as one of their own and kept us entertained with their bargaining experience with the stewardess.My sister ended up seated in an aisle seat with people she didn't know. This was a shame for her as she was so excited and would have loved to see more out of the window. Instead, the woman in the window seat proceeded to read a book all the way home. Unbelievable!At the time of the booking we were unaware of problems with landslides. However the connecting buses were well co-ordinated. (Our bus driver was intent on overtaking on hairpin bends, but with much haggling from all passengers, he was then content to take his time and entertain us with 80's music at 100 decibels all the way back to Cusco). This is no reflection on the train service, just part of travelling in Peru.I would recommend this service to anyone. The little stories just make travel interesting.

Good experience, great views.. Our tour groups experience was without incident and very pleasant. The train was comfortable, seating adequate and sevice was good. It was nice to have beverages and snacks served. On the return trip from Aguas Calientes, we even had a fashion show! But the highlight was really the scenery along the way. We'd heard of other headaches on this rail line, but our trip was fine. I could see how bad weather can create hazards on the tracks. Weather was great when we were there in April. Sounds like you have to be alert to possible problems during the rainy season.

May not be worth the extra $$. I really enjoyed the view of the mountains through the extra windows on this train. However, that seems to be the only thing that you are paying extra for. The ride to Aguas Calientes was ok except for the Andean music playing overhead at an irritatingly loud volume. I almost had to yell to talk to people right next to me. It would have been just fine if it was "background" music, but it wasn't. Then I realized why the music was blasting when the attendants came around with a cart of stuff to try to sell us, including the CD they had been playing. Then came the ride back, where we remained boarded on the train, in the station for almost 2 hours before moving. Other trains came and left. There was an issue with our train, but I would think that we could have been transferred to another train to get on with our vacation. Nobody ever told us what the delay was about or offered anything for our wasted time. By the time we finally got going it was almost dark, so I couldn't see anything out of the windows anyhow. The lights inside remained on so there was too much glare to see anything during sunset. We then got to watch a "fashion show" with more loud music. This was also so that the attendents could try to sell us more stuff. This train would be much nicer without being solicited while trying to enjoy your ride. If I went again, I may save my money and go on the cheaper train.

Nice view; very slow ride; return trip was switched to a bus 1/2 way. NIce train. Very clean. Slow ride, but you'd expect this going up hill. No room for suitcases so only take essential items and forward the rest of your gear to your return hotel.....unless you are going for more than 2 days, etc....then take a big bag. The train porters will let you board with a big suitcase. I saw many doing so even though the tickets says 5 kg max. The porters won't give you a hard time but just know that once you get to AC you need to be able to manage your suitcase on your own. We downsized and kept our essentials in our backpacks then went to our AC hotel before we visited MP; therefore avoiding lugging suitcases around AC. I think this is good advice that you should try to follow if practical. AC is hilly with cobbled streets, busy marketplaces etc. It's a walking town but it could turn into a big PIA if you are lugging a suitcase around....(my opinion). The train was nice as I mentioned before. Nice views, etc. However we had booked a return ticket to Poroy but were told that half way down the hill we would be transferred to a bus. This is apparently done frequently during the rainy season. It really wasn't a big deal. They were well organized and the buses were clean and ready to go when the train pulled into the station...one word of advice is to use the restroom on the train before you disembark at the bus pick up spot or you will be stuck in a long line for the restroom, thus in the back of the line for the bus assignments. They tried to assign my family of 4 to a nearly full bus where we'd all have to sit next to strangers and we requested to sit together so they moved us to an open bus where we could sit together. Fortunately our bus driver drove safely (unlike a previous traveler). We arrived at the Cusco bus station then caught a taxi to our hotel. I really didn't mind this transfer. The train is so slow (even downhill), that I think we ended up saving a small bit of time and also by the time we switched to the busses it was almost dark out so I don't feel like I missed seeing anything, etc. I'm just sorta thinking they should give us a refund of a few bucks cause the train ticket wasn't cheap and approx 1/4 of the journey was on a bus which should be significantly less...but anyhow it wasn't enough to irritate me too bad cause I had just seen MP which was spectacular. All I cared about was staying relatively on schedule so we'd get to Cusco in time for dinner etc then catch our flight out the next day.

A nice option. We opted for the Vistadome because of the open ceiling view, but sadly, it was rainy on our way in the Aguas Calientes and it was night time on our way out, so we didn't get the full feel for the view. The small meals were a surprise and were enough of a snack to help. Service on the train was very good and prompt. The train was also very clean and well-maintained. My husband and I were not booked to sit together on one of our trips and managed to coordinate with those around us to be together. Gladly, the staff did not challenge this.

Travel to Machu Picchu in comfort. The train is comfortable, and the views from the expansive windows superb. I went in April, when, because of very heavy rains, the first half of the trip was via bus. Not too bad, and everything will well coordinated by staff. Be sure to check the Peru Rail web site for changes to itinerary due to extreme weather conditions during the rainy season.There was a snack and beverage provided going and coming, as well as a fashion show (you can purchase right on the train), and a bit of entertainment from a fanciful clown.Worth the expense

Currently Coach+Train Service. We caught the last of the four daily Peru Rail services out to Machu Picchu, and on the following day the earlier Vistadome service on the return leg (getting into Cusco just as it got dark). We'd booked and planned our trip in advance, and not been aware of the Inca Rail service from Ollantaytambo.At present the service involves a coach pickup from Wanchaq, Cusco, that takes you to Pachar Station via Urabamba (Sacred Valley). The coach portion of the journey was 1:45, and admittedly we really enjoyed the scenery along the way. At Pachar we did have delays of over an hour, which was very disappointing for those who were only on a day trip to Machu Picchu. There was no compensation, only talk that the problem with the engine was beyond Peru Rail's control.The train journey is pleasant and scenic, and on the way to Machu Picchu its probably best to be sat on the left side of the carriage. Food is basic, as are the drinks on offer. On the return journey there is a fashion show, which wasn't as cringe-worthy as we'd feared. Still felt it was a steep price for what it was.

A Really Fun Train Ride!. The Vistadome train to Machu Picchu from Cusco is really a great experience! The train is very clean and modern and the Vistadome provides a great view as you go into the beautiful Andes mountains. Service on the train is good with plenty of opportunities to buy trinkets. A wonderful experience!

what a trip. Despite the change in path of train due to work after the period d rains Perurail that operates Vistadome proved to be very organized in advance indicating all changes. After boarding we were able to enjoy a delicious trip to Aguas Calientes at the foot of Macchu Pichu. The train is very comfortable and worth the price difference on the value of the basic train. The buffet option included in the Sanctuary Lodge in Machu Pichu is only average, it is possible to eat better restaurants in Aguas Calientes in wait for the return train. We were lucky on our visit to Macchu Pichu because the day before and following our view it rained. So I recommend to everyone to schedule their visits outside the rainy season, and if possible more than one day available to visit the park.

Does not worh the money if you travel in group. The difference in service does not worth a dollar, they try to sell you alpaca clothes that are at a decent price (maybe the best on board). The food is really bad, the rest of the facilities are not really better than the "budget" oriented Expedition train version. Just worth the more than an hour later that this train departs form Aguas Calientes.

For groups of 4 or more does not worth the money. During the rainy season, The Perurail attraction from Cusco to Machu Pichu just cover half or less of the trip. They take you in a bus to Pacha station from Cusco. The train transport passengers within the canyon formed by the Urubamba River. So the views, always beautiful are not really scenic neither better than form the trail or the road. If you travel alone do take the Perurail using the cheapest version "Expedition". If you travel in group, you'll save money and confort renting a van with driver directly with the owner (120 to 150 USD the day) if 4 or less a cab would do the trick for even less and the views will be the same, and your schedule will be flexible!

Going back to Cusco from Machu Piccchu. We finished the 4 day hike and returned to Cusco on the train.The actual train journey was fine, but 1/2 way we needed to change to busses because the train didn't go any further.I knew that Preu busses didn't have a great reputation, but we had been on a few already and they were ok, and this was from a big company.However, we were appalled by the way the driver drove the bus.It was dark, and he drove like he was on a race track. Constantly shifting down from 4th to 2nd around every bend, taking the wrong side of the road and as fast as he could.When we caught up with other vehicles, he would sit inches from the back of it, flashing his lights and then over taking at any point, including blind corners.He would randomly leave his full beam lights on when vehicles were coming in the other direction, making them have to flash him.To be honest, I'm surprised we made it back to Cusco without a serious accident.If possible I would seek alternative transport, as this company just seems to hire people with no ability to drive anywhere near safely.

Our Vistadome train service was mainly a coach/minibus.. I was looking forward to getting the Vistadome as it was recommended by a collegue. The day before we were meant to be travelling we received an e-mail saying that the train wasn't running and we had to go to a different station to get a bus for the first 2 hours of the 3.5 hour journey! Given that most of the people getting the train were travelling I was amazed that it appeared that everyone had got the message - so if you have booked make sure you check your e-mail right up untl you travel! The coach on the way was quite pleasant but on the way back we were cramped up in a little minibus for 2 hours. There wasn't even an apology for the lack of train. On the plus side the vistadome train itself is really nice and the views of the mountains were fantastic - it was just a shame we were on it for so little time. You can see large portions of the Inca Trail with the Porters racing ahead of all the tourists walking up. I was also surprised at how nice the food they served was. There were clean toilets at all of the stations on route and on the train itself.
Great way to visit Machu Picchu. Nice big windows, decent food make for a fun way to travel. It was a great way to see the countryside and also to meet other travelers.

enjoyable train ride. The Vistadome to Machu Picchu was a scenic and comfortable ride. The scenery through the mountains all the way up was beautiful. They had a "fashion show" entertainment on the way down and snacks for us both ways.

Rail to Machhupiccu. The rail service was amazing. the cars had huge windows extending into the roof so the view was amazing. For the return trip it became dark so the staff after food service put on a fashion show. It was very upbeat. Comfortable and the snaks were good.

Best for seeing views. This train provides excellent windows for almost 360 views. Service is more than adequate. Breakfast is basic but nice to have. Restrooms are bigger than most train toilets. Our particular trip was detained on tracks for over 3 hours due to a mudslide.(Dec,28,2012) Although frustrating, to have to wait, staff offered regular updates on progress of debris removal. Managed to still have enough time upon arrival at Machu Pichu to have lunch at Sanctuary Lodge and then tour site. Return trip uneventful. Onboard Fashion show entertaining to say the least.

Overrated. I wish I had looked into the alternatives (Inca Rail, etc) as this train was nice but overpriced for the services offered. If you do take the Vistadome, make sure to travel during daylight hours, (finish travel by 6 p.m.) because the view is really the only thing worth the money.

Great way to see Machu Picchu, but beware the rainy season. The vistadome train is very modern and clean on the inside and the staff are highly attentive. The only problem (and this is true of all the trains) is that during the rainy season, the track near Cusco is closed and passengers have to take a bus for the first hour of the journey to go meet the train.
nice train. The Vistadome is a unique experience, since you have a complete view of the surroundings during the trip. And they try theyr best to entertain you, with dances, shows.

Vistadome puts you in touch with the mountains. Is any place in the world as enchanting as Machu Picchu? Although the Vistadome is more expensive, due to some problems with altitude and food differences, I knew the older, rocky Hiram Bingham Train might prove counterproductive. We chose the Vistadome not only for its smoother ride, but in order to see the tops of the mountain passes. The entire trip felt like a postcard. Dappled light through the roof as clouds skimmed overhead. The river raging next to the rails. Delightful fellow passengers on the train. Great weather added to the mood, but I would think even rain would be more inviting if one could look up and see it falling from the sky. Worth the extra money in our opinion, as we arrived in MP refreshed and excited to continue the feeling of discovery, not beat and tired, as some of our friends who chose the older trains.

Very nice ride. We rode the Hiram Bingham to Machu Picchu and the Vistadome back. The Vistadome was very comfortable, but it can't be compared to the Hiram Bingham. They are a totally different experience. In relation to the Hiram Bingham, we thought the Vistadome was priced about right, you have great visibility, and we enjoyed the ride.

Pleasant train ride. The Vistadome only added to the thrill of going to Machu Picchu. The train was on time, very clean, and the view was fantastic. Seats were leather, comfortable and they served snacks during the trip. Watching the river rush by and seeing the beautiful mountain peaks was absolutely breathtaking.

Fabulous views. We were so glad to have traveled on the Vistadome rather than the Expedition because being able to look out overhead we were able to see the mountain tops; very high!!! They have healthy type snacks on there and sell some local items. You can also order drinks on there. Overall a very cool atmosphere.
Vista Dome rides better than the Expedition!. A large difference in ride quality may make the Vistadome a decent value. Twas dark when we rode it, so no scenic benefit derived.

Scenery - Wow!. Try to get seats on the left side of the train as the scenery is excellent. Mountain passes, tunnels, waterfalls...just beautiful. The also serve a small breakfast on the way up in the morning and a snack on the way back in the afternoon. Beverage service is also included. It is worth it to stay overnight in Aguas Calientes (Machu Picchu town) if you have the time. We stayed at the Sumac and it was good.

Vistadome worth the extra money. I should qualify my title. We were in Cusco in February, so any of the less expensive trains are fine in the rainy season. Suggest you give yourself an extra day...incase the train tracks wash out. This is pretty common in the rainy season. Our friends missed MP because it rained for 3 straight days and the tracks were flooded. We took Vistadome and we enjoyed the comfort of the seats as well as the snack. However, the Expedition train that time of years would have been just as good.

Don't spend extra for the Vistadome. Our tour group was split up because the rest of the group took the regular train. I wish I had not spent the extra $75 for the Vistadome. The only place we looked out was the window beside us. There were no views up above and I thought it would be completely domed over with glass and it only had a small window above. The food was not any better and I would have been happier to think beforehand to bring something to eat. But the trip was quick and I didn't really need to eat. The seats were comfortable but the rest of our group said theirs were fine. We did have a good fashion show and at the time I didn't know it but the prices were actually good so if you like something go ahead and buy it. Unless the seats are so important for you save the money and take the regular train.
Great entertainment, nice views. View was nice with clear domed top, snacks good, & they provided entertainment, so the ride went fast.

A great ride.. What an excellent way to reach the site. Comfy seats, large windows with great views, you get a snack and drink on board which is included in price, and they even stopped train so passengers could see points of interest along the way.

One of the highlights of our trip!. One of the highlights of our trip! We had such a luck! I brought the tickets way in advance and therefore we got the first seats in the vehicle; which meant having a big window in front of us, allowing us to take the best pictures and enjoy the breathtaking landscape outside!!

Incredible. We took the Vistadome form Ollantaytambo to Machu Picchu. and back. A ride in this train with its Glass domes and large windows is worth every penny, it was the middle of the day, bright sunshine, the view was incredible. The snacks were ordinary but the staff were efficient and professional. Would like to do it again.

One of the best staff I met for train travel. On 30 Jan 2013, I was in Cuzco, supposed to travel on Tren 303 from Ollantaytambo to Aguas Calientes. I was delayed while waiting inside a collectivo in Cuzco but was subsequently led by the bus station people to the shared taxi station 10m next door. There I met Alfredo del Castilo, who wore Perurail uniform and told me I could follow him and be assured to reach Ollantay in time as he would be travelling on the same train with me.Needless to say, we took the same shared taxi and arrived on time. He led me to the Ollantay station while showing me where to take the collectivo back to Cuzco the next day after I had visited Machu Picchu. On the train, on hearing that I need assistance in finding a hotel, he offered to help. Indeed, on arrival at Aguas Calientes, he did go with me and helped to negotiated a good price for a hostel for the night. This is certainly appreciated given that I speak only about 50 simple, broken words of Spanish. And then I found out his position in Perurail Machu Picchu station.The next day, 31st Jan 2013, when I returned to Machu Picchu station again, Alfredo was there looking out for me to ensure that I was alright with the hostel. He also reuested the on-board train staff to assist me if required.And Celso Rios on the train asked whether I needed help to get a taxi or collectivo back to Cuzco. He accompanied me outside Ollantay station to ensure I had a seat on the collectivo before he left.Thanks Alfredo (and Celso). You made Perurail a preferred way to travel.Henry

Odd but beautiful. The train was very average, but the view along the way was incredible. The seats were comfortable, the snacks, edible, the beer, cold. I did not like taking the train only halfway to Cusco on the return. The bus ride to Cusco was long, horrible, and boring. I also did not appreciate the sales pitch to buy alpaca stuff on the train--and the weird "fashion" show that we had to endure. Or the weird dancing shaman on the train. Odd, very odd. The view from the train, however, was incredible. The trains did run on time.

Don't believe the hype.. Well, we took the Vistadome train from Machu Picchu at the end of March, but we only rode the train to Poroy, then we were put on motor coaches to continue the rest of the way to Cusco. The only explanation for this was a prerecorded message saying something about the "rainy season" affecting the train service. We left @ 5:30 pm and arrived at an empty Perurail depot in Cusco @ 9:30 pm. Our transfer person said the other buses from our train had arrived @ 20 minutes earlier. We were not told we would be taking a bus until we arrived at the Machu Picchu station. We paid more for this train as was stated by other reviewers, but did not actually ride on the train for more than half the return trip. The train from the Sacred Valley the morning before was also inferior to the evening train today. The trains themselves are similar to commuter trains in the US, not like long distance trains there or in Europe. You can't really get up and move around, though there is a bathroom at the end of the car, but only 2 passenger cars and no food car. The view is nice, but you really only see the river from the right window seats and the overhead windows are essentially not functional. Don't expect the "meal" to be worth eating or adequate as both were smaller and less appetizing than bad airplane food. Luckily we ate breakfast at our hotel in the morning and lunch in Machu Picchu before the afternoon trip. We were treated to a fashion show of sorts by the train food service crew hawking "alpaca" products for sale on the pm train. It was somewhat amusing at best. The pm bus driver also answered his mobile phone twice and was driving with one hand while conversing with the caller in the dark on poorly lit local roads which were hilly and often populated with stray dogs along the side of the road. Our transfer person stated this is not legal in Peru, but that many people do it none-the-less. We were on the train leaving Machu Picchu in March, but I won't say exactly when as my friend on the same trip was afraid the driver would be fired for driving and using his phone. I really only want the company to enforce the phone ban on its drivers due to concerns about the safety of its passengers. I also tried to use the bathroom on the bus after a few hours in transit, but one of the train staff said it was not possible and the bathroom door was locked. I wish someone would have told us to use the train or station restrooms before boarding the buses. Luckily it was not an emergency. The seating assignments were odd also. I was traveling with 3 other people and we were seated in 3 different rows. Others around me swapped seats to travel with their companions. We arranged this trip 6 months ago and this is supposed to be low or shoulder season. I heard one passenger remark that it appeared the train company had made no effort whatsoever to seat passengers together. Ironically, at the end of the trip, they played a recorded message which stated they hoped it had been "an unforgettable trip"... It was.

Magic train ride. Unfortunately due to flooding we were bused for a couple of hours from Cusco, before getting on the train for the last 1+hours of the journey to Machu Picchu. The train was comfortable, the snacks provided were great. The staff provided great entertainment of the return journey. The scenery is breathtaking and time passed quickly!

Wonderful - BUT - Save money and ride the Expedition. We rode this train from Pachar to Aguas Calientes - the view is wonderful, it is about 1 and a half hours each way, travelling through the valley next to the surging Urubamba River. Although we thoroughly enjoyed this train ride (comfortable leather seats, morning and afternoon snack and beverage, glass top sections for better viewing, dance demonstration in the PM), we don't feel it was worth the extra $76 dollars on our tour vs. the Expedition train. The coffee was not good, the snacks were not worth the extra money (bag your own), and you can't see much through the top - better viewing is the side windows. Next time (and we will be back to the unbelievably beautiful Machu Picchu!) we will save the money and ride the Expedition - $76 gets you two nice lunches and two decent dinners!

Vistadome is worth it...if not just for the view!. I've lived in Cusco for almost a year, having been to Machu Picchu 8 times...lucky for me my company CAT Travel organizes customized trips through Peru, so I've made the trip to Machu Picchu trekking it (Inca Trail), training it (Expedition, Vistadome, & Hiram Bingham), and even one time I was with some old backpacker buddies and walked the train tracks to the town of Aguas Calientes! I will go ahead and NOT recommend that last option, if you wanna walk it...do the trek! In any case, the most reasonable option is the middle one, the Vistadome. It's not the fanciest of trains, however, the view from the cabin is truly incredible...why you might ask? Well, you can see where all the beautiful mountains touch the sky, and the curves and dives into the valley, without sticking your head out the window and pushing your friends for the window seat. On this train...everyone has what is seemingly ONE big window! The quarter panels of the ceiling on the train are made of Plexiglas, which means everyone gets to enjoy from wherever they are in the train. Yes, the food (or should I say snack) they provide is worthless, but if you want good food...well, you should find a local-minded guy (like me) who can recommend some good restaurants when you get there...or when you return to Cusco. Oh, and by the way, stay the extra night in Machu Picchu, sunrise over the ruins is incredible, and totally worth it after a long haul down to see such a beautiful site. Side note: If you're looking for fancy, go with the Hiram Bingham...there they will treat you like a king with a 3-course meal. If you're on a tight budget, just do the Expedition train...it gets you there comfortably (food is still worthless:)! See my post on Machu Picchu for more...!

OMG! So worth it!. What a fantastic way to travel. Our day was beautiful and we got the full affect of the windows - see up in tree tops, sides of mountains, down in the river, across the fields and mountains - very very comfortable trip!
Fantastic train!. We loved the vistadome! Extremely comfortable, nice lunch, fashion show and some entertainment on the way.The trip is worth every penny. Countryside stunning!

Nothing to write home about. Its in my opinion and over hyped train. Its very expensive. They gave a box with a sandwich and water, that was nice. The thing that i didnt like is that the trayect is actually quite short and they charge a HUGE amount of money for that. But all in all the view is something special. So for me its a nice view with a big price trag.
Terrific view, great service. It was a very pleasant trip, food was good, comfortable ride, good service...view from the Vistadome was terrific.

Train to Machu Picchu. Great way to get from Cusco to Machu Picchu. Comfortable, plenty of room and a complimentary beverage and snack were served. Train was prompt, staff were friendly and helpful. Nice big windows allowing ample viewing of the surroundings we passed.
Great scenery along the way. Other than having to get up at o dark thirty to catch the train you will enjoy chugging along the mountain side to marvel at all the outstanding beauty.
Wonderful train ride. Vista dome train is great way to visit Machu Pichhu. Staff on the train was very friendly and meals were served with style. We enjoyed this ride.

Great train ride. The Vistadome was great to get more light into the train. The windows on top didn't help you get a better view. I think this train is the middle of the road version, the Inca Rail the lower version, and the Hiram Bingham the high end version. Be forewarned on the way back they put on a fashion show to try to sell you the alpaca clothing. The train staff is cute and make it fun- but it lengthens the ride back.
train to Aguas Calientes. Fabulous service, a nice meal served. Had a fashion show and folkloric dancers on the way back. Clean and punctual.

this is one train ride you need to do.... one of Peru's well kept open secret...no visit to Peru and machu pichu is complete without a ride on the Vistadome...Peru Rail take a bow...simply beautiful...great staff...i love the zig zag (you will know) when you actually take the ride)...and of course the fashion show on board courtesy the service staff and the ticket collector...what a lovely way to sell merchandize...simply brilliant...all marketing gurus...they dont teach this at harvard business school...

expensive and comfortable. We traveled from Ollantaytambo to Aquas Calientes and back. outstanding scenery from the glass windows. The ride was smooth and seats were comfortable. The scenery was breathtaking. Rushing river, snowcovered mountains, rainforests...Staff was friendly. Poor food.
Wonderful!!. The train was on time, exactly what we expected and the views unbelievable. Our trip back was full of fun and entertainment with lots of laughs galore.

Vistadome train to machu picchu. Window seat gives one the best view of the mountains, waterfalls, rivers and Peruvian villages.A boxed breakfast and lunch was served, nondescript food. The weather was spectacular, photos from the moving train turned out spectaculr! 2 days after my Machu Picchu lifetime expeirience, service was terminated due to rain ,for about 2 weeks? I thank Pacha Mamma.!!

Wonderful scenery. We rode the train from Olantaytambo to Machu Picchu Pueblo. Very pleasant except when all the windows fogged up and had to open all the windows to clear them. Snacks were served almost as soon as we got on the train. The staff on the way to Machu Picchu seemed very indifferent. Not the norm for anything else we had encountered in Peru. The return trip was totally different. Smiling faces and even a fashion show of Clothing for sale made from Baby Alpaca.

Worst customer service I have experienced in my 58 years. Bought tickets online, Date of departure was wrong. After 4-5 emails with no resolve it took (no kidding) 5+ hours in two different train ticket offices in Cusco Peru to resolve and even then Perurail charged me 10% more for their mistake! Never again will I ride the worlds most expensive train! Train was OK but needed to take a bus for about 1/2 the trip which was never disclosed prior to purchase or departure. The train staff was nice and friendly and the trip was great but the prices for the tickets and coustomer service couldn't be worse. A shame a world tourist site is being held hostage by greed!

This is the train to take. If you can get past the infuriatingly arduous process of procuring tickets, the actual trip to Machu Picchu is fairly nice.The views were spectacular, and this train (the Vistadome) was smoother and more comfortable than the Expedition. Definitely worth the marginal increase in price.Those recommending the Expedition to save money must not have actually ridden it. If you enjoy a rickety ride and uncomfortable seats, then, by all means, choose the Expedition. It's not about the view or the snack - the Expedition is noticeably unstable, and it makes for a jarring 3-hour trip. So, unless you have very deep pockets and consider the Hiram Bingham a viable option, go with the Vistadome. Service was cordial and attentive, but the "entertainment" was a bit much for the ride home. Exhausted and still glowing from the whole Machu Picchu experience, we wanted to reflect and relax. The singing and dancing, while well-intended, was intrusive at a time when we all just wanted to be left alone. Demanding audience participation from tired travelers is bad form.Still, this train is the best option.

The only transportation to get Machu Picchu. Good quality of service but prices are quite high.. There are no roads that connect Aguas Caliente (also called Machu Picchu Pueblo) to the outside world. You take the train all the way from Cusco or you take a train Ollantaytambo (take a bus or taxi from Cusco to Ollantaytambo). The only other real alternative is by foot. Only company operating train to Machu Picchu is Peru Rail. Few services run between Cusco to Machu Picchu. Most of the train services run between Ollantaytambo and Machu Picchu.Reservations must be done with plenty of time (one week or more on peak months) in advance due the high demand on this trip (no orad except train or Inca trail). Buy your tickets well in advance on online. Do not wait until you arrive in Cusco or Ollantaytambo to buy ticket especially the peak months from May to Sept. All of tikcet can be sold out serval days in advance. There are three type of train: Vistadome, Expedition (reasonable price), Hiram Bingham (exclusive luxury). It has good qualityof service but prices are quite high. One thing I did not like about Peru rail is that train attentants asked me and all passengers serveral time to buy Alfaca products and clothes they are selling on the train. I paid $129 for round trip from Ollantaytambo to Aguas Calient, 2 hours travelling time, 47 km each way.

Panoramic windows offering scenic views and photographic opprtunties. Good quality of service but price are quite high. There are three types of train running from Cusco - Ollantaytambo - Machu |Picchu (Aguas Caliente): Vistadome, Expedition, Hiram Bingham. If you have choice to buy ticket what you want, you can chose one of three types of train. But reservations must be done with plenty of time in advance. All of the train ticket (especially Expedition, Vistadome which is lot cheaper than Hiram Bingham) can be sold out several days in advance. Do not wait until you arrive in Cuzco or Ollantaytambo t buy train ticket. Vistadome train is surrounded entirely by glass and sagons with large panoramic windows offering magnificient scenic views and opportunities to capture pictures. It serve snack and hot refreshments.

Fun, but Overpriced Transportation to Machu Picchu. My wife and I took the Vistadome to Agua Calientes. The 57 miles trip from Cusco to the foot of Machu Picchu took us about 3 1/2 hours. The early morning trip was a lot of fun and exposed the passengers to the scenic countryside. The 3 cars were packed with tourists anxiously awaiting their first glimpse of Machu Picchu. We sat in groups of four around a small wooden table. A very light snack was served along with fresh tea or coffee on a decorative tablespread. Tranquil Peruvian pan flutes piped out soothing sounds in the background. The crew was courteous and friendly. The seating in Vistadome is adequate and comfortable.I estimate the train never exceeded 30 mph, so the trip was long, but offered an opportunity for those of us not in a hurry to savor the beautiful views offered by Mother Nature. The ceiling windows came in handy when it came time to capture some very tall mountain peaks with camera. (not sure it was worth the extra $35 per pax, though). The various switchbacks along the tracks enabled the train to easily climb and descend the 400 meter difference in altitude. The train ride was relatively smooth, and the interior of the cars are maintained impeccably clean. Seats are assigned prior to boarding, so there is none of the usual scrambling to find seats. Passengers who wanted to be seat near a friend or loved one can work it out amongst each other.The Vistadome costs an additional $35 per pax over the cost of an Expedition train ticket. If you are on a budget, I would consider sticking with the Expedition... you won't be missing much. A little extra view and a meager snack is not worth the extra money. Overall, I would say the train is abit of a novelty, fun to ride, but way overpriced (around $140 US) for the service provided. However, the only other option to get to Machu Picchu is the Inca Trail. I prefer to go by rail. LOL.There is no handicap access aboard the trains or stations.

...not worth paying the extra $$.... ..we traveled Vistadome from Ollaytantambo to Aguas (Machu Picchu) and then Expedition from Aguas to Cusco. ...The travel to Aguas was very comfortable and you received a brunch/snack. Scenery was lovely, but we'd spent 4 days in Ollay already so it was much the same for the 1.5 hour journey. On saying that, we probably could have dropped down to the Expedition to save some money. ...However, from Aguas to Cusco on the Expedition, this was meant to be 3.5 hour trip. We ended up being delayed on the travel for 1 hour in the midst of the journey and were not given any explanation of the delay. Our trip was then a 4.5 hour. We were very lucky we didnt have a connecting bus that same night, which we originally planned to do, as we would have missed it. ...overall, I think this train service is overpriced for what it is. Its quite slow, so if you were to do the train one of you legs and perhaps look for an alternative for the other leg, you will save a lot of time and $$...
Vistadome is the way to go!. Greatly enjoyed the views from the VistaDome train to and from Machu Picchu. Definitely worth the extra money to enjoy of of the world's most beautiful places.

Gorgeous Views. Worth every penny to take this train and enjoy gorgeous views along the river. Snack is disappointing for the kind of train it is. Very comfortable ride. There is a sales pitch for genuine alpaca garments which are a bit higher price than what you can find in a good store in Cusco. Yes, genuine Alpaca!!! not imitations.

Mixed feelings. The best part of this experience was the travel time . We decided NOT to purchase our tickets through their web site due to many published problems and complaints. I really don't know if these people (The Peru Rail management) , have any idea of what means QUALITY CONTROL . They have a MONOPOLY in their hands , and instead to be happy and make it working for ALL ( Us and them ) They try their BEST to make you to want to NEVER come back . !! In the other hand , the ON train employees ( extra polite professionals ), and the great views helped to balance the negative feelings . !!!

Scenic Trip. We took the Vistadome Train from Ollantaytambo to Aguas Calientes and back. The Vistadome is a very cool train with windows on the roof so you can look out at the beautiful mountains and other scenery. We were in 1st class, which serves you lunch. It was a tasty, light and refreshing meal consisting of a sandwich, some fruit and a beverage. The ride itself was very smooth and we enjoyed it a lot. The only negative was on the train back to Ollantaytambo there were performers/sales people putting on a very loud show with the same song playing over and over. I wasn’t feeling very well and wanted to take a nap but that was not possible as the show/sales pitch went on for almost the entire ride. At the train station in Ollantaytambo there were bathrooms and a few restaurants/cafes as well as many people selling local crafts and bottled water. At the train station in Aguas Calientes there were restaurants and many, many stalls with people selling local crafts and clothing as well as bottled water.

Great way to see the Sacred Valley. The Vistadome was a most comfortable train that took us from Agua Calliente to just outside of Cusco. The service was great and included a fashion show and dancing presentation. It was a wonderful way to transition from the Sacred Valley, Macchu Pichu to Cusco.

Great comfort & service with a fashion show.. I travelled with a group of 27 from Cusco to Machu Picchu and then from Machu Picchu to Sacred Valley. Both trips on the Vistadome were wonderful. Food was interesting and good. The scenery is breath-taking and with lots of variety: from plain-lands, deep valleys and rushing rivers. Staff were courteous, friendly and helpful. The native dance and fashion parade were wonderful and I loved how the staff were flexible and gave us space to look at the lovely garments and try them on. If you have ordered a garment - don't forget to pick it up at the station on arrival.

Glad we got the Window Seats!!!. We guess it was karma, but we ended up getting the two seats on the Vista dome train to Machu Picchu right behind the picture window and next to the engineer. If not, we believe the trip would not have been as wonderful as it was, as some of the seats in the car are placed so you are traveling backwards, and although there are large side windows by each seat, the "vista dome" windows are small and narrow above the seats. So, when you contact Peru Rail (we went through Avanti Adventures and Condor Travel of Peru, so did not select the seats ourselves), make sure to find out how to get these two seats assigned to you!That aside, we were very impressed with Peru Rail. The stations at both Machu Picchu Pueblo (Aguas Calientes) and Ollantaytambo wee spotless, with clean banos (even had TP which is a rarity in Peru) and waiting room facilities. The trains were spot on, time-wise, and although crowded, the people in the station kept people moving to their trains.

Take the rail to machu picchu andthey serve food and the sights are amazing. After hiking, great ride back and surprises with a. The train was a fun way to go to the last stop where the hot spring sits. Love the staff and entertainment. I dont want to ruin the surprise on the way back, but it was creative. The train was on time and clean and felt very safe. What a fun country to visit! Tell that gorgeous conductor to wait for me, i will be back. !

Great Trip. The service in this train is great! We had a great trip to Machu Picchu and back. A good tip is to leave Cusco from the Poroy station which is closer to Cusco City. Make sure your trip goes from Poroy to Machu Picchu and back.

Nice train, the roof window is a bit pointless though. Very nice train. Anyone familiar with the golden age of steam will like the somewhat nostalgic feel of the train itself (although I emphatically point out it's not a steam train!). The service is decent, but the "snack" that had so much fuss made of it is pretty meagre considering the price, and you have no option, so if you're a veggie and today's option is meaty, you're stuck. However, you will have the sweet or cake to nibble on which comes with it. It's quite pricey, and I'm not sure I could really justify the cost considering that it's not that spacey when full, and the service is just ok. The ends of getting up to Aguas Calientes however really justify the means.

Fantastic Scenery. When travelling on the Vistadome try and get a seat on the left hand side of the train travelling towards Machu Pichu as this is the more open side with the best views over the river and up the mountain sides. The views were stunning with rapids, snow covered caps, rain forests, a huge variety of vegetation.

Love it!!. My husband and I went from Ollantaitambo to Machu Picchu, our seats were 1 & 2, the best seats!! we had nothing in front of us just the spectacular view!!It is worth every dollar we spent.On the way there it was early in the morinig so they gave us a mini breakfast, fruit, tea and cookies, on the way back was late afternoon so we got pasta salad and a soda.
