There was not anyone there to direct us so we stood outside in a line to speak to the person in the booth because we thought we needed a ticket in exchange for our email ticket but this was not the case....and no one told us, we simply got tired of waiting in the line.Once the boarding started, it went quickly, have your passport ready for inspection along with the email ticket that you rec'vd. Seating is really cramped as you are seated in a 4 top. a table divides you from the 2 people across from you, but it is difficult to stretch out your legs as you kick the person in front of you.The snack that they give you is nice. I like the attention to detail that they offer. They set the table including a little cactus for decoration; I thought that was a nice touch. The breakfast was good, the meals are vegetarian. Coming back, it was the same bottle neck situation with having to be at the station for 30 mins in advance again without a clear purpose. In the evening, you also get a hot snack, vegetarian which was also good. They provided entertainment, a dancer and then a fashion show. I understand why they would want to entertain the guest, but after hiking all day and having such an early morning, you simply want to sleep on the way back. I actually made out better as i had a 2 seater on the way back so I was able to stretch out my legs.the rail attendants were professional and courteous, the appearance of the cars were nice and clean.p.s. get your entrance ticket to Machu Picchu first, then get your rail ticket. I did the reverse, couldn't get a ticket to Machu Picchu on the same day of the rail ticket as they sold out, then had to pay a penalty to Perurail to change my ticket to go the next day. I was not happy about the 10% penalty. I could see if it was at the last minute, but it was weeks before I was due to travel.

Rocking The Rails. We rode in First Class to Machu Pichu, and Coach Class back to Poroy (Cusco). It was the same, 3.5 hours, a bit cramped. But the ride back to Poroy was fun. After the meal service which was good enough served with standard free beverages, the real drinks arrived. We were the first to order custom made Pisco, and the shaker woke everyone, with so many drinks made after ours you wonder how people walked off the train. Then with everyone loose, South American dancing in the aisles in costume, followed by a fashion show by the Service staff (ours were Roberto, Milagros, and Claudio), and sales of the displayed items resulted in a very fat wallet for PeruRail. The Team did a great job. Don't miss this experience as part of Machu Pichu.
Good. This is pretty much your only option, so it'll do. It's a nice ride; a bit expensive, but efficient. All-in-all a nice train ride to MP.

Long delays in getting a refund. PeruRail overcharged me on the 27 October. The process of getting a refund has been painfully slow and over 4 weeks later I am still waiting.27 Oct - notified PeruRail of overcharge27 Oct - received email from PeruRail that a refund would be made.29 Oct - request from Perurail to confirm credit card details 6 Nov - email received from Perurail that my refund will be processed13 Nov - email from PeruRail stating the refund will take another 2 weeks
Very pleasant ride. Whichever you choose you will be satisfied with the accommodations and snacks. We rode up in the Expedition and back to Cusco in the Vistadome

Train Company. Train Facilities were not bad at all, train tickets are in English and are easy to understand. It is easy to see that train company is ran by private Firm as they seem to be well prepared.

A great service for a very high price. Peru Rail makes a lot of advertisements , the train is well maintained and is clean and quite - the cost of tickets is very high taking advantage of the monopolistic situation !!

Could be better. If you ignore the poor railway track, this would be a 5 star journey between Poroy and Machu Picchu.The problem is the track. It is poorly laid and there seems to be a maintenance problem too. The tracks are held to the sleepers by bolts either side of the track and not in shoes and clips as you find in Europe. The joints have worn badly making for a rough transition between rails. During the descent from Poroy, the train jerks and rocks a lot making it quite uncomfortable. While on the return to Poroy, the carriages and linkages are in tension making the ride far more comfortable.Surely with the popularity of this line and high passenger numbers, more money could be spent on improvement.

great service. we took the VistaDome up to aguas calientes at 8:25 am, the view are amazing, very comfortable train, with huge windows. You get a mini breakfast of quinoa pancakes, fruit and juice, which is ok. on the return trip I suggest you take the Belmond Hiram Bingham, it is much more expensive, but super woth it (it is not on the morning). First it is night time, so there are no views, you have to enjoy the ride and train, they serve a superb dinner in a very elegant train, with a bar car with live music, it is a great way to end the magical day in Machu Picchu

You must ride this train. The moment you step on board, you are in another world, the comfort and the service is totaly out of this world, you are constantly pamper, every time one of the staff come into the car they take a quick look at all the tables to make sure we have everything we need the food is excellent and the service is spectacular and there are continous activities in the observatories car

Great. Loved this 90 minute train ride. We went in business class equivalent. Great staff and service. Train was only a few minutes late. Full of charm. Another Great bit of British Engineering from a long time ago.

Wow Best Train ever. The big Windows on the side and on top could not be better. The clean feel, and the surprising attentive service made everything more comfy. And of course the views. We traveled from Poroy (Cusco) to Machu Pichu and going in the sacred valley is special. We returned by car and the car route is much less impressive because the train goes down in the valley all along the river while cars go a different route.

Best way to travel.... It not so much the destination that counts but the overall journey experience..took the one way trip from Cusco - Puno, and the ride was excellent, excellent services on board, breath takings scenery..however this ride is not for people who is in hurry/impatient to arrived at the destination as the train is very slow
Great Experience. Comfortable transport with great service.......unbelievable views and kind staff. Take care in Aguas Callientes to find your train well before departure time to avoid any confusion.

Andean Explorer (Cusco - Puno - Cusco). I woudn't recommend this trip. Lunch service was poor (food was served at 3pm and food quality is average), train arrived 2 hours after scheduled time and disembarking process was a mess (we had to wait 20 mn in the train at station for "security" reasons). Train tracks follow the main road for the whole trip. Take the bus instead, it's much cheaper and faster (if you want to visit tourist attractions along the road, there is a tourist bus between Cusco and Puno that stops to main attractions).
Perurail travel. really enjoyed traveling by rail. some of the seats have tables, very clean, even had a tea trolley.. reminded me of Hogwarts Express :)

Best way to travel the Altiplano!. My husband and I love trains and this train ride did not disappoint. We were undecided if it would be worth spending the time and the dollars but it was an exceptional Peruvian experience. The seats are extremely comfortable and the food was excellent. We had brought good reads and work to do but spent most of the 10 hours looking out the window and taking pictures. The staff were very accommodating and the passengers were quite interesting as well. I am so glad we traveled from Cusco to Puno with the Andean Explorer!

Relaxing, comfortable way to see the beautiful Peruvian countryside. A friend and I took the train from Puno (near Lake Titicaca) to Cusco. It was a lovely way to travel across Peru. The train was comfortable and clean, the food and drink were enjoyable, and the service was great. I enjoyed standing on the caboose and watching the countryside change. Highly recommend!
Exceptionally good experience. Great service. The train was fast and efficient and meticulously managed by very friendly staff. The best train journey of my life.

Loved every minute of the journey. Easy to book online (contrary to some reviews I'd read). Was concerned about the price and whether we'd get bored during the 10 hour journey - not a bit. Our (adult) daughter got to make (and drink) a pisco sour. My husband and I loved every minute. Well worth the money.

Better than Connex South East. It's like stepping back in time to the Golden Age of rail travel. That would be when you didn't have any choice other than to spend 11 hours to travel 400km. These days we do, which is why I was somewhat bemused to find myself in a museum piece rattling along at a speed more usually associated with a bicycle.You have to like trains and if you do, you'll love this. The food is authentic - tasteless, cold and interminable. The carriage is very comfortable but after 10 hours of the same inane conversation over the aisle, I longed for the roar of a couple of PW4000 engines to drown it out. The scenery is remarkably flat for the Andes - the train to Aguas Calientes has far better views (if even worse food) but there was more in the way of electricity transmission. You also have to like train horns which the driver activated, for no apparent reason, once every 8 seconds on average.However, it looks fantastic and if you like this type of thing, you'll be thinking 'trip of a lifetime'. You already know where this reviewer stands on that.

Long but scenic trip. How relaxing to sit back and enjoy such wonderful scenery. This is an old train with so much charm and still had a luxurious feel and was very clean. Tables are set with a red rose laid on the fresh tablecloth and wait service is great. They clear your used dishes so much quicker than any airline I have flown with and I had 12 flights on this trip alone. The food is of a reasonable standard and enough of it with the snacks as well as lunch. Also a champagne drink near arrival was refreshing. There is enough entertainment like musicians, a dancing lady and parade of Peruvian scarfs etc in the back vista dome carriage if you wish to attend and there is a bar there to enjoy a drink whilst being entertained.The day we travelled a truck had fallen onto the lines and we had quite a delay to wait to have it removed making the trip 12 hours before arriving in Puno but it still went without boredom.Service to your seat is available throughout the trip. Would be interesting to know how far the staff walk in one trip as they are back and forth constantly and keep a smile on their faces.A 10 minute stop at the highest peak station to see a Church and buy some local crafted goods was a break to enjoy. Would recommend paying the bigger price over the bus to have the relaxation and spoiling as you go.

It's like stepping back in time. Yes, I know it is a 10 hour journey but the seats are comfortable and there is a lot going on with drinks/food/music/dance/fashion show etc that the time seems to whizz by.Some reviewers have criticised the food/service but IMHO I think you have to remember where you are and accept that things will happen at a different pace to what you may be used to!Access to the observation car and bar area at the rear of the train is good where you can sit and relax and take in the passing scenery and also enjoy the live music/dance performance.The furnishings and table settings etc resemble something off the Orient Express or an old fashioned British Pullman carriage. I loved it! BTW, unlike a lot of toilets we used during our 6 week trip the one on the train was fantastic
Fabulous journey. This train trundles along very slowly, but the experience was fabulous, Orient Express style luxury, silver service, superb cuisine and excellent views.

The Expedition Train. Awesome train ride. The scenery is great as we ride through the Andes. We embarked in Ollantaytambo and followed the scenic Urubamba Valley got off at Aguas Calientas. We travelled as a group and enjoyed it more. On our return we disembarked in Poroy. We were offered drinks and snacks for refreshments. There was a duty free shopping cart as well. the stewards were very friendly.

Not quite the five star experience . The train's fit out is lovely, the scenery amazing (note: you'd get the same if you opted for the bus, the road and train line are adjacent) and travelling by train is just a nice way to go, but given that the Andean Explorer is billed as a luxury trip my experience fell short.Firstly we were hassled for a tip by a baggage guy in Cuzco. Not a subtle smile or hand out, but he followed us, through the very nice lounge and onto the platform, calling out 'Tiiiip! Tiiiiiip!!' (we didn't even know he was talking to us, we'd just handed the bag to him at the bag drop) eventually catching up and tapping me on the arm until we essentially paid him to go away. Not a nice way to start the trip.Then there's the wait staff on board who, although plentiful, were just a bit slow to react - 20min for a coffee? Compared to the responsive and seemingly very happy guys servicing our carriage on Peru Rail's Expedition service to Machu Picchu, the servers on our Andean Explorer were a bit of a let down. Not rude, but sub par.Re the food, it's fine, but nothing to write home about. They've obviously tried very hard to create a menu of a certain standard, but perhaps the KISS principle would be well-employed here.Obviously a rating is a function of expectation, the actual experience and perceived value at the price. Three out if five stars isn't terrible, but I'm not sure I'd go again.Should you go if you haven't been? If it's not going to break the bank, absolutely! But here are my suggestions:- ask to sit on the north-east side of the train, it seems to have the better views- if you're a twosome, ask to sit at a table for two. You might get lucky and share with a really nice couple, but it's a 10hr trip if you don't..- take noise cancelling headphones, the muzak is relentlessI hope this info helps someone else to get the most out of their Andean Explorer journey :)

Best train ride ever!. First class service from the time you step into train station to board until you disembark. The 3 course lunch served with wine, as well as the mid morning and afternoon snacks were traditionally Andean dishes and absolutely delicious. The entertainment on board and access to the observation car at the back of the train, make this 10 hour journey feel really, really short. Apart from the spectacular scenery, it's incredible how the train goes straight through the middle of a few towns that you pass through. Because the train only runs certain days of the week, the locals have their market stalls over the tracks and quickly pack them up when they hear the train approaching, and as you go through they start packing them back on the rails. In all, absolutely fascinating - well done Peru Rail on a truly amazing experience. The friendly train staff even helped us hail a taxi in Puno to make sure that we were not going to be ripped off. For those of you who have not experienced the Andean Explorer, put it on your bucket-list!!

Luxury travel, take your time. Great way to get from Puno to Cusco. It's a long trip but you are spoilt. Food is served at your seat, drinks throughout. Try the Pisco Sour after the bartenders show you how to make it. Head to the bar carriage and take pictures of the beautiful landscapes passing you by. The toilets on board were lovely. Stopped at a little church in the middle of no where (it's nice to get of half way through the trip) that hasn't got much in it but worth a quick look. Be ready to walk through the villagers selling their goods, they only come for the train, they are very friendly. You can pay to get your photo taken with a llama too.

A perfectly relaxing day. Trains in Peru generally don't go very fast, so the the trip from Cusco to Puno takes ten hours. It didn't feel that long though. Throughout the day they serve a small breakfast snack, lunch, and afternoon tea. Food and most drinks are included, but funnily enough if you ask for a bottle of water, you get charged (just a glass of water is free-bizarre). Also, when it was time to pay the bill, the staff struggled to find change for our S/ 100 bill. Those are only small blemishes though. It is so thoroughly relaxing to sit in the comfortable chairs and watch the stunning landscape glide past your window. You can also get up and visit the bar car, which has an observation deck. Great for taking pictures!Two days before we traveled on the Hiram Bingham train. That train is in a league of its own, so it's not fair to compare the two. The Andean Explorer was definitely one of the highlights of our trip to Peru.

Brilliant and relaxing journey to Lake Titicaca. After weeks of travelling around Ecuador and Peru in minibuses and planes, it was so nice to be able to relax in this very comfortable Pullman style train.

A very long trip, but a beautiful train and beautiful views.. This is a beautiful old train, with modern features. The dining/bar car at the rear is wonderful. The trip is a very long one, being about 10 hours, climbing of the mountains.The train stops at its highest point at a local market which is a good break fro the trip and shows some local culture.The staff on the train are brilliant. Not only providing your food and services, but also putting on a fashion show and also providing entertainment. A very good concept.

A very relaxed day. For a rail fan this was a brilliant day and for the non-gricer or non-gunzel (non rail fan) a great day. The train leaves from the southern station in Cusco to musical accompaniment and works its way through Cusco and along a river valley. The best seats are on the left of the train but if you aren't sitting there just go to the back of the train where the observation car gives you brilliant views. There is plenty to eat and drink on board as well as musical entertainment and a demonstration of the making of Pisco sours. You leave early and get into Puno late (about 8 pm) but there are lots to see along the way with the climax being the trip through the market at Juliaca. If you can, go to the observation car and watch from the rear of the train.

The Orient Express of the Andes. This train journey was amazing.I was not looking forward to a 10 hour train journey,but WOW.The seats are like arm chairs and there is an observation car at the rear.The views from all the windows are amazing.Traveling through Juliaca was fascinating ,as the train only runs a couple of times a week,the locals hold their market over the line.It was amazing watching them pull their stalls in just enough and then retuning them after we had passed.A nice touch was the traditional dancers and musicians.You get a short "leg stretch" at the summit where the locals have some stalls.The place for bargains.

Wow!. What can I say? A ten hour journey would normally make us cringe but we wanted to stay on for longer. It was comfortable, the food was great, the views let us see the diverse countryside of Peru and we were amazed at quickly the market still holders set themselves back up on the tracks after we passed. The travel guide we used said it's not worth the extra money compared to the bus but we completely disagree - it was an experience unto its own.

Amazing trip. We had an amazing day on the Andean Explorer today. The scenery was spectacular, and the 10 hours flew by. Passing through Juliaca was interesting. The only reason I have not given five points is that the lunch was disappointing; the starter and pudding were fine, but the main course was very dry. The service was good, and the staff were all very pleasant.

Puno to Cusco in style. This 10+ hour train ride, considered one of the great rides of the world, was our splurge treat during our weeks in Peru and it met our expectations. Linen tablecloths, gratis Pisco sours at 11 AM, menu choices and wine for lunch, frequent snacks, a bar car, and intermittent entertainment by a Peruvian musical group playing native songs. The slow moving train skirts Lake Titicaca's marshes, goes through farmland, passes people doing laundry in the river, snakes very slowly between bazaar stalls in small towns, gradually climbs in to the snow capped Andes, stopping at its highest altitude for pictures and bartering with locals over handcrafts. Beware - tour groups abound with bossy guides, evident when boarding and getting your luggage at the end. The railway staff are professional and courteous. The man selling tickets in Puno was outstanding; when we realized we'd left something at our hotel, he called there, translated our problem to them, and waved me off to catch the train having solved our issue.

Fun, but not luxury and lacking "incredible" views. I love being on a train and the romance of this kind of travel but my experience on this journey fell short of rail I've been on in Europe, US, Asia and India using regular train lines. I felt lucky getting tickets on short notice for my wife's birthday and spent a lot of time building the experience up based on the many reviews and marketing online I've read. This is described as "One of the world's great train experiences". It is interesting, but it isn't what a lot of reviews here describe. First, it isn't really a "luxury" experience. The train is clean and interesting, but it doesn't feel like "old world" decor or atmosphere. I would compare it to first class on British rail or Amtrak in the US. The seats are comfortable, but look nicer online than they really were. The food is presented very well, but it is in very, very small portions (breakfast was probably 60g - no exaggerating) Lunch was extremely bland and the potatoes were so dry they could choke you. You pay for every drink other than tea - even water. We heard others around us complaining about the food service as well.The main attraction is the views through the Andes. For the first hour or two it is quite nice but for the remaining 8 hours you see a lot of flat, mostly barren landscape with few mountains. The towns you travel through are fascinating - watching bustling markets and crowded living gives you a feel for real-life in Peru. Honestly the pedestrian train from Cusco or Ollantaytambo is much, much more beautiful; green, mountains, Sacred River alongside. The staff were very pleasant and professional. They were really trying. Having fashion shows through the cabins to get you to buy alpaca goods you will undoubtedly see *everywhere* you go in Peru was a bit tired. The shows in the bar car were OK - but designed to sell you a CD full of covers of Simon and Garfunkel in pan flute.Perhaps I've done too many other rail trips to feel as positive as others. This is a worthwhile trip and a MUCH more comfortable way to travel to Lake Titicaca than the bus. It isn't a luxury trip and it isn't a "unforgettable journey through the land of the Incas". It is just a nice commuting train. It pains me to say that as I love being on long train rides, but this slow trek is simply "better than the bus".The train ride to Aguas Cliente is a digestible 2 hours from Ollantaytambo; is run by Peru Rail also; has much, much more spectacular views; has great service and staff. This is a cheaper alternative, likely on your itinerary anyway, the seats are just as good, the cars have the same kind of view windowsWe are glad we did it, but it is disappointing.

A great if snail pace journey. If you are into special train journeys rather than getting from A to B asap this may appeal to you. First up there are not too many train rides at this altitude, reaching 4,300m at one point and stopping so you can get pictures with an altitude sign. The average spread for the trip is about 25km/h so it's no rocket and just as well because it rattles and shakes a lot. The fit out is comfortable the seats being very much like large armchairs. Despite the 10 plus hours the journey was not boring for me. There is the scenery including snow capped mountains and vast rural pursuits from crops to herds of live stock which contrast against baron treeless mountains. But onboard things do happen. There is traditional music and dancing and a fashion parade of sorts, aimed at selling. The is a welcome pisco sour and a glass of wine with lunch plus a farewell drink all part of the deal and you can buy more. Nothing happens quickly with morning and afternoon tea plus lunch taking up few hours. It is a bit of a pity the train gets in when it is dark, it is so much easier to get your bearings in daylight and it would not take much to shave an hour or so off the journey time. All up a good experience and if you are not into unique trains rides there is always the bus.

A world's best train ride with all the Wow factors. The first hint that this is something really special is the view of the staff and the carriages from the waiting room at Cusco. The staff are dressed impeccably and the train is presented beautifully. Shades of the Orient Express! Boarding the train is breathtaking. One almost expects to see Hercule Poirot at a table laid with linen and silver, sipping a glass of an excellent red wine. The numerous dining events (not just meals!) are the stuff of movies. This is ten hours of heaven in gleaming brass and wood panelling on steel wheels. The train travels at a leisurely pace, so as to provide a gliding panorama of life on the Alto Plano, the high plateau of the Andes. The seating is wingback armchairs, perfectly upholstered for a lengthy relaxing journey. Even though the local children must see this train pass twice a day they are jumping with excitement and smile and wave as the tourists float by. The rear observation car is a truly unique treasure, for both conversation, hospitality and stretching the legs. At this Spring season we were delighted by snow falling on us at our stop at La Raya, the highest point of the line at 4319 metres, then twice entranced by the spectacle of 'phantom falls', where cloud cascades down mountain sides as it flows from one valley to the next. The staff complete the show with a fashion parade, wearing the luxurious fabrics of legendary baby alpaca. That includes the males of the staff too! The only jarring point was the dress-up masked bogey-men, apparently a feature of the Inca religion that pervades the region. The grand finale is to watch Lake Titcaca glide into view and glow in the setting sun and moonlight.

Fantastic experience in old time luxury. This was a wonderful way to travel from Puna to Cusco. There were fantastic views of both city and countryside. Service was excellent. Live music dancing and a bar tending class. The food was average. I especially enjoyed the last dining car which has large windows and an open rear wall that was great for photography. I had read that this was a trip for train buffs but I feel that anyone could enjoy this experience.

Relaxing ride to Puno. We took the 10-hour Andean Explorer from Cusco to Puno. We were a bit weary at first about the length of the train ride, but actually had a very enjoyable and relaxing ride. We enjoyed the food and entertainment on board, and found everything to be very clean and well kept. The staff were lovely and spoke perfect English. Bring a book, deck of cards, and camera- sit back and enjoy! Also, I recommened calling or emailing peru rail to request a two person seating assigment if you are only traveling with one companion. The were several tables that they sit 4 people at, and if you don't like the other people it would really stink to be stuck with them for 10 hours! Also, our train was almost 90 minutes late arriving in Puno, not sure why as we departed on time, but if you have a hotel or resort arranging transportation they may have to wait.

You should do this. This is a must journey.From the moment you set off you will I suspect,not expect at least one aspect of the journey...this will take you through a main street of a town that looks like a cross between 'blade runner' and a post armageddon horror film.Then onto great altitude,across barren plains and thru moutains all the time being fed average food {That does not matter} and given a constant sales parade or watching staff members modelling various nick/nacks.Great fun ride with lots to see and do.

Enjoyable, but long. Really enjoyed the experience of long train ride through the Andes, but the journey to Puno is apparently a couple of hours shorter by road. Last bit of journey very slow, so tired by the time we reached our hotel. Was prepared for 'fashion show' which was pretty dire, but staff all pleasant. Food was reasonable and a good Pisco sour was served on board.

Takes a full day to do this.. We took the train from Cusco to Lake Titicaca. The service was very good and watching the landscape change dramatically though out the day was exciting. You get to stop and see locals selling their crafts. But this spot is the great watershed. North to the Amazon and south to the Lake and the great plateau. Avoid the fresh fruit and salad...our companions got a stomach bug!
A trip to take. A great way to travel - slow - efficient - helpful staff, and comfort so what more could you ask for

Relaxing way to see the countryside. This was a special experience. First confession, I love trains. First class experience. Food good. Views stunning. Some highlights for me was going through the market at Juliaca- for about a mile the train goes within two feet of the market stalls which front onto the tracks. We saw everything from barber shops, food, housewares. People smiling and waving. Also loved the mountain passes- spectacular. At the peak (4310 meters) it was interesting that all the riders became quiet (and dusky coloured) but the lively conversation returned once we got lower. Good entertainment. One comment- SLOW. Took 10 hours. When we were along side of the road we were getting passed by dump trucks. This would have been a perfect 8 hour trip going faster but alas I don't think the tracks could support.

Over priced and over-rated. Yes the scenery is stunning for the first five hours. Then I started to feel packed in and uncomfortable. The staff did their best but overall the service was rather poor. Next time I´ll get a bus that can do a few more stops

Wonderful experience!. It is a wonderful experience to travel in luxury and admire the beautiful landscape. The trip from Puno to Cuzco took 10hours but you get never bored, the scenery is wonderful, there are singers, dancers, you can learn how to prepare a pisco sour, there is a fashion show, ... And the food is delicious! You are treated like a prince and a princess :-)

A pleasant experience. We travelled from Cusco to Puno, the journey taking 11 hours. The scenery was very interesting for the most part, though the last section was rather monotonous. Great opportunities to take photos, both from your armchair like seat or from the observation car. Service was excellent and the staff friendly. The food is not good. Our meal consisted of soup, which was good, trout, dried up and a cooked cheesecake which was poor. However, the reason we travelled this way was to see the scenery, which we did. Better than air travel between the two spots because you got to see Peru beyond the cities.

Loved it!. Always something to look at, the mountains were gorgeous. Small farms, animals...very interesting and beautiful trip! Enjoyed the bar car and the open view car. Pleasant and comfortable. Tables are in groups of 4 or groups of 2...groups of 2 can be side by side or across from each other.

Beautiful train and wonderful service. We pre purchased our tickets via the internet six weeks before our trip. We were going from Cusco to Puno, a ten hour train trip. The tickets were emailed to us and said 'depart Cusco', we didn't know that there were two stations in Cusco and even though we were an hour early to the station, we didn't realise we were in the wrong place until it was too late and we missed the departing train. We spent the next three and a half hours in a taxi and $90 USD trying to get in front of the train to board it. This experience was the most stressful part of our entire trip. The staff from Peru Rail did everything they could to help us, they got us in a taxi and told the driver what needed to happen, he didn't speak English and we don't speak Spanish, the taxi driver and the rail staff kept in contact via mobile phone and organised a catch up point, we missed the first one due to road works, traffic jambs and speed bumps in every small town. We finally made the second catch up point with ten minutes to spare, even after being pulled over by the police and them confiscating our taxi drivers licence. I think everyone was relieved that we finally boarded the train. Once on board the staff were extremely friendly and helpful and the rest of the trip went without any problems. My stress levels took quite some time to diminish though and I didn't enjoy the journey as much as I had hoped to. The food, scenery and staff were all good and I would recommend this train and Peru Rail, just be sure that your taxi driver in Cusco is taking you to the correct train station.

The great train journey. This was simply awesome.Another spectacular journey from the Inca Capital Cusco to Pre Inca Capital PUNO by Andean explorer train. The train was filled with travelers across the globe enjoying the glass view of the landscape with an open observatory at the back of the train, Peruvian music and dance and a breathtaking journey enjoying the climb that goes all the way up to 15000 feet above the sea level.

Train from Cusco to Puno. Fantastic ride. The views were spectacular and we especially enjoyed the bar wagon with its open end. The ride was super comfortable and the 10 hours flew by. I would love to take the train again!

Luxury train. We experienced a very well organized trip on the luxury train to Machu Picchu. Although the price tag is very high, it is a once-in-a-lifetime experience. Everything is included from start to finish. Only specialty drinks on the train are charged separately.We stayed at the Belmond Rio Sagrado hotel near Urubamba and had to take a taxi to/from Ullantaytambo to board the train. Would be even better if the train could stop at the hotel since the train is also operated by Belmond.

Beautiful Train Ride. This is probably the most interesting train ride I have ever had.Luxury train, replica of trains from twenties, travelling across the Andes with experiencing landscape from partially opened observation wagon, good entertainment... It's a pity that food wasn't on the level of the whole event.Be aware that due to the social turmoils in Juliaca or Puno train departures can be cancelled and you might be stuck with having hard time continuing your trip.
A long trip.. We found this trip a little boring, I think it took about 10 hours and thought the train could go a little faster and reduce the amount of time it took.

Wow !. Wow !I would never have expected living such experience in this train.The organization was extraordinary and full of surprises : Andean bands, cocktail degustation and workshop, Peruvian clothes mode show etc.At the end we still wonder how the 10 hours passed so fast.On board the atmosphere is cosy, the seats comfortable, and you have access at the rear of the train to an open panoramic coach.The food is good, not excellent, but good and different from the standard quinoa soups and potatoes side dishes served everywhere...Most of the beverages are included or offered (1 pisco sour is offered for instance).Obviously the landscapes and views are gorgeous. That being said it is true that the train crosses the cities in their very middle, passing at 15 cm from the inhabitants and that it is a bit a)dangerous, b)disturbing...Despite all their efforts it is also true that the service is sometimes slow and seems to last excessively.But overall, this trip is a very pleasant experience and a good alternative to the bus.

Excellent way to spend 10 hours. This is a lovely way to travel from Cusco to Puno. We had two options the train or a bus - both take 10 hours. The train provided superb comfort - although the chairs are a little like armchairs, they are comfortable. You can also get up visit the bar coach and the viewing car, with excellent open end. Food was good. The only downside is that you do see some of the poorer areas of Peru - only place where I got a negative response from a local herder, very anti train!! There is also entertainment.This may not be the orient express, but is still a quality way to see Peru, worth the money in my view.

GREAT!. The train is great. It has everything you need for a 10 hour ride, and the time flew by very quickly. They had a show, they have bar classes. The only minus is terrible food. Views are great and last cart which has panoramic windows are great also.

Breathtaking journey through the Andes. A fantastic train journey from Cusco, Peru to Aguas Calientes for Machu Picchu. The scenery was breathtaking, but made all the more exciting by the very professional staff and quality of food and service on the journey. We were even treated to a fashion show on the return trip. I would recommend this trip to anyone who feels the Inca Trail is too exerting !!

Luxury train ride. Extremely comfortable and luxurious train ride across the Andes. While the train ride is approximately ten hours long, passengers do not feel a minute of it due to the extreme planning and care given by the staff. One is greeted by a traditional musical group playing Andean music in the lobby of the train station prior to arrival. The train ride begins with a fashion show in the train's bar car. This is followed by two musical performances with traditional folkloric dancers from both the Cusco and Puno regions, and a lesson on how to make a pisco sour, which is coupled with the distribution of copious amounts of free pisco sours. For those with a love of photography, the final train car is an open air car that allows one to take amazing photographs of the Andean region or just sit and take in the beautiful scenery. The meals are freshly prepared on the train and they were very accommodating to my vegan diet. While the train ride is lovely and the staff is very kind, the high concentration of American and European tourists on board was disconcerting. Besides the staff, all of the passengers were foreigners. The very high ticket price prevents locals from having the opportunity to take advantage of such a trip. While I suppose it this is something to be expected for the cost, it made both my husband and I feel uncomfortable since we are not accustomed to traveling with so much luxury.

Can't think of a better way to spend 10 hours on a train. We travelled on the train from Cusco to Puno. It is purely a tourist attraction, as it is not the cheapest way to travel from Cusco to Puno. However, it is the most entertaining, breathtaking way to go. There is plenty of Peruvian music, interspersed with fashion shows. The local brews flow (this didn't have an influence on this review!) and there was a plentiful supply of the Peruvian cuisine. there was only one stop the entire length of the trip, which was a the highest point of the rail track. A small local market is there, where the hand knitted goods are so cheap, it is a sin to barter. Well worth the experience.

Wonderful way to travel between Puno to Cusco. We enjoyed the views, the information that was provided to travellers, the wonderful service of food and drink, including the Pisco Sour, the opportunities to stretch our legs at the high point where the Church lies, surrounded by a market. I loved the fashion parade which highlighted the beautiful wools of the region. It was a brilliant day of travel. I thoroughly recommend it. We had no problems with altitude sickness.

Best Train Ever!. Travelled from Puno to Cuzco on this train for about £90. It took 10 and a half hours but was the best train ride I've ever had. Our guidebook said go by luxury bus - goes the same route for a third of the price. But when your family are suffering from altitude sickness and too many hours squashed on a coach this was the perfect antidote. This is the sort of train that in England you pay around £250 a head to go on a trip to York from London. The only thing the train was missing was steam. Great food, great drinks (many free), great viewing compartment at the back. Great scenery throughout without the added thrill of wondering on which bend in the road you'd meet a lorry overtaking another lorry. Learnt how to make a Pisco Sour. Didn't bother with the fashion show. Went right through the main streets of a couple of towns. Stopped at the highest point to allow us off for a wander. Best train toilets I've ever seen - put English trains to shame. If I had to nitpick they could have organised the luggage pick-up at Cuzco a little more smoothly but who cares! Do this train. Excellent.

Cars and even animals overtake this train. The distance between Cusco and Puno is approx 400km. It takes around 6 hours by car and 11 hours by train as the train runs at 60km/h and there are sections where it goes even slower (particularly through little towns).Our journey took nearly 13 hours due to our having to wait about an hour for the train travelling in the opposite direction to pass (there is a section where the railway track is shared) and also due to heavy traffic in Juliaca.Yes the scenery is lovely but this is only fascinating for a few hours. They do provide some entertainment - Peruvian band + dancer (the Sunday market type who request tips when you do not purchase their CD) and a pretty awful fashion show where the model is one of the train staff.If you do not have much time to spare, definitely travel by car/bus or fly. You'll get to Cusco/Puno in nearly half the time which means more time spent at your destination.

We derailed, were late but it's still a must-do experience. This is an old-style Pullman train that wends its way between Puno and Cusco ..... slowly. Very slowly! But despite lots of things happening, it is definitely one of the highlights of our three weeks in Peru. One kilometre into the journey we derailed. It delayed us by a couple of hours whilst they found a digger to help us back onto the track. Later one of the door locks jammed, and the engineer had to come and repair it, and a little later one of the waiters dropped a tray load of drinks! And in the end we were two hours late.BUT - it's all worth it. The train is old-style luxury. Comfortable armchairs, excellent, if rather strange, food (although they don't heat the plates and so it isn't as hot as it could be). The observation car is a great place to see both the scenery and to observe life as we passed down a couple of streets filled with market stalls. Service was good, and we were given an additional plate of pasta before arriving into Cusco as we were running late.In the end we took 10 hours rather than 8, but our view was that this simply reduced the price to £8.50 an hour rather than £10!!

Magnificent Experience & Absolute 'must'. We used the Andean Explorer to cover the distance between Puno and Cusco on our way to Macchu Pichu. We were rather excited about it the day beforehand and we have to admit that all our exceptations were met. The trip was just wonderful.The andean experience starts at check in where you are greeted by peruvian mucisians while the friendly staff went through check-in. Everything about check-in is smooth and quick including luggage handling.Then you board the train. The train is picked out of an old picture book, mahogany interior, art deco details, winged armchair, tablecoths, fresh roses, ... The lot.The train slowly makes its way out of Puno and then hits the Altiplano. Always at a pace of between 50 to 60 km, sometimes, unforeseen, stopping, which gives you a good possibilty to take the scenery in.Our guide adviced us to be in the vista waggon by the time the train crossed the city of Juliaca as the train would cross the market street. We shot some of the most beautiful pictures there. The train indeed cuts the market in two in a very narrow street. You can literally touch the goods from aboard the train. People sheer and wave at the train enthusiasticaly.After a light breakfast of coffee and muesli, in the bar waggon, there's a music show and complimentary pisco's before it's time for lunch. Now, in all honesty, apart from the experience of dining in such beautiful surroundings, the food is nothing special and neither is the tea and bellini's in the late afternoon. Then, that's not what it is all about I guess.The staff, without exception, is great. Some of them even showing some dance skills while the band is playing.At la Gaya, half way, the train stops. Here both trains interchange and outside there is a small market of weaving and knitting articles ... Ofcourse !Everywhere there's an interchange, the train needs to stop as tracks are changed manually. Be prepared for people selling their goods at the vista car. (These moments give you however equally the time to reflect how some of us can afford to travel like this and others need to live a life that is much harder ...)The train then makes it way to the ever more dramatic scenery of the Andes, partly while the sun sets to reach Cusco in darkness. Turning the antique waggons into something extremely cosy.Nearlyeleven hours on a train, the old sound and rocking of the train on the rails, the horn to get people and animals of the track, ... Wonderfull and you would not at all have thought it took so long. If international flights could only have part of the charm and entertainment ...We were seated in waggon A, adjacent to the vista waggon, and from the constant passing of people and camera's to and from the vista waggon, I think I can say we were not the only ones that thought this experience to be great.We are looking forward to a similar experience from Cusco to Macchu Picchu on the Hiram Bingham Train in a few days

Slow train to Cusco. Our journey from Puno to Cusco took 11 hours but they passed very comfortably. This is old style Pullman service. Our seats were wooden wing back armchairs. We had a dining table with tablecloth, rose in a vase and a brass table lamp. All was dark, varnished wood, even in the luxurious loo. We left Puno promptly at 8 am. We were served a late breakfast, a decent lunch and afternoon tea. Tea, coffee and wine were served with the meals and everyone was given a complementary pisco sour. At the rear of the train the observation car was great as we could sit or stand and watch the Andean countryside pass by slowly, the average speed was around 25 mph. A slight annoyance was the inevitable pan pipes band and a truly dreadful 'fashion show' but overall the journey was good. Arriving in Cusco at around 7 pm we collected our luggage which had been carried in the luggage van and then laid out on the platform, all clearly and efficiently tagged and checked. A good, relaxing way to travel through the Peruvian countryside.

Worth every penny. This was a really worthwhile part of our itinerary. The trip takes 10 hours, leaving at about 8am. We had seats in the dining car and I was actually surprised by the level of service. The seats were luxurious and the food excellent. We had a light breakfast after departure and delicious lunch and afternoon tea later. Very high quality service and plenty to see during the trip, with ever-changing landscapes and views. The staff even gave a fashion show and a demonstration of the making of a perfect Pisco Sour cocktail - free samples too!!. There are a couple of stops on the way too, for those who like to shop for bargains like alpaca hats or sweaters.Travel by rail is a great way to see what's going on in a country and this one had an observation car at the rear so it was possible to get really good camera shots or just relax and take in the scenery. Wonderful and highly recommended.
OK. Nice train. Weird food. Not very fast. Actually, painfully slow...But, hey! You gotta get there, right?

Wonderful train trip - do it if you can. The Andean Explorer is a classically restored old train which meanders between Cusco & Puno. To really enjoy the trip it is a must to spend some time in the observation carriage & enjoy the welcome drinks - Pisco Sour & the traditional music & dancing. There is also a fashion parade & lessons on how to make Pisco Sour! A very relaxed way to spend a day. Sure it is more expensive that taking a bus but it is well worth it. Enjoy!

Highlight of Peru. I have been wanting to come to Peru most of my life and for my 50th it happened.We went from Puno to Cusco on the train and as teh train pulled out and started to go round the lake this is when my adventure came alive and I got a bit emotional!The train cannot be faulted - it is beautiful - all mahogany and brass (that includes the fab toilet!). we had a table for 2 which was perfect - romantic.We were recommended by our guide to get to the back of the observation car ready for when the train left the first stop - excellent advice. You go through a market on the tracks for almost 15 mins! It is great seeing everyone putting their stalls back now the train has passed! the scenery never stops amazing - from the lake views, to the high plateau and then coming down the valley getting more lush as you near Cusco.there is entertainment in the bar carriage if you want it but for us the scenery was all we wanted.The food and drink are fantastic - michellin quality. The service could not be faulted.By the end of the journey you are full from all the constant food being brought and a bit squiffy from the drink -perfect! DO NOT TRAVEL BETWEEN THESE CITIES ANY OTHER WAY!I would recommend this to anyone and it ranks up there with Machu Picchu. It brought tears to my eyes several times because it was so perfect. I can't speak too highly of it.Anyone interested in more detail, please contact me.

Painfully slow, immensely uncomfortable, rediculously overpriced. Took this train from Cusco to Puno. Started off with having to wait in waiting room that only had enough chairs for a small fraction of the passengers there. Had to sit on uncomfortable armchairs. A fellow passenger recieved multiple insect bites, most likely from the chair. I went into observation car at one stage & a child ran after the train for a bit - this was possible for the child as the train was so slow. The child then threw a rock into the train, via the open back deck, narrowly missing a passengers arm then a glass window. Although the child should not have done this, it is understandable given this train travels through towns, right in front of the locals homes, it is noisy & dangerous and this must be annoying for them. Also, they see what would appear to them to be well-healed, pampered tourists travelling along in apparent luxury that they have no access to. But the luxury is apparent, it is anything but luxurious. As I have said, the chairs are uncomfortable.The ride is known to be a bone shaker. The food is disgusting & the meal services lasted for hours. From the time the cutlery was first brought out until the end of the 'meal' was several hours. All of the food was stone cold when it arrived. The food was so dry it was difficult to eat. The portions were tiny which given the poor quality of the food was probably a blessing. The scenery was not great but I cannot blame the train company for that, however, it meant there was nothing worth looking at to pass the long, slow hours away. We were only 20 minutes late getting to Puno so we were among the lucky passengers. It seems it can be many hours late.My advise it book the bus - a fraction of the price, hours quicker, goes along almost the same route as the train & stops in a few places so you see more. I have never been on a bus as uncomfortable as that train so the bus is most likely to most comfortable option as well.

Great experience. Wonderful sightseeing.. My husband and two kids younger than ten had a wonderful time during the trip. It is quite a long trip but the staff is sure we have plenty to do during the trip. Even my kids had movies to watch and board games to play. One thing will be helpful is to have headphones for the kids to be able to listen better the movies.

Great trip not to be missed!. We loved this train trip: the train is very special, a little like the Orient Express in Europe. Nice uniformed staff helps you carry your luggage. You are seated at a table with a white tablecloth and silver cutlery. Lovely "waitresses" service Pisco Sour and other cocktails, and ask you to choose your dinner, which is included in the train ticket price. In addition to the landscape around and the extraordinary city-crossing action, the train organizes a fashion show, cooking classes, not to mention a musical show with live andean musicians and ballet dancers!
party train. pisco sours at 11:00 am got the whole train going… everyone was super friendly and great food. Don't need the Hiram Bingham… this train was just as good!

Yes, it's more expensive than the bus, but if you love trains.... My husband and I took the Andean explorer train from Cuzco to Puno during a honeymoon visit to Perú. The train is extremely luxurious; it kind of feels like you are riding a train in about 1890 or 1900. You'll sit in armchair-type chairs at a table with a tablecloth. Meals are served with china and real silverware; alcohol is available. There is a really cool observation car at the back where you can take pictures. There are occasional musical performances on the train trip. It's definitely the most comfortable way to travel from Cuzco to Puno, although it's actually a bit slower than the bus. However, my husband is obsessed with trains, and he loved the journey.

Stunning train journey. The Andean Explorer is possibly the best value-for-money luxury train in the world. At $139 (May 2014) for ten hours of pampered travel, with very comfortable seats, attentive service, good food and wine, some home-made entertainment, and a superb observation car (with bar and a demonstration of how to make a good pisco-sour), you can't go wrong.

a great train journey. We had an really good journey on the andean explorer. The views were stunning and the observation carriage enabled us to take some very memorable photos. The entertainment was good and encouraged travellers to get involved. The food and service was good, a really enjoyable way to get to Puno.

One of the highlights of a trip to Peru. We took the Andean Explorer from Cusco to Puno and although it was 10 hours long there was plenty to occupy us, wonderful scenery, luxury seating, good food, entertainment on board and excellent service. We would recommend this train as it would be more comfortable than the alternative bus journeyWe arrived in Puno as darkness fell which was good timing as Puno is not an appealing city, just a way to get to Lake Titicaca.

Elegant train, but journey too long. Comfortable, but 10 hour trip from Cusco to Puno is simply too long. Train is not heated or air conditioned, so depending on weather it can be too cold or hot.Observation car is fun and the rear is open air. Food is average, but service is very good. Would be great for 3-4 hour trip.Views are good, but there is not a great deal to see unless you enjoy 8 hours of prairie land with a mountain backdrop.Train goes through on town where the market stalls are literally 2 feet from rail cars on both sides. This was one of most fascinating parts of the trip.
PeruRail Cusco/Puno. The tourist train from Cusco to Puno or Puno to Cusco is possibly the best value-for-money luxury train in the world.

Andean Explorer Train. We took the Andean Explorer from Cusco to Puno, between our Inca Trail Trek and our visit to Lake Titicaca. What a great way to rest and relax after our walk! Think "Orient Express", comfort and elegance from a time gone by. The included food was delicious and beautifully presented. Portions were perfect for us, though additional menu items are also available at extra cost. The club/observation car offers great views of the countryside as the train climbs out of Cusco and over the Andes, along with music, a fashion show and a performace by dancers in traditional Peruvian costumes. We booked through Llamapath, and they can provide transportation to and from the train stations (at both ends). That really simplifies your life, especially if you are running late in the morning (savoring the hotel breakfast), and since the train arrives in Puno after dark (about a 10-hour trip).

A great train journey. I went on this train from Cusco to Puno it's like a poor mans version the orient express the 10 hour journey was slow so you could take it all in and enjoy the trip, we had a three course lunch on board which was very good, it had a open observation car at the back so it was real nice, I used this also as a great train journey off my bucket list would real recommend

An unforgettable journey. I had been recommended this journey by a friend and thank goodness I took her advice! This was a wonderful way to travel from Cusco to Puno...it was definitely a journey that was part of the holiday experience rather than interrupting it. The train is luxurious, food and service were great and the views spectacular. Add to that the music, dancing, fashion show and Pisco sour making demonstration and the 10 hours flew by. The observation car was wonderful and definitely a place for sharing notes with other travellers over a drink or two! Worth every Sol!

Awesome train ride - the ride is the attraction. 10 hours in a train from Puno to Cuzco .... So glad we did it. Some people were just sleeping, reading, on the phone texting the whole time ... unbelievable. The scenery, villages ... so awesome. I watched out of the window and out of the open end wagon for most of the time. Drinks, food were adequate. Sadly enough we did run out of beer. Ridiculous. Especially since this happened during "happy hour". Service was ok. A little too much running around. The doors were an obstacle for the servers. They kept slamming into the seats. A few times the servers slammed into them and dropped glasses which pieces got cleaned up 1/2 hour later. In short - they try some more than others but service could be better. The views are unbeatable though. The pisco brewing, other entertainment and the bar in general were a nice touch. Would recommend it.

Best Decision of our holiday. Yes this is expensive but worth every penny/sol. I've never known a 10 hour journey go so fast. Only stayed in our seats to eat as spent most of the journey in the observation carriage or bar. The train goes right through town markets where you can touch stalls either side and in some cases go over stall holders' merchandise. Later nearer Cusco the scenery is magnificent. Right from the start we were having fun, dancing or tasting pisco sours. It was an incredible social experience where we got to know most of our fellow travellers from diverse backgrounds, Peru, Brazil, Spain, Japan, USA etc. (wonderful). 2 days later, bumping into a fellow passenger, all we could talk about was the train journey. Staff were cheerful and friendly and gave the impression they were having fun too. Food was excellent, more than we expected.Journey did go over time by 30 minutes and I can understand other travellers becoming frustrated if it was delayed any longer. Once it becomes dark there is little to provide interest. My only recommendation would be to provide warning if going over time and perhaps another activity if this happens.

Well worth the cost. This is part of the Orient Express Group. It is a 10 hour journey but well worth it. The train stops about halfway and there is a small market to go round. You can get your photos taken in front of the train. Thee is entertainment on the train. Meals were very good.

Train to Ollanta. Although the train was delayed it was a magic ride to Ollantaytambo. I booked late and was given seat number 2 - right in the front nose of the first carriage. This vantage point offered a fantastic view of the surrounding areas at sunset. The scenery was spectacular.
Beautiful Train - beautiful scenery. I love the scenery and the food was great, all the shows during the train ride and the Pisco Sours! service and beautiful train!

Amazing experience!! Experiência incrível!!. Ten hours from Puno to Cusco that were worth it. I could read my books, play cards with my family, the seats and the environment were confortable, the services were great, everything is well explained in english, spanish and french. And besides all that, we could see amazing sights all the time. Also, there are music presentations, dancing and a class of how to make their "pisco souer"(alcoholic drink). I only missed wifi.

Like times of old. I felt like a turn of the century explorer on this incredible train journey through the most amazing and diverse scenery. The highest point at El Alto afforded views from National Geographic, just amazing. It is a long journey though, takes 10-12 hours, so it can be tiring towards the end.

Surprisingly good!. This train surprised us with its spacious cars, its comfortable arm-chairs, and its ease of passage from one car to another that helps make even a ten-hour journey seem palatable. The observation car at the rear of the train enables the tourist to see a constantly-changing landscape and the details of town and village life as the train travels through at a modest speed. At-your-table service is unfailingly courteous and well-organized, and there are usually extra attractions such as a fashion show or an entertainer to help pass the time. Move over Hiram Bingham! This is THE train to take from Puno to Cusco.

Train Buff. If you are a train buff this is an absolute must. Narrow gauge, verandah at the back, sinuous track with views of the train against a background of snow covered peaks. Unwelded track, noisy point work. Pushing through markets, we even ran over a bicycle with the observationcar when it fell into our track, cut it clean in half!If you are not a train buff but bit of a romantic. The trip is long, over 10 hours. The scenery is stunning, snow,mountains, golden plains, primitive cottages, colourful folk, llamas, smiling children even a craft market you stop at. Live music (yes those pipes again), a fashion show with very pushy sales tactics. Reasonable food. But hey, riding by rail is romantic, to be shared with your loved one.
transportation. It's a train, It gets you there. Slept part of the way but rails are rough as a coaster. Not much to say.

Brilliant. I didn't realise initially that this trip was part of our itinerary but am so glad it was. It's quite spacious and it has a bar car as well as observatory car with glass roof. The food and service were good and given that you're spending 12 hours on it - more or less - it's really relaxing; it meant that everyone was quite friendly and social so it was a marvelous way to spend a day. It wasn't until I got home that I realised how many pictures I took - it goes through scenery to die for and I couldn't get enough of just peering out from the observatory car. Probably the best way to do Cusco to Puno.
Great trip. We were not looking forward to this very long slow ride but with music, fashion shows, lunch etc the day went quickly and pleasantly

A train ride of beauty and wonder. A rickety but yet a wonderfully comfortable and entertaining ride as the train rolled up and back down the tracks to and from Machu Pichu. The glass windows on the sides and on top of you put you out there and in the natural beauty the and majestic Andes. A must do for anyone who appreciates the miraculous beaty of nature, mountains, running rivers and ancient presences!

An Absolute MUST!!!!!. I wish I could give a higher rating than TA allows. This rail trip, besides walking the Inca Trail, was one of the highlights of our three week trip in Peru. We were two couples travelling together, but I took charge of doing all of our bookings. I booked easily on line, but then realized our four seats weren't together. I emailed Peru Rail and was immediately re-issued four seats at the same table. We arrive at the train station about 40 minutes prior to departure (they tell you to be there at least 30 minutes before). We checked in quickly with a gentleman in the waiting room and were then entertained as we waited by a four person local Peruvian band.All guests are assigned a table in the dining car. It's a throw back to the old days of train travel....elegant and comfortable, with table clothes and comfy wingback chairs. There is a separate bar car and viewing / observation car. Bathrooms are large and spotless with granite counter tops. Once on board I asked for coffee and it was delivered quickly (good coffee as well). We were then given a menu and made our lunch selection and drink orders were taken. Not long after we departed we went to the bar cart for musical entertainment (combined with an early morning gin and tonic of course). There was also afternoon entertainment (another band and a fashion show). Lunch was very good and they came around a couple of times with complimentary wine. There was also wine to purchase and we enjoyed a nice bottle as we whiled away the afternoon. I had brought my e-reader with me thinking I would have a ton of time to read during the ten hours.....but I found the scenery and ambience too distracting to read. I was back and forth to the viewing car which allows for stunning photos. The scenery was ever changing and I defy anyone to say they were bored. Service was excellent throughout the day and it just made for a truly memorable way to get from Puno to Cusco.If you are even debating taking this train ride, do not hesitate. The four of us talked about this experience long after we disembarked. Truly a highlight of our trip. Great job Peru Rail!!!!

Best rail trip I have done to date.... It is 11hours by train from Puno to Cusco...but what a way to go. The Andean Explorer is just a beautiful train. Comfortable armchairs adore each carriage. The last carriage is the viewing platform with lots of standing and seating space. Great to watch the landscape pass by from the rear. Also makes for lovely photos. The there is the fun or entertainment carriage (has the bar in it) and is also where the on board entertainment takes place during the journey. The staff are so lovely and so friendly. The band and entertainment were just awesome. 11hour was by no means a hardship at all on this train. So worth the it...enjoyed every minute. Food was amazing too...

A Wonderful Way to Travel. We have just returned from a trip to Peru that included travelling on the Andean Explorer from Puno to Cusco. The staff on board we attentive and fun. The food was excellent and the vistas from the train second to none. Although there was entertainment during the 10 hour trip, we found the scenery and the views of everyday life as the train went by to be entertainment enough.This train like other Peru Rail trains that we took during our trip ran on time and was sparklingly clean. In my opinion it was also excellent value for money. I would recommend everyone travelling to Cusco and Puno to consider this mode of transport rather than flying or driving.

Loved the relaxed pace and pampering. I am a train lover and I thoroughly enjoyed every minute of the 10 hour journey on the Andean Explorer from Cusco to Puno on Lake Titicaca. We were welcomed on board by attentive staff and the in-train band playing music on the platform. We spent the time appreciating the beautiful vistas from the observation car, where we were offered a complimentary Pisco Sour, or from our seats. We listened to live Peruvian music from the in-train band. We watched some dancing and a fashion show of Peruvian knit wear. We feasted on two delicious meals served by the most attentive servers. We also enjoyed the company of our friendly neighbours on the train and exchanged travel stories with them. We had a quick stop about half way where we could stretch our legs and visit a market, We also had time to read and have a little snooze.Travelling right down the middle of the extensive market of Juliaca after a huge rain offered a glimpse of Peruvian life most tourists wouldn't normally see.I was amazed when we arrived at our destination in Puno because we were dropped off at our hotel from the train (Casa Andina Private Collection) and were met by hotel staff to help us with our bags.The whole trip was reminiscent of a charming long-forgotten train era and it felt great to have lived that experience!

The way to MachuPicchu. One way to get to Machu Picchu is the train - the other is the Inca trail. The train is much more comfortable. This narrow gauge railway has comfortable seats with "vista vision". Cocoa tea and other drinks are served as well as a snack by friendly staff. It is a pleasant way to see the beautiful river gorge and the mountains as you descent to the Sacred valley.
Amazing.. Sit back and enjoy the views whilst all the americans buy the merchandise. Definitely the way to get around. The first class trip to Puno was a highlight of our trip.

A charming way to slow the pace down. Highlight of a great trip!. We were a party of five and we traveled by Peru Rail from Puno to Cusco. It was a ten hour journey, in a charming train which minded us of the Orient Express. The food and service was great and the small amount of entertainment was just enough. We spent most of our time in the rear viewing carriage which was perfect. The speed was slow enough to appreciate the landscape and take some time out of a packed schedule to really see the country. Highly recommended and anyone that suggests it is too slow are missing the point spectacularly!! A "must do" and worth every penny.

Andean Explorer Train Ride. It was a ten hour journey that is part of the Orient Express company. Finely appointed furnishings, comfortable seats, food very nice, entertainment and country side viewing. Lamas and Alpacas running free and along side of the train as we traveled. Last train car is partially open allowing fantastic views and photo opportunities.

Amazing experience not to be missed. We had the best day on this wonderful train. The most comfortable seats and wonderful service. We didn't know anything about this train and it was a wonderful surprise. We were served pre lunch pisco sours and had some wonderful musical entertainment and dancing. We then had a lovely 4 course lunch with wine.In the afternoon there was yet more entertainment with a small fashion show, a demonstration on how to make pisco sour and yet more music and dancing.This was followed by afternoon tea with Bellini.All the while the scenery was fantastic and it was great to watch the changing landscape from the observation wagon. Never aboring moment during the 10 hour journey. Well done Peru Rail.
Magical. This is a great way to spend a day. Big comfy arm chairs, good food served at your table and fantastic views all the way. Well worth the money.

One of a kind wonderful experience. All four people in our group enjoyed the travel on Andean Explorer from Puno to Cusco. It was a unique experience. Staff on board were well trained, pleasant, attentive, and accommodating. They are dedicated to make your experience on this train a memorable one. Peruvian band, fashion show, and a session on pisco-sour drink preparation added additional entertainment.

Wonderful experience!. In March 2014 we travelled on an 8 hour trip on the Andean Explorer along the foothills of the Andes! It really was a very special experience with well trained and attentive staff, great entertainment with a Peruvian Band, a Fashion Parade conducted by staff, pisco sours (very good!), and the food was good as well. Loved the small train and the beautiful fit out of the carriage and the bar/observation car! While there are faster ways to get to Puno from Cusco - I doubt whether the experience is nearly as good. Well done, Peru on your levels of customer service, well trained, friendly staff and your English language skills were excellent!

Excellent!. Initially I was worried about the 10 hour trip ahead of us, wondering what we'd do to pass the time, however it was a pleasure to spend it on the train and it reminded me of being back on the Orient Express. Staff were very attentive, food was great (even catering for special diets), entertainment in the form of pan-piped music, dancing and complimentary pisco sours helped to while away the time and we all arrived to Puno with a smile on our faces. The rear carriage is a car-bar outdoor observatory for which you can admire the stunning scenery and when we reached the city of Juliaca we stood in this car amazed at the most incredible market that we were travelling through, literally selling everything and anything, and sited both sides of the track and actually on the track in places! Has to be seen to be believed! I'd highly recommend the Andean Explorer and would definitely repeat the journey if ever in Peru again. Enjoy!

fantastic experience. Lovely ambling train ride through gorgeous scenery. Think Orient Express but in fabulous mountain valleys.Great photo opportunities from the open observation car. Lovely food and a bar as well!

It costs an arm and a leg but............ There are cheaper ways of travelling from Cusco to Puno, quicker ways too, but if you get the opportunity to do this then take it.There were five coaches when we went early season, one for luggage, one for the kitchen, the bar and observation coach and then just two coaches for the actual passengers. You are sat in armchairs and your every need is catered for. We were constantly being fed and watered with exquisite cuisine and top class cocktails, with the bar there if ever you felt you were sobering up!The passing scenery is of course dramatic, but it was fascinating watching how it changed as we climbed towards Lake Titicaca.Two criticisms would be the cost of those drinks not included in the ticket, and the chaos in the baggage retrieval hall at the end of the journey.
This is the ONLY way to get to Cusco. What a terrific experience - travelling from Lake Titicaca to Cusco by train through the Andes and treated to the full Orient Express service - unbeatable!

Wonderful experience!. The Andean Explorer is a wonderful way to experience Peru from Cuzco to Puno. We found the journey comfortable. The viewing area was excellent for photos...although a little crowded sometimes.The food was very nice, but the service was a little slow.The bathroom was cleaned regularly, which is essential on a long journey.The time just flew by. The highlight was driving through the Juliaca Markets! This was an amazing experience and the locals love see you wave or to hear you call-out "Hola!" as you pass through...
Andean Explorer. The seats were not that comfortable and the smell of diesel fumes coming into the carriages was most unsettling.The food supplied was only average.

Great Way to Travel in Peru. We took this train from Puno to Cusco - it's a 10 hour ride, but the time went by so quickly! The train is so very comfortable with cushy chairs and fresh flowers. The wait staff is always coming by with drinks and food. Lunch was actually very good! You can get up and move around - and the end car is open air so you can get some beautiful pictures. The landscape changes drastically as you travel from the high plains of Puno to the lush valleys surrounding Cusco. Highly recommend!!! Would rather travel this way than rent a car. Truly. And we rent cars everywhere we go.

A great way to travel. We travelled by train from Cusco to Punto. Very comfortable, well appointed train. Food served was very good. The scenery was a super bonus. The journey is almost 10 hours, the staff does a lot, including fashion shows to keep you engaged, but 10 hours is 10 hours!

It was good time, but lacking in prompt service.. We had spent most of our time in Peru travelling by bus and wanted a change, so we booked a ticket for the Andean Explorer. The train ride is 10 hours from Cusco to Puno, and throughout the day we were treated to 1920's carriage, a delicious lunch, afternoon tea, music show and at the back an observation deck to enjoy the scenery. The 10 hours actually went by quickly unlike some of our bus rides. It was a great experience.However, my only complaint of our experience was the service. The staff whilst friendly, were not very attentive and when we asked for water (for a long trip like this people need to stay hydrated) they would walk off and forget. This was consistent throughout the day and was quite frustrating. We ordered drinks for lunch but they never came and when we asked we had to ask 4 times! Very disappointing since this is meant to be a luxury train. I think it would make sense for staff to walk through the carriage filling up water so people don't have to ask. There are plenty of restaurants that offer this. This is my only issue, other than that we had a lovely time.

A highlight of our holiday. Traveling on the Andean Explorer from Puno was one of the highlights of our visit to Peru. The train was made up of luxurious Pullman carriages, and the ten-hour trip from the shores of Lake Titicaca up through the Alto Plano to Cusco passed quickly - amazing and changing scenery, fascinating towns, lunch, tea and complimentary drinks served by lovely staff, and musicians too. And great value for money compared to the cost of a rail journey of similar distance in the UK. Not to be forgotten was the sight of the open air market traders in Juliaca reforming their pitches over the track as the train passed through their town, observed from the open observation car at the rear of the train.

Absolutely top-notch!. From the linen covered tables with flowers, to the Orient Express style carriage lamps, this PeruRail service is first class. Sit back in your armchair and enjoy the ride!You are served lunch and afternoon tea as part of your ticket price, and there's a bar and an observation car where you can go and stretch your legs and take in the impressive views over the AltiPlano. They also do 'happy hour' drinks if you are a fan of pisco sours or Peruvian beer.My husband is a train enthusiast, I just wanted a comfortable ride to Puno. We were both more than satisfied with this journey. It really was an unforgettable experience.
Andean Explorer. Wonderful way to travel from Cuscu to Puno. Excellent staff and first class food,recommended.Great scenery

Got to be done but takes a long time. One of those Iconic journeys you have to and you remember more fondly when you have finished. The journey is through fantastic scenery and you are fed and watered all day long to a decent standard in a 100 year old Pullman train. Down side it takes 10 hrs goes very slow and will rattle your fillings out if you have any. That said famous rail journey that has to be done and you will enjoy.

Fabulous Experience. What a wonderful way to travel from Puno to Cusco! We were supposed to take the bus but changed our mind at the last minute.
