The staff was extremely professional and personable, they went out of their way to take care of all of our needs. Food was excellent and you can't beat the views. Our favorite place to hang out (besides our beautiful window table) was the bar car and attached dome car for picture taking and the Puno music entertainment.

The only way to go to Puno. This train makes any US train look like a disaster on wheels. The food is excellent, the views amazing (once you leave Puno and Cusco), and it is 1000% more comfortable than any bus.

Unexpectedly Enjoyable. The thought of a 10-hour train ride from Cusco to Puno was a bit daunting, at least initially. Overall, the train ride aboard the Andean Explorer was very good, and my wife and I enjoyed the experience. The seats were comfortable, the food was good, the views from the train were nothing short of spectacular - views of the Andes as well as the small towns. The ten hour ride seemed to fly by. The one-stop at La Raya at 14,100 feet above sea level was the highest altitude of our entire trip to Peru! The slow ride through the city of Juliaca was memorable in that you could reach out of the window(if you wanted to do this) and actually touch the shops along the tracks. That is how close some of the vendors had their shops alongside the train tracks. It was interesting to see that as soon as the train passed by, the vendors would immediately use the train track space for their "shops." The entire trip was very informative and interesting - I would do it again.

A train ride to remember. Our train ride was booked by our agent and we were glad we had this experience. The journey is long but entertainment and meals keep passengers occupied. Service and food is of a high standard and the beautiful and changeable scenery make this trip enjoyable. The one-hour slow ride into Cusco train station was rather tedious after this long but interesting trip. I would recommend this experience to other travelers.We were there on the 11th April
10 hours went so quick. What a brilliant day! So much to see all the way. The country side was a great insite to how the locals live. Entertainment on board as we went and adequate meals as well.

fabulous scenery. Don't close your eyes; you'll miss something. Wonderful range of eco systems, snatches of agrarian life, and the unforgettable town markets that the train travels right through. Nice food though they could be a little clearer on what is and isn't included. Tea at 3 isn't. Tea a little while later is. The large car in back provides additional excellent viewing.

Not to be missed!. Yes it is expensive, but after trekking and many early mornings it was lovely to just relax and enjoy the experience. My husband and I travelled from Cusco to Puno in April. The service was very good and staff very friendly and polite. I thought coffee upon leaving the station early in the morning could have been included. Yes lunch was a bit late but that was ok, there was plenty of entertainment to keep us occupied, and the complimentary pisco sour was nice. Afternoon tea was served a bit late as well, and it was cold and a bit dried up. Good thing was that this made us full so we didn't have to worry about dinner! Going through Juliaca was a highlight for me, the locals were so friendly as we passed through their market and many waves were exchanged. It was easy to get a taxi to our hotel on our arrival in Puno.The Observation Car was the best, a great way to travel!

A graet way to travel !. we took the train from Puno to Cusco and found this trip a fantastic experience. it is a really comfortable and luxurious train ( although somewhat "old Agatha Christie-style"): a great way to travel and being spoiled. the trip will take about 10 hours, but you never get bored because you get different landscapes to see. We recommend this train !

Disappointing food. We were supposed to be travelling first class but the food quality, presentation and service was below economy standards in most aircraft and nowhere near our expectations gained from travelling on Canada's Rocky Mountaineer and Rollos Rail in Africa.Seat comfort was quite good and the large windows afforded excellent views of the mountains during the first half of the trip but we found the plains of the second half rather boring.

Great day on the Andean Explorer. I took the Andean Explorer from Puno to Cusco and rediscovered my love for train travel. Our trip took around 11 hours from the time we left Puno station until we pulled into the station at Cusco so it does make for a long day. However, the time really flew by as we get to sit back, relax and enjoy the sceneries of the Andean. There are also two meal services (lunch and an afternoon snack) along with a free pisco sour & music show which again help with making the trip seems a lot shorter.I've read some previous reviews which compare the Andean Explorer to a bus which would have been much cheaper. For me though, I would highly recommend the Andean Explorer even at the higher price because it is just a much more comfortable way travel.

Old world style. The carriage was clean and tidy. Service was excellent, as was the food. Views of the scenery from the viewing carriage and our allocated carriage were excellent. However, when boarding the allocated carriage, people sat where they wanted rather than their allocated seats. Although the seats we sat in were good, some people may have been disappointed where they sat when arriving late. Although it was a 10 hour train trip we really enjoyed the trip. We met people from all over the world in the viewing carriage. We highly recommend the train trip.
Train to Aquas Caliente. Amazing - the train was lovely, great comfy seats, excellent views and a wonderful experience overall. We all really enjoyed it

One of my Highlights. If you love train journeys, this is a must do. Forget the cost - just do it! We went Puno to Cusco and I loved every minute (even the "long, dull haul into Cusco"!). The armchair seats were comfy, the service excellent, the food great, the sights amazing, including right through the middle of the Juliaca markets, with stalls centimetres from your window! The scenery was fascinating - past Lake Titicaca, up the dry plains to the pass at La Raya (4313m) and then downhill through the fertile valley to Cusco. The whole 10 hours was brilliant. You can move up and down the train, the toilets were spotless and the 'sightseeing caboose' at the back was fabulous.

Above and beyond. I travelled from Puno to Cusco on this wonderful train on 14th April - would have been my 41st wedding anniversary to a keen railway enthusiast. Right from checking in I was really well looked after, especially by Phatrycya. Everything was beyond expectation, especially the view from the observation car. The onl;y slight drawback - and there's not a lot one can do about it - is the long, dull haul into Cusco at the end of a spectacular journey

A disappointing journey!. What started with such high expectations finished as a disappointing journey. The train is built along the lines of the old Pullman carriages. Arm chair seats which one has for the 10 + hr journey. The trip is not cheap but the service is very average when it comes to the delivery of food and drinks. The lunch service started just after 11.30am but dragged on for nearly 3 hrs. Plus all the food delivered was cold, cold soup,cold fish... This is unacceptable.Afternoon tea.... Was served at 5.45pm!!! Very late and several of the listed choices were not available.What worst is the train arrived late. Our carriage did not un load until nearly 7.00pm.The scenery becomes a bit boring after several hours and service on board made the journey seem even longer.Not a great experience !

One of the highlights of our fantastic Peru trip!. If you have to travel between Cusco and Puno, forget the coach and do this trip! It is fantastic with great views from your luxury seats or the observation car at the back of the train. Traveling past rivers, mountains, high plains, street markets, Peruvian life unfolds before you. The food was great, drinks reasonably priced and the toilets are amazing. British Rail, come here and see how it should be done!
Simply great train trip!!. Relaxing train ride first class second best after Machu Picchu to enjoy in peru !! Views beuitiful ..

No better to travel!. I am not a train spotter but am a train lover when it comes to travel and this is a great example. Cusco to Puno either bus, plane or train. Train is the best option as allows you to move...see countryside not accessible by road...whilst doing it in style. Pisco sour at 10.30am is a great way to start a long train journey. Followed by 3 course lunch and afternoon tea with Bellini. The highlight for me was the last carriage with open back. Beautiful vista at every opportunity and surprisingly not too busy. For me a taste of the Orient Express and Britishness except not at those kind of prices!

A magical ride!. Not often would you say that you enjoyed a 10 hour train ride. However, this ride from Cusco to Puno is fantastic. Seats are individual wing back chairs with large tables and brass lamps. There is also a bar car with a dome where there is live music with various local dances performed. There is also a fashion show and items can be purchased. Included in the ticket price were three meals. The morning snack was fresh fruit, yoghurt and granola. Lunch was a 3 course meal with several things to choose from. It came with a glass of wine. Afternoon tea included several sweets. The food was surprisingly good. There was also Happy Hour where drinks were 2 for 1. ( Just watch your bill at the end - there were many errors)The views from the train were spectacular through the Andean plains. We stopped for a beautiful view of the Andean Mountains and a market where the sellers were quite aggressive. We went through several crowded towns and throughout the trip saw many Peruvians living their daily lives.

An interesting experience but could be better organized. It is an interesting experience, but –and especially taking into consideration the price of the ticket- it must be better organized. For some, it is about the details, but it is the details which make you feel satisfied. Firstly, the boarding could be better organized. In Puno, it is somewhat chaotic with no clear explanations given with regards to check-in etc. Not enough space in the waiting room to sit. On board, it takes forever for the train attendant to pay attention to you. And then it takes roughly from 30 min. to 40 min. to bring your order, even if it is only the coca tea. Besides, in our case, they run out of white wine while serving fish as the main plate. “We don’t have enough for everyone”? With the cost of the ticket close to 200 dollars, you at least expect that they don’t save on wine. By the way, the coffee is the instant coffee. On the positive side, the train attendants helped us with washing fruits and brining extra plates to serve them. One more thing to mention. The tracks are in horrible state. It is like flying in constant turbulence.
unexpectedly pleasant. I was expecting some old, dirty train ride and boy was I wrong! Great views, seats and it comes with free cookies and tea/coffee service!

Great trip!. Take a day to travel between Cusco and Puno on this Orient Express train. The relaxing day helps you adjust to the altitude and the train ride is terrific. The train ride, meals and entertainment all add up to a good value.

Spectacular journey. We took the Andean Explorer from Puno to Cusco. Everything was top. From the beginning - buying tickets on internet -, til the boarding - well organized with the luggage -, the trip - wth good food, drinks and shows, until the end - receiving your luggage again in Cusco. The staff on the train phantastic, very smart and all the time present. It was an unforgettable journey. At the night we had one problem. Our legs fellt weak and we had the impression the earth were trembling. But sleeping this kind of feeling disappeared totally. Thanks to the guys on the train! Cusco! Machu Picchu! Puno! Lake of Titicaca! Copacabana! La Paz! Combine this places. You will never forget it!

The Only Way to Travel (Puno to Cuzco). This is possibly the most pleasant way to spend 10hours whilst travelling. It is very comfortable, the food is very good, as is the drink and the service but the scenery through which you travel is by far the highlight of this journey. This starts as soon as you leave Puno and travel along the shores of Lake Titicaca across the Altiplano to Juliaca. As you enter Juliaca make sure that you are at the very rear of the viewing car as you will not have seen anything like the market that you pass through and over just make sure that your camera is secure, and snap away. The demonstration of how to make a Pisco Sour is enjoyable as are the Pisco Sours themselves. The music and dancing interludes certainly break up the journey, but they do go on for a while, so choose a seat towards the back so that you can escape in to the viewing car.The journey through La Raya Pass is truly spectacular as you climb up to 4,313 m (14,150 ft), this is also where you pull in to allow the train from Cuzco to pass and have the opportunity to stretch your legs at the little station at the head of the pass,This is also a very relaxing journey and a good way of recharging your batteries as you travel through Peru. If you do find yourself wanting to travel between Cuzco and Puno this is the only way to do it!

Great way to travel to Cusco!. Brilliant service, amazing food and entertaining performers! Very glad we splurged the $150 on the 10 hour train from Puno to Cusco! Very comfortable and the performers in the observatory car made the journey pass quickly. Would recommend to all who have a day free in their itinerary as an alternative to a flight or overnight bus!
Fun. We had an amazing trip with wonderful entertainment and beautiful scenery. The service was great too. Would tell anyone this is a must do trip!!!

What a way to travel. We took this train ride as it is said to be one of the most beautiful train rides in the world. I would have to agree. Cannot beat the scenery. Train left on time, but never went more that 40 mph. If one thing could be changed, I would have it go faster. The carriages were great and since the train was not full, we had the table and seats across from us all to ourselves. We enjoyed music from local musicians, a welcome pico sour, fashion show and a lesson on how to make pico sours. Lunch was good with several choices. We were asked what would like to drink with lunch, however it never arrived. Our host was transferred to another section and our preferences were not followed up. We were then asked to pay for the juice and coffee we ordered, but never received. This made the end of the trip very unpleasent. We also arrived 45 minutes late which after 10 hours, you are ready to be at your destination.

Beautiful Scenery. We took the Andean Explorer from Cusco to Puno. This is a leisurely ten hour journey. The scenery is spectacular and was riveting the entire journey. There was a very nice lunch provided with bar service available. There was one stop at the highest elevation with a small market where you could purchase items. The train itself was beautiful with a great bar and observation car. Our only complaint however was the seating in the main coach. While the coach was beautiful to look at the seating was extremely uncomfortable. All the seats are upright upholstered chairs in which it was impossible to get comfortable for any length of time. The two of us were at a table for four with four seats and it would have been agony if all four seats were occupied. While we were glad we took the Andean Explorer we wish it had been a bit more comfortable.

Cusco to Puno by train. 10 hours on a train across the Andes. We enjoyed a delightful meal, and entertainment was supplied to help pass the time. Passengers were invited to the open observation carriage to enjoy a free Pisco Sour (Peru's national drink) and watch the crew model local knit wear - Peru is famous for Alpaca wool - I did make a purchase and if I didn't live in a hot climate I would have bought much more. We were treated to local music and dance as well. A wonderful trip.
Nice trip. Good train, Nice views. No vegetarian sandwich option so take a snack + water just in case. Have to take pictures / video through glass

A brilliant train trip. First of all I love a good train journey - relaxing and a great way to see the countryside / country.This train trip was high on the list of activities we wanted to do whilst in Peru and our itinerary was worked around taking this train as it doesn't run every day.We were taken to the station by our guide who helped us check our bags in and made sure we had everything we needed for onboard. The train departs at 8am and we were settled into our seats well in advance of departure.It begins at a leisurely pace through Puno and Juliaca (where it stops) before slowly weaving its way through the Juliaca market that is located only inches (and in fact on top of) the railway lines. The whole journey is approximately 10 hours arriving into Cuzco in the early evening.Lunch is included in the price but snacks are available on board to buy throughout the trip. Given the early departure we also chose to wait until we were on the train before having breakfast and the scrambled eggs and fresh breads we had were excellent. Lunch is a three course affair and we had a lovely chicken soup followed by beef and then a chocolate pudding.The train makes a brief stop at the highest station allowing you to get out, walk around and take some photographs. Another benefit of the train is the rear carriage is open at the back allowing you to get fantastic pictures without glass windows in the way.With each carriage on one side there are a series of tables for 2 and on the other side mainly tables for 4 with the odd table for two.It was definitely the most amazing train journey I've had the pleasure of taking and something I would recommend.
Worth it just do it. There are many way to get from Cusco to Puno, but this train trip is the best way. Wonderful staff, stunning scenery, lovely food this is a total package. Peru is the highlight.

my best train ride ever!. The Andean Explorer was an amazing experience during our trip in Peru.Old classic style train whith first class service and dramatic mountain view from the window. 10 hours passed unnoticed!

Puno. This is a very posh old style train that took us to Puno to see Lake Titicaca. The appointments are very nice, armchairs and walnut tables, the service excellent and the views spectacular. The open observation car makes you feel like FDR on the campaign trail. Going through the towns where they have to move from the track to let you pass was cool.

Couldn't have imagined that spending10 hours on a train would be so enjoyable. The Peruvian version of the Orient Express? Almost. Wing chairs, tablecloths and standard lamps on the tables, nice curtains, wood panelling, brass trimmings, comfortable bar and spacious viewing area all contributed to a very classy and comfortable ride. The Andean scenery was spectacular and ever changing, from flat, wide plains to snow capped peaks, finishing on the shores of Lake Titicaca. This is a train journey I will never forget. The whole 10 hours was a joy.

Great Train Ride through the Peruvian Countryside. We took the Andean Explorer on our way to Lake Titicaca. It is an outstanding experience if you have the time. The trip takes 10 hours and takes you through part of the Andes, with the highest point reached being 14,172 feet. The first half of the trip takes you through the suburbs of Cusco, along the southern part of the Sacred Valley, and along the Urubamba River. You get into the mountains during the second half of the trip. The cars are luxurious. You sit at four person banquettes, with two arm chairs on each side. The chairs are comfortable but they are placed a little too close and getting out from the window side chair to the aisle requires your seatmate to get out of is/her chair. For sure, order window-side seats on the left hand side (so you can have unobstructed views of the Andes) if you are heading south to Puno. There is some entertainment provided, two musical groups, one playing Cusco music and the other Puno music. They are different. The groups include a dancer demonstrating local dances from Cusco and Puno. The ticket comes with food - a morning muesli, lunch, an afternoon tea, and a free pisco sour. There is a club car for additional beverages which you can purchase and an observation car with an open-air back. The musical groups/dancers play in the club car. In the club car we were treated to a class on making pisco sours and a "fashion show" of alpaca sweaters, dresses. Some might be put off by the 10 hours it takes to reach Puno, but the ride is relaxing and the scenery something you will miss by flying. Bring along some reading material and binoculars. The entire check-in, luggage drop-off was quick and hassle-free. If you try to order tickets on line but your dates are unavailable, try contacting Peru Rail directly by email. That happened to us and our email was quickly responded to and the purchase process was again relatively hassle free.

A wonderful experience. This was a full day trip from Cusco to Puno and was so much more relaxing and enjoyable than a flight. The ticket price included morning tea, lunch, a drink, afternoon tea and an evening meal all while traveling through the countryside with incredible views.

Wow. ONE OF THE HIGH LIGHTS OF OUR FIVE WEEK TRIP. The train travelled thought a market. Stall hollers just move everything just enough for the train to pass and you could see the market close back over the line behind us.
10 long hours!. A long ride but Interesting , the view is of course spectacular, shows on board, and the service is very good, but food is very "moyen". worth the experience.

Andean Explorer of PeruRail. I was expecting more of a third world rail experience and was thoroughly surprised at an excellent tourist experience. The scenery was spectacular and justified the length of the journey. The decor of the train was comfortable, not modern but fitting with the original design of the train cars. Wingback chairs were so much more comfortable than standard train seating of the original construction - and much better, sylistically than if they had simply inserted standard "modern" airplane seating. The food was better than one might expect - not gourmet but that was not the point. If you are touring Peru, take this and enjoy it.

Comfortable and entertaining ride from Puno to Cuzco. The scenery on this trip was spectacular, although the trip would have been more enjoyable had it not taken quite so long. (It took 11 hours to cover the 240 mile route.) The food and drinks were very good, the service was exceptional, and the Andean musicians and dancers who performed for us were very entertaining.

We were entertained the whole journey!. The day long journey to Puno was very enjoyable, wonderful scenery via the observation car and the staff kept us fully entertained with local band and traditional dancing plus fashion shows and bar-keeping instruction!

relaxing and calm way to get to Puno. Runs only on certain days, shifted schedule so can take thisComfortable seats, the timing of the meals was a bit odd and rushed towards the endOvercrowded in the bar and vista carriage at times ("hoggers" at the prime photo spots)The food was not up to par but despite this the overall journey was great and saw some stunning landscapes. Did not seem like 10 hrs at all.

Good service, but can be better. For a route of 10 hours and such and excellent service with all the hospitality they need better chairs. It has an authentic angle but to sit on those chairs for 20 hours is not very relaxing.
Wonderful experience !. It was relaxing to made this trip from Cuzco to Puno without having to drive, perfect service, good food, comfortable atmosphere, beautiful landscapes - well organized !

Top Experience. We have just reached Puno after a 10 hour trip from Cusco on the Andean Express. The seating was very comfortable. The carriages and most importantly the windows were clean. The food was fresh and as they had been advised in advance that I needed gluten free food I was presented with an excellent freshly prepared selection. The entertainment was optional as was the fashion parade as they were held in the observation carriage. There was absolutely no pressure to attend and there was no need to buy extra drinks etc as there was more than enough provided during this journey. We did, however have 2 excellent cafe lattes, at reasonable prices. The train was on time, meals were served at the times announced. All in all we were sorry that the journey came to an end.

Comfortable train with great views. The train trip is part of the whole Machu Pichu experience. Not fast but goes through some fascinating scenery. Light refreshments served. Make sure you are on river side of carriage -view from other side are limited.

A let down. My wife have travelled on the blue train in South Africa and the Maharajah Express around parts of India and were expecting at least parity with the Andean Explorer Train. We travelled from Puno to Cusco and being the time of year there was only one carriage which was to our benefit in that we left and arrived on time, meals were served earlier than announced (although the announcement was for the train coming from Cusco to Puno) and the service was timely. The scenery on the second half of the trip was fantastic - partly due to being in the rainy season. So that said why am I only rating this as average. Well, through out the journey there was a sense of the staff aggressively upselling additional services (drinks / food clothes etc) and when turned down the smile became a frown. For the price coffee and tea should be included as should the breakfast. What should be a pleasant laid back trip is ruined by the aggressive upselling. As mentioned in many of the reviews the quality of food was not great and looked as though it had all been pre prepared and just heated up for the trip. The afternoon tea was slow and by now the staff gave the impression they were would be glad to reach the terminal and finish for the day.

Pretty scenery, fun activities and ability to relax. I was apprehensive about a 10hrs journey, especially after reading some comments on TA. I was especially worried about my 8yrs old and 10yrs old sons' ability to be patient, even though they are used to long flights and travels. Of a 2 weeks tour of Peru, this turned out to be one of our favorite days. The chairs are extremely comfortable, the rustic elegance takes you back to travel in the old days. Everything was clean, and we found the service to be quite good. I agree that the food was only average. I had also read the comments about food delays, we packed snacks and a couple sandwiches, but we did not experience that problem. As we traveled the day before Christmas and the train was only half full, I suspect that we lucked out on the server/traveler ratio. We enjoyed the dancing, music, and pisco happy hour. The tables allowed us to play cards and other games. We spent a lot of time in the viewing wagon, talking to other travelers. Oddly, not many people partook, despite the scenery and beautiful weather.I do agree with other travelers that the doors are a problem. We had originally been booked at tables near the door, and were thankfully able to switch, else wise it would have been miserable. The company should invest in automatic doors or systems to not aggravate the situation. I highly recommend this trip.

A day in the Andean Explorer. We did the less selected route from Puno to Cuzco, which is cheaper. The train ride is about 10 hours (350 km) and includes food, live local music and dances as well as a fashion show (local alpaca clothing) and a course to learn to do the Pisco Sour, the Peruvian notional drink.Service on board is perfect. Train goes slow through many villages and it's possible to enjoy the view. The only thing that didn't met our expectation was the food. We had the local Titicaca trout but it was so over cooked, it was hard like plastic. Same with the steamed vegetable, too cooked.
Fantastic Experience. Perfect service on board,deliscious food and a panoramic view of the beautiful natural sights of the Andean Mountain.

Trainride from cuzco to Puno. 15th january 2014. If you have the money and need to get from cuzco to puno or the other way around then take the Andean Explorer with Peru Rail. It is first class and takes you through amazing mountains and scenery. The observation deck is amazing. They have live music and dancers on board and the food that is included fits to the first class. The service from the staff is also first class. This is a trainride you should get on if you have the posibility. There will be no regrets

A very long train ride. The cars were very nice, but we were told on booking that it was a 7 hour ride and it took over 10 hours to go from Cuzco to Puno. They took our lunch order at 9 and served lunch at 2. Be sure to bring warm clothes as the cars at times were very cold. Food was just ok. The scenery for the fist half was spectacular (similar to the MP train), but the second was the dull drab altiplano.

Fantastic!. We took the train from Puno to Cusco on a Saturday. Be aware that it doesn't run every day, so build your itinerary accordingly. It was easy to book this train through the Peru Rail website. Any questions I had were answered promptly and accurately. Also be aware that you can check your luggage on this train.The train, itself, is just like in the pictures- comfortable armchairs, tables with tablecloths. The observation car is great giving you the opportunity to stand outside and get a great feel for the route you take. The meals were very good- 3 course lunch, and afternoon tea. Not mentioned in the information is the morning pisco break with entertainment, the pisco making lesson with more entertainment including a band and dancers or the stop at the highest point with the usual possibility of souvenir shopping. The 10 hours passed most pleasantly as we enjoyed the luxury of this 20s inspired train through the Andes.

Great way to get from Cusco to Lake Titicaca, overpriced. This was a great relaxing way to get from Cusco to Lake Titicaca. The scenery was nice, and the train was nicely done up too. The down side is that it is very expensive and when we hopped on they told us that water was free. We asked several times for more water but at the end of the trip they tried to charge us for the bottles of water that they had brought, considering the price that you have to pay and that you are told it is free we thought it was disgraceful. We refused to pay, and they let us go without too much fuss.
Andean Explorer. Disliked the seating. some passengers did not sit in their assigned seats creating problemsThe train seemed crowdedI would upgrade to the Hiram Bingham if visited again

A great train journey.. My wife and I took the Andean Explorer from Puno to Cusco on December 30. We were impressed by the quality of the train and the service provided by the train staff. The seating was comfortable armchairs facing our own table. The carriage was a little cool early in the day so we asked for blankets to cover our legs and these were brought immediately. Whatever we needed was provided. The train was not full, and the ratio of staff to passengers was good. Free pisco sours were served in the observation/bar car twice during the trip, and a champagne cocktail was served just before afternoon tea. Lunch was served on time. My wife's meal of soup and lasagne was very good, my meal of potatoes and trout was not as good, but the chocolate dessert was fine. Afternoon tea was served around 4:30, and was good, especially the dessert chocolates. Although this is a long trip the scenery is spectacular and the armchairs were comfortable enough to snooze in. There was live music in the bar car and a demonstration of some local costumes. The observation/bar car was the centre for socialising throughout the day. Overall this was a memorable trip.

Andean explorer train. I travelled from Cusco to Puno with my husband on Christmas Day. It was a very pleasant experience almost as if traveling back in time. The interior was very well decorated and maintained, and the toilets were comfortable and clean even after a 10 hour ride. The staff were up beat and helpful. They offered a fashion show of lama wool products (serving free pisco sour) as well as a short music show which made time go by pleasantly. On a whole the food was not amazing but they kept coming by with various nibbles. The main negative point was the temperature. The carriage we were in was next to the last open carriage ( really very beautiful and good for taking photos) and the door between the two was rarely closed making our carriage increasingly cold. On a whole it will remain an unforgettable experience.

Andean Explorer train. The interior was great, the scenery was fantastic - but the food was average. The service was below standard and the staff kept door of the carriages opened so I was rapidly developing cold. I got up several times to either close the doors or plead with them to close the doors behind them and that was randomly respected. When you enter the train like that, one expects better service. I do believe the staff was not trained properly and they really should speak languages better because it is the train that regularly takes tourists from all over the world.

Great journey apart from other travellers. What could have been a sensational trip was marred for us by where we were sitting and the behaviour of fellow passengers.. We booked online with Peru Rail and were allocated seats 31 and 36, a table for two opposite each other in Carriage A which is right in front of the drinks/viewing car. This table is right next to the door on the left as you go into the carriage. This meant that for ten hours (except when people were eating) we were closing the door behind people going to the viewing car. It was like sitting in a throughfare - middle aged fellow travellers who should know better but unable to close the door behind them plus harassed staff with trays of drinks. The same people kept coming through, oblivious when we slammed the door behind them to keep out the noise and the cold. However despite this major irritation the train is gorgeous, well appointed, and reminiscent of a bygone era. Love the little bud vases on the table with red roses, table lamps and cloths. Expect morning tea, lunch and afternoon tea plus pisco sours and entertainment on board. The scenery ever changing - what a vista, going through villages and towns, fields and gorges. It left on time from Puno but was late getting into Cusco but this is about the journey as they say not the destination. There are plenty of photo opportunities and one retail opportunity for handicrafts halfway. But don't expect to see anything you haven't seen before from these sellers. If you are getting picked up by your hotel as we were, there are two pickup spots at Cusco railway station. We thought we had been let down but our taxi was waiting on the street up a walkway from the station. Our advice is to get seats in a carriage at the front of the train and when you do go to the viewing car at the back CLOSE the door behind you.

Andean Explorer Train from Cusco to Puno. The train was luxurious. The seats were very comfortable. One was big enough to seat my 26 lb. toddler and my 55 lb. 6-year old. There were four seats to each table. The food was delicious and the service fantastic. There was live entertainment in a separate car. There was also an open caboose where you could stand and get some fresh air. The best part about the train was the relaxed way in which we were able to take in the country side. We are able to take amazing photos and the children liked that they could stand in the back, walk around, wave at village children, and look at all the animals as we went by. It was quite an experience to ride through Juliaca and observe the poverty. Every foreigner on the train was in awe as we rode through that town. Because the train ride was ten hours, we made friends with almost everyone in our car and that added to the enjoyment of the experience. It was certainly one of the highlights of our trip and I would recommend it to everyone.

Great part of our vacation. We took the Andean Explorer from Puno to Cusco, and it was a great experience. The food was good, the service quick, and the views of the countryside were great (especially from the observation car on the rear of the train). Highly recommend.

Good Experience but a few glitches. Overall the trip on the Andean Explorer was good however there were a few gliches. The seats are comfortable and it is good to be able to move around the train. The viewing area and the lounge are excellent. The food was good given the limitations the staff work under. I felt the service was patchy mainly because the staff were rushed off their feet so requests for drinks seem to get forgotten. My main issue was the timing of the meal. Our table was set up at 11.30 but we did not actually get lunch until 2.30. After a 6.30am start we very hungry. The scenery was great and ranged from the mountains to passing through busy towns. I would recommend the trip but felt the service could be improved.

UNIQUE EXPERIENCE. We had the time of our life and thoroughly enjoyed the train ride through the Andean landscape. Service and entertaiment were perfect and staff and personnel did everything to make it a memorable journey. We would recommend this journey to every tourist who has to travel from Puno to Cuzco !!
One of the worlds great train trips!. 11 of the best hours of my life. Wouldn't have minded if it lasted twice as long.Fantastic train and amazing sceneryWhat more could you want

Comfortable Journey Puno to Cusco. We enjoyed this relaxing journey from Lake Titicaca to Cusco. I have nothing negative to say. Seating was comfortable, the food better than I expected after reading some of the reviews, all facilities clean and the staff very friendly.Passing through the market of Juliaca is a once in a lifetime experience, make sure that you are on the observation deck before passing because taking pictures of this event is fantastic.The scenery keeps one entertained, take a good nap when it gets boring and the 10 hours fly by. We were a little bit late arriving but nothing worth complaining about. Overall the best way to get from Puno to Cusco.

Very relaxing and enjoyable day. The train itself is very comfortable and the service is excellent. A three course lunch, afternoon tea and a welcome drink are included. You can also order other drinks and food though out the trip. The scenery changes quite a lot from mountain vistas to small villages. A much more enjoyable way to travel between Cusco and Puno than by bus or plane!

Luxury on rails. A great experience not to be missed on a visit to Peru. We travelled from Puno (Lake Titticaca) to Cusco. The journey, taking a full day from morning to early evening, takes you through a varied Peruvian landscape and towns. The open rear wagon gives passengers an extensive panoramic view as the train slowly makes it way, at one point passing right through the middle of a market, with the vendors clearing items from the track then immediately putting them back again behind the train, in some cases leaving them in place as the train passes harmlessly over them, truly amazing sight. With so much to see and appreciate, enjoying the splendid onboard service was secondary. The carriages are fitted out very elegantly, polished wood and soft furnishings abound, very comfortable armchairs at your own dining table, super service, provided in our case by the ever atttentive Nora. It's all very indulgent.The train was late into Cusco, but that's not the point of it. Travel by road and everything flashes by, not much quicker and far far less civilised and enjoyable. Take the train, it's really very wonderful.

Great trip. We left on the Andean Explorer - Cusco to Lake Titicaca.The journey was a wonderful way to see the countryside. The train was like a time warp - dining car and viewing platform, polished brass and mahogany.The facilities were good - staff kept the toilets very clean. They were welcoming and very hard working. They seemed to be overworked and the company should maybe employ more staff. Food decent - free coca tea but have to pay for coffees and other drinks.The stop at Central Arraya was the highlight.Only downside is the time at 10+ hours as 8 would be perfect.

Above & Beyond service on Peru Rail. I recently returned from a trip to Peru where we used Peru Rail quite a bit. Our first trip was from Puno to Cuzco. The service on board the train was great - good attetiveness by the staff, fun experiences (from bartending classes on how to make Pisco Sours and more). However, I had a bit of an issue upon arriving in Cuzco wherein another passenger took my suitcase (apparently, they didn't check that it wasn't at all similar except in color!) At any rate, as you can imagine, I panicked! However, the staff at Peru Rail, particularly, the supervisor (Patricia - I may be spelling her name wrong) - were so helpful! They admitted this had never happened before and yet, that didn't deter them from being as creative as possible to figure out how to get my bag back. Finally, we tracked down the gentleman who took my bag, and Patricia came with us to the hotel to ensure that we traded bags properly. Granted - this is something they should have done but it was the professionalism by which this was handled that I was impressed by.Later, we took Peru Rail from Cuzco to Machu Pichu. And, upon arriving in Machu Picchu, we were greeted by a representative from Peru Rail who said that Patricia had sent him with her sincere apologies for what had happened. He then gave us each a "welcome" bag of sorts which had a Peru Rail backpack and a Peru Rail water bottle (filled with cold water for our trek up to Machu Picchu!) - how thoughtful. This part was unnecessary in my opinion - it wasnt' there fault that some guy took the wrong bag! All in all, very impressed by the professionalism of the staff at Peru Rail - particularly, Patricia! And highly recommend this as an option if you travel to Peru!

A very enjoyable day.. Cusco to Puno is either 10 hours by coach or 10 hours by rail. Take your pick. This is old rolling stock running on an old line so don't expect what you find on some of the world's other great train journeys. You see rural Peruvian life pass by slowly as the train climbs to 4300m for the main stop where you can stretch your legs. The staff work hard and are very responsive. Lunch was good considering the situation and the bar/observation car are very good. All in all a very god experience.

Cheap for Orient Express, but still overpriced for what you get. As a couple of 20-something backpackers splurging on a $200+ luxury train ride, we weren't too suprised to see most occupants were at least 20-30 years our senior.The trip started off well with prompt breakfast service, although you had to PAY for breakfast... even after I've already forked out all that money for the train ride. This was followed by a free pisco sour (at 9am? I like this train..) but then I began to wonder when these 'wonderful' views would turn up.The scenery was nice, but if you've taken the train to Aguas Calientes, visited Macchu Picchu or gone on one of the tours to the Salt Mines or Moray (out of Cusco) then it isn't anything new. The train itself is really nice and well fitted out, but the service really lets it down.Lunch eventually arrived, 2 hours late. When we stopped for photos up by the mountains my girlfriend had fallen very ill (not from the train food, probably from dinner the night before) so I asked if we could access our luggage to get some medicine. Eventually one of the staff told me that the luggage compartment was locked and we couldn't, but he would get us some medicine and bring it to us. We never saw him again. We also asked one of the waitstaff the same question but he never seemed to do anything about it.As expected (from previous reviews) the train was about 1.5-2 hours late, but we figured that would be the case. With no real information over the speakers or from the staff, we eventually all shuffled out onto the station.The train was nice, the scenery was just okay, but there was no way I would contemplate doing the trip again. The train tracks follow the highway for 90% of the journey - you'll get the same views on the bus, get there faster, and spend a lot less money.

Disappointed. We had high expectations for this train journey.On the plus side, nice observation car.Downsides, scenery monotonous, especially after taken the visadome train the Machu Picchu.Took forever for the lunch to be served. We were told lunch served at 1pm. Eventually got the starter at 140pm, the mains was delivered at 210pm. And desert at 235. The outcome was that the stewed beef was cold. I think it had just taken so long to serve the food. We were in carriage A , which was at rear of train. It was a shame since the food itself seemed well prepared. If there is a shortage of staff, then much better to stagger the meal times by carriage. It was clear that the service was being done by carriage, since before our meals arrived , people who had finished their meals were coming through our carriage to the observation car. Seating was comfortable howver when the sun came out, the train got very hot as no air conditioning. Remember to take own water as only free with lunch, The process was similar for the afternoon tea, we were told to take our seats early at 450pm, they served a pre-tea alcoholic drink, but nothing for those not drinking alcohol. The tea didn't arrive until 530pm , again I suggest serving by carriage, if there are not enough waiters. The journey took 11hours, and the guide that met us, informed us that it was common for the train to be more than 12 hours. In hindsight having spoken with those that took the much quicker bus journey, we would have taken the bus.

Great experience on the Andean Explorer train. Recently travelled on the Andean Explorer train from Cusco to Puno with my spouse. I had read reviews about it prior to our travel and they were spot on. The 10+ hours did not seem long at all - I have to say that I rather be 10 hours on TAE than flying for the same time which can be quite uncomfortable especially travelling economy. On TAE it was first class service all the way from the cheerful and obliging staff whom I thought were efficient and very polite. The train is beautifully decked out and chairs were very comfortable. Passengers were free to move to the observation deck for photos, join in the entertainment provided or enjoy a drink or two at the bar. I learnt to concoct Pisco Sour on TAE! Of course one of the highlights for me was simply to relax and take in the stunning countryside scenery most of the way and what photo opportunities. Thank you TAE for a most enjoyable and memorable trip. Highly recommended.

A long journey but worth it. We travelled from Puno to Cusco having travelled to Puno by bus. Whilst the bus was very comfortable, cheaper and quicker than train by a couple of hours or more and shared the views the train return was well worth it. The train carriages are beautifully fitted out in wood, brass, glass lights, fresh flowers and comfortable arm chairs. The bar and viewing platform were great to relax and enjoy the stunning scenery. (And the best toilet we have seem in Peru or on any train).The staff were great with entertainment of ticket inclusive morning pisco sour cocktails with musicians and dancers from Puno, a good 3 course lunch with wine, afternoon happy hour with more music and dancing from Cusco, ending with afternoon tea.The trip was over 10 hours but a classy way to travel through amazing scenery so worth taking time out.One note, book seats facing forwards, we forgot but staff found us free seats facing forwards.

A journey not to be missed. It was with great trepidation waiting to board the train from Puno to Cuzco...what could we have been thinking of - 10 hours on a train! As soon as we boarded the train our fears were allayed. Luxurious seating, an amazing observation carriage, attentive staff and even on board entertainment. As the train trundled through the ever changing countryside, stunning scenery around every corner, we were so delighted to have made the choice of this wonderful train journey rather than a boring flight.

one of the highlights of our trip. We were really excited about the train journey from Cusco to Puno and it did not disappoint. We boarded at 8.00 and spent the majority of the morning in the observation car looking at the amazing scenery and taking an incredible amount of photos. The train is very comfortable and we had a table to ourselves, as did most of the people in our carriage. We stopped off at a local market before lunch. The views from this stop off point were great an\d it was a good way to meet some of the locals and a chance for me to buy some presents!The food was tasty though a little on the small side and it took a long time for it to be served - we were supposed to eat at 1.00 but didnt get our main meal until 2.30ish. Afternoon tea was also then served late.All in all a great day, worth the money and a highlight of our trip.

Lived up to all expectations.. This train trip was pre booked for us as part of a package tour of Peru and after several days of strenuous walking and climbing we really appreciated the comfort and relaxation. Although owned by Peru Rail the train is operated by Orient Express and it certainly lived up to its name. We were entertained by an Andean music group in the station while waiting to board the train. They then joined us on board and entertained in the observation coach. The seats were very comfortable and tablecloths etc pristine. The staff were attentive and professional and the food was beautifully presented. The few minutes 'half way house' stop along the way helped to stretch our legs and gave the shopaholics yet another chance to buy at the little market! The scenery was spectacular all the way. We lost count of all the little blue 'thunder boxes' in the villages!!

Cancelled. The journey on the Andean explorer today was supposed to be one of the highlights of our trip to Peru. Late yesterday we received a call from the travel agency to inform us that the train was cancelled due to the protests in Juliaca which started on Tuesday. I fully understand that the safety of the passengers and property is of prime concern. However by the time the agency was notified every tour bus was full. At 9 pm we were notified that they had managed to arrange for a private car, guide and driver to transport us to Puno. It would have been extremely difficult if we had to make these alternate arrangements on our own.

A full day on train, nice but long.... We did this nice ride from Puno to Cusco. The train is nice, clean, the lunch was good but not a fancy one. They do some kind of divertissement on board, music and dance, Pisco Sour hour. But for us it was to see the view on the way, who was interesting. After all the scenic ride become all the same and if we have to do the choice again , next time we will take the plane.

Only if you are a train buff. Advertised as one of the top train trips in the world. Was supposed to take 10 hours from Cusco to Puno. Took us 12.5 hours. Delay was due to a an accident that blocked the tracks, which was not the fault of the train company. We had to change trains to the one that was coming from Puno to Cusco and those passengers had to get on our train. The staff did not clean the train we transferred to, so we, the passengers had to bus the tables and remove dirty table cloths. Staff was always in a hurry and did not provide good service. Also, the train company should have provided complimentary water due to the delay, but the passengers had to pay for everything.Once it gets dark, there is nothing to see. After about four hours, I was done. In retrospect, we should have flown to Puno. Only two hours.

Do Yourself a Favour. Sharon and I had been recommended that we up-grade from bus to train for this portion of our trip from Cusco to La Paz by our travel advisor and WOW what an awesome day.The train leaves from Cusco 4x a week at 8am and takes about 10 hours to get to Puno about 6pm. The scenery is amazing and constantly changes as you slowly wind your way up to the heights of the Altiplano ... slow enough so you can leisurely take in the wide and masive landscape views and get small snap-shots of the lives of the many people who live along the tracks.You will be fully entertained with on-board fashion shows, live andean music, beautifully prepared and tasty cuisine, pisco sours and local wines.There is a stop 1/2 way during the day at a local market on the side of the tracks for some recreational shopping.The carriages offer plenty of comfort with wide window views to take in the scenery ... seats are very comfortable. There are plenty of seating options arranged to cater for groups of 4 or 2's either sitting facing each other or side by side ... get to the station early so that you can ensure you get the best option for you depending on the size of your party.All the entertainment occurs in the rear carriage which also has a outsde viewng platform for those with asperations to take that perfect picture or just those to take in some fresh air.Eat, drink, immerce yourself in the entertainment, and take in some absolutely amazing scenery.One of the highlights of our trip .... you just have to take this option if you intend to travel overland between Cusco and La Paz.Breathtaking !!!!

lovely train trip. Delightful train ride from Cuzco to Puno....wonderful service, excellent facility, beautiful scenery. Highly recommended for travel between those points. Would do again in a heartbeat.

GREAT WAY TO TRAVEL BETWEEN PUNO AND CUSCO. Whenever I go on holiday, I try to include a train trip of some sort. This trip whilst in Peru (my route was Puno to Cusco) did not disappoint.This is a very comfortable journey. You have your own table and chair in your dining cart and can leave your belongings at your table, if you wish to go to the bar or observation deck. I was a solo traveller and had my table for one. It was very spacious with plenty of legroom. The lunch included a complimentary drink and you also get a welcome Pisco sour included in the price. The wooden panelling of your dining cart and the toilets gives this a lovely sophisticated feel of a bygone era. The toilets are constantly kept clean.The scenery during this 10 hours and entertainment provided throughout the journey means the 10 hours go by very quickly indeed. Entertainment includes: welcome pisco sour in the bar, live music and dancing, a cocktail making demo and a small fashion show where they showcase some of the items of clothing (made from alpaca of course) that you can purchase on the train.Considering the price, my lunch was of a very high standard. Afternoon tea consisted of a couple of pieces of sandwich, but I was too full up to try it. This trip is excellent value for money and a really nice way to travel between Cusco and Puno.I would highly recommend this to anyone.

An accident spoilt our journey. We booked the Andean Explorer as a treat during our backpacking trip, from Cusco to Puno. When we arrived we were very impressed with the waiting area and live music but couldn't help noticing no one else had luggage except us. Turns out they were all collected but we were made to carry our large backpacks and find somewhere to put them on the train. The service was good, the train was comfortable and the views were amazing. Our lunch was extremely rushed and we wondered why the staff were running up and down the train. Before we'd finished dessert they announced there was a problem on the lines and we had to get off and change onto another train. We had to jump down a 4 foot drop onto unlevel ground, again carrying our bags as a lorry had overturned on the lines. While this wasn't Peru rail's fault at all, the way they dealt with it was what ruined our trip. The engine was connected to the viewing car which filled with black smoke so could no longer be used. The seats were all facing backwards, we were never told how long the delay would be (we were stuck at the scene for less than an hour but arrived in Puno 3.5 hours late). I'm glad I experienced it but if I had the chance I wouldn't do it again.

The way to Travel in Peru. I had the opportunity to ride the Andean Explorer train from Cusco to Puno, Peru and would do it again. We arrived to the train station at 7;30 and boarded the train almost immediately. Seating is reserved on the train. I was with a small group and we were all together. The train left on time at 8:00 am on our 10 hour trek to Puno. The cars are in wood paneling and very comfortable seats combined with a table where you are served beverages and meals.The service level was impressive throughout the trip with a 3 course lunch, afternoon tea and a Pisco Sour time. They also have a viewing car with a bar that offers entertainment throughout the trip. The train makes a stop at the highest point where you can get off and stretch your legs. the altitude could be felt at that stop but it was good to stretch our legs.The bathroom was always kept clean and was quite large for a train bathroom. My only negative was not about the train but in going through the towns - the trash. Peru must work to clean up their towns, it was probably the worst I have ever seen in all my years of travel. Such a beautiful country and such bad trash in the towns the train passed through.

WOW! One of the great train journeys of the world.. Absolutely the best train journey I have ever taken in my life. Surely this must be one of the great train journeys of the world. The scenery was breathtaking: snow capped mountains, herds of alpacas, Inca villages, a stopover at 4375 meters and a cool journey through Juliaca. I recommend you get your camera ready and be at the back of the observation car when you get to Juliaca. The train passes through a really cool market. Books, vegetables etc. for sale are laid on the sleepers.

No better way to travel. I booked on perurail website without problem and looked forward to the trip for several months. It is a beautiful train and wonderful journey. The staff are friendly and go out of their way to make the experience an excellent one. They are clearly proud to be working with this special experience. The lunch was not as warm as I like but tea was great! We travelled Puno to Cusco and cannot imagine a better way to arrive in this lovely city. Money well spent.

My best train ride ever!. The train car was out of the past, being a 60 year old, an excellently refurbished Pullman model. The service was above expectation and fun. I would much rather spend 10 hours on this trip than travel the same timespan by air, even in first class. The scenery was constantly changing and full of surprises, from sunshine, to dust and rain storms. All exciting. A great travel experience encompassing the past and the present.

Travel in style. This train was great fun! Spending 10hrs on a train did not fill me with excitement but I loved it. it has the elegance of yesteryear. The countryside is ever changing so there is no boredom and the Andean folk music and dance were not tacky. The train travels through a market where the stall are less than 20cms away and there is a photo stop at the highest altitude point of 4320metres. Train travel certainly beats the bus and affords great insights into the Peruvian outback. The lunch and afternoon tea were about average for train food. One word of warning you will be offered expressos, hot chocolate and water which are not included in the package and staff do not make you aware of this.

This time it wasn't a surprise. After enjoying the train trip to Macho Pichu, we weren't surprised , yet by no means was this trip less enjoyable. On the contrary, we loved every minute of this long trip. Frankly an the time the travel agent suggested we take this trip I was a bit hesitant , after all, 10 hours. But, these were the shortest 10 hours I remember. The train is in a very good shape, well looked after and one is reminded of Agatha Christie's books. It was long enough trip to make new friends, enjoy the sights from the observation car, the Pisco sour, food and the entertainment. It made me look for other interesting train trips around the world. I do Hope to experience another trip like this. I think it is a great way to climb to the altitude of Puno . But it was a strange experiens to drive through Puno,s market, made us feel like colonialist.

Wanerful way to go from Cusco to Puno. The train is luxurious. The lunch was elegant and very good. The two music groups, one playing music from the Cusco region, one from Puno region, were very good. The service was excellent. A great way to travel, at least once.

Andean non train trip. We are so disappointed as my husband, who is a train enthusiast, was so looking forward to the Andean train trip only to hear it was cancelled the afternoon before we left.Fortunately Lima tours (with a little encouragement) helped us change our arrangements so we could get to Puno to continue our tour into Bolivia However it disappointing and people will not take the risk of booking as it is expensive and it is not easy to make other arrangements.

train ride to tell your friends about. This train is designed for comfort and to allow for you to enjoy the magnificent surrounding scenery, dinner, drinks entertainment, viewing carriage,.. this is not one to miss.

Wow. What a fantastic trip and was one of our highlights of traveling round Peru. Service was outstanding the food was excellent and the train itself is reminiscent of Victorian splendour. Seats were very comfortable which was very welcome for the 10 hour journey. Viewing car is fantastic and allows for a great view over the terrain. Very highly recommended and much more pleasant than others that had taken the bus.

Step back in time. What a wonderful experience this is and definately recommended. These pulman carriages furnished with dark timber, brocaded ceilings and walls,linen cloths and table lamps, roses on the tables and large comfy armchairs make you feel like aristocracy. An excellent 3 course meal with wine included, musicians and dancers all make this 10 hour ride fly. We didnt want to get off. The only thing missing was Inspector Poirot!!So far the highlight of the trip.Room to move in the last 2 cars with a bar and an open area. Train doesnt get faster than about 80 ks per hour.

Gorgeous. It would have been far quicker to go by bus, but doing so means missing out on a fabulous experience. The train is designed for comfort, the food is excellent (although the service was a little slow, particularly with drinks) and the entertainment in the bar really broke the journey up. The 10 hours flew by. Particularly interesting was the time through the market at Juliaca, when the market stall awnings had to be lifted out of the way of the train. My only comment - why do they have to serve the horrid Coca-Cola San Luis water?!

Best deal ever!. I took the train from Puno to Cusco and highly recommend this to other. You travel in first class with your own table, have an observation car, they include lunch and afternoon tea, a few free drinks and some entertainment. It is an 8 am to 6 pm journey with gorgeous scenery. Puno to Cusco is about $165 which seemed like an incredible value to me. The reverse direction costs more but is still well worth the money. The trip makes for a delightful and relaxing day.

PeruRail - Expedition Train from Cusco to Agua Calientes. Taking the train from Cusco to Agua Calientes to see Machu Picchu. The seats are comfortable, snacks and coffee or beer is offered. The trip to Agua Calientes is about 3 hours long and takes you through the Andes Mountains. The views are breath-taking. You can easily take a cab from your hostal in Cusco to the train station. Should cost only S/.10 and if you know when you return you can make arrangements with the cab driver to come and pick you up and take you back.

«One of the best memories from Peru!». We did the Puno-Cusco distance for about $ 300 for two persons and it's absolutely worth it! The scenary is amazing (the highest altitude on the trip is at 4319 metres!), the train in itself is geourgeous with nice interior, best train bathroom ever, superb service, great menu, and the last carriage has large windows in walls and roof, is partially openair for a perfect view. A three-course lunch is included with wine, and afternoon tea, other than that the prices were a bit stiff. The hours passes quickly and we absolutely recommend this way of travel, either Cusco-Puno or Puno-Cusco – instead of bus or plane!

Great Ride with Spectacular Views. We took this train in June 2013 to Aguas Calientes (Machu Pichu). This same day, a rock slide occurred cancelling many of the earlier trains and threatening our trip. Luckily the train company and railroad workers were able to clean the debris up in time to get the trains running again in time, but it was a little hectic to say the least. We did pay extra for the upgraded package and food service but never received the upgrades due to the chaos, but in all honesty we were just happy to not miss our train and trip to Machu Pichu.The train stewardess Luz was incredibly friendly and knowledgeable on the history of not only Cusco, but the entire country and she stayed with us throughout the majority of the ride and talked with my family and I informing us of a lot of interesting information. Thanks Luz!

Very over-priced ride but gorgeous views are priceless. We took the train from Cusco (Poroy) to Aguas Calientes and back. The train trip was the most expensive thing we purchased on our entire 3 week trip in South America other than our flights into and out of the country.The Poroy station is not in Cusco. You must taxi or bus here. Our hostel recommended taking a taxi which was kind of expensive but divided by 3 people it was alright.We were told by the Peru Rail Agency in Cusco to not bring any bag, just to have a little backpack or bag in comparison to the standard size backpacking bag... well once we arrived at the station we saw people with large suitcases and backpackers with bags even larger than ours. They do not check for luggage and we did not hear of anyone having to pay for their lugagge at all.We took the cheapest service in the train in the Expedition class and franky the seats were great and the views were stunning. I do not think the Vistadome would have been much better. Included in the service is a drink and a snack.

A great trip with sights of snow covered Andes and villages on the way to Machu Picchu. Purchase a ticket at the Perurail Office off Plaza Armas. It's easy. We took the expedition train there and the vista dome back. I wouldn't spend the extra $ on the vistadome. We left early which allowed us to get to Aguas Calientes by 11 am, obtain tickets for Machu Picchu then hike the Putucosi Peak in the afternoon. A great way to spend the day. After an early sunrise tour of Machu Picchu we caught the afternoon train back. Well worth it!

Unforgettable. Lonely planet says don't waste your money on this trip...NONSENSE...this is an unforgettable experience.five star luxury..cocktails..lunch..afternoon tea..fashion show..dance and music exhibition and scenery to die for. Room to move around..an observation car..a separate bar area.It is not cheap but is worth every penny.

Easiest 10 hour train ride you'll ever take-- a great experience. We took the Andean Explorer Train between Puno and Cusco and it was a GREAT experience. Instead of feeling like we lost a day of our trip in transport, we felt like we had spent the day on a tour. The train itself is lovely, outfitted like something out of an old movie, with wood paneling and details. The seats are quite comfortable.The day is designed to keep the traveler interested. From live music in the station lobby, to dining service and activities schedule throughout the day (live music, dancing, a cocktail class, etc), There's an open viewing car in back where you can take in the spectacular scenery. Really a delight.
Vert good staff ni Pérou rail. Thank you very much a henry, mirla, and Pablo for their smile and positive energy !! Good trio for us ni thaïs train ! Claire and lucie (the 2 french tourist)

Wonderful views, nice service. Pricey but worth the money (note that the ride is much cheaper in the Puno-Cuzco direction). The train has coaches with restaurant seating and a carriage at the end, which is half bar--half viewing platform (open-air platform at the end -- wonderful on sunny days).The ride is slow and very bumpy. The service is good, the food adequate. Drinks not included (some wine available with lunch).The journey is doable in a mechanical wheelchair. The staff proved accommodating. The easiest way is to spend the ride in the lounge car (with the added bonus of an easy access to the viewing platform) because the restaurant cars have no space for wheelchairs, which necessitates transferring to the fixed-position restaurant seating at tables.Beware that the door to the lounge carriage is very narrow. The door to the restaurant carriage is somewhat wider, but the passage between different carriages is narrow again. Most wheelchairs will not fit through, and wheelchair-bound passengers will need to be carried through.

Machupicchu was amazing!. The food the train served was horrible. The people were overall nice. The tour guide we were given spoke mostly Spanish and was very crowded. The views were amazing. I really enjoyed the trip to Cuzco, Peru

Striking imagery and a time to reflect on the world. After hiking the Inca Trail, this day on the train ride comes in #2 for best experiences in Peru. It wasn't until after lunch that I discovered the Observation Car. It is a shame because there were so many amazing photo opportunities of the farming communities that I missed on the first half of the ride. I spent much of my time in the observation car leaning out over the back, with the wind in my hair, waving at anyone I could see (especially little kids) and observing the Peruvian countryside. It was a very introspective time, allowing me to really experience the moments. By the time we got into Juliaca, I had heard about the people throwing rocks at the train and the danger of it. A security guard came out to ensure that nothing bad happened and to warn us not to lean out to much. We did get rocks thrown at us and a couple people flipped us off, but I also got some waves and smiles. And honestly, I don't blame the people who have resentment towards us. I can understand seeing a train that represents a small group of very wealthy (especially in global terms) observing the very poor. Even with the minor hostility, I have to say that this part of the trip was one of the most interesting. You are going through this large town and the train tracks seem to serve as a marketplace. There are people everywhere selling food, electronics, auto parts, pretty much everything. It was so overwhelming and there was so much going on, but it was fascinating and made for some fantastic photos. This trip will always have a special place in my heart for how it made me feel and the sadness of the world. There were areas that were poor and polluted. Areas that were vast and empty. Areas that were full of activity and crime. There were people that loved us and people that hated us. Very incredible experience.
TOO EXPENSIVE FOR JUST A RIDE. not so good as for the amount of money asked one should expect much more... but good in general terms, nice landscapes.

Unique Experience :-). Definitely the most interesting train journey I have ever taken. The seats are very comfortable, the food is good, service is excellent and the entertainment was a unexpected but welcome treat, a fashion show of local wares being the most bizarre but fun entertainment. The views are spectacular, thank you Perurail :-)
trip to macchu picchu. The breakfast was very local, and very nice. Beautiful ride. Didn´t like my family didn´t get tickets together.

An exciting train ride. I have to start by admitting that my review is probably biased: I live in Switzerland, a.k.a train country, and as many of my fellow country men, I am somewhat of a train buff. Consequently, I knew before boarding the train, that this would be a memorably journey, and it indeed was. The seats are comfortable, the crew very sympathetic and polite, but most important: the landscape is breathtaking and offers many pictures opportunities, either from your seat as you can slightly open the window, or from the observation car at the back. I had a book with me, but didn't open it at all, and spent the entire trip literally devouring the landscape with my eyes. I was quite amused to see other people around me either sleeping or playing with their i-pad, when there was so much going on outside. During our stay in Peru, we also travelled by bus, but the Cusco-Puno train ride was from far the most comfortable transfer, and the one that allowed us to profit a maximum from the landscape, and well worth the cost.Now I have seen that there are some negative comments regarding the slow service. I cannot deny that it is not optimal, but I found that the crew was doing a wonderful job carrying the plates from the kitchen at the front of the train up to the last passenger car. After all, nobody is in a hurry, so who cares if it takes 90 minutes between the start of the lunch and the end. The only complaint I have is that they brought us the desserts, but we then had to wait 20 minutes until they brought the spoons, thus having to look at a very appetizing dessert, without being able to eat it: it is almost a kind of psychological torture!My only recommendation: do it!!!

Get aboard - this is a very special train ride. We travelled from Cusco to Puno aboard the Andean Explorer and despite the fact that this is a 10 hour journey, loved every single minute. The seating (super comfortable armchairs) is sumptuous and the Observation car at the back of the train is an absolute must. We spent ages in there watching the various landscapes as we travelled higher and higher across the altiplano towards Lake Titicaca. You'll ascend at a nice slow pace and see so much of life from herds of Alpacas, extraordinary market scenes in the various towns (with a number of stalls on the railway track itself!), groups of children all waving and cheering the train etc. It's spectacular scenery en route - makes great photograph material. The service is brilliant - breakfast if you want, coffee & tea, three course lunch (excellent and caters for vegetarians) and afternoon tea - lovely. Pisco Sours a go go if you fancy, wine etc throughout the journey, music and dancing entertainment in the Observation car which is hilarious and all part of the fun. Book your ticket!

Great experience but don't forget to go to the back of the train. This train is a bit like the Peruvian Orient Express taking you on a luxury 10 hour trip from Cusco to Puno (Lake Titicaca) in comfort with excellent food and service.10 hours is a long time though, so don't fall asleep or get lost in your book, wander down to the cocktail bar and observation car at the rear where live music and dancing is going on a times during the trip. For us the last 4 hours we spent there was some of the best fun of our tour.

Comfortable ride.. We took the train back to Cusco from Aguas Calientes after the Inca Trail. We were glad we didn't spend the extra money on the Vistadome because their Expedition class seemed to look exactly the same with large windows on the sides and ceiling. We took the train to Poroy and then a bus back to Cusco (about 30 minutes). Based on my trip research, I thought this station was closed but this was booked by a travel agency and we traveled on August 17, 2013. We brought our big backpacks, no weight restrictions whatsoever. Our train was on time and we had a snack and drink on the train. No complaints, other than it was a pretty slow journey (25mph) and got tiring once it got dark and there was nothing to see.

Out of this era experience. Great, 10 hours long trip, with breakfast, lunch and five o'clock tea, while admiring the view and enjoying leisure time. Few hours longer than bus but with it.When traveling from Cusco to Puno, seat on the LEFT side !

Wonderful way to travel for 10 hours. I have never been on a scenic train journey like this. The time absolutely flew by. It was amazing. Apart from sitting in our luxury seats for lunch, we spent most of our time in the observatory carriage at the back. The scenery was just fantastic, everything from the mountains of the Andes, the vast antiplano with grazing Alpaca and the markets on the tracks in Juliaca. It was all just fabulous. Finished off with a sunset before reaching Puno. A journey never to forget.

Definitely Take The Train. Reading some of the negative reviews here, we were really in two minds as to whether to take the bus or train. Luckily, we opted for the train - it was a fabulous day. The scenery is great; perfect leisurely speed; and a real luxury feel to the carriage - which was not full so we could shift seats. Staff were lovely, and the fashion shows, Andean band, bar demonstrations, etc are all held in the observation car, so you are not disturbed by them unless you want to be. The train and service ran a bit late but if you're a stickler for absolute punctuality, then you're on the wrong train and the wrong continent. Holidays are for relaxing and this was perfection - reading, taking photos, playing cards, staring at mountains, and continuous at-table service. Our travelling companions took the bus. They got to Cusco 30 minutes before us, and missed out on one of the best rail journeys in the world.

Memorable. We had some apprehension on travelling on a train for 10 hours.Boarding in Cusco we were allocated settee style seating with a table.The chairs are very comfortable and the interior of the train creates a relaxed atmosphere. Our apprehension had soon passed as we took advantage of the observation car to view the stunning scenery. Passing through towns and villages the friendliness of the people waving at the train was great. Service was excellent, the staff although limited, appeared to have a set routine when serving meals which worked well. During the journey we were given a fashion show, dancing, music and shown how to make a Pisco sour. With these activities the time was broken up really well and it proved to be a most memorable journey. Would recommend this trip without any hesitation.

Out of the world experience - remember to keep your camera ready !!. Wow !! We had such a great time from macchu picchu to uranbamba - in Peru !! The service in the train is awesome !!
