Great snacks and coffee !! Ad the view as the train rolls to destination is fabulous. Remember to keep your camera ready , !!

Panoramic view on the way to Machu Picchu. This train has transparent roof so you can see the Andes cordillera on one side and the river and some Inca ruins on the other side. The staff is friendly and they serve you refreshments and a sandwich on the way.

Travel in time and luxury. What a fantastic way to discover the vast highlands between Cusco and Lake Titicaca! I loved it! From the minute you step into the train with its Orient Express wood design you know you are in for a wonderful trip. The 10-11 hour trip is expensive compared to other transportation means in Peru, however it is really worth it. You will see nature change between the different micro-climatic zones of Peru with a peak at 4300 meters above sea level! The train is comfortable, however be sure you ask the attendants at the station before embarking if you have a seat that is adjacent to main doors- this brings in cold breeze in winter and is simply annoying! I also recommend bringing some snacks since the first meal served is about six hours after leaving Cusco, depending on where you are seated. I was sitting towards the last wagon and I was served food more than one hour after the advertised time. The other meal is supposed to be tea time however this arrived as we were arriving to Puno. The staff is excellent, but I felt that they were overworked and for the entire duration of the trip they were literally running around the wagons to ensure everyone is being served. Why are there not more people hired, given the steep price of the tickets? Some of the passengers were annoyed by the slow service, but I just admired how much a few attendants could do in one wagon and continue to smile.Some of the highlights of the trip include watching nature from the back wagon's observatory deck- it is a wonderful experience. Another big moment was entering some of the towns just before Puno where you go right through markets.Time passed by very fast and I would highly recommend this voyage. The only improvement required is for the service on board to improve.

Think about catching the bus. I boarded the train at Puno for a 10 hour train ride to Cusco. The train was gorgeous- the service appalling. Lunch was supposed to be at 11.50 am- the process was so slow that lunch was not completed until 2.30pm- we were offered 1/2 glass of wine with the meal- it arrived half way through the second course. The afternoon tea took an hour to arrive from the time the tea cup was placed on our table.The staff walked up and down the Isles but did not seem to notice that things needed clearing. No one bothered to brush down or tables. The train arrived 1 and1/2 hours late-no explanation was offered. I asked to speak to a manager- I was told they did not know where the manager was! ! Appalling! Everyone in my car- the last car (the one next to the bar seemed annoyed- the painfully slow service definitely marred the experience. I had expected to be winding through the Andies but it was actually a very boring dragged out trip. I will be telling my friends to catch the bus.

The best way to travel, and a wonderful taste of luxury. My boyfriend and I are huge train fans. A comfortable train ride is the absolute best way to get from point A to point B while having a wonderful view of a foreign landscape. If only the scenery is beautiful we'll feel the trip was worth it, but on the Andean Explorer, the train itself, as well as the services provided, were just as exciting as the views. We took the train from Puno to Cusco. One step into the car and it was like we'd stepped into an Agatha Christi novel: Ivory wallpaper, brass accenting, dark wood, draped tables with real red roses, and wing back chairs greeted us. When the train got underway we explored the back bar car and observation deck, and were further amazed by the almost endless windows, open air observation areas, and wonderful decor. The food was good, and the staff was wonderful. We ordered two mokacchinos early on the in trip, but there was a malfunction with the espresso machine. Our very attentive and polite waiter informed us of this and said it would be ready in about 10 minutes, which we were fine with. Then the waitstaff got swept up in one of the activities on board (live local music and dancing in the bar car) and soon it was over half an hour and we still hadn't received the coffees. We reminded our waiter, who was shocked to hear they had not arrived yet, and he bustled away. He returned shortly after and said "You know pizza, yes?" We were confused and said yes, and he continued: "After thirty minutes it's free? Same here." Moments later our two delicious coffees arrived, free of charge. I find that good customer service shows itself the most when something doesn't go smoothly, and this was an excellent example of that. The trip was long, over 10 hours, but so comfortable and engaging that, with the right book and travel partner at your side, you won't even notice. The staff also fills your time with food, drinks, and unique activities. There are parts of the journey where the scenery is sprawling and flat, but mountains soon dot the landscape and there's always interesting people about to watch. If you know you enjoy seeing the world out a train window, you would be amiss to pass this up.

Long but lovely day. A 10 1/2 hour ride but extremely pleasant. Don't worry about seating since both sides are fine and you may spend much of the day on the last car, which is mostly open air. Great food, so do not feel compelled to bring food or water. The end in Juliaca is not particularly charming and you arrive at night so make sure that you have arranged in advance for your Puno hotel to provide a car and driver since Puno is about 30 minutes away.

Would have been great if it was not for the terrible service.... We boarded this beautiful train full of excitement and anticipation, but the poor service almost spoiled what should have been a great experience (especially when you think that a smaller crew can serve twice as many people on a plane). We were told when we boarded that lunch would be served at 1 pm and afternoon tea at 4:30. Now we were on holiday and do not mind waiting, but it would have been helpful to have some information, especially as I am diabetic. As far as lunch is concerned, the starter – a nice but very tepid soup - finally arrived at 2:30 and we just had to look at our main course (another 30 minutes later) to know it was stone-cold, as the sauce had congealed on the plate by then. We were offered a homeopathic amount of wine in “compensation”. By the time tea was served, we were supposed to have arrived… The menu stated “Assorted tea and coffee from the Sacred Valley”, but coffee was not an option. The chaos with the luggage at the end has already been described by others, but at least ours were not damaged. Our guide had been waiting for over 2 hours when we finally reached destination, but was quite philosophical about it as it is apparently always the case – but he still has to be there when the train is due.It really could and should have been great.

Too slow and scenery not as good as expected. At times, we could have walked faster. If you like 19th century style train service and have lots of time then it is the way to go. We thought the scenery was not as good as expected (maybe Chile altiplano spoiled us).

Relaxing way to travel in luxury. We were booked onto the 8am train to Puno. We knew it would take around 10 hours. Arriving at the station in good time a porter took our luggage and issued us with a receipt. Nice waiting room with comfortable chairs, the usual Andean panpipes music while we waited to board.Seats are numbered and we were on a table for just the two of us, maybe best as the rest of the carriage appeared to be German speaking. The staff were friendly and polite coming to introduce themselves before the train was on it's way.Seating is comfortable rather like an easy chair, table with white damask cloth, lamp (which we needed later) flowers and a menu.Breakfast is not included in the ticket price but we'd had ours before leaving the hotel although there was a good choice of hot and cold items if anyone required it. We did however order coffee which was served promptly.We were in carriage number one which is adjacent to the bar area open all day for hot and cold drinks and again comfortable informal seating. Beyond the bar is the observation carriage with padded bench style seating and large glass windows plus an open air area right at the back. During the day there were fashion shows and entertainment in these areas.It's very relaxing just to sit back and watch the lovely countryside roll past, the train doesn't speed along and there is one stop along the way for about 15 minutes close to a town where the locals have set up a market.Just before lunch, served an hour later than expected, we were served with complimentary Pisco Sours. The waiter took our order, not much choice but then one would hardly expect so with such limited kitchen space, but all perfectly adequate and acceptable. Wine and soft drinks were complimentary with the meal but coffee afterwards was at an extra cost, unfortunately we had to wait over an hour for the coffee to arrive - such a shame.Afternoon tea followed on a little too quickly, again this was included in the ticket price, sandwiches, fruit, chocolates and cinnamon tea.We arrived on schedule at the station in Puno and were told not to disembark the train until all the luggage had been offloaded. This took around 20 minutes.Our tour guide was waiting to greet us, we collected our luggage on the way through (easy and well organised) and were soon on our way to the hotel,

Luxury in thrilling scenery. We travelled from Puno to Cuzco. Meals, drinks and entertainment were great - with fabulous service. The stars of the show though were the mountain scenery and the train travelling through the market at Juliaca.Real trip of a lifetime stuff.

Great train ride on the Antiplano!. A great way to travel from Puno to Cuszo. It's a 10 hour journey but the time flies and the scenery is outstanding. There's entertainment to while away the time, food to eat and a stop at the market at the highest point in the journey but for me the scenery was all that was necessary- a photographer's dream!
Dancing in Aisles. After 4 days of trail walking, it was soo nice to get the comfy train back to civilisation... Loved onboard entertainment, where I ended up dancing in the aisles..

Like stepping back in time. We were apprehensive about a 10 hour train ride but this flew by. The service and food were impeccable. We went to the last car to enjoy the view and take pictures throughout most of the ride. It was a fabulous experience and I highly recommend it.
Good service. Thanks to the good service by Miqule Palmino and Raul Ortega. They gave the smiled by the whole tout.

Also from Puno to Cusco. We took the Andean Explorer from Puno to Cusco, which is a slightly cheaper options than from Cusco to Puno. Booked tickets online, no problem, everything worked swimmingly. You have to report at the only station in Puno at 7.30 and your bigger pieces of luggage are tagged and put in a luggage wagon. Upon arrival in Cusco they are put on the platform (guarded) for fairly easy collection.For not entirely clear reasons our trip took two hours longer than predicted, we waited a bit at one unnamed station somewhere in the Andes for the train driving in the other direction to pass by. This did not pose a problem for us, the driver from our hotel in Cusco was still faithfully there waiting for us.I refer to other reviews for all the good things whichbhappen to you on board. For us the biggest highlights amongst many were the observation wagon (spent hours there taking pictures and developed a sun tan along the way) and the passing through the market at Juliaca. Here the market stalls are about 20 cm or so from the train on both sides and the market closes like a zipper behind the train. Make sure to be on the observation platform in Juliaca!

If you don't hike to Machu Picchu, you might as well ride!. We rode the Vistadome train and had spectacular views of the Urubamba river. The train is the way to go. On the ride, you can see many farmers getting their crops ready to sell. They do provide one small drink for free and snacks during the ride.

Overpriced circus. After hiking the Inca Jungle Trail we wanted to take transportation back to Cusco. As Perurail is the only option (besides walking back) we bought two tickets for the Vistadome train from Aguas Calientes to Ollantaytambo. We paid over 80 dollars per person for a traintrip of one and a half hour. During this time we were 'entertained' by a dancer and a catwalkshow which we really didn't appreciate. Afterwards they tried to sell us 'traditional clothes' for three times the price you would pay at a local shop. We just wanted to relax after our great trip to Machu Picchu but were constantly interrupted. It's a shame that Perurail doesn't have any competition because they would certainly go out of bussines.

wonderful experience. Fabulous scenery. Very comfortable seating. Excellent service and food. 10hrs were passed enjoyably and did not drag. Fun entertainment in the wonderful observation car. Unmissable delight.

Web Site Needs Work, Cramped Spacing & I Paid for Transportation, not Marketing Theater!. I recently returned from a trip to Peru and had a wonderful time visiting Cusco, Ollantayambo and Machu Picchu. Everything from the hotels to the restaurants were great. The sole exception to the enjoyment and my satisfaction was Peru Rail. First Issue: I ordered my train tickets well ahead of time online but still needed to pick the actual boarding passes up at their designated locations in Ollantayambo and Cusco for verification since my credit card wasn't one of their chosen cards. I'm not sure why this inconvenience is necessary since I don't need to provide the same verification for airline tickets (or anything else I ever order online). The whole purpose of ordering tickets online is to save time from having to stand in line at the stations later. Also, the ID numbers of your ticket orders need to be printed at the time you purchase them online. If you don't print them, there is no way of finding the ID later on the Peru Rail web site page later. However, you are able to track your planned train routes. Not sure why the ID numbers of the orders aren't included in the itinerary shown since it's needed later when you pick up the boarding passes. Second issue: The space in the Vistadome train is too cramped. I'm just about 5'10 and slim and had no leg room. A small older lady sitting across from me kept kicking me since there was not a sufficient amount of space for both of us. It 's also a tight squeeze with the person next to you as well.Third issue: From what I read on other reviews, there isn't much of a difference between the Vistadome and Expedition trains so the value is poor as well. I spent $173 round trip. Way to expensive for the service provided and I expect to get more from a "better" train.Fourth (and the most annoying issue): I paid for transportation, not marketing theater! Here is what happened. About an hour into the return trip from Machu Picchu to Cusco, the train stops. I'm trying to sleep having been up since 4AM to hike Wayna Picchu and all of sudden, this loud Peruvian salsa techno music starts blaring on the train speakers waking me up. Then, this Peru Rail employee dressed up in a rejected Mardi Gras-like costume comes running down the aisle hooting like a wounded owl. He selects a young female passenger and starts dancing with her while continually making this horrid hooting sound. He temporarily stops and leaves. Meanwhile, the male and female train attendants for the train car begin walking down the aisles modeling alpaca clothing for the passengers to buy (everything from sweaters to scarves). When they go behind the curtains at each end of the aisle to change wardrobes to model, the costume guy returns and performs the same irritating dance, clapping and hooting. This goes on for 15 minutes (but seemed longer). Can't make this stuff up. All I wanted was some peace and quiet, but instead, I get woken up by this nonsense. For damn sakes Peru Rail, your service is to provide safe/comfortable transportation, not to hock your alpaca items onto your passengers for a few extra bucks - let alone disturbing the hell out of them while doing do. There is a time and place for that (like the many markets around Peru aimed at tourists). You'd think for the overpriced tickets being charged, this wouldn't be necessary. Fifth issue: If Peru Rail is going to transfer passengers from their train to a bus for about half distance of the route, they should seriously think of lowering the rates until the track is repaired (or whatever the reason is for the transfer). It's not right to charge customers a full rate for a train when they are only receiving a portion of it.Again, I really enjoyed my stay in Peru and make a point of not being too sensitive/picky on the trips I take when I know effort is being made in the service provided. Peru Rail was disappointing.

One of the best train rides of my life. Very beautiful, very comfortable train ride that's highly recommended for travel between Cusco and Puno. While it's a 10 hour trip, the time flies by due to on-train activities and changing landscape. Dances, musical performances, a bartending class, a fashion show (excuse to peddle some alpaca wear) break up the time nicely. Beautiful seats and good food, nice bar car and full glass observation car with an open back. You roll across some beautiful landscapes and villages. Service is very attentive. All in all, the cost wasn't that much more than a flight and we though was very worth it (especially considering the Hiram Bingham is double the price for 1/3 the length and is essentially the same ride). The class/wealth divide between some of the more impoverished villages you ride through is all the more obvious when you're gliding through in a gold-gilted train escorted by white gloved servers, but the locals don't seem to mind and are actually very friendly, waving up at the spectacle of the "rich" foreigners traveling through their midst. An eye-opening look at how lucky we have it in the west.

Time passed very quickly. This was a pleasant surprise. The food was very good although it wasn't red hot but when you consider where you are not a problem. Wine was good and the coffees. Most people seemed to have problems with their bills. Worth have cash to pay.

Simply Amazing!. Taking this train was the highlight of my trip. It's an amazing experience! Indescribable feeling of riding slowly through the Andes just observing life in the rural areas, the crazy small not touristic cities and the beautiful, breathtaking sceneries that change gradually from Cusco to Puno. There's only one, 10 minute stop in La Raya (4000m altitude) and the whole ride lasts 10 hours. It seems long, but it's surely not long enough. Specially if you stay most of the time on the back panoramic wagon. Food is OK and some of the on board attractions can get a bit annoying. Staff is very nice and helpful. I don't think there are rides everyday, but make sure to plan your trip so you can take this train. Unforgettable!

A JOURNEY OF A LIFETIME. My wife and I travelled from Puno to Cusco on the Andean Explorer this June and considered this train an highlight of the trip to Peru!Be prepared to step back in time travelling at low speed on an 1919 beautifully restored train. You will pay around US150.00 for the trip one way but this includes lunch, with a glass of wine and an afternoon tea. You simply won´t notice the 10 hours ride. We spent most of the time on the observation car and the changing landscape is stunning. Last but not least there two shows of andean music, a fashion show and a lesson on how to make a Pisco Sauer. Please do not miss this ride!!

Gorgeous Alternative to the trail. I didn't get enough time to book the trail but the train, particularly in daylight, is stunning. A fantastic few hours to sight see on the way to MP. I travelled in this train and the class below on the way back. There was almost no difference.

An Incredible Experience. This train ride was like stepping into the past, when train travel was an event! Your sit in real chairs, at a table set with linens. The food was tasty and everyone was nice. Those who chose to read or even slept, but many of us chose to spend much of the time in the club car (where free Pisco Sours started flowing at 10 a.m!) The last car was open and what an amazing place to stand and take photos. I took so many my battery went by mid day and I had to switch to my phone camera! Midway through you stop for ten minutes and get out, where locals have a small market filled with beautiful goods to buy (with a 14,500 ft snow capped mountain in the background). There were musicians who played (in the club car), dancers, a fashion show and a pisco sour making demonstrations. Lots of us got friendly and had fun passing time in the last two cars. Nine hours flew by...sadly it was already dark as we went by Lake Titicaca, but the lake was still there in the morning!Dealing with PeruRail from the US is challenging, but I'm so glad I persevered and got this train trip scheduled. So much fun and such a great experience.

Simply stunning. The Lonely Planet book advises against using this train. We could not disagree more. It is one of the best experiences of my life. The scenery is simply magnificent, the train is fabulously comfortable, the food is fantastic.

Beautiful train and enjoyable ride. The nine hours went pretty quickly on our trip from Cusco to Puno. I loved the lamps on our tables. The last car had a bar in it, and the back was open so that you could sit or stand there and watch the scenery out the back. It was a very enjoyable travel day.

A Must. We traveled Puno to Cusco by the Andean Explorer in May and from start to finish was one of the high lights of our holiday We had a brilliant train journey, with fantastic scenery, Could not fault any thing from the toilets been clean, to entertainment, food and free pisco sours, There is viewing car were you can sit and take photo's or just take in the views and the staff are brilliant

Great trip from Puno to Cusco. The trip was beautiful. I would rate as excellent except I had problems with the reservation system. Be careful with this. We went from Puno to Cusco the trip is much cheaper in this direction. With a promotional are from Taca the trip to Puno and the train was about he same as flying to Cusco. Highly recommended.

What a train journey. This was a wonderful memorable train journey. We travelled from Puno to Cusco. The photo opportunities were quite amazing. The trip through Juliaca with the market either side of the track and even on the track was extraordinary. The views of the Andes were also fantastic.Food on the train is excellent.We are glad that this was part of our trip

The absolute best way to go from Puno to Cusco. We travelled Puno to Cusco by the Andean Explorer, and returned Cusco to Puno on the Inca Express bus, which has 4 site stops on the way. Without doubt, the train was by far the best and most comfortable way to travel. We had a delightful train trip, with magnificent scenery, plenty of opportunity to move around, clean toilets, good food, and other travellers to talk to. And if you're a photographer, the windows open for terrific clear shots, and the opportunities for photos from the viewing car are unlimited! The first 9 hours fly past. It's just the last hour when it gets dark that tiredness sets in. The bus in comparison, whilst cheaper, is cramped and the views and sites from the road are inferior to those from the train, in our opinion. The train route seems to provide much better vistas in many places, or perhaps it's the large windows that make it appear so. For photographers, the bus windows don't open & there's little opportunity to photograph what you see. The lunch included with the bus journey was very ordinary. The 4 stops that the bus makes are interesting, but if you have a choice of either the bus or the train, I would always choose the train, without hesitation. It was a truly memorable trip. The bus was not in that category. If you're doing the return trip, for some reason the Puno-Cusco train trip costs a lot less than the Cusco-Puno leg.

This is a train trip not to miss!. We spent 10 hours on the Andean Explorer travelling from Cusco to Puno. This is an amazing train ride, the scenery dominated by the Andean mountains makes it an unforgettable journey. There is a carriage with a high glass dome roof so the views are incredible. There is always something happening, live music and lovely girls dancing in national costume. The music groups love to entertain. We learnt how to make Pisco Sour cocktails and we were treated to a fashion parade of pure Alpaca scarves and shawls. The food was excellent and the staff were so friendly and only too happy to provide anything we needed.Arriving in Puno was another amazing experience as the train travels through the middle of the markets. The Andean Explorer was a definite highlight of our tour to South America.

Mixed feelings about Puno-Cusco train ride. We rode the train from Puno to Cusco in late May. While I would say I enjoyed it, I'm not sure I would choose to do it over again after having had the experience. On the bright side:- Friendly, service oriented staff- Lunch was nice - not outstanding, but not bad either- Scenery was spectacular- Observation car and train setup meant you could easily get up and move around the train to stretch your legs- Early in the day it felt like a fun adventureCons:- Train ride is 10+ hours long. Late in the day it just felt like a really long train ride that was never going to end- There was only one touristy stop, for 10 minutes at the highest point in the trip. No information was provided about the areas and places we were travelling through- You are sitting in your great grandmother's wing chair the whole time, at a table. The seats have lots of springs and not much padding. And they don't recline. You might be facing backwards.- The train rocks back and forth relentlessly; this is not a smooth train swaying gently. It feels like a washing machine- If you are uncomfortable with a classic contrast of privilege and poverty, you might be uncomfortable as the train passes through the street market in Juliaca, where the market literally engulfs the train and the security guy in the observation car makes you stand away from the open end of the car so people won't grab your camera- A large rock was thrown at our wagon as the train rolled into Cusco through poor neighborhoods after dark. It could very easily have crashed through a window, bringing our day to a messy endAll in all, it sounds like a better idea than it really is, and it's a lot more expensive than the tourist bus from Puno to Cusco. I would probably try the tour bus if I were to make this trip again - the bus stops more frequently but makes the trip in about the same time from what I've read.

Service with smiles. Service was always with a smile - the head honcho was always asking if we were alright. I'm short so I didn't really find the leg room to be a problem though going to the bathroom meant my friend having to get up for me to do so.10 hours is a long time but it sort of flew by. Food - my trout - was good though the quinoa soup was not as good as I had on Taquiles Island. Dessert was good.During the meal services (1 meal + 1 tea time), you could ask for as much nonalcoholic beverages as you would like but in between those two times, you needed to pay. It seems silly that a bottle of water was not included for the 10 hour ride but over all it had great service, lovely views and opportunity to get up and walk as much as you liked. The back was always crowded! Try to get seats at the back of the train so it's not much of a walk to enjoy panoramic views.

A little disappointed.... This trip started off well and we were very impressed by the decor and comfort. I was a bit disappointed that we had to buy all drinks at inflated prices. I thought that at the very least a bottle of water could have been included, and perhaps a mid-morning drink? Dinner portions were small. We were fed and watered much better on our Inca Trail!It's a shame because the experience is one that should have been second to none, and you pay enough for the initial ticket. The views from the train are fantastic though and the entertainment was good.

torture chamber. "tour operator" promised seats on Vistadome, but delivered late night Explorer train, little torture chamber, seats face each other over a common table, not enough leg room under table for four people facing each other. Everybody has to untangle for one person to get up to go to the bathroom. No food beverage service for 2 hour train trip. Little Horror train
House1899. Comfortable table and an excellent lunch. Train staff were helpful and gracious. Entertainment in the lounge car was an enjoyable experience during the 10 hour trip. Scenery spectacular.

An excellent way to travel. Ten hours flew past and it is interesting watching the scenery change. Didn't like the fact that you have to pay every time you want a coffee when the tickets are not exactly cheap.
A relaxing ride. Our trip to Machu Picchu from Cusco started with a two hour bus ride over bumpy roads in a small bus. The Explorer Train was very relaxing.

The most amazing 10 hour train ride ever!. A group of us did this trip (Cuzco to Juliaca) in 2005, and I will always remember this awesome trip! The service was outstanding, the food exotic and delicious, and the views were truly unforgetable. We were especially touched by connecting to people along the track all along the way. Everyone would stop working and come wave at the train! Suggestion: Bring candy or coins to throw out to children along the way!It should be on everyone's bucket list!

Wonderful way to go to Puno from Cusco. Much more comfortable than the bus, service excellent, food good. The scenery was amazing in the high Andes. The rear observation car is the best. Be sure to try the snacks in the bar car. We had fried corn, which was so good.

Superb views. We had paid well over £100 to travel on the Andean Explorer rather than the coach from Cusco to Puno and was slightly dissappointed. Whilst the ambience was excellent and you can see that it is owned by the Orient Express company the service did not match. The carriage was very comfortable with excellent views and at the rear of the train was a bar and a great viewing area. Unfortunately the staff seemed chaotic, the lunch which was announced to be served at 1.00pm finally started at 2.30pm. Afternoon tea due to served at 4.00pm arrived at 5.45pm but fortunately instead of arriving at Puno at 6.00pm it was almost 7.00pm or else we would have had to take the tea off the train with us! Lunch, whilst well presented, was not hot. The staff seemed more interested in trying to sort out everyones extras bill towards the end of the trip and did not seem to have a system to identify what each table had had. However overall the views across the Andean Plain made up for the disappointment although whether I would pay the extra again is doubtful.

Right On Track. This is a must. Don't travel Cusco to Puno by ramshackle buses if you can avoid it. The distances are huge; the scenery dull; the toilets few and far between! The Andean Explorer is the way to go, even at 10 hours long. The level of service, in the midst of the usual level of none, is remarkable. Smartly-dressed staff serve the lunch (only moderately good), afternoon tea and drinks at the bar, while you can leave your comfy armchair seat and listen to the live band while drinking your Pisco Sour and watching the Altiplano roll by from the open-ended observation car. It costs, but it's worth it, really.

A Memorable Experience - the best way to travel from Puno to Cuzco.. This is typical of the Orient Express. Travel in comfort and elegance accompanied by good food, excellent service and original entertainment.The train boarded from 7:30am and departed Pno at 8:00am. The journey to Cuzco took 9 hours but the scenery was interesting and often extremely beautiful. Initially the train slowly travels through the streets of Puno; then skirts Lake Titicaca before reaching Juliaca. The next phase crosses the Andean Altoplain reaching the high point at La Reya for a short stop and opportunity to stretch your legs before the descent down to Cuzco through more fertile valleys.During the trip we were entertained in the Bar Car by two Andean Folk Groups with dancers; a Fashion Show and a demonstration on how to make a Pisco Sour. The Lunch was brilliant and there was a small snack served before arrival in Cuzco.We loved the whole experience.

Delightful Surprise. What a delightful train trip!This 10-hour journey between Cusco and Puno on Lake Titicaca is wonderful. The train is decorated and styled in early 20th century motif. It's very comfortable with seats taking the form of real armchairs. There is lots of glass in the cars to allow for great viewing of the scenery. There is a bar car that is combined with a viewing platform at the end of the train. Price includes a very good lunch with wine as well as entertainment, a fashion show, and drink-mixing lessons. One stop midway at over 4000 meters altitude allowed guests to take photos and view local crafts and people.The train - as all Peruvian trains are - was very punctual and departed and arrived perfectly on time. Staff were cordial and friendly.Highly recommended trip.

The best 10 hour train ride in the world. We had a great time traveling form Punos to Cusco by train. Although 10 hours, it flew by. The staff was superbe, the food great and the view breathtaking. Between the live music, fashion show, bartending classes to learn how to make Pesco, and the stop with the locals to look at their crafts and alpaca, we never had a dull minute. The observation deck was perfect to take photos and mingle with other passengers. The head conductor was great at keeping things flowing and ontime. The staff was very yprofessional and courteous. We would easlly do it again anytime.

Wonderful view of the countryside from Puno to Cusco. We really enjoyed our train trip from Puno to Cusco and an added plus was that by going in this direction it was nearly half the cost of going from Cusco to Puno! There is an observation deck at the back of the train which is a good place for taking photos. There was a fashion show and cocktail demonstration in the bar area at the back of the train. However for us it was the ever changing views that we enjoyed. The food would have been quite good had it been hot but unfortunately as the kitchen is towards the front of the train and we were at the back it was a bit on the cool side. Having said that we are glad that we made this train journey.

Great!. The Andean Explorer Train was fabulous! We loved every minute of it! The entertainment was great, beautiful scenery and very pretty train cars. If I was to travel from Puno to Cusco again, I would choose Andean Explorer.

great way to travel. It takes about 1-2 hours more than the bus from Cusco to Puno, but it is so relaxing and pleasant. The bar/observation car is partly open air and fantastic for pictures and looking around.
Fantastic!. Okay I am biased and I love trains, but what a lovely way to travel, glass roofed train carriages, nice food, a fashion show, and some of the best scenery in the world! a Great Trip.

No airport hassles. Having scanned all the positive comments it's hard to add to the list ... it's all true! This has been one of the highlights of travelling in Peru (Cuzco to Puno). Met interesting people, watched the fantastic scenery slide by from the carriage and the observation 'caboose', entertained by the on-board shows, impressed with the style and quality of the fit-out (including the toliet which is worth a review on it's own) and the service staff. Even with the 2 hour delay caused by a broken- down train ahead very happy we did the trip. Overall a Gold Kangaroo Award experience.

Most scenic & entertaining route to Puno/Cusco. Well worth every penny you pay. It really is something you should do once in your life given the opportunity. Not only is the train sophisticated with full dining, but the scenery is exquisite every pat of the journey. From rolling mountains, to thundrous rivers, you see it all. What is simply fascinating about this journey is that you really do get additional insight into how real people actually live today, still in their primitive and colourful lifestyles. A humbling experience of the peruvian lifestyle mixed with the class and sophistication of the train. This is a train journey to be remembered. We did it MArch which is autumn and everything is green. I'm sure the landscape would be very different when everything is brown. Either way you are bound to see many glacial peaks amidst the mountains. The three course meal was delicious and the live music on board very festive adding true Andes flavour to the hole experience. Very enjoyable from the minute you set foot in the train station until

Slow down, enjoy a taste of history and comfort. On our journey through Peru we flew to Puno and took the Andrea Explorer back to Cusco. So glad we did. From the moment you enter the station you get a sense of being set apart from the outside world here, which can be rather stark and impoverished.The staff are friendly and seem happy to assist you. There is even a group of musicians playing before you depart.The train looks to be older but in a nice sense, with polished brass and dark woods and leathers used throughout. Seating is mainly first come, though they try to accommodate large parties and situate them together.We were pleasantly greeted and welcomed aboard, found our seats, and quickly moved into slow mode as this trip is several hours long (10hrs). Luckily they have a bar and observation car separate from the dining area. The dining area seats are those you keep for the duration.They offer a show and some entertainment in the bar car, but the best opportunity here are the drinks. The pisco sours (national drink?) mixed here were the best we'd tasted the whole trip long. You have the freedom to move about as you like, and the observation car is wide open, so you have full unobstructed views of the countryside. It is such a lovely and slow paced way to travel. The food is well prepared and tasty. The linens plates and silver are selected to add an upscale feel to the meal.There are good clean restroom facilities provided as well. I think at the end of the journey I counted and there was like 3 staff to each tourist, so you never want for attention and service.The one disappointment came at the very end when you arrive in town and baggage and transportation is confused. The baggage was summarily piled up on the platform and we weren't quite sure what happens next or where to get a taxi, but it wasn't horrid... just awkward. Knowing that, make sure to grab a porter at the finish. If you are on vacation this is a perfect way to slow down and appreciate life and your companion rather than rushing to the next queue like a mad tourist. The luxury, the pace, and the opportunity suited us quite well. We would do this again, maybe on another route.

A look to the past. The rail trip is a lovely was to travel from Cusco to Puno and vice versa. Lunch and teatime was included, not to mention a pisco sour after the demonstration. The car was comfortable and a unique was to spend a relaxing day traveling.

Vistodrome Service is First Class. Scenic ride and very comfy with breakfast in the morning and a snack in the afternoon plus staff modeling sweaters to buy on the way back to Cusco and tradiitonal Peruvian music playing.Note that during the rainy season you have to take a bus for half the way.

Amazing. We took the Andean Explorer from Puno to Cusco, and headed to the station a little apprehensive of a 10 hour train journey.  The minute we got to the station we were blown away, Peru Rail have this route perfected. The events, staff, services, and food were all excellent. The scenery on route is amazing; from the edge of Lake Titicaca up through the hills to Cusco.A three course lunch is included (with wine), as well as an afternoon snack. Breakfasts and burgers, teas and coffees are available at extra charge. Large luggage is taken into the luggage carriage, so the passenger carriages are uncluttered. There is also an observation / bar carriage at the rear of the train where you can watch the scenery go by with Pisco Sour in hand. Bathrooms are clean, and there is a short tourist market stop on route in case you need to stretch your legs a bit.Recommend this journey to everyone, this journey was one of the highlights of our time in Peru.Definitely try to get a seat away from the ends of the carriage, and in the carriage closest to the bar.
Cusco to Agua Calientes. What a trip: first class all the way from the food, service, bar, entertainment and cocktail making demonstration. I was even given a present as I got off.

Amazing experience. This was one of the highlights of my trip to Peru. The scenery was fantastic and the viewing carriage superb for making the best of all that was on offer. The food and drink are expensive as although lunch and tea are included in the price, during a 10 hour journey, you will want more to drink. The toilets were among the best in Peru!

Atmospheric and A Highlight of the trip. We spent about 60% of the time in the observation car at the back, watching, socialising, drinking and snapping. Food was good, wine surprisingly very quaffable, scenery and passing scenes beautiful, incredibly good VFM. Would do it again at the drop of a hat

Andean Explorer - a great way to get to Puno!. A long journey (10 hours) from Cusco to Puno was made enjoyable by being on board the Andean Express. From good food, served by a team of waiting staff whose serving was like a well choreographed dance routine, to the fun aspect of the band and fashion show teams this was a great way to spend the day. Don't miss the view from the observation car as you pass through the main market in Juliaca with the stalls literally inches away from the sides of the train, and the train travelling on the area that the shoppers had been on minutes before. I missed some great photos as I was too late to get to the observation car in time for this spectacular sight so make sure you know the time you will be passing through this market when you get on the train. Great fun!
Looooved it!! one of the best train rides in South America!. I really loved it. The sightseeing was incredible, picturesque beautiful landscapes. The food was nice and so the attractions on board : )

Wow. This was one of the highlights of my trip to Peru. The time just flew by. I spent most of the journey in the observation car at the rear of the train. The views from here were stunning. I have a huge number of photos from this trip. In my view the scenery is best at the start of the trip from Cusco and later in the day as the sun is setting. The train is very comfortable and well equipped, the staff were friendly and helpful.

Lovely Experience.. Travelled Cusco to Puno. A lovely experience being transported back in time to a more glamorous age of train. Rolling stock beautifully restored and manned by well-trained; very efficient Orient Express staff. The continual traffic through carriages to the observation cars was irritating especially if you were sitting beside the door. Food was fine but at best luke warm... Maybe cold foo would be better. Some lovely scenery en route. Entertainment on the train was OK (live music/dance a fashion show)but why do Orient Express insist on playing canned Peruvian music for hours on their trains and coaches to places like Machu Picchu. Poor and reluctant USD exchange rates on board - odd because everyone in Peru takes dollars and this is one trip populated almost exclusively by foreigners. The train has a luggage compartment. (Well managed and secure). Hand baggage space is limited to generrous overhead racks.Worth doing if you can afford it and don't mind 10 hrs on a train! (Tales 5 hours by car!?)

Beautiful Trip!. As others have stated, this train does not have luggage restrictions. The train station, the porters who check your luggage, and the staff are all first class--very nice. The interior of the train is very pretty with comfortable chairs, tables, and table cloths. We were sort of dreading such a long trip but they did a nice job breaking it up with little "events" in the lounge/bar car. Additionally, there is another observation car that is great for taking pictures or just relaxing and getting fresh air. The food and drinks served were all very good. Lots of beautiful scenery, and it was nice to see all the little towns and markets along the way. Our only complaint is a minor one: for the first few hours of the trip, there was local music played over the speakers and it was very loud--was not relaxing at all and did not seem to fit with the "theme" of the trip. After over an hour of it, we put our headphones on, but we could hear it over our music. I don't know if someone finally asked them to turn it down, but eventually it was put at a much more bearable level.

Fantastic journey...(and a clarification on luggage policy!). We travelled on this train in June 2012, and it was one of the highlights of a trip to Peru that was overall full of "wow" moments, one of the best holidays we've ever done.Firstly to clarify, given the previous review and a number of others, that the Andean Explorer is the luxury ten-hour train ride running between Cusco and Puno, and NOT the Vistadome or Hiram Bingham train that runs up to Aguas Caliente just by Machu Picchu. On these trains there does indeed seem to be a baggage policy that limits people to taking only small rucksack/overnight bags. There is no such restriction on the Andean Explorer...though big bags are "checked in" by efficient and friendly porters and stored in a separate part of the train.We did the journey in the direction Puno to Cusco and it was truly wonderful, certainly our first experience of this kind of Pullman luxury travel. The main carriage, where you have assigned seats and where meals and drinks are served, is very elegant and comfortable, with attentive and friendly service living up to all our expectations.For us the best feature was the panoramic viewing carriage at the back of the train, that included the bar area (where the enjoyable entertainment is laid on), informal seating and the superb open ended viewing area...lovely to stand here, move around and chat with other passengers and take in the specacular scenery, as well as the the vibrant street markets in Puno and Juliaca that you slowly trundle through...colourful fruit, vegetables and goods laid out both alongside and between the rails!!...the market flowing back to life in the wake of the train. The stop at high point of the journey was also great, small tourist market and spectacular views up to glacial peaks. So very very highly recommended and we think, having talked with others who'd done the journey by bus, that they missed out on something special. Finallly, for what its worth, we felt our overall "circuit" direction (Lima then Arequipa to Colca Canyon, Puno and Lake Titicaca - including Sillustani and Taquile island visits - then Cusco ending in Machu Picchu) worked well for us with, overall, increasing "wow factors" as the trip progressed. But can see there's maybe also a romance of taking the train up from Cusco up to the Lake Titicaca area. Evidently this has to be a personal/logistical choice and think either direction will be very good.

Nice train - shame about the luggage policy!. Friendly staff; a hot drink & sugary snack is provided; too little room for luggage makes staying anything more than 1 night at Macchu Picchu (Aguas Caliente) very awkward. The train company ought to review its policy and perhaps run more trains so more luggage can be accommodated. View out of the perspex roof panoramic windows is good - allows you to look up at people walking the Inca Trail!
Awesome scenery!. First class service, amazing scenery! The staff were very helpful, food excellent, and enjoyed the Pisco sour lesson in the bar car!
Watch who you sit next to. Nice train journey spoiled by an idiot at the opposite seat boasting about how many drugs he'd taken in Peru.

Magic journey. A 10-hour journey on the Andes with all the comforts that you could ask for.The service is impeccable, the foods very good and we were give a table for two with two bug armchairs.The journey itself is very spectacular and an exciting way to travel through the Andes, especially if you are looking for a bit of rest. Well worth the price.

Very nice train service. We were pleasantly surprised by the attentive service of the staff on the train. The train ride is well worth it and no need to spend the extra money on the expensive alternative. Keep your bags and personal items in view and locked. Highly recommended.

What a way to travel!. Rather expensive, but don't miss this unique experience. This beautiful train brings you in 10 hours from Cusco to the city of Puno on the shores of lake Titicaca, reaching altitudes of 4200 meters. Amazing.

A fantastic and spectacular journey. Not accustomed to luxury train travel, I may be overrating this trip- but, we enjoyed the comfort, entertainment( how to make a pisco sour like a local) and the spectacular views. If they could ensure the meals were hot when revved it would have been perfect!

Wonderful Experience. This was worth every penny. Wonderful service, dining experience and entertainment. The views are breath taking on the train, the observatory a great place to hang out- I thought a great way to travel across Peru and not an every day experience

Great Value for the Time. The trip from Cuzco to Puno is 10-hours, but it can be made to seem much shorter on this train. Lots of on-board entertainment, great three-course lunch, Pisco Sours and awesome views of the backbone of the Andes made the trip very enjoyable. Be prepared for the thin air at these high altitudes!

Be careful booking with your credit card.... I booked a one way trip from Cusco to Puno online for one person. The train ride was very beautiful and first class all the way with great service. The price is a little high probably due to the fact that there are no other companies at this time that offer a service like this. The main problem that I have with PeruRail is that they double charged my credit card for the trip. I have sent emails with no reply. Also they have a complaint book link on there website that doesn't seem to work. I would recommend that anybody that wants to use PeruRail to buy their tickets with cash and not to use a credit card as I have read other complaints with people having similar problems seeking reimbursement. Otherwise this would be a 4 to 5 star review.

Amazing experience!. Touring Peru in various means of transport, the group of 6 can happily say that this is by far the best one so far!The 1920 train takes you back to the old days... Train superbly looked after!Dining, service and all details down to fresh roses on the tables were perfect. And of course the scenery... Priceless.Highly recommended.
Great train and service. It gets a little hot in the train. And when there is a delay, they have no way of dealing with irate customers.

A High-Light of the Machu Pichu experience. On the way there, we took a bus/train combo to Machu Pichu, on the way back we took the train all the way to Cuzco (3.5 hours) WHAT A TRIP. Great experience. The dinner, the drinks, the fashion show, the entertainment ~ not to mention the scenery. FANTASTIC
The best way to travel from Cusco to Lake Titicaca. Amazing 10 hour journey from Cusco to Lake Titicaca with food, drinks and entertainment. A great way to see the countryside
one way trip. Great budget alternative to see Macchu Picchu.Would suggest one way on the Andean Explorer and one way on the Vistadome.

Traveling from Puno to Cusco. It was an excellent experience travelling aboard of the Andean Explorer from Puno to Cusco. The landscape were perfect and the crew makes you feel confortable all the trip.

Cuzco to Puno. The Andean Explorer to Puno from Cusco was great first class trip and worth the extra money. Only one problem that Peur Rail has is catering for English speaking people and giving better explanation of what is included on the price of the trip and what is extra. We nearly had a mutiny when we arrived at Puno when there EFTPOS machine did not work. They want cash for any extra purcases onboard the train. Taking this away, it was an outstading experience.

Unforgettable - for the best reasons!. The Cusco railway station lounge welcomed us with comfortable lounge chairs and a most enjoyable 4 member pipe band wearing traditional clothing. It was a shame to leave it but the train itself was even better - in the fine style of Pullman 1920 trains - comfortable lounge chairs, tables with white damask tablecloths, each with a beautiful red rosebud which opened throughout the day. The rear open air observation car and bar was perfect for viewing the spectacular scenery as well as the entertainment by the same pipe band. The staff were very professional and versatile, providing a fashion parade of local clothing and dancing in local costumes. The food was superb and beautifully served. Even the toilets were spacious and elegant with beautiful wood paneling and a vase of red roses. A fabulous experience that I'd love to repeat.

A Pure Tourist Attraction. The train is luxurious and the staff is very kind. The meal is simple yet, a very small portion. The choice was soup, salmon with veggies, or 5 ravioli instead. End ing with a piece of chocolate mousse pie. Though there was on-board entertainment, it was geared to sell you something. The train, for the most part, followed the highway to Puno. So, for the cost of $210 USD, I felt it was severely over priced.

Very beautiful train ride. I think this train ride is worth the high price ($150 from Puno to Cusco, or $250 from Cusco to Puno). The landscapes are amazing, and you ride through rural areas that I'm not sure you'd see otherwise. You definitely see more on the train than you would on a bus! I'm pretty picky about comfort and I get sick on long bus and plane rides, but this train was impeccably clean, there was plenty of room to move around, and plenty of stuff to see in the day. It's a long ride, but I was never bored. I love this train!

What a train, highly recommended. We took the train from Puno to Cuzco, the service is excellent from the time that you arrive at the station. It seems to be fairly common that when you book your tickets you're not necessarily sitting together but before we even mentioned it the staff moved our seats before we boarded the train. It's a long journey but it is very comfortable on this train, you can also take a bus, it travels mostly the same route for cheaper but what you are paying for is the experience and the comfort. The scenery is fantastic and you can view this from your seat, the bar carriage or the viewing area out the back. The very back is open so you can take great photos from there. One of my favourite parts was going through the streets in Julianca, as you squeeze through the markets you could probably buy some souvenirs. Your lunch and afternoon tea are included and are very good, you can also get breakfast and snacks for an extra charge. There's also entertainment included, not really for me but others seemed to enjoy it. The Pisco Sour cocktail class was good fun. And of course the Pisco Sours were superb. 2 for 1 during happy hour.I would do this journey again.

Excellent service on Perurail. We had a great trip on Perurail on our Machu Picchu trip from Urubamba. The trains were on time, the staff were very friendly, and the Vistadome allowed great views on our journey. Allowing us to board the train at our hotel (Tambo del Inka) was very convenient as well.

Wow! Choo choo!. Great experience! Met some lovely people on the train which made the trip enjoyable. The food and service was excellent. The entertainment made the time go by. Loved every minute of it and saw some great scenery along the way.

Very poor service handling our cancelled train journey. Our rail journey from Puno to Cusco with Perurail was cancelled due to strikes/protestors. We understand these things happen, but the way Perurail dealt with it was disappointing.We were given inaccurate information which led us to go to the bus station to try to find alternative travel, by the time we returned all the other travellers who were booked onto the cancelled train had gone so we couldn't negotiate a shared arrangement with them.Perurail offered as an alternative means of travel a taxi for $300 (a bus costs $40 each) and given no help other than that. Even getting a refund was difficult - they wouldn't give us one in Puno, or in the first office we visited in Cusco, we were told to go to a third office, after an hour walk and an hour wait we got our refund but no compensation for the trouble we were put through.

Fun rail travel. We travelled to and from Agua Calientes (Machu Picchu township) by Peru Rail and what a marvellous trip it was. The Vista dome train allowed wonderful views but by far the most attractive part of trip was the staff and state of the train. The staff were very friendly and helpful. On the way back we were entertained by a traditional dancer (I think a staff member) and a fashion show. The models were certainly staff members and the garments very fashionable. The snacks were beautifully served (tablecloths were even laid) but that aspect needs some more work.

Good service in the train but not at their offices. We had a problem with our flight due to bad weather and missed the train, they do not offer any solution or accommodation, the only thing you can do is buy tickets again ( which are not cheap), I think that since they are a monopoly and there is no other way to get to Machu Picchu they take advantage of the tourist.On the other side the train ride is really beautiful and service is very good in the Vista Dome.

A trip of contrasts. A most comfortable experience with an excellent lunch served. The trip is in two distinct parts, the high, mostly bare and arid altiplano followed by the long descent towards Cusco in a lush and fertile valley. Highly recommended way to travel.

Great Value. I was pleasantly surprised by the train ride from Puno to Cusco. I have been on lots of trains but this one was really luxurious. The seating area and the observation car were wood paneled from a by-gone era. A 3 course lunch was served along with afternoon tea. Service was superb. Entertainment was cheesy but good. The view of the mountains were great but there are other trains in world which take you to great mountain scenery. What was unique was the 3rd world charm of seeing people clear their stuff off the tracks as the train approached and then quickly reassemble their stalls after the train passed by. Not something you would see in Europe. I heard but did not verify that it costs more if you take the Cusco to Puno route than taking the Puno to Cusco route. A luxury ride with food, wine, and entertainment included for $150, that's a great value in my book.

Train journey of a life time. We left Cusco at 8am and arrived at Puno just before 6pm. The 10 hours just flew past. We had breakfast, lunch and afternoon tea - that were all delicious. We had a 2 seater table with a linen table cloth, brass lamp and a fresh rose. There were blankets on the chairs if you were cold and bar service all day long. The entertainment was cheesy and 10 hours of piped Adean music is a bit hectic. But the pisco sour at 10 am and the champagne and peach juice at 4.30 pm certainly helped. We loved the open observation coach and spend a lot of the journey there - the views are amazing and we saw many interesting things - especially going past farmsteads and through small villages. Would do it again at the drop of a hat.

Train travel at its best. Do it!. The overall experience could either be described as a bit cheesy or one of the most memorable days of your trip. Depends who you are, what you are and what floats your boat.Andean music to welcome you at Huanchaq station in Cusco and, once underway, breakfast is served.We just had scrambled eggs and coffee but it was delicious.The observation car on the rear is great as you trundle out through the streets of Cusco and is a great way to get fresh air as the journey unfolds.There was a fashion show with two ladies modelling knitwear which you could buy, followed by more folk music and dancing. Free Pisco sour was served at this time.The 3 course lunch was truly delicious and after this the barman gave a demonstration on how to make Pisco sour.We had another band, a stop at an artisan market, happy hour with 2 for 1 drinks and then afternoon tea - sandwiches and fruit with orange tea.The journey of 10 hours passed so quickly and I would recommend you do this.Might help if you're 40 and above though. Not sure it's younger people's cup of tea.

What value for the money. Watch out Orient Express!. After travelling on the Hiram Bingham two days earlier to see Machu Picchu, my wife and I were not expecting anything approaching, or in some cases exceeding, the level of service, food, entertainment and comfort quality from Peru Rail's Andean Explorer. How wrong we were and what a terrific 10 hours of travel we had. The time just flew past and all too soon we had reached our destination at Puno, Lake Titicaca.The entertainment started on arrival at Cuzco station with one of the two top class live music groups who remained on the train for the first part of the journey, being supported by local dancing and subsequently a fashion show. We had three brief stops one at a rural tourist market where the afternoon's musical group joined the train for the remainder of the journey.A most enjoyable lunch and tea were included in the price, along with a variety of drinks; breakfast being available as an optional extra at a quite reasonable cost.The onboard Peru Rail staff were both helpful, friendly and highly professional, providing the finishing touches to one of the most enjoyable rail trips my wife and I have ever experienced and we have done quite a few.The Andean Explorer journey really does come highly recommended with varied and changing scenery throughout. I'm sure that anyone reading this review and subsequently going on the train won't be disappointed.

Stunning journey through the Andean high plains. Although a 10 hour train journey seemed daunting - it was entirely worth it. The train itself was comfortable. The view that unfolded as we traveled through the high plains of the Andes from Cusco to Puno was quite incredible. You see rural life as must have been for centuries in these parts. There are multitudes of llama and alpaca farms as you role by. The train also has a beautiful observation car that is open in the back - perfect place to while away a few hours. Definitely a great experience if you are going from Cusco to Puno. The train does stop once in La Rena(?sp), which is the highest point of the journey. There are souvenier vendors and a cute church. Food on the train is good. Lunch is provided and other food and drink can be purchase. Happy travels!

Website double billed charges for the great trip. Website charged my card twice which I did not discover until I had returned from to the US. Just search for your ticket even if you think that it didn't go through. A narrow guage rail line that sways quite a bit, but is well run. The swaying made the bathroom degrade as the trip continued. Don't sleep through the orchids as the train goes along the river gorge towards Aguas Calientes.

a way to go in the past. You have a few alternative to go from Puno to cuzco: flight, road and train. These last option is somptuous: 10 hours in a well renovated train with a perfect service. You have the leisure to see without any stress the nice landscape and benefit of your travel. Everything is perfectly orgnanized and for your confort. The meal are good, the bar is a fullbar and the price are really reasonnable for the confort

Beats the hell out of Amtrak.. Here is a strong review of Peru Rail, broken down simply: Prompt, despite difficult route (Ollanta to Aguas Calientes). Friendly, despite (some) difficult passengers. Outstanding sights thanks to windows everywhere. Easy to use website. No drawbacks from my experience. Recommended.

Train trip from Puno to Cuzco. We took this trip in September 2012 as part of our 3 week Peruvian tour and this was undoubtedly one of the highlights, which we had not expected. The 10 hour trip just whizzed by as we watched the ever changing scenery. This was a great way of seeing more of the countryside and was far better than going by road We started off at Puno and gradually climbed up to La Paya Pass at 4321 metres, where we stopped for a while to take photos and do some shopping for those who needed their shopping fix, before descending.We even passed through a mini blizzard at one point. The viewing carriage at the back of the train allowed us keen photographers to snap away uninterrupted.It was amazing to see how the market stall holders packed up their stalls as the train approached and put everything back over the tracks as the train passed by as if nothing had happened.We had great service and meals provided on the train, all the staff were very helpful, we could not have asked for a more enjoyable way to spend a day getting between these two places. Even had some entertainment provided - musicians, dancers, pisco sour demonstration.

Loved it - remember you're in the South American Andes not a city elsewhere!. It was wonderfuly South American! Relaxed, great views and access to inaccessable parts of the continent. Service was what I'd expect in South America - not five star,but more than offse by the staf being friendly and there to assist! I loved it and the people. In my mind I can't think of a better way to travel this part of the continent.

Beautiful scenery....terrible service!. My wife and I took the train as part of our honeymoon in Peru. We opted for the train as a treat to ourselves after 4 days on the Inca trail, little did we know that the food and service from the mobile kitchens on the trail would far outshine the train. To start off all the meals were late by at least 40mins. When they did eventually arrive they were cold! This goes for everything, the soup, the main course and even the tea was cold. How hard is it to keep water warm???? The dissapointment did not end with the food. We had a table for two, nice and romantic. Only down side was that it was next to the cartridge door. Not a problem we thought, perhaps the odd over enthusiastic tourist may forget to close the door when passing through to the observation carriage but not the staff right? Wrong! Despite being ask by my wife on at least 2 occasions one of the train staff repeatedly left the door open, letting cold winds, noise and diesel fumes. On one occasion I watched her stop the door from closing with her trailing hand as she barged through. Overall this was 10 hours of my life I can never get back and I would not expect this type of service from British Rail never mind someone with links/ambitions of Boeing like the Orient Express. This trip should have been a highlight of our honeymoon with the beautiful scenery and a first class experience. Luckily the scenery more than lived up to expectations.
Excellent. The Peru trains are so well organised. Excellent service with appetising food. The entertainment on the trains is exceptional. Loved the train trips. Hard to find a dislike.

great way to travel from Puno. 10 hours of old worldly orient express style travel.food was good, some light entertainment and amazing views.Early morning start, and pulled into Cusco as it got dark, but we were well rested.

Great service and super entertaining. Upon our return to Cusco from Aguascalientes, we were exhausted. All we wanted to do was sleep, but to our surprise, there was a "fashion show" scheduled to go on during the train ride. The crew members were the models and needless to say, they were hilarious! They made us laugh, dance and forget how tired we were earlier that day. Hands down, best service we received throughout our trip. Our crew were Milagros, Victor and Wilberth...Thanks guys! Keep up the good work!

Fun and Beautiful Day in Peru. This was quite an experience. Takes the whole day and is certainly an adventure. While you can fly/taxi in 2 hours...this longer trip lets you relax and see the entire countryside on a safe, comfortable and relaxing train ride. A few stops along the way, a delicious meal, first class service and some on board entertainment make the day seem more like an attraction than traveling. Rear car is open for great views and fresh air while you ride. Only thing is we wished the train could have gone a bit faster at times through the open country to cut down on the 10 hours.

Amazing scenery and great service. The Perurail train station was one of the best buildings we were in on our trip. It was comfortable, clean and efficient. The train ride travelled through diverse, beautiful scenery from green farmland to mountains to jungle. Along with this beautiful ride we were treated to a meal served on colorful table clothes with real china and silverware. It was a relaxing, very enjoyable trip with some of the most georgeous scenery we had ever seen.

The only way to travel. An experience not to be missed. Not the quickest way from Puno to Cusco - we were overtaken by tuk-tuks!! - but certainly the most interesting. Able to walk around and into observation car with its open rear. Went through market where some traders spread their wares between the rails. Wonderful scenery, excellent cuisine served with panache.

wonderful relaxing journey. This is an upmarket but very slow train journey that takes you from Cusco to Puno on Lake Titicaca. It takes about ten hours. (The journey is actually quicker by road and plane and just as cheap. ) It is however a must for train enthusiasts. The old traditional carriages are clean and comfortable, food and drink are freely available and largely free of charge. We were provided with an excellent breakfast (continental with choice of eggs) and a very pleasant afternoon tea of cakes and sandwiches. The lunch however was disappointing as we found the main course (trout) to be overcooked to the point of being inedible, and cold on its arrival at our table. However the journey reveals the most beautiful and variable scenery and an insight into the rural life of indigenous people that are seen enroute. The high altitude at La Raya (5800metres) visibly affected some people who got off the train to visit the market. Moving at a snails pace through the middle of the bustling market in Juliaca was quite an experience.

A very nice experiece. This trai is a very pleasant ride to Machu Picchu. I was very surprised by the throughtful service, good facilitities and seating and lite snack that was delicious. Of course, the scenery never stops. A very interesting trip
Nice way to travel. Spent the 10 hours from Puno to Cusco. Only two carriages of travelers and a nice bar and observation car. Lots of attentive staff. Food good.
We love the train. We took the upscale train from Puno to Cusco. It is worth the extra money to take the train over the bus.

A touch of luxury. Not our normal style, but what the heck. You check in your big bags for the duration and sit in comfy armchairs where lunch and tea are served. The food is ok, nothing gourmet. Free pisco sour prelunch. Dancers and shopping are confined to the observation car, so you can opt out. Best bit was riding down the market street in Juliaca.
take the train. We traveled Puno to Cusco - the train trip was awesome. bar car - fantastic, observation car - unbelievable. Do not take the bus, take the train, it is worth it.

Enjoyed more than expected to. Don't like the idea of 'tourist trains' and would much prefer to take a train used by local people. However, this is not an option in Peru (unique in this respect in my experience). However, despite the rather outrageous cost, this was a really good trip.

Great experience!. We took the Andean Explorer from Puno to Cuzco. The comfort and luxury begins as soon as you hand over your baggage and enter the well heated and comfortable waiting room with live music. The train itself is a throwback to a bygone era of travel, with armchair seating, wood paneling, linen covered tables, elegantly dressed staff, a bar car and a spectacular observation car at the back of the train.The service includes a live music show with Pisco Sours to taste, a three course lunch, afternoon tea with sandwiches and champagne, and a fashion show. We had additional Pisco Sours during the happy hours as well.The best thing about the journey though, are the views. The plains, the mountains, the rivers, the alpaca herds and the terraced fields ... No better way to see them than from the window or observation car of a slowly passing by train. The stopovers to switch tracks with the oncoming train, and at La Raya ( highest point of the route, tourist market and pretty church) are good fun too.Certainly beats flying!!

One of the Greatest Rail Journeys in the World. Our group of 10 decided to splash out on this pricey journey from Cuzco to Puno whilst climbing the Peruvian Andes mountains and exploring the country. And boy, what a great decision that was.We had a fantastic day, being treated very well on a throw back to a golden age of travel. Silver service lunch, a bar car, a viewing platform and all under the Peruvian sun. The landscape can only be fully appreciated by this slower pace of travel - from deep valleys, snowy mountains, rivers and plateaus. Could not have been happier to spend the money on this excursion.The lunch was excellent, the afternoon tea less so, but not enough to take the gloss off the journey. Soft drinks should have been included in the price, and that is something I hope PeruRail take on board.Would highly recommend this to anyone who wants to enjoy a bit of the high life on a journey round the country.

Fantastic Experince. Not the most comfoartable experince - armchairs, with arms that don't raise so diif to get in and out - not much leg room and I had a wooden panel as a windowSo I spent most of the time in the observation car - which had great views, and open at the back for great photosDon't expect to be seated with your travel companion

Magnificent. What a treat! To travel gently and in such comfort, with the freedom to walk around and take advantage of the observation car at your leisure was a delight. The grandeur of the landscape could be fully appreciated whether it was the deep valleys, snow capped mountains, extensive altiplano, bubbling rivers or the river terraces. The train also gives a greater insight into the life and work of the inhabitants; small villages, farming methods, the chaos of traffic and bustle of an unbelievable market in Juliaca. Both lunch and afternoon tea were good as were the complimentary pisco sours. An unmissable experience!

lots of fun. This was one of the few things we splashed out on in South America and it was well worth it. It's a bizarre, one-off experience that keeps you constantly amused. The train is beautiful, the food and drink good, the entertainment quirky but fun and the landscape beautiful. As well as the natural scenery you trundle through many settlements which are invariably interesting.

What a trip. This is a must if you are travling in this area. We paid £140 for a full day (10hrs) of first class service with lunch and afternoon tea inc, there is also live entertainment and one stop on the way at the highest point (10mins).You are seated at tables which rivels the Orient Express (and much cheeper) with 3 course lunch with wine and the afternoon tea comes with a glass of fizzy wine mixed with orange all with silver service.Only go from Puno to Cusco as the other way round is in the dark and the best views are on the right hand side of the train.

Take some time and reward yourself. Rode this lovely train from Puno to Cusco and had a fantastic time. First class all the way from fine dining with table cloths, fresh roses, china, silverware, chef specialties, live entertainment (3 musical groups), dancing girls, fashion show, bar tending class on making (and drinking) Pisco sours.

The only way to travel across the Andes. Couldn't the trip. Seats wide and comfortable, food plentiful and good quality. Regular supplies of pisco sour and cocktails made thevtrip easier to bear. Although thevtrip was 10 hours long it was not tedious at all!The on board entertainment was quaint and could be easily avoided if you wanted.We saw a bus group traveling the same direction as us and they looked at us with envy.For $165 USD it was value for money.The views were fabulous the train stopped at the highest point 4050m above sea level where you had the chance to buy more alpaca stuff!Highly recommended.

An eloquent way to travel. We traveled from Puno to Cusco it took 11 hours. I was a bit nervous about the length of this trip but the time went by very quickly we chatted with the other passengers and could get up and walk about the train. We had a wonderful lunch and the scenery was spectacular. When I think about the alternative in taking a bus I know I made the right choice and will definitely recommend this to everyone.

Andean Luxury. No better way to travel from Cusco to Puno. Amazing scenery with luxury service. Takes about the same time as a coach but so much better. You get star treatment, food very good. Observation car at the back brilliant though you do get the people who selfishly seem to hog it ! You do get some cheesy entertainment , but just go with it or stay in your own armchair. The only down side is the non stop pan pipe music you could find yourselves hearing it for day's after and be prepared for a slow departure from train while they sort the luggage at your destination .

Pleasant journey across Peru. The trip from Cusco to Puno on the Andean Explorer was a very pleasant journey. While long (every bit of 10 hours), we passed through some beautiful scenery and they did their best to keep you entertained. The service was good and all the staff were well trained. We enjoyed the observation car and it was a relaxed way to travel. We had been sightseeing all day, every day for a week so it was nice to sit back and watch the world go by or chat with the others on the train that came from all over the world.

Just not worth it. We took the Cusco to Puno leg which for some reason is almost twice the price of going the other way. At $240 per person I was expecting some serious quality, this is South America we're talking about after all.
