Firstly, the seats are literally arm chairs bolted to the floor with no recline (for 10hrs!). The scenery was mediocre at best and most of it was arid farm land. The service is terrible, for example it took over an hour and asking 4 people for a glass of wine, and generally the staff are all moody. The food was cold, the white wine was warm and there's no snacks, only set meals.If you insist on taking this route versus bus or other transport, make sure you ask Perurail to seat you with your partners or friends, they have a habit of placing people randomly.

Pleasant ride to Aguas Calientes. We had a good experience with the Peru Rail Vistadome. I chose it for the schedule, and had no issues booking online. There is space for luggage on this train, so don't worry about stowing it before you leave. Also, they give you a snack and coffee just after you depart, so save your money and don't buy anything at the train station (the coffee is tempting that early in the morning, but wait for the stuff on the train as it's still pretty decent.) The "entertainment" on the way back is a bit annoying and touristy, but you can ignore it and read if you prefer.

Fantastic trip. Started in a nice departure lounge with live Andean music - might have been nice to have coffee or something while waiting though. Once on board it was first class all the way - white tablecloth, rose, comfortable armchairs, excellent food (breakfast, lunch and afternoon tea) nice observation and bar car at the back. Beautiful trip through valleys farmland and mountains - very brief stop at the highest point with small market if you want to buy the usual sweaters, hats etc. Enjoyed all the people waving all along the route especially the little children who would run out when they heard the train coming! This was a great way to travel and a nice treat after all the walking and climbing we did the few days before. Highly recommend

Good scenery terrible customer & managing services. Firstly checked our baggage in Puno and enjoyed the 12 hour train ride through the Peruvian countryside. But to our surprise when we arrived in Cusco and got off the train we found our bags in a pile on the ground outside the train. We noticed that one of our brand new suitcases (was a matching pair we travelled with) was damaged. We picked our luggage up off the floor and went to find someone in charge. We found a staff member who went to find someone in charge, he returned with another employee who we drew attention to our damaged bag. He told us that 'that the bag isn't broken it's just sort of wrecked' ... Now we told him that when we paid top dollar for what is described at a first class service we didn't expect our new bags to be treated the way they obviously had been and to go and get someone who can do something about it. We were then approached by a group of staff and finally the 'manager' Mr Gonzalo Alfaro who looked over the bags and agreed that they had been damaged. He then told us that there was an administrative procedure that had to be followed to determine who was at fault for damaging the bags, whether it was 'the people who loaded them in Puno or Cusco'. We told him that we didn't need an inquiry into who damaged the bags but just wanted a solution. He said they were a British owned company and they had to follow this procedure. He also said that 'it would have to come out of someone's pay'. So unfortunately we had to leave the station with our damaged bag. Before leaving I told him that im not someone who regularly makes complaints (as you can see from my other reviews) and so long as 'there was a solution we were happy'. 5 days later with no contact from Mr Alfaro we contacted him as we were due to leave Cusco. He told us that the issue was still being investigated. Another week passed and we had no contact from Mr Alfaro so contacted him again, we told him that we needed a solution ASAP as we were leaving the country (he was aware of our traveling itinery previously also). He replied to us that the issue has been investigated and they haven't found anything.I wasn't just surprised by the lack of customer service in the first place but this response was just absurd. So if you do travel with Peru Rail be aware they advertise first class, charge top dollar, tell you they are a British owned company (to aleviate our concerns when initially we told him we were worried the issue would be swept under the carpet) but clearly are incompetent when it comes to customer service and dispute resolutions.
very good experience. very nice experience , good service and is not expensive , the only way to go to Aguas Calientes , by train.

A great journey to Machu Picchu. We took this train back from Aguas Calientes, after hiking the Inca trail. Definitely a beautiful journey, and a comfortable carriage. They served a snack, and you could buy beer, wine etc. They looked after you the way airlines used to, back when they actually cared about the customer experience. The staff were all really nice and helpful.One thing I will say though, there was a fashion parade mid journey where the staff modeled Peru Rail alpaca clothing. The aisle was the catwalk, there was music and some passengers even got in on the act. In the beginning I thought it was obnoxious, but as it unfolded it was actually really good fun. The clothes were surprisingly cool, and everyone in the carriage was clapping etc. A really good vibe.One thing to watch - the train doesn't go into Cuzco. It stops a little way outside it, so you'll need to organize a taxi to and from the station.

Nice, luxury experience. 1st, prepare yourself for a long day...it's over 9 hours, so once you've accepted that, it's worth it. The scenery is spectacular through the altiplano, although after the initial excitement of the 1st couple hours wears off after leaving Cusco, the view can seem repetitive. Along the way, the service is very professional and has in mInd the long journey: lunch, live music, a pisco sour, etc. Traveling through the towns is amazing to see how rural folk live, just be prepared for 3rd world-ness in your face. But the sight of cute kids waving to you will melt your heart. All that said, if you're okay with the cost and time, this is a great ride.

Expensive and over-the-top. We used the Andean Explorer Train to travel from Cuzco to Puno. The ticket was expensive, but was the only train that PeruRail offered (and we didn't want to take a bus.) The train was very touristy - they had dancers, a band and performed a "fashion show" with alpaca scarves. The sights from the train were great - especially the observation car at the end. They served an OK lunch and afternoon tea. As we were drinking our tea we traveled through a very poor area of Juliaca. It felt wrong to be on such a luxury train in such a poor area. I enjoyed the ride, but I don't think it needed to be so extravagent.

Brilliant!. My wife and I travelled on the Andean Explorer from Puno to Cusco during our five week trip around Peru. What a fantastic train journey this was. We were given a lovely little table for two on the right-hand side, which meant that we had a great view of the lake as we passed by. The observation car offered even more spectacular views, especially when we crossed the Altiplano, and my wife actually spent more of the journey there than sitting at our table (she was very dusty when we arrived in Cusco but said it was worth it!).Passing though Juliaca was an experience! Market stalls were set up beside the track and in some cases over the track. We saw a card table being put back on the track after the train had passed through, with the hands of cards still intact and the men sitting down and resuming their game! The train had to move through very slowly to allow people to get their stalls, and themselves, out of the way. It was chaotic, but fascinating to watch!The food was very good. There is a bar and entertainment in the form of a pan-pipe band. There was a group of about a dozen Spanish students who virtually took over the observation car and created a real party atmosphere. It was great. The scenery was spectacular and it's something that we would highly recommend to everyone travelling between Puno and Cusco, it's the only way to do it really.

Luxury Train. This was a very nice train, lunch was in the cost of the journey and was lovely. Everything else you had to pay for including breakfast, drinks including bottled water. They bring you the bill at the end of the journey. Not sure it is worth paying £130 each extra over going by bus. We choose to go by train thinking it would be better being able to walk arounnd rather than being trapped in a bus. Other people in our tour group went by bus and said they made numerous stops on route had seats that reclined (nearly as good as a bed) and the bus was quicker than the train, they were at the hotel in Lake Titicacca 30 minutes before us. Overall if I was to do this journey again I would go by bus and save £260.

This journey lets you see some of the real Peru..... Being owned by the Orient Express group, Peru Rail, provides quite a comfortable level of rail travel, whilst you take in what we felt was the "real Peru". From Cusco to Puno you absorbed much more of Peruvian life than just being holed up in a city hotel...or an airport. Much of the scenery was pretty, but towns like Juliaca shows you of how many Peruvians in rural areas would really live. The railway carraiges were almost brushing the street stalls that are permanantly set up in this seemingly industrial town.10 hours of informative, sometimes eye opening travel.....whilst being looked after, well fed and refreshed.It was great.

Very long, but scenic ride from Cusco to Puno. My husband and I traveled from Cusco to Puno on the Andean Explorer. The views were incredible, however the train ride was extremely long. We knew it was a 10 hour ride, so it wasn't a surprise, but by the end of the trip, we were wishing we had chosen to take a plane.

Good IF you have the right seats!. Nice train, friendly staff but watch out for seat assignments. We were assigned the seats going backwards the entire way with a very small window, the people sitting right in front of you are seeing the entire forward view and have a window twice the size of yours. On the way back from Aquas Calientes we changed our tickets for an earlier train, at the ticket office, we were told there were NOT two seats together (this was on the same day)...the car was half empty and we along with 2 other couples switched our seats around so we could sit with our spouses and be in the right direction with a window.

The most amazing journey!. It was a few years back and I managed to get this journey for $45 - but I would Paul much much more. It was the most incredible train journey I have ever taken - amazing vistas, fascinating villages and towns, and great pisco sours - what more? Oh, an observation car with open railings at the back which makes you feel like a king or president as you wave at everyone.

same company and style as the orient express. the whole trip was first class luxury with the most impeccable waiters and waitresses beautifully trained in silver serviceThe only downside was the contrast with the people of some of the towns we past through whose lives were so markedly different from the luxury we found ourselves enjoying

Brilliant. I loved this train ride, you really see the landscape and beauty of Peru. A few shocks when we pulled into Juliaca, the train went straight through a market. The food was excellent, drinks flowing and the views from the open area just fantastic. It didn't feel like a 10 hour train ride, we really enjoyed it. There is a 10 minute stop were you can get off, a small market where you can buy the usual tourist bits and photo opportunities with the locals.

Wonderful trip and great service. We loved the train, the service and the views. They also provide great live music from two different groups (we even bought the cd). The food was very good and well presented. Be sure to carry enough cash. The only things included are a small Pisco sour and lunch with one glass of wine and then afternoon tea. If you want other drinks, alcoholic or not, there is a charge. We didn't think the prices were high. A great way to travel.

Andian Explorer from Cuzco to Puno. We really enjoyed this train ride. The seats were like padded wingback chairs, the club car and observation cars were nice. The food was good, the service was great. The scenery is quite like Eastern Oregon, grasslands and livestock, but the mountains were snow covered and nice to view. It was a good adventure and a pleasant way to travel from Cuzco to Lake Titicaca. Price was US$210 which equated to a flight, but was more pleasant.

Amazing Experience. I travelled on the Andean Explorer on July 30th, 2012 from Cusco to Puno. It was an amazing experience. Breathtaking landscapes as the train chugged along the track, alpacas and llamas grazing, panoramic views of snow capped mountains, musicians playing panpipes inside the train, fashion show, making your own pisco sour, etc. made the experience a memorable one. I would highly recommend all tourists intending to travel to Peru to undertake this journey. It is a bit too expensive but nevertheless worth it. Better to have an early breakfast prior to boarding the train (only a three course lunch and afternoon tea is included in the ticket). Do not think twice - just go for the Andean Explorer!
Fantastic!. A magnificent experience both for adults and kids. Food, travel, staff and stops - everything was good.

Check your email the day before you travel!. We travelled Puno to CuscoWe were sent an email the day before our travel time moving the departure time forward 90 minutes because of a planned strike. Fortunately I checked my emails and saw this. If not we would have missed the train.The trip is great, service good.Get out on the observation deck as you pass through Juliaca (may need warm clothes) the town scenes as you pass through the market are not to be missed.They don't allow taxis into Cusco station so you have to go out on the street, but the security staff went out of their way to find a taxi for us and ensure that the driver had the right address.We were double charged on my credit card as the site crashed while I was booking. Getting the refund required phone calls to the office in Cusco as the staff at Larcomar in Lima were not able to help. I have now received the refund.Overall, this is a not to be missed journey.

Great trip but shame about the delays.. This was a great trip with great views.The food was good, the service excellent and the seating comfortable. The observation car which included the bar was a great place to take photographs. Included were a fashion show, dancing and folk singing. We also had a Pisco Sour demonstration !The only drawback was that the train was 3 hours late getting in to Puno and the last quarter of the trip was in the dark. There was no explanation as to what caused the delays nor was ther any apology. Compensation was a complimentary hot drink. The delays may not have been the fault of Perurail but an explanation would have put speculation to rest. Despite the delays it was a great experience and one we would not have missed.

Amazing Train. We took the train from Cusco to Puno and loved the Andean Explorer! This train is a rare experience, a very special train service the kind of which is usually much more expensive. Historic cars including an Observation car, bar and comfortable seating made the 10 hour journey very special. If you like train trips this is definitely one for you, it was so much better than taking the same trip by plane or bus.

One Magnificent Train. This was the highlight of my Inca Trail Adventure. We took the train from Puno to Cusco. A very scenic ride with Andean music and dance to entertain us. The meal offered was first class as was the service.

Loooong ride. The ride was supposed to be 9.5 hours, but ended up being about 10.25. It was a long day on the train. I thought the scenery was nice - nothing super spectacular - just valleys, rivers, and mountains. There was a stop at a little market in a town, so get ready to be hounded. The ride doesn't include breakfast or drinks, so I suggest taking snacks and water with you. The lunch was good and the high tea was nice. The passenger car doesn't have windows up above, so if you want the upper view you need to be in the viewing car behind the bar. There was a fashion show, two local bands, and a bartending mini-class. The service was nice, but overall Perurail isn't known for fast trains. If you want to get from Cusco to Puno more quickly, the bus or a flight would be much quicker. Be sure to check with your hotel to have them pick you up at the train station when you arrive.

Surprisingly, one of our favorite experiences. We decided to take the Andean explorer because we were doing a lot of short flights around Peru and wanted something different. Having spent a total of six hours the day before on the train to and from Machu Picchu, I had mixed feelings about getting back on train for a ten hour haul. It turned out to be one of the best parts of our trip.The train itself is comfortable and inviting. The assigned seats are easy chairs with a dining table, configured for either two or four people. Lunch and tea are included, other drinks and breakfast are available. Bathrooms are way above average for both trains and for Peru.The service is good and the employees are friendly. They take their synchronized lunch service a little too seriously - they stack up like a swat team and rush the tables two at a time, the first time I thought we were being arrested for something. The food is ok. Presentation was good, but we found it all to be pretty bland. I'd say it was roughly equivalent to business-class airline food, albeit better presented. I suppose it's perfectly decent given that it's prepared on a train and served at altitude, but I would have liked a little more flavor. Still, not unpleasant and certainly not a deal breaker.The observation and bar cars are what make the trip. We ended up sitting and watching Peru go by for hours. After having seen all the major sites, it was fascinating to see the non-touristed countryside. This involves seeing quite a bit of poverty (especially in Juliaca), which was effecting at times. But it was educational to see some 'real' Peru.There were only two passenger cars on our train, so there were a very manageable number of people aboard. The bar and observation car were pleasantly busy during the scheduled events (a 'fashion show' and some live music) but were pleasingly low-density at other times.As with literally every organized activity in Peru, there is a handcrafts market. This one is located at the highest point on the journey, which has some nice views. We bought our fair share of generic Alpaca goods here - it was more gratifying to do it in the middle of nowhere and to give money to some people that weren't wholly ingrained in Cusco's hustler culture. If you don't want to participate you can remain on the train.Our only other minor complaint was the perpetual loop of pan-flute theme songs - we heard "el condor pasa" and, surprisingly, a song from the Kill Bill soundtrack eight times each. Overall, this was a great experience. The ten hours went by surprisingly quickly, and we saw more authentic Peru from the train than anywhere else on the trip.
Amazing views. Views of the valley and mountain peaks were wonderful and the large windows allowed for great pictures

Puno to Cusco - a MUST DO. What a beautiful journey!Ignore the catering etc for a minute...it was "OK". The selection etc was great but most was Luke warm. Now...that aside. THE TRIP.A great speed to see all the sights and sounds of the many changing landscapes you pass through. Beautiful mountains, wide open plains, along rivers and more.The locals wave and look on with interest and others turn their backs in disdain, either way the tapestry of humanity is great to see. Make sure you you have the camera ready as the train passes literally through the middle of the main street of towns with bustling activity 10cm either side of the track.Having done it, there is no way I would choose any other option if your budget allows ($120).

A wonderful train experience for Peru. I boarded the Andean Explorer from Puno (after Lake Titikaka) towards Cusco ready for a full day of treats – good meals, good drinks, entertainment even, and that’s on top of the visual treats of the rolling landscapes of Peru. It was an exciting journey. So relaxing just to be able to be comfortable on board the train and wander from carriage to carriage to enjoy its facilities and the view. We were seated at the two seater with dining setting. Once on board, we were given our first serving of complimentary coffee. (After which we had to pay) As the train rolled out of the station, many rushed towards the viewing / observation car to snap photos of the landscapes of Puno that we were leaving behind. It was a slow ride and soon the train rolled in to a little town settlement and we found ourselves rolling along the track really close to housing, and stalls set up just beside the track, rolling over their goods and wares they were peddling and which they set up on the tracks too! However the locals knew that the clearance between the train’s undercarriage and the track would accommodate their goods so they had no qualms leaving it all there as the train rolled over it. The speed of the train was not fast, and it gave us plenty of time to appreciate the colours of the town, the dress of the local people and the hustle and bustle of market commerce. At La Raya which was the highest point of the ride, we were allowed to get off the train to stretch our legs, get some fresh altitude air (I think at that point we were about 4,300m above sea level) and also do some shopping. Vendors set up shop at a platform just next to the La Raya train stop, selling local handicrafts, accessories, plush toys of animals alpaca, vicuna and llhama and also clothings made from alpaca. Back on board the train, we were also treated to entertainment. The musicians that had welcomed us bright and early at 7.30am at Puno station had boarded and was ready to perform their first set of entertainment – music and dance. My partner was also pulled up for a jiggle, a dance on the train in the altitudes of Peru. There was also a Pisco Sour making demonstration, after which everyone was treated to a glass. (Subsequent orders were on paying basis) Lunch was served in the carriage at the seats and tables we were earlier assigned to and I had the vegetarian lasagne while my partner had meat for mains. In the afternoon and just before afternoon tea (hot beverages and sandwiches), we were treated to yet another round of music and entertainment (seems another group had boarded the train towards Cusco) and so started to entertain us in the bar carriage. Special mention has to be made of the spacious toilets, they were clean and well maintained too! The train was scheduled to pull in to Cusco around 6pm however we were delayed till 8pm. Somehow. All the booked drivers had left the station but some had probably heard that the train had come in so they returned to meet and pick their passengers. We were not so lucky as our driver never came back. However a staff from on board the train saw our predicament and as he was also going in to Cusco, he offered to arrange that his taxi also drop us off at our hotel on the way. For that we were grateful. Overall however, the Andean Explorer would rank as one of my favourite train journeys. And it was definitely a wonderful way to see Peru and all its landscapes she had to offer. Don't miss this amazing journey if you can help it. You won't regret this ride.

A scenic train ride. We rode this train back from Machu Picchu after taking the Inca Trail to get there. After 4 days of hiking this felt like luxury and we found the river valley it traveled through to be very pretty and mountainous. Our only complaint, a small one, is that the seats (2 on each side of a table) lacked much leg room. This was offset by better than expected comfort in the compartment and the seats.

Overpriced ride!. This ride is overpriced but there is not option if you cannot do the Inca trail. The service is fine but not worth the price. If you are not traveling with little kids you are going to be better taking the cheapest train available. You will get to the same place in about the same time for less money.

A Peruvian manmade "MUST DO". Read the recent reviews. They tell it all. A step back in time to old style railway comfort. The views of the passing world scenic and human -ever changing- mean that reading is not a real option! Go to the observation car at the back, enjoy the entertainment of singers and dancers, relax in the comfortable seating, wallow in the (nearly) silver lunch service, and so much more. Peru tourism is not geared up enough to trumpet this jewel, so we sussed it ourselves. Are we glad we did. Another highlight amongst so many during our 2 week Peruvian adventure with Intrepid travel.
journey on the andes. best way to travel from cusco to lake titicaca. gourmet meal included in fare. 10 hour journey but worth it

Worth the money. This train journey is an experience. The train is on a par with the Orient Express, all brass and leather. Check in is by a man wearing a bow tie. Food is delicious and served like a well rehearsed ballet. Views are to die for and comfort is all that was promised. Really, just do it.

Uncomfortable journey. The train was FREEZING cold when The journey began. It was about 30 degrees, everyone was bundling up trying to get comfortable in the impossible cold. Passengers were wearing hats, gloves, scarfs and large winter coats on the ride. There was no heat and no alternative. It stayed cold for about 2 hours into the 3.5 hour trip. On the return it was HOT. My travel companion and i were both sweating and miserable from the heat. It did cool approximately one hour into the return trip. I traveled in June which is their winter but there is no excuse. Its cold at the perurail station and hot in macchu picchu. As another reviewer stated, we are paying tourist prices, we deserve tourist comfort. The seats are comfortable and the scenery is worthy. Our travel agent warned us not to take perurail but we didn't listen. If you are offered a cheaper option, take it. I was very disappointed. After this trip I was ready to return to the states. I had enough. A minimal snack is served. Everything else was for a fee and they were constantly trying to sell you clothing, gifts, souvenirs, drinks, etc. It wasn't a bad experience but I would not do it again.

A Delight.. A ten hour train journey sounds an ordeal however this was great. Fantastic spacious seats with a table, lovely food, amusing entertainment and the viewing platform was a wonderful way to see the scenery and people.

Expensive but worth it!. We'd been travelling for a while and just finished a 42km Lares Trek hike, so the thought of spending 10 hours on a luxury train from Cusco to Puno sounded like heaven. It was!From the moment you step into the posh waiting room you can tell that this is no ordinary train ride. The inside of the train is very tastefully decorated and looks even better than the photos on the website. There were free Pisco sours (delicious!) at 11am, followed by live Andean music (twice) and a fashion show. The three course lunch was delicious and included some wine. The views of the Andes are also great as you go along the countryside.Thoroughly recommended if you don't mind spending the $220!

Great ride, Puno to Cusco. We took the Andean Explorer on May 28 from Puno to Cusco in the first class car. Thought the 10 hour trip would have some boring moments, but we were enthralled for the entire trip. The scenery along the way was spectacular and ever changing. The one short stop we made in La Raya was a nice break (some people bought items at the typical Peruvian "craft" market; we enjoyed just taking pictures). The food on the trip was really very good and the nice presentation was unexpected. The service throughout the journey was excellent. They kept everything clean including the restrooms (which were large compared to an airplane). There was some entertainment (small band and dancer) during the trip, which also provided a nice interlude. It was nice meeting people from all over the world. Another great adventure.

Not to be missed. First, ignore those reviews that talk about the train to Aguas Calientes, THAT IS NOT this train - the Andean Explorer runs between Puno and Cusco (both ways). Top notch, a step back in time, elegant, and with wonderful scenery. A great value, we thought, way better than a plane ride. Unforgettable. If you can put it in your intinerary, it's worth the day. We have been to Peru twice and would make this trip one of our top recommendations.

Nice but make sure you have something to do!. LONG RIDE!!!!!!!!! We went to Puno with this train, leaving from Cusco... Its a 10h ride!!! Even though its a nice little train, its old so its moving a lot inside so you cannot really write or stay concentrated in a book! It also smells diesel a lot, even if you close the windows, but I guess its part of it.. Food was not so good (for my husband and I), but entertainement in the train is cool, if you like to watch, and the view is really nice!!! You can be outside, in the train, on what they call the observatory deck. On this long ride, they stop 1 time, for like 15-20 min, to the highest point in altitude, where you can take pictures and where there is a market, another one, where you can buy things if you want to.

What an adventure !. After spending 4-5 days slogging the Inca Trail this is a perfect way to treat yourself to a little indulgence. You know its going to be fun because as soon as you roll up to the waiting room (get there early to get a comfy lounge chair), you discover yet another pan pipe band belting out tunes. After a while you board the train and are able to order breakfast (not included in price) which is delivered to your seat. Everyone has a comfortable lounge-like table with a table in front of them.The view is constantly changing as the train wends its way through the countryside. At around 10am the conductor brings along a Pisco Sour for everyone who is interested.The back of the train is a bar and observation car which is open right at the back. During the day, a couple of different bands play here and there is an exhibtion of Peruvian costumes and some dancing. There is also a demonstation of Pisco Sour making with audience participation.At lunch time the smartly turned out wait staff bring out the various courses in a very efficient and military-like fashion. There are choices for each course and the meal is good, including a glass of vino. At around the halfway point and also the highest point 4000 mtrs the train stops for around 20 minutes. Coincidentally, there is a small market here with the locals selling their handicrafts and there is, once again, a photo opportunity to capture the locals with their baby alpacas and lambs (Fee involved). The train reaches Puno just after dark, in time to grab a light dinner and roll into bed.Summary: well worth the $200 (US) for the day
One of the hundred things to do before you die. This was just brilliant from start to finish. The food, the service, the entertainment just made our day so good. Cannot fault in any way

Either dishonest or very poorly run. I canceled my trip to Peru and asked for a refund of the amout I paid by credit card knowing they would charge me for that (it´s something like 5% or 10%).The problem is that it was almost 3 months ago and so far I haven't recieved neither the money nor any kind of information about my request.After sending them an email asking what was going on I got a response saying they were verifying with the credit card payment administrator why there was a delay on my reimbursement, but other than that nothing was done!Still waiting for the money.My advice? Think twice before booking it online.
The only train in and out from Machu Picchu. It was very comfortable- we had the best class I think- this was arranged and included in our price of our Inca Trek tour company.

An exciting day's travel. We travelled from Puno to Cuzco. rly start, for an 8am departure from the very anonymous rail station at Puno. A four coach train, with cooking facilities, and a great observation car. The programme for the trip looked busy, but was very enjoyable- Puno and Cuzco folk music, Pisco sour demo, and a fashion show. The views all along the line were fantastic, no more so than the route through towns; the street vendors were right by the track, and sold everything from ducklings to welding torches! The Puno side seemed poorer, in contrast to the Cuzco district, which looked like it got more rain. A great days
Make sure you take this train during day time. Marvel of of sights both side of the car. Viewing ports upwards. Good service, like in a flight.

Old fachion slow train. Very specail and luxorious train. You can go to the back of the train and take photos. It is open back. Also the restaurant vagon is something very special. Lot of programme on the train like dancing and making Pisco Sour.

Worth every penny. The irst three hours or so are not specatacular, but after that the ride becomes incredible. It is a long journey to Puno, but the staff was fabulous and made the time fly.If you are lucky to meet Angela on your ride you will have met one of Peru's most beautiful ladies. Keep your hands inside the train while going through the market in Juliaca, but otherwise enjoy the photo opportunities.

Great Train Journey. On the Andean Explorer by Orient-Express by 7:30am ready for an 8:00am start. The train took us from Cusco into the highlands and on to Puno, almost 4,000 metres above sea level. The train itself is tastefully decorated in the style of the great Pullman trains of the 1920's much like the Hiram Bingham we travelled on from Machu Picchu.The bulk of the first part of the trip to La Raya, the highest point on the line, was alongside a river and the valley was reasonable tight. As we got nearer to La Roya the valley was wider much like open plains with a backdrop of snow-capped mountain peaks of the Andes. We saw the mountain peaks, lush river valleys, quaint towns and rolling plains glide by. Travelling in Andean Explorer Class (first class), we enjoyed access to the lounge car as well as the open-air observation bar car. The open end at the rear of the train enabled photos unimpeded by windows so was great. We stopped at La Roya for photo opportunity and also a small local market for tourists.After this stop we were then treated to a treat of a delicious three-course lunch. It was served in military precision by PeruRail staff immaculately clad in uniform. It was a great experience with delightful food.La Roya was a watershed in the mountains so we now continued downhill in a much wider valley to Puno some 10 hours after leaving Cusco. A rail journey not to miss!

Luxurious train ride from Puno to Cusco!. For 220 USD you'll have a wonderful 3-course meal, entertainment with local dances and music onboard, service-minded staff, comfortable chairs, table cloths and an unforgettable view of the Andes mountains. Can it be better?Do it if you can afford it is my advise!

Ten hours of pan pipes and diesel fumes.... We set out on this train journey with some enthusiasm, having greatly enjoyed the Hiram Bingham train. I hadn't realised just how long the trip is, but even that would not have been a problem, were it not for the single traditional Peruvian pan pipes CD playing on continual loop. It was interrupted twice on the trip by the performance of live traditional pan pipe music, played enthusiastically but badly, I thought. Coupled with the constant background aroma of diesel fumes billowing from the engine (doesn't help the breathing at 4000m altitude), what should have been a very pleasant (if long) trip was not that great. Fantastic scenery after leaving Cusco, for about the next three hours following the river, very beautiful. Then a bit tedious for about five hours, then the last hour towards Puno looked like it would have been very nice (lots of water on a large open plain), but in our case was replaced by a crashing thunderstorm (also very nice).If the trip had been half as long, with no pan pipe CD (I'll suffer the live traditional music and the diesel fumes) it would have been a five star experience, but as it is I'm pleased we did it, but the Hiram Bingham train gives you pretty much the same upsides, is much shorter, and doesn't have the downsides.
A ride of your life.. A wonderful trip, never a dull moment. Good food & entertainment aboard. Great staff. Little expensive ($220/person) but worth it.

Best train ride ever!. First class travel with fine food, entertainment, and amazing scenery. We took this from Puno to Cuzco. Travelling from Cuzco to Puno would help fight altitude sickness at the Puno end as it is higher than Cuzco. The daylong journey was a nice relaxing break to a holiday. The view from our seats was fine but the open deck at the back of the observation car offered reflection-free photography.

Amazing scenery, unique experience but expensive. We had heard that this was one of the great railway journeys and so took the plunge on spending the money on the train rather than the bus. The scenery you pass through is amazing and of course being on the train allows you to appreciate this much better than on the bus. The train itself is very nice, with wooden panelling, individual table lighting, a bar carriage and observation carriage open at the back. We had a seat for just the two of us and it was spacious and comfortable. The train makes a leisurely journey out of Cusco, through the countryside and it's great to just relax and watch traditional farming and village life pass by as well as the amazing scenery before finally arriving at Puno on the shores of Lake Titicaca. The staff were very friendly however there were certain elements of the service that I expected better for the price ($220 per person). Firstly, the train leaves early, 8am and you need to be at the station 07:30, however no breakfast is included but continental breakfast is offered as an expensive option. Small elements such as no free bottled water during the journey (stock up with your own before you board the train) and coffee after lunch that has to be purchased rather than included. Including these would have made the difference between feeling pushed to buy extras and being really well looked after.The entertainment included (fashion show, "traditional" music, pisco sour making etc) did not really do it for me feeling, as these usually do, less than authentic and staged for foreigners however I did appreciate picking up the recipe for Pisco sours which were of a good standard on the train!Overall really enjoyed the journey however given the cost this is a once off experience.

Worth the money. I almost decided against it and taking the bus, when the family (including kids 12, 12 and 6) pressed me into it. I hate candyfloss tourism with display of pseudo-culture, and there was some of it indeed on this train (fashion-show, local music performance on the train, pisco making etc.).But it was easy to ignore when it got too much because of the vistadome (last carriage of the train), which was also an open carriage with just a rail as tha barricade between the carriage and the tracks below. Not dangerous in any way since the train moves at a liesurely pace.However, we did spend hours in the vistadome carriage just marvelling at some of the most beautiful scenery we have ever seen in my visit to 24 countries. Although the bus route runs close to the train at several places, it is difficult for me to understand how can you get the view sitting at a bus seat.Although pricey (average ticket price is close to average monthly income for a Peruvian), we thought it was one of the most memorable part of the trip
Not a european train, but works well. Air conditioning, comfortable seats and on time. It's not the main reason to be there, but accomplishes the mission to get you there.

Cuzco to Puno: One of the great train experiences. My wife and I went from Cuzco to Puno, and we were delighted from the moment we left the taxi in Cuzco. Live music, excellent reception hall. It gives you a welcome telling you that you are about to have a beautiful experience. We were lucky and we had two seats, without having a couple opposite to us. All seats have tables in front, with white tablecloth, a table lamp. Windows are huge and give you a panoramic impression. During the whole train trip, which lasts for 10 hours, you are served breakfast, lunch and tea, all included in the price. In addition, you can have other meals or drinks, paid directly from you. The service on board is first class, very polite. There is a show or two on board, the last wagon is also a bar, where you can enjoy a drink or two (beware of what high altitude does to you, better off without alcohol!). and the panoramic windows are excellent. The pace of the train is slow, giving you the opportunity to enjoy a view which is memorable and unique. Some people might be complaining about prices, and that is not comfortable enough. I will say, enjoy. This is a unique experience, and I will do it again, when I am back in Peru. You can do arrangements directly through Internet or through a respectable Peruvian travel agency. The price is almost the same.

Not good value for money. Cusco to Puno, seemed like it was going to be a very special experience but seats, although like armchairs, were uncomfortable as did not recline. Early start ie 8:00am but lunch not to served until 1:00pm. In the meantime you had to buy both food and drink. No coffee served after lunch, had to buy it. Staff not overly friendly, however scenery amazing. Suggest go by bus.

Felt like Royalty !!!. From Cusco to Puno, it was an amazing day. The staff make the whole trip into a Theater production. Everything was timed from meals to entertainment to provide the best possible experience. I think the best part of the whole trip was the scenery. I must have over 100 photos of the differing terrain. So nice to spend 12 hours talking to other travelers in that setting. Loved it !!! Would do it again in a heartbeat.
scenic. Large windows (+ overhead) to view mountains, smooth ride, professional staff

One of the world's great train trips. Excellent! Full marks to Peru Rail for one of the best train trips ever (and I have traveled on a few). Very efficient communications with Daniel via the internet to organise this and we were not disappointed! It went beyond all the hype. Tickets are issued a few weeks before the trip so have some patience if you book well in advance. Arriving at the station were were welcomed with Andean music in the nice lounge until boarding time. Efficient loading and seating (our bags taken earlier) and the train most luxurious. Staff were super-efficient, friendly and a lot of fun. The trip was smooth and through spectacular scenery with a stop over at the village of La raya (over 4000m) for shopping of local handicrafts (excellent, nice things, nice people). Excellent 5-star food and table service on board capped with great drinks (table or in the club car) and entertainment (traditional dancing, fashion parades and our great 4-piece Andean band). Great trip for good value. The destination, Puno is another great place to visit on Lake Titicaca - the cultural centre of Peru

Worth every penny. This trip was a real highlight for me. Ten hours (didn't nod off for even a wink) of pure pleasure. The train was beautiful, old-fashioned, comfortable and felt like luxury! There is an open observation car at the back, perfect for taking photos and being open to the elements. Also a car with a bar where we had a lesson in how to make a Pisco Sour. They also provided us with a live Peruvian band. Yes, it's touristy but what better way to see the countryside than meandering through the Andes on a slow train?We made a couple of stops where we could buy local hand-made sweaters etc. There was a good lunch and then tea. It was expensive at 220 dollars one way (Cusco to Puno) but it was a once in a lifetime experience and a treat to really consider especially if you are a train buff like me.

Wonderful experience. We were a little apprehensive, as the cost is high by local standards, but it turned out to be one of the best days of our trip so far. Staff were very friendly, service excellent and such a relaxing way to see the amazing andean scenery. Even the "entertainment" which we was expecting to be somewhat cheesy, turned out to be good and fun. Naturally, everyone tried to extract extras (CD's, alpaca goods etc) but that's to be expected. Maybe our trip was better than normal because there were only 8 other passengers, but the whole experience was fantastic.

Nostalgic train journey. We started our journey on sunny January morning and were greeted by a smiling and very hospitable train crew. When we wanted to change our seats from the right to the left side of the train they immediately met our wishes. Although the train ticket is on the expensive side ($ 220/pp) it was worth every penny of it! After the sometimes noisy and hectic towns we encountered during our stay in peru, it was essential to slow down and enjoy the peaceful and breathtaking views during our 12 hours journey! Food and drinks were good, the entertainment fun but not necessarily authentic. All in all a very recommendable journey !

One of the Great train journeys. The spectacular Andes are the showcase here. The train is in excellent condition and the observation car is fantastic. Well worth the price. Now the negatives....At booking time the ladies at the Cusco Peru Rail office were advised of my gluten free requirements. They said "just tell them on the train, it will be fine". Worried, as it seemed as though they didn't really understand, we visited the office the next day to double check. The guy in the Peru Rail office seemed to understand the sin trigo requirement and sent an email to the Harem Bingham booking email account. No surprise then when there wasn't alternatives to bread on the train. Annoying, and given the high end positioning of this train, very disappointing.

Well worth it!. You'll definitely get what you pay for on a typically luxurious Orient Express run choo choo.Food, drink and live entertainment all thrown in as part of the price, and views you couldn't pay for, beats flying over the Alta Plana and missing it all, and surely more civilised than the old coach journey?!Splash out, if you've just done the Trail you've earned it!!

Great Scenery. We took this train one way from Cuzco to Puno. The sights were fantastic and the observation car at the rear of the train enabled everyone to get uninterrupted views of the scenery.Food was OK. Staff were very friendly and helpful. They had a number of activities on the train during the day to prevent you from drifting off to sleep. While not my cup of tea the activities were well received and the staff clearly enjoyed their work. A trip worth taking.
Great Train ride. Loved the train ride- very comfortable, entertainment to keep you from boredom. Food was delicious well worht the price.

Fantastic Journey. We travelled on the Andean Explorer from Cusco to Puno as part of a tour around South America. I hadn't heard of it, but we booked through Imagine Latin America - Meike was fantastic and put together a tailored itinerary for us, which included a recommendation for this train which of course nicely links two key attractions we were interested in visiting: Machu Picchu and Lake Titicaca. The idea of a long train journey appealed to us (it takes 10 hours) - we'd previously travelled on the Ghan from Alice Springs to Darwin, and had very much enjoyed it. The Andean Explorer didn't disappoint! From the moment we got on, we enjoyed every minute and the 10 hours flew by. As well as fabulous views of the Andes, the train passes through several bustling towns, and you feel like royalty as the locals stop to wave as you chug by.The carriages are very comfortably furnished, we had a freestanding armchair type chair each and a 'table for two' - the next two passengers faced the other way so we (quite happily - is that bad?!) didn't have to share. Something I just have to comment on - maybe because I'm used to travelling on trains in the UK and their standard of facilities, but the toilets on the Andean Explorer are the most exquisite toilets I have ever seen on a train: well stocked, nicely decorated, and remarkably fresh-smelling. Good news considering we were there for 10 hours!Throughout the day there were a couple of sessions of entertainment in the bar carriage, which is at the back of the train and links to a final 'panoramic' car, with big windows and an open back so you can take in the view. Fashion show, dancing, pan pipes band, cocktail making, we enjoyed it all over a few pisco sours.Before lunch there is a brief 10 minute stop at a 'village', really just a collection of market stalls where you can buy souvenirs. It's a good photo opportunity though - you can cross the train lines and take an unbroken shot of the snow-capped Andes without another person in view. The three course lunch (included as part of your ticket) is served at your seat with a complimentary glass of wine and was nice. The service was great all day, the staff look after you very well, but as other reviewers have said, whilst lunch is included, other food/drinks are not, and it's very easy to just say yes to another coffee or pisco sour when offered without really thinking about the running total. At the end of the journey you are presented with your bill and you have to pay cash (credit cards are not accepted), so make sure you've got enough.Overall this was a great way to travel across Peru - luxurious and stylish. Thanks for the recommendation, Imagine Latin America! I can pass on the recommendation heartily.
Stunning views during your adventure. I recommend this train as the way to get to Machu Picchu. Stunning views, and comfortable trains. Plenty of leg room, and the snack provided was really good!

A lovely ride. If we hadn't been on honeymoon I don't think we would have gone on this but we were so we were like "Why not?!" Food was good but you needed to make sure you had cash on you coz they do ply you with drinks & unfortunately we didn't have a load of cash on us so we haad to abstain. So it could have ended up being quite expensive but it really was the most comfortable way to travel. They had a pan pipe band on which was sweet but got a little wearying & then they had a fashion parade with various alpaca wear. It's on the more pricey side but possibly a bit more upmarket then you would find in the local markets

Royal experience. I took this train one way from cuzco to puno. it was significantly better than i expected it to be. almost like a royal palace on wheels. food was great and almost 5 star like. the views were breathtaking. totally worth the 200 odd dollars.

Great way to go to Puno!. This trip is one of the things to do if you are thinking of going to Puno.Ok, it takes 10 hours.... when you arrive to your destination the earth will be moving till you go to sleep.....The train in itself is great, the food is also very good, the scenery is fantastic.

Costs a bomb but amazing views. We took the train from Cusco to Puno. The scenery was great and this was the highlight of the train ride. There are a couple of Peruvian dance and music performances on the train and a round of Pisco sour. The food was alright. The US$ 220 only included one tea/snacks and lunch for the entire duration of the 10 hour journey. I am sure they can include some additional drinks / food options. Overall i enjoyed it.
Loved the ride. Got to meet lots of other travellers. Very scenic and bright.

Great way to see more of Peru. We took the train from Cuzco to Puno, and the views cannot be faulted. The carriages were very comfortable, if a bit warm - both our main seats and the bar/observation car. The food was excellent, but we felt a bit ripped off by expensive drinks (no price list was ever produced). The route allows you to see a bit of everything - rivers, mountains, valleys, the Altiplano, city centre market at Juliaca (right arose the tracks), even a smidgen of Lake Titicaca as you near Puno. A great train journey.
More than sufficient. Its a waste of money to take the Hiram Bingham train
Fantastic River views close to the start of the Inca Trail. This was another fantastic trip combined with great weather,stunning scenery and unique on train entertainment.
Beautiful and Scenic. Clean and comfortable beautiful scenic train ride. Snacks are served along the way.
luxury train. From the moment the train set off down a main street in Cuzco we loved this. Excellent service, fun things - fashion show, pisco sour lesson, good food and wonderful scenery.
This train ride makes the trip to Peru worth it.. I'm not sure about Machu picchu- but the Andean explorer makes your trip to Peru worth while, especially if you are a photographer.
Great trip. The best way ever to get to Machu Picchu. The train is comfy, clean and comes with airplane like service and snack.

Back to the old days. This train trip is wonderful, no doubt about that. Sure, it is slow - but that is exactly the objective of the whole trip. To slowly enjoy the landscape, while talking to other passengers, drinking beers/cocktails in the bar wagon, making photos at the back of the train, enjoying a wonderful lunch menu and be entertained by local music and dance. We did not get bored for one single second and this train ride was one of the highlight of the holidays. As for the price, it is expensive. But this also has a positive side effect: Not everybody that you meet during the Peru tour is on the train and those that are on it, REALLY want to be on it - the atmosphere is therefore somewhat festive (we found). This trip inspired us to look for other, similar, train rides around the world. Be it in Canada or in South Africa or anywhere else. Not for long journeys, but for the occasional day on a train like this is just so much fun!A+E

Too expensive.... We did the train from Santa Rosa to Aguas Calientes, as well as from Aguas Calientes and back towards Cusco. The service on board is excellent, comfortable chairs, and the views breathtaking. I really like the windows in the ceilings so you can see the tall mountains from any seat in the train. Drawbacks were the price, as well as the silly fashion show. There was also some sort of entertainment by some mythical figure. No information was provided to explain what this figure was, and it all seemed a bit awkward to the group I was travelling with.
Great as long as you love the pan flute. The service on this train was great and the ride was smooth. My only complaint was that after 3 hours of hearing pan flute music I was ready to go crazy.
slow train ride to heaven. Do pay for the vistadrome carriage - worth the extra for the stunning views. Liked the totally unexpected fashion show!

Enjoyed the ride. OK folks don't expect a bullet train winding through the Andies at up to 14,000'. Do expect a wonderful ride through extremely varied scenery at a speed that allows you to really see life in rural Peru. Service is great, the observation car is perfect for photography.It's not the cheapest way to Puno but after we met a couple that had all of their camera equipment stolen on the overnight bus to Puno, we thought it was well worth it.It's a way of travel that is quickly vanishing, one where you can relax meet new people and kick back.

RARE AIR ON A TRAIN. We travelled from Cusco to Puno on Peru Rail - the trip was called the Andean Explorer and it takes about 8 hours. It was a memorable experience with really great service and wonderful staff. The food is adequate and tasty and the entertainment included traditional music and dance and a fashion show. There is probably no other train journey which has such warm and friendly staff on board. It is so eay to meet with other tourists especially in the observation car and to share experiences. The train stops at the highest point on the journey for a welcome photo shoot and a visit to the local craft market right next to the train. The views on the complete trip are fascinating overlooking subsistence farms in the Andes.We have travelled on luxury train rides in Alaska and South Africa and the Andean Explorer is up there with the very best.

Great way to relax in Peru. I am typically a frugal traveler, so I struggled with taking a 6 hour bus from Cusco to Puno ($31 on PeruTour with no sight-seeing stops in between) versus the $220 train on PeruRail (aka Andean Explorer). So, I decided to do both. I did the 4-day Machu Picchu trek and decided take the train as a celebratory treat. I have to say that this is where the journey is more important than the destination. It was very relaxing, clean, and comfortable. The food and drinks were great, as was the service. I enjoyed getting to walk around to stretch my legs and meet other passengers. I took the bus back and the scenery is pretty much the same and it's still quite comfortable. Do the train if you want a little luxury. The bus is totally sufficient if you are tight on time and money.
Room for improvement. Great train and fantastic scenery make this route to Puno worth taking, however the service wasn’t great, lunch just OK and afternoon tea a disappointment.

A very long journey. OK so I knew that it was 10 hours, but didn't realise that you crawled along for 10 hours at about 30kph! - the comfortable arm chairs are no longer comfortable after a couple of hours and are not designed for sleeping with no head rests. Most people dropped off to sleep during the journey at some very strange angles.A 3 course meal is served at lunch time, supposedly soft drinks are free, but we were only offered wine and as we didn't drink were not given any alternative, but the extra menu is brought around many times with exorbitant prices.There is a fashion show and music in the observation car, but a group of tourists decided they were going to occupy it for the whole journey and not give anyone else any room.Look out for the thermal pool at Aguas Calientes before you get to La Raya, here kids are swimming and men washing their clothes! - at La Raya there is a 10 (ish) minute stop, where you are followed by people selling their goods and old ladies asking you to take their photos.Afternoon tea is also served, two tiny little sandwiches and 2 dainty little cakes, plus tea or coffee (no other alternative, not even water).Try to get into the viewing car for the journey through Juliaca, the market lies either side of the train track and you can touch the stalls. There is stall after stall of tiny used car parts, wing mirrors, every piece of rubber needed on a car! - then moves to food, it goes on for a long time - well actually maybe it is just because you are going so slowly that it seems you are going on for such a long time! Through the whole journey the train is sounding it's horn as there are no level crosses and people just cross constantly in front of the train.Before you pull into Puno you are presented with your bill for the journey for the extras you purchase - 17 Soles for a hot chocolate, more than 3x what I paid anywhere else. In hindsight we should have stocked up on supplies first.I guess I would put this down as an experience, but not one that I would want to repeat.

Expensive but nice to do once. I rode the train from Puno to Cusco. It was well appointed with wingback chairs and table cloths. The service was a bit slow when you ordered a drink but I was so relaxed it did not matter. Seeing the landscapes, towns and villages was very interesting and I spent a lot of my time in the open car in the back. I watched the road as we followed it most of the way and it is a very well maintained black top road so next time I will drive or take the bus for A LOT less money.
wonderful ride. of course, Machu Picchu is the high point of the Peru trip. The expedition train is just fine; no need to take the Vistadome.

A day to remember. Today from Puno we take the Andean Explorer 19 http://www.perurail.com/en/ to Cusco. There is a good map of the route on the web site. This is turning out to be a highlight of the trip, (so far) It’s just like the Orient Express (it belongs to the same company)the carriage is immaculate as if it’s just been built. We were filled with joy when we stepped aboard. The train is only 40% full so everyone can spread out. It has two carriages with the seats. Then a back carriage wih a bar and large viewing area, with an open back. It is fitted with beautiful wooden panels and luxury seats. The landscape was just amazing and made the time go so quickly.

Great for seeing Peru but very long journey................... Travelled from Cusco to Puno which took 10 hours. Gave us a great opportunity to see lots of Peruvian landscape but was an overly long journey at 10 hours. We are glad we´ve done it but wouldn´t care to repeat it!

Amazing, beautiful, unforgettable experience.... While organizing our trip, we were not sure about booking the Andean Explorer because of its cost. it was much more expensive than the bus, and we were not sure it would be worth it.Well, we did book, and we realized from the moment we checked in that we had made the right decision. The welcome experience was great, the waiting room was comfortable, and the train... Where to start?!?The cabin was extremely comfortable. The decoration has been thought of in details, with a lot of elegance... I almost felt like in an Agatha Christie's novel! The crew was very helpful and very well organized. The bar area was also very comfortable, and the platform was an amazing way to enjoy the fantastic sceneries while travelling. I spent most of my 10 hour trip there, outside, looking at the country side, mountains, rivers, colors, passing by villages, and even talking to people who were always very enthusiastic to see the train coming! I am really glad I didn't have to see all of this from behind a window...The onboard entertainment was fun: fashion show, music, dance, cocktails... We even had a class on how to make the famous Pisco Sour!The lunch was very nice too, and the service irreprochable.My day on the Andean Explorer is definitely a highlight of my Peru trip. It was a beautiful experience, yes, more expensive than anything else we've done on our trip, but definitely worth every penny spent.Thank you Andean Explorer, you gave me one of my best travel memories so far!

Incredible experience. My wife and I traveled on the Andean Explorer from Puno to Cusco while on our honeymoon in Peru. Its a throwback to the Pullman cars of old. We loved the whole experience of trundling along the altiplano at a stately place in the luxurious cars. The service was brilliant and the staff very attentive. Was great standing at the back in the observation car looking out as we went past towns and settlements. Comfortable chairs with three course meals served with proper cutlery; whats not to like!!! Even had entertainment thrown in with live music in the bar.

Fantastic Day Out. The Andean Explorer is a fantastic train trip that provides a very relaxing and enjoyable way of travelling from Cuzco to Puno. The train is very comfortable and on a par with the first class trains of the United Kingdom, Europe and North America. Lunch is included - and although not a fine dinning restaurant, the food was equally as good as that found on most first class trains in the world. Breakfast is not included, but a good meal of eggs, toast, orange juice and coffee can be had for about $10.The main attraction, however, is the fantastic views along the entire route. You will see rolling hills, mountains, gorges, rivers, and wide grassy plains. You will travel through small villages, farming communities, the main streets of larger towns, and markets. The people along the way were always friendly, waving at passengers in the observation car at the rear of the train. For photographers, it is a delightful day - my son and I are both serious amateur photographers and took nearly 1,500 shots between us. We've taken the best of these and turned them into a book that shows the ever changing scenery throughout the day.Although some people have complained about the price, it is hard to understand what their comparison point is. A 10 hour first class train trip, with lunch, some drinks, entertainment and fantastic views for about $220 per person. This is much cheaper than similar trips in Europe and elsewhere!! Overall, a highly recommended experience. If you don't like trains, don't like relaxing for 10 hours, or don't like amazing landscape and indigenous photographic opportunities, then this trip is not for you. For everyone else, you will find it amazing.

Overpriced. It ia a nice travel, with some hightlights during it, such as the market right in the middle of the way.They make you pay so much money for a medium service... Food is very poor and only one drink is included...It is a nice experience, not an unforgettable one and so expensive!!

Wonderful, Comfortable Excursion. This is probably the most comfortable way to travel between Cusco and Puno. High-end buses cover a similar route, but there's nothing like walking around this beautiful train and chatting it up with other travelers. Seating is incredibly comfortable, and there's lots of space to walk around. There's a bar and observation car at the rear of the train for having a drink or taking in the sights, although bar service is also available at your regular seat. The train also features the nicest bathrooms in all of Peru, which is a big deal on a ten hour journey.Quite a few passengers had issues finding seats with their travelling companions, even though all of us had booked in advance. It seems that the ticketing system isn't very smart about seating people together. Most people were able to change seats with other passengers, but my wife and I were left seated separately, and the train staff wasn't very helpful in resolving this - I'm not sure there was much they could do as the train was full. We borrowed seats from other passengers while they were up and about and spent some time in the lounge, so it wasn't a huge problem. Seating is varied, with singles, two at a table, and four at a table.A wonderful, although not plentiful, lunch is included. They even offer a vegetarian option. A glass of wine and water is included with lunch. Afternoon tea and desert is served late in the day. Breakfast, drinks and snacks are available for purchase. The full bar also makes some wonderful coffee drinks. These additional food and drinks don't come cheap, but that's to be expected on a luxury train. I do suggest bringing plenty of water, because a small bottle is 5 soles on the train.There is one stop just before lunch at the highest point along the route. There's a small artisan market there, but little in the way of food or drink. We were able to buy a large bottle of water there. The views are quite nice, but the stop is only for 10 minutes.Our train arrived in Puno about an hour later than the schedule had indicated. This meant that we saw the sun go down in Juliaca instead of along Lake Titicaca, but it was no major inconvenience.

The best way to travel from Cuzco to Puno. Yes it is more expensive than going by bus and you travel through the same landscape. But the tranquility, comfort, service and just the overall experience make it well worth it.You travel exclusive, with about 40 travellers on the train. The main carriage is spacious and luxurious. The observation car and bar car make for some change of scenery.They put on a fashion show, had two different Peruvian bands play (one in the morning and one in the afternoon) a bartending class to teach you how to make Pisco Sour.The service overall was spectacular, friendly and formal at the same time. Silver service for lunch. And the facilities in the train put you back to colonial luxury.We loved every minute of it and I didn't even open my reading material. The scenery is spectacular enough!

Loved every minute, beautiful passenger car, views and phenomenal service!. I wrote a review for Perurail, then came across the Andean Explorer's profile. Below is my review for the Perurail/Andean Explorer:My Mom and I rode the Andean Explorer from Puno to Cusco. It was absolutely one of the highlights of the trip. The views were stunning, and the service was incredible. A true testament to Peru's tourism and hospitality infrastructure.We purchased our rail tickets through their website and printed our boarding passes from the States (they send a PDF, so no worries about losing your boarding pass). As we boarded, we realized our seats were apart from one another. No problem - they IMMEDIATELY and graciously resolved this issue. Our fare included a 3 course lunch, tea time (finger sandwiches included) and non-alcoholic beverages of our choice. Again, I feel compelled to mention the service. They were simply phenomenal. The journey itself takes 10 hours (with a short stop in La Raya) - but like all spectacular rail journeys, those 10 hours just blew by. Our only regret was not taking the Hiram Bingham (another Perurail train) from Cusco to Agua Calientes (we met up with our tour operator in Cusco - a mistake. Peru has amazing transportation and infrastructure, no need to go through a tour operator).Our fare for the entire rail journey (including meals) was $220 per person. Quite nominal when considering the exceptional quality of service and facilities (beautiful, comfortable interiors and the observation car was awesome). We cannot recommend Perurail enough!

Not as much fun as you might think. We just got back from Peru and rode the Andean Explorer from Cusco to Puno. The trip lasted about 12 hours. Apparently part of the track has some damage and they had to go very slowly through that section of track. The scenery was not as great as I had hoped for. The 3 course meal was a joke. Probably some of the worst food I have ever tried to eat. The pork chop was so tough and overcooked I actually had to discreetly spit out the one bite I attempted to eat. The vegetable lasagna my family had was equally awful. We were starving by the time we finally got to our hotel, about 9 PM. The bar car and observation car were occasionally fun and the service and staff were very good. If we had to do it over we would fly, hire a driver or skip this area of Peru completely. We thoroughly enjoyed the rest of our trip to Peru, the people and some of the best food we have eaten anywhere. The Andean Exlorer was a very long and disappointing journey, and I enjoyed it the most of anyone in our group.

Comfortable and entertaining. Very comfortable train through amazing scenery. Entertainment provided to make the journey seem shorter and there's a bar and observation area to give you things to do. Seats are spacious and much more comfortable than a bus. Only downsides are that it is slow, food could be improved and staff seemed inexperienced. Given the price you're paying a few more free drinks wouldn't go amiss either (you even have to pay for a coffee after lunch).

Not bad as far as train travel goes.. After having the chance to explore some of the beautiful sights in Peru, the Andean Explorer train didn't really have much to offer in the way of scenery. Having said that, seats were very comfy and the whole experience is quite upmarket (lunch was terrible). 10 hours is a long time to be on a train but the Andean Explorer is a comfortable and clean option. Much more expensive than the bus but worth it if you can't afford to fly.

One of the great train journeys of the world. This is a fantastic experience. A grand old train with excellent staff to serve, inform and entertain the passengers. The scenery is lovely, a very relaxing way to get to Puno and Lake Titi CACa.

Cusco to Puno Peru...10 hours to go 340km. The Andean Explorer was nice. The domed car was a fun place to sit and watch the landscape...even though the Landscape was not very interesting. Ten hours on a train seemed very long. They had Peruvian music on board and a fashion show which helped the time pass. I would fly next time.

Disappointed. Lunch and afternoon tea were both one hour late. The food was cold. The bar prices are really expensive. However, the menu was balanced, the observation deck a real treat and the ten hours pass quickly. The train passes through some unique places in Peru, so be prepared, it does not filter out for the tourists like the tours in the cities. We are glad to have taken the train, but if your budget is tight, please consider the coach. The road takes the same route as the train and has more stops en route. Plus it is slightly quicker on the coach.

All aboard.. This really was an amazing experience and one you should do if you are going to Peru.To some people the sound of a ten hour train trip may well sound like a complete nightmare but it was quite the opposite.We paid out £150 each to be on this and it was worth every penny. (There is a more expensive option called the Hiram Bingham but that was more than double the cost of this trip).We were in beautifully appointed carriages, with exceedingly comfortable seats. The meals were all laid on and the quality of the food was exceptional. Free drinks with lunch, morning coffee, afternoon cocktails. It was awesome.At the back of the train was an observation carriage with a bar and a lounge area. There really is no better way to see the Andes than in comfort and with a beer in your hand.Our conductor was called Victor Velarde and if you are lucky enough to have him on your train say hello from me. Great chap!

take it!. No better way to travel than on a spacious train. Our seats were quite roomy but the real bonus was being able to get up and move around at will. You would not be able to do this on the bus. There is a carriage for drinks with armchairs and then another carriage which has all glass for looking out of with a bench to sit on to watch the scenary go by.The food served was really nice and it was my first tast of alapaca and I really enjoyed it. The 10 hours didn't feel like 10 hours and we kept ourselves entertained playing cards and reading and talking. We didn't partake in the the music or fashion show that they had on offer to keep you entertained.

Save your money and take the bus. The target audience seems to be inexperienced travelers and/or elderly people who would enjoy cruises, which makes sense as this is like a cheap cruise: bland, airplane-quality food; silly activities (a ridiculous fashion show with clothing that pales in comparison to what Cuzco's shops offer; a lame 'Come to the bar and learn how to make a pisco sour!' session); waiters bearing trays with cans of Pringles potato chips for sale. The staff rudely dislodged one solo traveler in our car to make room for a couple who complained about loud children in another car. The train was excruciatingly slow--so slow that even those who began the journey enthusiastically were mired in get-me-out-of-here stupors by the time the train finally reached Puno.While the carriages are well-appointed, this is not the sophisticated, refined throwback to grand train travel of the past that Peru Rail would like you to believe. It's a pretty cheesy tourist experience. Yes, the scenery out the windows is gorgeous--but that scenery includes the road where buses made the same trip at significantly lower costs in significantly less time. And their passengers weren't exhorted to "Come to the bar and learn how to make a pisco sour!" Next time I'm in Peru, you can bet I'll be on one of those buses.

Best Part of Our Trip to Peru!. The Andean Explorer was incredible. Every moment exceeded my expectations. From the initial greetings as we boarded, to the service staff, the entertainment... and of course - the breathtaking scenery... it was all worth every penny! The food during our three course lunch was fantastic. The drinks were delicious. The best part, though - is ten hours through the changing terrain of the Andes mountains from the plains around Lake Titicaca to the lush green terraced mountains closer to Cusco. I couldn't take enough pictures. The small families standing rail side waving from their farms, the family dogs sprinting from the house up to the tracks and alongside the train, the traditionally dressed women tending to their sheep herds... it was a National Geographic moment the entire ride. As wonderful as everything was inside, the views and 'experience' outside was something I'll never forget. I went through two camera batteries trying to capture every moment. If there is one thing you MUST do when in Peru - it is ride the train from Puno to Cusco. Absolutely incredible.

Definitely worth including on your itinerary. Our trip on the Andean Explorer from Puno to Cusco was amazing. I was dreading a 10 hour train trip but the time flew by. The train is decorated beautifully with comfortable chairs and tables. The service was excellent and our lunch was delicious. We had several choices and with dessert I chose to pay a small amount extra for a huge fruit salad. We spent a lot of time in the observation car which is fully enclosed (in case it drizzles) with the back part of the carriage open to the tracks. It was a great spot to experience all the beautiful landscapes floating by. We left and arrived on time. Well worth the journey and so much better than being processed at an airport and flying for two hours.

Wonderful experience - one of the highlights of our holiday!. I have been meaning to write this review for a long time. My husband and I travelled to Peru in September 2009 on a pre-arranged tour. As part of our trip we were privileged to travel on the Andean Explorer from Cusco to Puno. It was one of the highlights of our holiday. The train is quite beautiful, the staff attentive and professional, impeccably turned out in livery, and the food was extremely good. However, it is the scenery that this train passes through that makes this journey an unforgettable experience. It is quite breathtaking in places and a dream come true for any amateur (or professional) photographer. The journey may take 9 hours but it passes all too quickly, and anyone who needs a book to pass the time really can't possess a soul!And a special word of praise for the staff. The morning after our journey my husband discovered that he could not find his camcorder (on which he had recorded footage of Lima, Cusco, Machu Picchu, the Sacred Valley) - disaster! We informed our tour guide who arranged for our coach to visit the station later that day en route to the airport at Juliaca. More in hope than expectation my husband went to enquire at the station office as to whether it had been found and handed in. To his immense surprise it was there and was restored to him intact.
