A wonderful example of customer service and honesty!Incidentally the tour that we took has since dispensed this amazing train journey, and now takes its tourists to Puno by road, which is such a great pity.

Scenic views and enjoyable train journey. We booked our trip in Peru through the travel agent and knew that we will be taking a train from Cusco to Puno. However, we did not expect that we would be on this Andean Explorer Train and was very pleasantly surprised when we got to the waiting area. A Peruvian band was playing the waiting area entertaining the guests.The train is comfortable and has a plush old world feel about it. Food is good and some drinks such as glass of wine and one glass of pisco sour are also provided as part of the service. It is a slower train ride of nearly 9 hours but they have activities to keep you entertained such as 2 different bands playing and fashion show with a stop to buy handicrafts at a small town. However, 9 hours can drag on at times and it is always good to have a book or magazines to read.For photography buffs, there is a last carriage with glass panels where you can have a great view of the scenery.Definitely beats taking the bus and the journey itself makes the holiday memorable.

Indulge yourself !!. There can be no doubt that the Andean Explorer is not cheap, nor will it get you between Cusco and Puno as quickly as the coach will, but now and again it's nice to treat yourself to some luxury and to be able to relax, and this train scores highjly on both counts.We travelled from Puno to Cusco and loved every minute of it. The train is elegant with plenty of room at all the seats, and the observation car at the rear was a delight to travel in and watch the scenery pass by in total comfort. Travelling through the market at Juliaca was a special experience and made the journey worthwhile on it's own.The meals were good and we have no complaints about the food although, considering the price of the journey, free tea and coffee should be provided throughout the day. It would cost the Company a minimal amount and negate the penny-pinching impression it gives.There can be no comparison between this opulent train journey and travelling by coach and our biggest regret was when the journey came to an end. If you have the chance - take it and enjoy the moment !

What an experience - value for (a lot of) money. Highly recommendable. Great seating, great food and service, 2 times good musical entertainment, very good view and phote opportunities in the observation wagon etc. etc.We would consider doing it again ....

A Great Way to Travel from Cusco to Puno. A great experience for those who think that the journey itself is as important as the destination. We enjoyed first class service from the moment we arrived at the station in Cusco until we arrived in Puno. The ride served as a break from the busy sightseeing schedule. We loved the passing scenery, including very large herds of camelids. The food was fine, but not gourmet.

Great way to relax half way through your trip. We were 6 days into our Peru vacation and needed a winddown day so we took the Andean Explorer from Puno to Cusco. We knew ahead of time it was slower than the bus or private car but we wanted to relax and be pampered. Drinking starts early with a welcome pisco sour at 10AM and a glass of wine with lunch (both complimentary). The lunch was very good and all 4 of us had the BBQ short rib. The alpaca appetizer was good and the passionfruit mouse was a nice dessert. Wait to buy your afternoon drinks until the 2 for 1 happy hour starts during the fashion show. The bar & observation car are a plus for photographers. Bring some toys, pens & pencils to give the children at the La Raya stop. If you book the train trip through a Peru agency you may save some money (we saved $60).

Waste of money and time!. Went on the Andean Explorer in May 2010 - very long and slow train ride. The journey started off ok, staff were very friendly, and came around offering drinks. We ordered hot drinks, and then sat back for the long and bumpy ride. Lunch was served- meal was ok. Afternoon tea was not worth eating- stale bread with salad inside. Only choice of drink was tea- when I asked if there was other choice- was told everything else I had to pay for-even water ! (Hot chocolate =17 soles- a 3 course meal is 11 soles in Peru!). At the end of the trip, which arrived 1.5 hours late- we were given a bill for the drinks we had in the morning. We complained and told the manager that were were not told the early drinks were not included (no prices on the menu)- and he apologised and said not to worry. Unfortunalely- one of the waiters did not like this and presented us with another bill! I explained the situation to him- & he then told me I could give him a tip for great service. What a joke!! For $220 US- you would expect some complimentary drinks and snacks onboard the train. My advice is take the bus- much cheaper, quicker and you get a number of stops to look at sights.

A wonderful experience between Titikaka and Cuzco. Run by PeruRail and owned by Orient-Express, this experience is correspondingly flawless and expensive. The views, including crossing the marketplace (!) of the town of Juliaca are spectacular, food is quite acceptable, and service is perfect. Actually, the whole thing is perhaps TOO perfect, and the fashion shows/andean music perhaps a bit much, even though nobody is pushy. It´s probably better to go from Titikaka to Cuzco than the other way, and for pure railway exhilaration and atmosphere the occasional Andes train from Lima to Huacayo is in a category of its´ own, but yes you can´t travel between Cuzco and Titikaka without taking the Andean Explorer!

Amazing experience, totally worth it. Took the AE from Cusco to Puno. We had a great time. There were only about 8 passengers on the trip. I think there were more staff to take care of us than there were passengers. The train is beautiful, it is what I imagine traveling was like in the glory days of train travel in the U.S. The food was great, the views were great, the service was great. I highly recommend this experience.It is an experience. If you are just getting from point A to point B, by all means, take the bus or fly. The bus would also be a great (and very different) experience, and much cheaper, but this train provides an experience that is hard to find at any price, and I found $220 very cheap for what is provided. I love trains and have looked into luxury short trips in the U.S. For anything like this, for this length of trip and quality of service, it is (not surprisingly) much, much more expensive. I would label this train as a great value.Do note that aside from lunch, afternoon high tea, and an afternoon drink, things do cost extra. Bring a breakfast along if you don't want to pay a few dollars for the very nice items that are available for purchase on board.Also, one important word of caution. If you are planning to get dropped off at the Casa Andina Private Collection, they do have a stop there. BUT YOU MUST ARRANGE THIS WITH PERURAIL MUCH IN ADVANCE. I SUGGEST COMMUNICATING WITH PERURAIL ABOUT THE DESIRE TO BE DROPPED AT CAPC WHEN YOU MAKE YOUR TRAIN RESERVATIONS. We were never told about this by anyone. I blame the hotel for this, but do take note. It is not enough to merely let the onboard staff know about your request. It must be approved by PeruRail headquarters in advance. Once you have done this, then be sure to let the onboard staff know as well, but without prior authorization, they will not make the stop.

Take the bus instead!. You have to know that for a very expensive price ($220 one way), you have NO breakfast (just a lunch), NO explanations/ NO guide at all of all the fantastic various villages and landscapes the train goes through, NO map (unless you pay), not even a mate de coca (unless again you pay); except for the lunch, everything is additional!!... I found it outrageously expensive for what it is. Yes, indeed it is very nice and confortable... but knowing you can get a bus that takes the same road, including a guide and various stops at interesting places on the way, for the same 10h and at only $30, if I had to redo it, my choice would definitely not be the Andean Explorer.By the way, it is worth noting that organised group get a $148 rate!! How to rip off the ones booking through the Internet...

A great way to see the Alti Plano. We rode the Andean Explorer from Cusco to Puno and thoroughly enjoyed the trip. The train is very comfortable and true to style. The lunch was a bit ordinary but I have never had a meal on a train that wasn't. The trip lasts 10 hours and it is a good way to see the high plains of Peru. The scenery was interesting rather than spectacular, with lots of alpaca herds, flamingos, ibis and heron, the not to be missed filth of Juliaca and the change from green agricultural land to high barren plain with the mountains still towering above it. I know some travellers would move Puno a little closer to Cusco to cut down on the length of the trip and maybe insert a few lakes and more trees to liven up the view but until then just enjoy it for what it is. Its a bit like the Australian Nullabor Plain - you have to do it once. I am certainly glad I made the trip.

This is an incredibly fabulous train ride!. Two of us rode the Andean Explorer from Cuzco to Puno, Peru Oct. 23, 2009. It was spectacular all the way -- amazing scenery, great service, entertainment and food. The crew almost worked themselves to death. It is an unequaled way to see a huge slice of Peru from the agricultural areas outside of Cuzco to the awesome plains and peaks as you approach Puno, gateway to Lake Titicaca. Animal lovers will revel in the huge herds of llamas, alpacas, and vicunas. Highly recommended!

WOW doesn't even begin to describe it.... So, do yourself a huge favour and take the Andean Explorer from Cusco to Puno or vice-versa. This is a real, old world train experience with top of the line service, a beautifully appointed train and a fantastic observer car (open at one end - no glass so excellent photos) at the back of the train where you can sit and admire the scenery, or do what myself and others were doing - taking hundreds of photographs of the beyond breathtaking scenery the train travels through. Foodwise - over the top for lunch and afternoon tea (yes people, real china, silverware and stemware), served at your own private table. The train is set up so that groups of 1, 2, or 4 all sit together at their own table for meals, playing cards etc, seated in elegant wingback chairs for each passenger. I have never before, and will likely never again experience a train like this - an experience not to be missed.

What a great train ride!. We rode this train from Cusco to Puno. It is a 10 hour ride and leaves the station in Cusco around 8:00am and arrives in Puno around 6:00pm. The station in Cusco has comfortable seats in the waiting room and one can check his luggage in just outside of the waiting room. The train has comfortable seats and an observation car with a bar. The end of the observation car is open so one can stand there and get some good photos during the trip. Lunch is included in the price of $220 per person as well as an afternoon snack. Peru Rail provides entertainment on board as well as music. Travel by plane from Cusco to Puno would be about as much and one would still have to get to Puno from Juliaca as there is no airport in Puno. Taking the train is a much better option. The tourist specialist, .Ms Carolina Saenz, did an excellent job in overseeing things. She is really a nice person and she and her staff did a wonderful job during our trip.

Slightly expensive, but worth the experience. We did the Cusco-Puno journey after a tiring few days at Machu Picchu and Wayna Picchu. Hence we were looking to relax, chill out and enjoy the ride- which is exactly what this journey offered us. The cons, I agree with other reviewers:1. it is a little more expensive than other travel options2. the journey takes all day.3. Food included as part of the ticket is basic, portions aren't huge.4. Food and drinks are available for purchase, but at "luxury prices"With all of the above said, and expected. the journey is pleasant, the staff is professional and the views are great. We had a good time and I'd recommend it to other tourists who are ok spending a little extra money for comfort and who are not in a hurry.

Strike problems. Recently, the Andean Explorer was hit by a couple of strikes with one being a general transportation strike which gripped Peru and the second wasa regional strike which caused a blockage of the tracks. Twice I had to change my reservation and finally had to pay extra to fly from Cuzco via Lima to Puno to keep my hotel and travel reservations from Puno. I arrived at the station at 6:30 am was informed about the strike by one of the train stewards who was informing passengers at the door. The next step was to go in, take a number, and wait for a reimbursement. The travel agents were given priority and it was over an hour before the first individual was called. We were told that Peru Rail would not refund to a credit card and would only refund in cash but they didn't yet have dollars on hand to give to the customers and we had to wait for the cash to arrive. They have a bank of computers there for online purchases but would not allow anyone to use the computers to rebook their travel as the computer supervisor had not yet arrived but would be in "eventually." The man in the "customer service" office was bored with the whole thing and unwilling to expedite anything for anyone. His ony advice was to sit down and wait my turn. The customer service reps were unhurried and seemingly oblivious that people needed to make other travel plans. I understand that while the strake may have been unavoidable, nevertheless, Peru Rail could have been responsive in helping people receive a reimbursement and making other travel plans. It would not have been a huge stretch to expect some of the managers to help behind the counter and turn on the computers for people to use. No one apologized and no one seemed to care as if this was a buniness-as-usual situation. I was shocked that Peru Rail is owned by Orient Express as the level of client service at the train station is abysmal.

Not worth the expense . . .. The train is a luxury first-class job - well staffed - who are willing - but the food and drink included in the massive $220 per person price is only a well produced nouvelle quisine 3 courses with a small glass of wine - breakfast, snacks, coffe, tea, water, cocktails are all extras and expensive - e.g. Pisco sour @ 25 soles each!. There is a well-recommended all day bus tour with 4 sight-seeing stops with guide and meals and drinks included for 130 soles per person - try that instead and see more too!TonyRegular independent traveller

Beautiful views, but a bit long. This train from Cusco to Puno is operated by PeruRail which also runs the trains to and from Machu Picchu. They seem to have mastered running a tourist rail franchise, for better or worse. On the good side- this luxury train offered old-style travel with armchair seats and white tablecloths, decent service, and amazing views of the Andean valley, either out the windows or the caboose (windows all around and a balcony on the back of the train to get 360 degree views). The downside was that it took 10 hours whereas a bus might have been faster (particularly slow going through Juliaca) and a bit touristy (piped in Andean music non-stop, a stop at Abra La Raya that was a total tourist trap, and the ubiquitous fashion shows to sell overpriced alpaca sweaters). Also it's pricey for the luxury of the journey at $140 one way. Still if you want a unique luxury ride on the rails it's definitely a worthwhile experience.

A pleasant trip through the Andes. This is a 10 hour trip; I went from Puno to Cusco that takes you back to a more elegant time.Lunch and afternoon tea are provided, that lunch was OK, but the desert was disappointing. The only option on the menu was a poor rice pudding, but they were happy to offer you something else at a cost. The afternoon tea was miniscule which was hardly worth bothering with.The train departed Puno right on time and heads along the side of the lake. It goes past the Grand Old Lady of the Lake, The ship Ollanta. This Ship was built in Britain and assembled in Puno. It used to meet the train from Cusco and operate the night sailing from Puno across the lake to Bolivia and you could then go onward by train to La Paz. Sadly, this stopped some years ago and the ship has been left high and dry since. It was bought by The Orient Express Hotels Group and has been waiting for refurbishment as a luxury cruise ship to sail on the lake. I guess with the way things are now, the likelihood of this happing in the near future is slim. Shame, as I for one would love to do it.About and hour and a quarter after leaving Puno, you arrive at Julicaca where the train stops. On departure from Julicaca, the train then heads down what appears to be the main street and you have market stalls on both sides of the track.The only other scheduled stop is at La Raya, the highest point on the trip there is nothing really here apart from a local souvenir market and the train stops for about 15 minutes.This is a very pleasant trip and was good watching the countryside go by and seeing the Alto Plano change as you then start going down towards Cusco. The train is not the TGV and at one stage a dog was out running us, but then nobody seemed to be in a hurry. The only thing that spoilt it was the loud Australians sitting behind me who seem to think that they were the only ones there and seemed to take great delight at being as loud and annoying as possible.Well done Perurail, but please do something about that rice pudding

Andean Explorer was wonderful. We really loved our day on the Andean Explorer and felt the additional cost compared to road travel was well worth it.We booked it months in advance although since the train wasn't full this was probably not necessary. The booking clerk was called Gladys Human and was very helpful both on email and subsequently when we actually met her at the Perurail station.The 10 hour journey was delightful through beautiful scenery and with wonderful service from the staff. I have never been on such a luxurious train. You didn't have a seat you had a movable armchair!

Beautiful views. The train journey itself is incredible, it's 9-10hrs, but unfortunately, it soon goes. We went on the Andean Explorer both ways, which was pricey. There was food included which was nice, but not amazing, no drinks though.There was some entertainment on board, which was exactly that!The viewing platform was dissappointing, generally i wanted to take photos, but you can only do this off the very end, unfortunately, 95% of the journey there are people just smoking or chatting and just generally stay in the way, so it's very difficult to get a photo.The worst thing was getting the ticket, although we booked a month or so in advance, you have to go to the train station in Cusco and queue up for it, we waited for an hour.
